HEADLINE: AT WORK WITH: Peter Schickele;
When P. D. Q. Meets P. D. Slow

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL

 BODY:
It is one of those hoary musical anecdotes that, no matter how preposterous, survive and even find their way into college classrooms: With an operatic premiere looming, the notoriously laggard composer Giaocchino Rossini was spirited off to a tower by his noble patron to complete the overture, long overdue. His guards were instructed to drop the pages from a window as completed, for copying; if production stalled, they were to pitch out the composer himself.
As the hours dragged on in the largely deserted studios of Minnesota Public Radio here one Sunday, the tale seemed oddly appropriate, the more so in relation to Peter Schickele, that master of preposterous anecdotes. For there in the next room was the bearded, bearlike Mr. Schickele, amiable composer and unrepentant perpetrator of the mercifully mythical P. D. Q. Bach, scribbling a radio script long past the appointed hour. 
 Not to worry, however. "Adrenaline is a real friend," he had said the evening before over dinner at the St. Paul Grill, and the pages just kept piling up.
Mr. Schickele will appear as lecturer and narrator of his "Bach Portrait" -- a delightful deflation of Aaron Copland's grand "Lincoln Portrait," based on some of J. S. Bach's more trivial correspondence -- with the Brooklyn Philharmonic on Friday and Saturday evenings. But he was here in St. Paul in yet another of his many guises, as host of "Schickele Mix," a weekly hourlong program distributed by Public Radio International.
Dedicated to the proposition that "all musics are created equal," "Schickele Mix" presents a wide variety of classical music, mingled with a wider variety of everything else, from Miles Davis and the Beatles to polka bands and hard rock. It is carried by 135 stations nationwide, reaching some 270,000 listeners, and is broadcast in New York by WNYC, on Fridays at midnight, with repeats on Sundays at 7 P.M.
Although the show is just three years old, the image of Mr. Schickele in a broadcast studio seems somehow ancient and inevitable, for many of his most memorable comedic turns have cast him in this role. He began spoofing classical radio in the hilarious Vanguard album "P. D. Q. Bach on the Air" way back in 1967. Who could forget his riotous misadventures at WOOF, the one-man station of the University of Southern North Dakota at Hoople?
Not Mr. Schickele, it seems. "In true Hoople fashion, part of the wall just fell out," he said now in the plush, modern studio, wielding a dislodged acoustical panel.
But the WOOF era was a simpler time for classical radio. In a march toward triviality, many stations have reduced their repertories to snippets and light classics, swathed in happy talk whose only redeeming feature is its brevity. As Mr. Schickele inadvertently proved in perhaps his weakest P. D. Q. Bach album, "WTWP: Classical Talkity-Talk Radio," four years ago on Telarc, the medium has largely outrun the reach of parody.
In these anti-elitist times, classical music has been cast adrift in the rough-and-tumble of a fragmented American culture. Mr. Schickele, with "Schickele Mix," is showing one modest direction it can take, positively embracing the "enemy," pop culture, and subversively educating listeners about musical styles, forms, practices and history as he entertains them. Current classical broadcasting wisdom holds that talk is death to ratings; but surely it depends on who is talking.
"I guess we've all got some regrets, and one of mine is that I can't dance, or anyway I don't," Mr. Schickele said, easing his way into a program on the waltz that would eventually take up sophisticated musical issues. "I'm a lousy dancer. And that's particularly sad, because I believe in dancing. It seems to me that when it comes to things that are good for your body and your mind and your soul, dancing is right up there with prayer and laughter."
Mr. Schickele, whose effervescent patter and exquisite comic timing have always been crucial to the success of his P. D. Q. Bach ventures, finds that such chatter serves his very purpose of placing classical music in a broader context.
"We find that if I talk more, people accept a wider range of music," he said. "It is seen more as information rather than just music. I always assumed I would be a teacher, but life turned out differently."
Life has indeed held surprises for Mr. Schickele, now 59, who lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with his wife of 33 years, Susan Sindall. (Their son and daughter, both in their 20's, perform in a rock band, Beekeeper, in New York.) His performing abilities were severely curtailed by polio when he was 19. "My left foot flops, and if I had wanted to be a serious pianist, that would have put an end to it," he said. "There is nothing much going on in my left hand."
He taught at his alma maters, Swarthmore College and the Juilliard School, leaving Juilliard in 1965 after going public with the momentous "discovery" of P. D. Q. Bach. That bit of zaniness quickly came to dominate Mr. Schickele's activities. He composed new "finds" as needed, performed in concerts, made recordings and wrote "The Definitive Biography of P. D. Q. Bach."
Feeling that his own composing was suffering, he cut back sharply on his P. D. Q. appearances in 1991, abandoning touring altogether. He spends his summers in Woodstock, N.Y., composing his own music as well as the odd bit of faux Bachiana.
"To me, the constant of my life is composing," he said. "I've taken on a bunch of orchestral commissions recently. I'm just like the girl who can't say no."
Mr. Schickele's "serious" music, as friendly and accessible as the man, has been greeted with more respect than enthusiasm by critics. As with the music of Leonard Bernstein, it may be impossible to assess it independently while his other creations and activities hog the limelight.
Mr. Schickele repairs to St. Paul three times a year for marathon series of radio tapings. Eight programs were to be recorded over 11 days on this occasion, and the first, "Why Are Conductors Paid (And So Much, Too)?," which will be broadcast next week in some areas and on March 10 in New York, was about to begin, more or less.
"We never know exactly when we're going to get one of these dogs started," Tom Voegeli, the producer, said at 3:45 P.M., having already shoved the 4 o'clock starting time back an hour. Mr. Schickele -- the "star, talent, whatever you call him," in Mr. Voegeli's words -- kept scrawling on a legal pad.
"He's half done," Mr. Voegeli reported at 5:30. At 6:18, with the script still only three-quarters finished, the taping began.
When Mr. Schickele finally donned his radio persona, the lilting, resonant speech patterns and the homey manner felt as comfortableas an old slipper. The program, with its finely tuned informality and staged interruptions, fosters the harmless deception that Mr. Schickele is right down the hall at your local station. In fact, he is in Studio P (of course), with Mr. Voegeli.
Once the taping starts, it seldom stops. If Mr. Schickele trips over a word or misses a desired inflection, he simply stops, and starts the sentence over, entrusting the result to Mr. Voegeli's editorial expertise.
"We do pretty much everything in real time," Mr. Voegeli said. "We want it to feel live, so it's important to do it as a whole, though it's kind of a sloppy whole at this point."
As the program approached its premature cutoff, it became apparent that something would have to go. With 9 minutes of music still to play, the 13 minutes of remaining air time would not leave enough for Mr. Schickele's indispensable palaver.
The obvious place to start, as Mr. Voegeli pointed out, would be to excise an example or two from a segment in which Mr. Schickele compared the work of 10 different maestros in a single excerpt from Mozart's "Paris" Symphony (No. 31).
The program included a running joke with a phone ringing repeatedly. Mr. Schickele worked the bell himself.
"He won't let me do that," Mr. Voegeli said. "P. D. Q. Bach has spoiled him."
Mr. Schickele is, by his own admission, "a control freak." Still, he said, "Tom spends much more time on the show than I do."
At 7:15, it was back to writing for Mr. Schickele, and waiting for Mr. Voegeli. "We'll be done by 1," Mr. Voegeli said, sounding unconvinced.
Then, however briefly, Mr. Schickele could sleep, perchance to dream about the realm in which, he is convinced, "angels sound like the Everly Brothers, and God has a sense of humor."

HEADLINE: Kleenex, Juice (Sniff), Aspirin, Fax

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
NANCY SMITH has a two-line telephone, right by her bed, that can handle conference calls. She has a laptop computer. She has a boss who leaves anxious-sounding voice-mail messages. She also has the flu.
So she compromised: she stayed home one day last week, but took part in a meeting on the phone. The problem was, the conference-call connection had the fidelity of a subway public-address announcement. 
 "I was feeling the pressure of having a lot of things to catch up on," said Ms. Smith, a consumer affairs manager for AT&T in Basking Ridge, N.J. "But it was hard for me to catch what was being said. The little snatches that I could hear made me think it was very interesting, but I eventually gave up."
The flu that has hit the East Coast this winter seems to be making people sicker than in previous years, and for longer. Stalwart workaholics who insist that they never come down with more than a 36-hour bug have missed entire weeks of work. To be at home for that long is to risk life-changing revelations. Yes, your apartment really is a mess. Yes, you may lose a few clients for being in bed instead of at their meetings. Yes, you are stuck in a lousy job with a monomaniacal boss who should be told off in no uncertain terms.
But despite triple-digit fevers and megadoses of antibiotics, the old fear sets in.
"In today's economy, with companies being downsized all the time, there's a real concern about not appearing weak," said Joseph R. Weintraub, a professor of management and organizational behavior at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass. "You don't want to acknowledge you may be ill or, if you are, you can't function. Even if you can't get in to work because you can't stand up for longer than three minutes, you still try to get things done from home."
This applies to those who do the downsizing -- namely, bosses -- as well as those farther down the organizational pyramid. Penny Glazier, an owner of several Manhattan restaurants, missed four nights of table-hopping and two days in the office. But miss work? Not a chance.
"I dragged myself into the room at home where I have a fax machine and tried to take care of paperwork," she said. "I felt so far removed from what was going on that it was difficult to stay in bed and not constantly be thinking about what I was supposed to be doing. I had a big breakfast meeting planned. We were inviting all these event planners from major corporations. I had the sales kit on my mind, and in the end I did it over the fax machine."
Ms. Glazier is not alone. Some flu sufferers live for the four or five hours when they can get something -- anything -- done.
"Being able to work was an important part of the recuperation," said Christopher W. Hunt, the editor in chief of Workplace America, a newsletter that follows employment trends. He was out sick for a week. "As long as you pace yourself and yet know that work's getting done, that makes you feel better," he said.
Dr. Robert Campbell, the medical director of Gracie Square Hospital in Manhattan, said that hard-driving flu sufferers face the usual dilemma -- "whether to give in to the illness or to push themselves and try to do, inadequately, the work they shouldn't be doing." But the longer recuperation period this year presents a different problem.
"They've got all this time, so they think they should be happy, or at least relieved," he said. "But they really do feel sick, and that interferes with their ability to watch television, to appreciate humor. They don't have the attention span, they fall asleep in the middle of it. They just aren't accustomed to that, and that throws them for a loop."
People who fall sick while on business trips are thrown for an even bigger loop: a day cooped up in a strange hotel room in a strange city goes by slowly, as Gail J. Franck, a management consultant from Manhattan, discovered when she came down with the flu in Boston.
"I would basically sleep for four hours, do four hours of work, or try to, and sleep for hours and hours," she said. After four days, she felt well enough to go home. On the fifth day, she slogged into the office and quickly lost her voice.
"All you want to do is have your mom come and take care of you," she said, "but your mom doesn't have two weeks to do that. Everybody that you talk to is happy to commiserate and tell you they had it and share their home remedies."
Home remedies? Diana David was so unaccustomed to spending a week in her apartment that she began working on remedies for her home. "It's in a sorry state of neglect, as are homes of people who are married to their jobs," she said of her apartment on the Upper West Side. "Every time my temperature went down, I'd start cleaning the windows, but slowly." She called a cleaning service to tackle her dirt-encrusted Venetian blinds where, she said, "the dirt weighs more than the blinds."
Even home-repair people have been at home. Dennis Michaels, a contractor in Manhattan, took two days off. "The first day, you're so upset, you just throw the TV on because that's the easiest thing," he said. "After a couple of hours, you're even more disgusted. It's all talk shows. When you were a kid, TV was more fun. The second day, you switch to books, but you're constantly thinking, 'When am I going to get better? One more day? Two more days?' The third day, I went out and tried to do the things I was supposed to do, and ended up back in bed."
Frank English, a photographer for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, said that the hardest part of his weeklong convalescence was not being able to talk about the flu.
"You feel like you're at one with everybody because you're sick with the same bug, but you can't share your fear," he said. "It seems overwrought. You don't want to go to the emergency room, because there are people there who really need help. And you can't call your doctor because what is he going to tell you? It would be good to get some clarification, but by the time they can do a culture and figure out what the bug is, it will probably be gone."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Union Decides to Keep Contract-Signing Freeze

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
On the eve of the resumption of negotiations with the owners, the executive board of the baseball players' union decided today to continue the freeze on contract-signings, potentially preventing some players from signing multimillion-dollar contracts but also disrupting the plans of some teams to improve themselves by signing those players.
The board also voted to advise players on major league 40-man rosters not to report to spring training when camps open in a couple of weeks and to ask players not on 40-man rosters to refrain from playing in exhibition games in Florida and Arizona with strikebreaking, or replacement, players. 
 None of those moves was surprising, but they emphasized, just in case anyone had forgotten during the 40-day absence from the bargaining table, that the two sides remain in a highly agitated state of labor strife.
They will resume talks Wednesday under an urgent directive from President Clinton to settle their differences by next Monday, but neither the White House nor any other interested party is in position at the moment to force an agreement.
In a news conference after the board meeting, which 46 players from 24 clubs attended, Donald Fehr, their labor leader, said the players' "desire is to negotiate day by day by day by day until it's done." But he cautioned, "I think they know what it will take to put us within shouting range of an agreement. We'll see if they're interested in it."
The players won't have to wait long. The owners' negotiating committee met here today and completed work on a new proposal it will present Wednesday.
"The proposal will be a comprehensive one, wall to wall, unlike our prior proposals, which have dealt strictly with the central economic issue," Chuck O'Connor, management's chief labor lawyer, said. "It is, in our view, an indication of significant movement in some important areas, and it is a serious effort to get negotiations off dead center and respond to the President's call."
O'Connor, who declined to provide details, said the "significant movement" he mentioned included the core economic issue. The owners' previous proposals have called for a salary cap (which they implemented Dec. 23) or payroll taxes that the players viewed as the equivalent of a cap.
In all instances, the owners' aim has been to reduce the players' share of industry revenue to 50 percent. It would have been an estimated 58 percent if last season had been played uninterrupted.
Talks are scheduled to begin at 10 A.M. at the Mayflower Hotel. Dick Conn, a spokesman for Bill Usery Jr., said the mediator had no plans to meet with each side separately before holding a joint session, as he often has done since joining the talks Oct. 14.
Following the players' meeting, Fehr said the signing freeze would remain in effect until the board decides otherwise.
"We believe it's appropriate that contracts be signed only under a system that everyone agrees to and represents a fair and negotiated settlement," he said. "More importantly, we believe the system unilaterally implemented by the owners was unlawfully implemented."
No player has signed a major league contract since the salary-cap implementation. The players most immediately affected by the extension of the freeze are the 38 players who became restricted free agents under the new system.
Under the rules imposed by the clubs, those players have until Feb. 6, next Monday, to receive and sign an offer sheet from a club other than their last one and until Feb. 15 to sign with that club. Otherwise, they would have to return to their former club.
The two most notable cases involve two Montreal players, pitcher Ken Hill and outfielder Marquis Grissom. Their agents have tentatively negotiated offers with the Florida Marlins -- 5 years, $27.5 million for Grissom and 5 years, $25 million for Hill -- and the Expos would not be expected to match them under the right-of-first-refusal rule that makes these free agents restricted.
But if the players go past the deadline without meeting the requirements, they would lose the chance to receive those contracts and the Marlins would lose the chance to improve their team with a top-flight center fielder and a front-line pitcher.
"We've talked to those players," David Cone, a member of the negotiating committee, said, meaning all of the restricted free agents. "To a man, all understand the situation and agree the freeze should go on."
Asked about those players, Fehr said: "We've initiated some contacts about that. I'm hopeful by tomorrow that won't be an issue. If it is, I'll have a lot more to say about it then."
Two people familiar with what Fehr was alluding to said the union has asked Usery to ask the clubs' representatives whether they would agree to set aside the deadlines. O'Connor said he had not heard from the union or Usery about the matter.
Asked whether the clubs would agree to such a request, he said, "I don't know. That would be something our committee would have to look at."
Fehr did not disclose the position the board adopted on players not on 40-man rosters, but people who attended the meeting said the board will not ask them not to report to camp, but that its preference is they don't because they would be in a position of helping replacement players prepare for replacement games.
However, these sources said, the board will ask the players not to play in exhibition games because they would be replacement exhibition games.
The board took no action of the status of managers, coaches and trainers, who belong to the union's health and benefit plans and licensing program. Union officials plan to meet with them in Dallas next Monday.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 RICHARD BRODSKY, the New York state Assemblyman, did not, as he said he would, introduce legislation that would bar the Mets and Yankees from using replacement players at New York's two publicly owned stadiums. A Brodsky aide, ED FISCHMAN, said the bill was being prepared by the bill-drafting commission and would not be introduced before next Monday.

HEADLINE: GOLF;
Smoothly Covering the Course for PGA Tour

BYLINE: By LARRY DORMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 31

 BODY:
The commissioner of the PGA Tour was striding through the organization's offices in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., recently, checking his watch, talking about membership requirements and looking to make certain that workers were correctly taping the seams on a new wallboard.
His pace was brisk and purposeful. Then he spotted something on the carpet, to the left of his polished black wing tip. It was a tiny piece of Styrofoam packing popcorn. Without breaking stride, he bent over and scooped it up, veering just slightly off course so he could toss it into a wastebasket as he continued down the hallway. 
 Tim Finchem, it seems, doesn't miss a thing. No detail is too small, no situation too trifling, no point too obscure. Since he took office last June 1, replacing Deane Beman as the commissioner, Finchem, 47, has personally visited each member of the PGA Tour and the Senior PGA Tour and most members of the Nike Tour. He has spoken to the more than 100 tour co-sponsors and has met with potential sponsors. During one withering three-month blitz from June through September, he logged more than 100,000 air miles in a quest to alert players to upcoming problems and to listen to any complaints they might have about the way the tour looks after their affairs.
"Tim is the kind of person who, at the end of the day, will have analyzed a problem from every possible angle," said Alistair Johnston, senior executive vice president of the influential International Management Group. "And he is always looking for the solution. Usually, he finds one."
Within the last three months, Greg Norman and the organizers of the proposed World Golf Tour found out just how fastidious Finchem's attention to detail can be. When Finchem learned about plans by Norman to announce the startup of the rival tour, he launched the most efficient pre-emptive strike golf has ever seen. Two days before Norman was to make his announcement, Finchem issued a news release outlining the World Tour proposal and listing his opposition to specific parts of it.
He explained that he and the tour were very much in favor of growth in the game and worldwide inclusion, but not growth that would destroy the foundation of the PGA Tour and others around the world. He was joined in that opposition by the heads of most major golf organizations worldwide. PGA Tour players joined the chorus. Weeks after its inception, the World Golf Tour sits dead in the water, without players, sites or sponsors. Norman has gradually backed away from the concept.
It wasn't by happenstance that Finchem received such blanket overnight support. In the first 90 days of his tenure, he laid the groundwork. "I thought early on that the only way for me to do this job was to open up and keep open the lines of communication with the players and the other organizations," Finchem said. "You need to be able to build a consensus. If you get into a crisis of some sort, you need friends, you need support."
Finchem built the consensus necessary to meet the first crisis head-on and subdue it. This came as no surprise to the people who know him. It has been his way since he entered the University of Richmond on a debate scholarship, went on to the University of Virginia Law School and gravitated toward Washington, where he served as an economic adviser to President Jimmy Carter and became the staff director of the Carter-Mondale presidential campaign in 1980.
Now he will face more crises. The Federal Trade Commission investigation into the rules of the PGA Tour has occupied most of his time recently. Before coming here to meet with the rules officials and field staff of the tour, he spent four days in Washington, meeting with friendly politicians in Congress to brief them about the tour's position. Should the F.T.C. commissioners decide to recommend an action against the tour, ruling that its policies regarding conflicting events and television releases are "restricting product," Finchem might go right to the Hill in an effort to get legislation so the tour could avoid a lengthy court battle.
"It's a decision we'll have to make once it becomes clear how the commissioners will rule," said Finchem, adding that a ruling could come as early as mid-February.
Finchem is a dapper man, small of frame, standing about 5 feet 7 inches. His suits are perfectly tailored, his nails are manicured and his dark, slightly wavy hair is held captive by some industrial-strength mousse. Since taking over for Beman, who resigned March 1, 1994 after 20 years on the job, he has worked mostly 12 to 14 hours a day, rising at 5 A.M. to work out and laboring at the office through the day and into the evening.
"I am a workaholic," he admitted. "But the demands of this job are formidable. I've learned that there's a big difference between being the No. 1 guy and the No. 2 guy in terms of responsibility."
It is also a different game in terms of exposure. That Finchem is an emerging force in the big-time world of sports commissioners is a given, but just where does he fit? Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, had the good fortune of taking over for Pete Rozelle, one of the smoothest public relations men of all time. David Stern, the National Basketball Association commissioner, took over a drug-infested, fiscally faltering league, instituted Draconian anti-drug policies and a salary cap, and resuscitated the game. For this, by the way, he is paid more than many of the players.
The jury is still out on Stern's disciple, Gary Bettman, the National Hockey League commissioner who at least was able to convince the hockey owners that it was a bad idea to kill their sport just when people were starting to notice it. There essentially is no baseball commissioner, and boxing and tennis are promoter-driven nightmares.
Finchem, who earns $700,000 a year plus bonuses that could push him over $1 million, presides over a sport with possibly the cleanest image of all.
"I've said many times that the image of our sport is the most important thing we have," Finchem said. He really believes that. Example: When Craig Stadler was hit with a two-stroke penalty at the Mercedes Championships for allegedly teeing off late -- even though he was on the tee and wasn't announced -- there was some negative press. Finchem, who doesn't mind a fight but deplores controversy, issued a three-page document clarifying Rule 6-3 and sent it to the tour rules officials.
When he came into the job, he seemed at first glance to be similar to his predecessor, Beman, the tough, confrontational bulldog of a man who oversaw huge growth on the tour: assets increased from $730,000 in 1974 to more than $200 million in 1994, with total revenues up from $3.9 million to $229 million under Beman. But Finchem is not nearly as combative as Beman. He is a bridge-builder.
Already he has reached out to woo possible title sponsorship from Karsten Manufacturing Co., the Phoenix-based club producer that engaged the tour in a fierce and expensive legal battle over the legality of square-grooved Ping Eye2 irons (the case was settled). He fired off a couple of conciliatory letters to the comedian Bill Murray, who was exiled by Beman from the AT&T National Pro-Am last year for conduct Beman deemed unacceptable. Murray is back in the field at Pebble Beach this week. Finchem tried to find equitable ways to accommodate foreign players wishing to compete on the PGA Tour, and Nick Faldo and Ernie Els both joined the tour this year.
Finchem's approach has held other surprises. At the Tour Championship in December, he bought 15 tickets and put together an outing for some players to the Rolling Stones concert in Oakland.
The PGA Tour commish at the Voodoo Lounge?
"Great concert," he said. "It was better than the Steel Wheels tour back in '89. Tighter. The orchestration was better."
During the concert, Finchem found himself next to a rather scraggly fellow who had a large cloud of what appeared to be cannabis smoke hanging over his head. The man took a look at the PGA Tour logo on Finchem's jacket.
"Hey, man, you in golf?"
"Yeah. I'm in golf."
"Cool."
Cool. So far, that's as accurate an assessment of Finchem's tenure as any. He has coolly and methodically built a base of support. He is popular among the players, sponsors and staff. There are tough issues and challenges ahead. He probably won't beat all of them. But one thing is certain: they won't take him by surprise. So far, nothing has.

HEADLINE: Real Estate

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.

 BODY:
IN a lift to the real estate market in Springfield, the third-largest city in Massachusetts, the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company is rejuvenating its property in the central business district and plans to bring in new commercial operations in the process.
Two weeks ago, demolition began on the site of a vacant department store, Steiger's, on almost an acre of land across the street from Baystate West, a 1.6-million-square-foot mixed-use complex that Massachusetts Life built and owns. The company, which bought the 80,000-square-foot store from the city for $1 in December, intends to find a developer to build a cinema complex there. 
 The redevelopment plan is part of a $10 million effort to upgrade Baystate West, particularly its retail component, to which the company hopes to attract large discount stores. Baystate West consists of a 29-story office tower, a 264-room Marriott Hotel, a two-story, 200,000-square-foot retail mall and parking for 1,120 cars. Massachusetts Life, which has its campus headquarters elsewhere in Springfield, developed Baystate West as a real estate venture in the early 1970's. The vacancy rate is now 9 percent for offices and 16 percent for retail space.
Springfield, a city of 155,000 people 90 miles west of Boston and behind Boston and Worcester in size, sees itself as the regional hub of western Massachusetts. Its planning officials hailed the Massachusetts Mutual project as one that might help get the city out of its recessionary doldrums. The project calls attention to the benefit certain New England cities have derived from being home to major insurers.
For instance, last fall the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, finished a $7 million renovation of its 780,000-square-foot headquarters, built in 1947 in the Back Bay section of Boston. It reinstalled 30,000 square feet of retail space at street level, which it had converted into offices as the company grew. In the last few years, however, it cut its staff from 2,750 to 2,300, and therefore no longer needs that space for offices. The New England has leased 23,000 square feet of the renovated retail space, which opened in November.
It also rebuilt and landscaped the sidewalk along Newbury Street, a choice retail location, and along Boylston Street, which is parallel.
Now, the ground-floor space, once an expense, will generate about $1.1 million a year in rental income, Peter Harrington, the company's spokesman, said.
Several blocks down Boylston Street, the Prudential Insurance Company completed in 1993 an $85 million renovation of the 1.7-million-square-foot office and retail complex that it built there in 1965.
In the last 15 months, the remodeled retail and common areas have helped decrease the office vacancy rate at this complex to 7.5 percent now from 19.1 percent, said Mark R. Friedlander, a company spokesman.
In Hartford, which has 10.7 million square feet of offices, insurance companies occupy about five million square feet. In 1992, the largest among them, the Aetna Life and Casualty Corporation, completed a $200 million rehabilitation of its two-million-square-foot headquarters there.
Now the Phoenix Home Mutual Life Insurance Company is doing a $5.3 million renovation to a 75,000-square-foot building it bought in May from the Travelers Inc., for $7 million. Phoenix is enclosing an outdoor courtyard to build 6,000 square feet of additional offices on two floors.
In Springfield, the insurance, computer and military companies have scaled down, failed or folded. Its unemployment -- 7.4 percent before seasonal adjustment -- is higher than the state average of 5.3 percent, and its job creation is lagging, Sara L. Johnson, a regional economist at DRI-McGraw Hill said.
For instance, a 400,000-square-foot office/hotel complex built in 1986 by the now troubled Monarch Insurance Company for about $130 million was recently sold at auction for $25 million, David F. Moriarty, Springfield's director of planning, said.
But, with its relatively low business operating costs and good transportation, including Interstate 91, a north-south highway, and the Massachusetts Turnpike, an east-west road, "Springfield's rate of decline is moderating," Ms. Johnson said.
While the downtown still has distressed pockets, the 1980's boom brought in 900 new units of housing -- rental apartments and condominiums -- and almost two million square feet of offices, stores and hotels.
Massachusetts Life plans to spend $9 million to refurbish the retail space at Baystate West and $1 million on the Steiger's demolition. "We want to have a vital downtown so we can attract a viable work force," Joseph Mondy, a company spokesman, said.

HEADLINE: At the Atlanta Games, Culture Will Be a Serious Competitor

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 31

 BODY:
To some skeptics, using the five Olympic rings as the symbol for an exhibition of 130 of the world's greatest works of art is a trifle unseemly. But don't tell that to J. Carter Brown, the former director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
"Because there is so much fame attached to the Olympics, it would be very easy to take the knee-jerk reaction that everything is just part of a big sideshow," said Mr. Brown, the man behind "Rings: Five Passions in World Art," which will be the centerpiece of the Cultural Olympiad that is being held here in conjunction with the 1996 Summer Olympics. "It has nothing to do with a logo. It's about interconnectedness, and if there is anything more important to the future of this planet, I'd like to know what it is." 
 Clearly, the stakes are high for Mr. Brown's show, which has a $3 million budget and uses the five Olympic rings to refer to 8,000 years of art representing the universal emotions of love, anguish, awe, triumph and joy. The exhibition was commissioned by Ned Rifkin, the director of the High Museum in Atlanta, and will be mounted there in 1996 from early July to the end of September. But the stakes and contradictions pretty well sum up the Cultural Olympiad, a sometimes awkward mix of art and sports that is part of each Olympics. Indeed the contradictions may be greater than ever when Atlanta tries to mix fine art, mass entertainment and Southern culture for the Summer Games.
There will be new plays by Sam Shepherd and Alfred Uhry. There will be music ranging from James Brown to Jessye Norman, from Mahler to Willie Nelson. This spring, there will be a unique gathering of Nobel laureates in literature. During the Olympics, in addition to "Rings," exhibitions will include "Souls Grown Deep: African-American Vernacular Art of the South," an ambitious collection of the work of black Southern artists being planned by the staff of the Michael C. Carlos Museum at Emory University.
Most of the cultural events will take place during the Summer Games, from July 19, 1996, through Aug. 4, but some events, including "Rings," will extend beyond that period, and others, like the gathering of Nobel laureates and celebrations of Africa, Mexico and Norway, will have taken place by the time the Games start.
Whether this all will turn out to be art, circus or some blend of the two remains to be seen. But the details are finally coming together for Atlanta's Cultural Olympiad, which has been quietly inching forward for three years, with a budget of $25 million. It is expected to include more than 750 performers and artisans and draw 3 million people, and is being billed as the most ambitious cultural effort in Olympic history.
Not everyone, of course, is a believer. Already there is grumbling that efforts like the Nobel gathering and particularly Mr. Brown's extravaganza are misguided attempts at cultural blockbusters, rounding up the superstars of writing and painting with the superstars of the decathlon and water polo. These critics say the Cultural Olympiad will be to serious art what Kenny G is to cutting-edge jazz.
"It strikes me as an unconvincing thesis and a misguided idea for an exhibition," Keith Christiansen, a curator of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, said of "Rings." "They put the Olympic rings on T-shirts and beer cans, so why not on an art exhibition? It's about as meaningful as that, isn't it?"
But despite some skepticism about some of the programs, and about Atlanta's cultural credentials, organizers are confident they have put together an ambitious, even potentially inspired, mix of international art and culture and that of the American South.
Jeffrey Babcock, a founder of the New World Symphony in Miami and the director of the Cultural Olympiad, seems entirely comfortable with its mix of funk, flash, grit and show biz. "What we're doing is different than creating and presenting a free-standing independent arts festival," said Mr. Babcock, who was in Los Angeles with the Philharmonic when the 1984 Summer Olympics were held in that city. "Our mission is to enhance the overall Olympic experience, to be an important add-on component of the Games experience. You can't compare this with a festival like Spoleto."
Similarly, Mr. Rifkin of the High Museum said he was not worried about the art world sniping at "Rings." "If people want to call it hokey, that's fine," he said. "I know there will be critics no matter what you do. But if it works to bring people to begin to see and appreciate works of art of different cultures it will be very successful. It's trying to be populist in spirit, and it's only because of the Olympics that we have the opportunity to do it."
On the surface, art and athletics may not have much to do with each other, but in fact from the time of ancient Greece the Olympics have integrated sports and culture. The form has varied in recent years. In Los Angeles, a small group hired by the Olympic organizers put on the cultural festivities, which were criticized locally as lacking in community involvement. In Barcelona, Spain, organization of the Cultural Olympiad was kept entirely separate from that of the Olympics, as a way to enhance its artistic independence. But its organizers ran out of money six months before the Games started, and many people felt the cultural events that did take place were difficult to find.
Atlanta has tried to involve as many people as possible from the city and regional art communities. And in keeping with its "run it like a business" civic ethic, it has taken a route opposite to that taken by Barcelona. Planning of the cultural programs is fully integrated into the planning of the Olympics, to such a degree that visitors will be able to buy a package that might include the javelin throw, women's basketball, the Atlanta Symphony and the Dallas Black Dance Theater.
That approach has helped with fund-raising and efficiency, but it has at times led to clashes between the Olympic organizers and the local arts community. Many kinks have been ironed out, but some in Atlanta's arts world still see the organizers, including Billy Payne, the president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, as intrusive micromanagers with no feeling for art.
"There's a narrowness of vision there," said one cultural figure who would only speak anonymously. "They see art as a dangerous business. It could be controversial."
From the beginning, this Cultural Olympiad has had to deal with at least two other major hurdles. The first was the extraordinary expectations raised when the Summer Games were awarded to the city. These included an idea that, as Mr. Babcock put it, "somehow the Olympics would absolutely transform the cultural life of Atlanta."
Second was that Atlanta, despite its go-go economy, isn't exactly a cultural powerhouse, particularly in the visual arts: most people agree that gallery space and the amount of major art being produced are less than world class.
"Atlanta has a relatively weak infrastructure compared to other American cities," said Louise Shaw, director of the Nexus Contemporary Arts Center. "There is not enough exhibition space, not enough high-quality, fully equipped theaters. There was hope the Olympics would spur a new symphony hall, but that's not going to happen.
"Years ago, when I was in Houston, the city had been in a recession but they built a new opera house and commissioned 'Nixon in China.' Back then, I said I couldn't imagine Atlanta doing that. I'd say the same thing now."
Many of the details -- from the artworks that will be included in "Rings" to the names of most of the performers, to the content of the Festival of the American South -- have not been announced or even finally agreed upon.
Still, despite early worries about financial backing and the pace of planning, arts groups in Atlanta and the region are now relatively upbeat about the Cultural Olympiad.
"We've already been through the five stages of a project: excitement, disillusionment, panic, the blaming of the innocent and the praising of those not involved," said Maxwell L. Anderson, director of the Carlos Museum, which is mounting an exhibition of the work of the Alabama artist Thornton Dial at the museum in addition to "Souls Grown Deep" at City Hall East.
"People learned pretty quickly this would not be a panacea, but I think it's going to de-Bubba-ize us," Mr. Anderson said. "People will see Atlanta differently from the stereotypes it's easy to have from afar."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
New Clinton Plan on Mexico Spurs Big Rally in Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply against leading currencies yesterday after President Clinton announced moves to deal with Mexico's financial crisis.
The proposal includes a loan of $20 billion from the Treasury's Exchange Stabilization Fund, which is used to help stabilize the dollar against large currency fluctuations. The International Monetary Fund agreed to lend another $10 billion beyond the $7.5 billion it promised last week, and central banks around the world will lend $10 billion. 
 With the plan, Mr. Clinton is sidestepping Congress, which had seemed increasingly reluctant to approve a previous proposal for $40 billion in loan guarantees.
News of the relief plan surprised the currency markets and eased mounting concerns that Mexico's troubles would worsen and spread elsewhere in Latin America. The threat of continued instability with some of the United States' biggest trading partners had put downward pressure on the dollar.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar, which touched a three-month low of 1.5015 German marks on Monday, rebounded to 1.5238 marks from 1.5054 marks late Monday.
The dollar also rose yesterday to 1.2855 Swiss francs from 1.2672 francs on Monday, and to 99.57 Japanese yen from 98.42 yen. The British pound slipped to $1.5795 from $1.5955
The dollar was bolstered by the President's announcement in part because the new relief plan is denominated less in dollars and more in foreign currencies.
"The market was positioned for disappointment, so it was caught short," said Ron Leven, global currency strategist at J. P. Morgan. "In addition, under the old package Mexico would have only gotten dollars. Now they are going to have a whole basket of currencies."
With a greater proportion of funds coming from countries outside the United States through institutions like the International Monetary Fund, the dollar was seen as less vulnerable should Mexico be forced to rely heavily on the package.
But while the Mexican plan bolstered the dollar, currency dealers said yesterday's action was not the start of a prolonged rally.
"The upside for the dollar is still very limited," Mr. Leven added. "There still appears to be a lot of selling interest around 1.53 marks."
In other trading, the Canadian dollar rose to 71.09 United States cents, from 70.42 cents on Monday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Plan to Expand Disneyland Is Canceled

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Jan. 31

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company has shelved plans for a $2.75 billion resort development that would have doubled the size of Disneyland.
In a meeting on Monday, Disney project managers told city officials, who had helped line up tax money for improvements, that they still intended to develop land around Disneyland, but on a smaller scale. 
 The decision was a disappointment to local officials and businesses that had counted on Disneyland to attract more tourists to this area of Orange County.
However, local homeowners who opposed the project on grounds of greater noise, air pollution and traffic were pleased. "I guess it's good news," said Curtis Stricker, founder of Anaheim Home, a neighborhood group, of Disney's decision. "But it's time they level with the people and tell them what they're going to do."
In disclosing its decision, the company was not explicit about future plans. "We still have this vision of creating a theme park that will work, but one that would not accommodate as many" visitors, said Disneyland's new president, Paul Pressler. "What we had originally envisioned was a very, very large resort. What we are looking at today is the ability to break it into component parts and build on it."
Responding to speculation that Orange County's declaration of bankruptcy had been a factor in the decision, Mr. Pressler said it was not.
The scaling back of Disneyland's expansion was one of a number of recent reversals in company plans or prospects. Last September, Disney canceled plans to build a $650 million Civil War theme park in northern Virginia, a project opposed both by historians and local residents. And over the last two years, Euro Disneyland, outside Paris, has proved to be a big financial drain on the parent company.
The Westcot Center project here had envisioned an international theme park, an amphitheater, a lagoon, two of the nation's biggest parking structures and 4,600 new hotel rooms in the area.
It was estimated that the project would have brought 27,000 jobs. Anaheim increased its hotel bed tax and approved rezoning. Gov. Pete Wilson of California organized a $60 million state finance package, and Congress allocated transportation money.
The project's cost was first estimated at $2.75 billion; later estimates put it as high as $3 billion.
But Disney never committed itself to proceeding. The company said it had passed on six options to purchase land in the heart of the planned development because the plots were too expensive. "It did not make sense, given the price," said David Malmuth, a vice president of the Disney Development Company.
Anaheim's city manager, James D. Ruth, said he remained optimistic. "They are still committed to developing in Anaheim, but will do so incrementally," Mr. Ruth said. "A lot of time, effort and energy has gone into getting us where we are, and we don't think that is lost."
Stan Pawlowski, co-chairman of a community group, Westcot 2000, remarked: "They probably took a look and said that $3 billion is unrealistic today, but something is possible. Even though it's not the full loaf, half a loaf is better than nothing."
Southern California's tourist industry had regarded the project as an antidote to recession, earthquakes and rioting. While Los Angeles tourism increased last year, Orange County recorded the lowest number of visitors -- 37.1 million -- in at least eight years.
Disney's shares closed today at $50.875, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Mexican Shadow Falls On Emerging Markets

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
For the emerging markets of the world, January was the month that investors began to focus on what could go wrong, not on what could go right.
The result was substantial losses for investors in almost every emerging market, losses that are still large even after the strong revivals in Mexican and other Latin American markets yesterday after the Clinton Administration disclosed a new rescue package for Mexico. 
At the same time, many third-world currencies have come under pressure, as investors sought to get out rather than risk another devaluation. Central banks have intervened to defend currencies, and in some cases have sought to identify the speculators who were putting pressure on their currencies.
The declines have perplexed and in some cases angered governments, which argue that their countries are not Mexico and have not made the same mistakes its Government did. But Wall Street analysts, who had focused on a rosy outlook for economic growth in the third world, have turned instead to looking at possible problems.
Countries that have been running substantial current-account deficits in trade and services -- and therefore were extremely reliant on foreign capital -- were quickly identified as possibly vulnerable. So were countries with relatively low reserves of foreign currency. Mexico had faced both problems before it devalued the peso in December, but most analysts had been unconcerned. Now, suddenly, there was great worry.
Countries identified by Merrill Lynch as having big current-account deficits included the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand. Those with low foreign-exchange reserves included China, Indonesia, South Korea and the Philippines.
Mexico's stock market was the worst performer for the month for foreign investors, losing 22.3 percent in dollar terms despite a surge yesterday that saw some share prices rise more than 20 percent. But it was hardly alone. Other stock markets that saw prices fall by more than 10 percent in the month included those of the Philippines, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea, India, Pakistan, Peru, Turkey and Hungary.
To many countries, the change in investor focus has been baffling. The most successful countries in attracting foreign capital, in many cases because of promising investment possibilities, were often running large current-account deficits.
One result has been a tendency to view the enemy as speculators who are betting against the country, either by shorting stocks in it -- that is, selling stocks that are not owned in hopes their price will decline -- or by shorting the country's currency. Currency values in most developing nations are pegged by their governments, as was Mexico's before the devaluation.
Asian central banks held an unusual meeting and said they planned to share information on the identity of speculators betting against their currencies.
In Malaysia, where the stock market fell 9.2 percent in January, the Government has announced plans to toughen laws banning stock manipulation and short-selling. In addition to larger fines, Malaysia proposed to cane -- that is, whip -- violators. And, as was typical in many countries, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia said he thought stocks were a good investment.
As the stock markets suffered, Mexico's problems were far from the only ones cited. There has been widespread fear that the Federal Reserve Board, which is expected to push up American short-term interest rates today, will damage emerging economies, as well. And the Japanese earthquake has evidently caused a number of Japanese institutions to pull in their horns, too, and take money out of Asian stock markets.
The decline in many emerging markets began well before last month, but even with substantial losses in many markets in 1994, enthusiasm for the idea of investing in such countries remained high. Barton M. Biggs, the international strategist for Morgan Stanley, argues that the emerging-market bear market is now 13 months old. "I think we are very close to the end of the cyclical bear market," he said yesterday.
Over the years, the amount of public and press attention that has lately been given to Mexico has often come only when a problem is at its worst, and soon to improve. If that is the case now, then emerging markets may generally be bottoming.
That will be true if investors are willing to go back to the way they used to think, before they were stunned by Mexico, focusing on possibilities for growth and on hopes of drawing in money from those who want the big returns that are difficult to get in more established markets.
The success of President Clinton in putting together a bailout proposal, despite Congressional opposition, could help to bring about that attitude, at least for a while. Many American investors -- those who bought Mexican debt that was denominated in dollars but payable in pesos -- seem more likely to emerge whole. Perhaps that will help investors to forget January's terror.
If not, if the month does serve as a powerful reminder of the risks of investing in developing countries, then it could set back the flow of capital to such countries -- and to the stock markets -- for years to come.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally On Clinton's Mexico Move

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
In one of the busiest sessions on record, financial markets rallied as the Clinton Administration took quick action to aid Mexico. Stocks recovered, bonds rebounded and the dollar soared as the imminent threat receded of Mexico defaulting on its debt.
The announcement of the aid package also lifted a burden from the Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, as the Fed's policy-making committee concludes a two-day meeting today. If, as traders expect, the Fed raises interest rates today or later this month, higher rates would have further damaged Mexico's economy without a rescue plan in place. 
 "This frees up the hand of Mr. Greenspan," said Jose Cerritelli, a fixed-income strategist for Baring Securities Inc., which specializes in emerging-market securities. "If interest rates were raised, it would have struck at the heart of Mexico. Now the dagger has been removed."
The new plan, offered in tandem with the International Monetary Fund and Bank for International Settlements, could raise the total amount of financial aid to Mexico to as much as $50 billion in loans and loan guarantees from $40 billion and does not require lengthy Congressional approval.
"It's even better than the previous plan," said Paul Hennessey, senior vice president for the Boston Company, which manages $16 billion worth of stocks. "It's got more dough and it's quicker."
Whether the markets will remain sanguine is an open question. The new plan also extends loan maturities from months to as long as 10 years and lacks details from important lenders, including the I.M.F.
"We're on the hook forever, basically," said David De Rosa, a director of foreign-exchange trading at Swiss Bank in New York. "But the markets knew it was coming. When a person is about to become insolvent, you either write off the debt or extend the maturity."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.78 points, to 3,843.86, as trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange hit 409.5 million shares, the ninth-busiest session on record. The exchange also reported that January was the busiest month on record, with average daily volume of 325 million shares, compared to daily volume of 315.7 million shares in January 1994.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 1.91 points, to 470.42. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 3.37 points, to 755.20.
The dollar rallied, rising to 99.57 yen from 98.42 Japanese yen and advancing to 1.5238 German marks from 1.5054 marks. Bonds rallied, too. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 7.69 percent from 7.75 percent.
The biggest movers in stocks were mostly related to Mexico and Latin America. The American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican telephone company, rose 4 5/8, to 35 3/8. It was one of the day's most active stocks, with 17.66 million shares traded.
Similarly, the A.D.R.'s of Grupo Televisa, a leading broadcaster in Mexico, rose 5, to 24. And Compania de Telefonos de Chile, the Chilean telephone carrier, rose 4 3/8, to 73 3/8.
The A.D.R.'s of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, parent of the MCA film studio, dropped 6 5/8, to 140 1/8, after an article in The Wall Street Journal reported that "Waterworld," a film the studio is producing, may be most expensive ever, at up to $175 million.
The Taiwan Fund, a closed-end mutual fund for Taiwanese stocks, fell 5 3/8 to 23 1/8 after its shares traded ex-dividend, the period when the company does not pay a dividend. Premark International, which sells Tupperware plastic products, fell 5 1/4 to 41 after the company said the devalued Mexican peso and the Japan earthquake would hurt 1995 earnings.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.03 points, to 255.93; advancing stocks outnumbered decliners 1,289 to 918. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.82 points, to 435.36.

HEADLINE: Labor Costs Show Small Increase

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The Employment Cost Index, which measures the wages, salaries and benefits paid to American workers, rose during the last 12 months by only 3 percent, the smallest annual increase on record, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
That restrained increase in the Government's most comprehensive measure of labor costs gives strong statistical support to a growing impression among some economists that a fundamental change may be taking place. More than in the past, wages and benefits have failed to rise in response to robust economic growth and low unemployment. Labor costs eased off even in the fourth quarter of last year, rising only seven-tenths of 1 percent. That matched the record low for a single quarter. 
 "Labor shortages are simply not translating into wage pressures, even in areas like the Carolinas and the Midwest, where the unemployment rate is very low," said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. "If this were a normal recovery, one would have expected more wage pressure by now. But the world is not the old way anymore."
The latest Employment Cost Index, an indicator issued quarterly since 1982, came out only hours before the Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee began a two-day meeting to consider whether to raise interest rates again. The Fed's goal would be to slow the economy, thus easing labor shortages -- and the wage pressures and rising inflation that in the past have resulted from labor shortages.
"I guarantee you that this latest data on employment costs entered into the debate today at the Federal Reserve, but it will probably not change the outcome," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Like many on Wall Street, Mr. Roach believes the Fed's policy makers will announce today an increase in short-term rates, the seventh increase in a year. The Fed, they note, deals in expectations of what will happen in the future, not what has already happened.
Some Fed policy makers, in recent statements, have expressed the view that labor costs must rise, despite the mild increases so far. What will inevitably make that happen, they said, is the combination of an unemployment rate that has been below 6 percent for months and a vigorous economy expanding at an annual rate of more than 4 percent.
"If you look at the unemployment data, you can see that we are closer to wage pressures than we were a year ago," said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist.
Perhaps. Or perhaps wage pressure requires much stronger economic growth and much lower unemployment than in the past, some economists argue. If that is the case -- and no one really knows yet -- then the Federal Reserve, by raising interest rates on loans to dampen demand, might end up slowing economic growth prematurely, bringing on hardship unnecessarily.
"There is no question that we are going through a sea change of some sort," said Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant.
Many explanations are offered for the weakness in wages and benefits so evident in the Employment Cost Index, despite the low unemployment rate and strong economy. One is that employers are hiring the unskilled at low wages and training them, rather than bidding for scarce skilled workers, raising wage scales in the process to attract them.
That has worked even in the Midwest, where the unemployment rate is generally under 4 percent, though in some cases -- the booming construction industry in Phoenix is an example -- workers are in such short supply that wages are indeed rising.
Another explanation for the weak rise in labor costs is that Corporate America is making its employees work longer hours, rather than seeking new employees, who would have to be paid benefits has well as wages. In addition, the vast service sector, in the past a source of rapid hiring, has cut back in recent years, preferring instead labor-saving devices like cash registers that not only ring up sales but track inventories.
Then, too, layoffs and the widespread concerns about job security have made workers reluctant to demand pay increases that exceed the inflation rate. And union bargaining power, already weak, has waned even more.
In a separate release yesterday, the Labor Department reported that union contracts negotiated in the fourth quarter provided for annual wage increases averaging 2.5 percent. That was nearly a percentage point less than the contracts they replaced, which had been negotiated in 1991 and 1992, when the economy was weak.
Finally, outlays for health insurance and other benefits, usually a source of sharp increases in the Employment Cost Index, rose only mildly last year, even tapering off along with wages in the fourth quarter. "What happened to benefits is almost entirely due to a slowdown in the rise of health insurance premiums," said Wayne Shelly, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Whatever the reasons, the Employment Cost Index, adjusted for inflation, rose three-tenths of 1 percent last year, among the smallest increases in the 14 years of the index. Each of the components behaved with similar mildness. Before allowing for inflation, wages and salaries were up 2.8 percent for the year and six-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter, while benefit costs rose 3.4 percent for the year and seven-tenths of 1 percent for the final quarter. In each case, the increases were among the smallest on record. That was also true after adjustment for inflation.
Separately, the Conference Board, a business organization, reported that its consumer confidence index had fallen to 102.1 in December from 103.4 in November.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Mixed On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the long end of the market up sharply on a rally sparked by news that President Clinton had abandoned plans to seek Congressional authority for the Mexican bailout, deciding instead to use existing executive authority to put in place a peso stabilization plan.
Meanwhile, shorter maturities remained tentative as the Federal Reserve's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, began a two-day meeting to determine the course of interest rates over the next few months. Most traders and dealers expect the Fed to raise short-term rates at the conclusion of the meeting by half a percentage point. That would be the seventh rate increase by the central bank in a year as it moves to slow economic growth and keep inflation in check. 
 Traders and analysts said that news of the new Mexican rescue plan eased concern by some market participants that the Fed might delay a rate increase in order to spare the Mexican financial markets from further pressure.
By late in the day the 30-year bond was up 23/32 , to a price of 9724/32 for a yield of 7.69 percent, down from 7.75 percent on Monday. That means bondholders gained about $7.18 for every $1,000 invested. Shorter-maturity bill rates, which would be the first to bear the brunt of a Fed rate increase, rose slightly, with a three-month issue up five basis points, to 5.82 percent, and a one-year up three basis points, to 6.37 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist for Josephthal Lyon & Ross, said that the prices of longer maturities were pushed higher by more than the rally in the dollar that followed the announcement of the new Mexican rescue plan. He believes that investors are buying longer maturities because they believe that the economy is finally beginning to slow enough to keep inflation generally in check. Market analysts and traders said the firming of the dollar against other major currencies yesterday, and signs that inflation currently poses no immediate threat, helped to underpin the strength in bonds.
The Employment Cost Index, which the Fed looks at closely for any signs of new price pressures, showed only a marginal increase in hourly labor costs and worker benefits at the end of last year. And for all of 1994, the index rose just 3 percent, its lowest increase ever.
Some economists find it hard to believe that with unemployment at 5.4 percent, that these kinds of numbers are possible. But most say this will not dissuade the Fed from raising short-term rates once more.
In another report issued yesterday, consumer confidence eased slightly in January to 102.1 from a revised 103.4 in December, according to the Conference Board.
Anthony E. Spare, chief investment officer for the $2 billion money management firm of Spare, Kaplan, Bischel & Associates in San Fransisco, who also thinks the economy will slow down further at end of 1995, says "that inflation can be in the 4 to 5 percent range by the end of this year along with lower growth. We assume that a 7-7.75 percent yield is a good guess as to the proper risk relationship for that bond." He believes that the long bond at a 7.75 percent already reflects that expectation.
Mr. Spare also believes that 1995 will be a year when we'll see a flight to quality. And as a result, Treasury rates will decline and junk rates could go higher.
Today the Treasury plans to announce the size of its quarterly refunding, which would bring supply to the market.
Elsewhere, municipal bond yields fell to their lowest level in nearly four months as prices rose on existing issues because of the scaricty of new issues. On a yield to maturity basis, the yield on The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues fell to 6.66 percent yesterday, down from 6.70 percent on Monday. It is at its lowest level since October 19, 1994, when the yield was 6.64 percent.
Over the next 30 days, only $1.7 billion in bonds are scheduled for sale, that's 70 percent less than during the same period a year ago, according to The Bond Buyer.
Bloomberg Business News reports that municipalities sold $6 billion in bonds in January, the lowest amount since 1988.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices for Gasoline Surge On New Jersey Selling Plan

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gasoline prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid expectations that New Jersey retailers would not soon switch to selling a grade of reformulated gasoline not yet traded on the exchange.
On other commodity exchanges, gold and silver prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.94 point, to 232.78. 
 New Jersey officials have been considering allowing the sale of gasoline with 2 percent oxygen content, which would be cheaper than gasoline with 2.7 percent oxygen. A reduction to 2 percent would allow the state to comply with Federal law requiring the sale of a cleaner, reformulated gasoline but would have effectively let it drop out of an optional, statewide program requiring it to sell the 2.7 percent grade during the winter.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, speaking at the National Governors' Association in Washington, noted that southern New Jersey would be able to sell the 2 percent grade as of March 1 while the northern part of the state would be able to sell that grade by May 1.
Gasoline prices had fallen last week on fears that New Jersey would switch to the 2 percent grade before those deadlines, decreasing demand for the 2.7 percent grade, which the New York Mercantile Exchange requires be delivered until May 1.
Traders took the Governor's comments to mean the state would not switch to the cheaper grade immediately, as had been speculated.
The February gasoline contract, which expired yesterday, jumped 1.55 cents, to 57.76 cents a gallon. March gasoline rose 1.25 cents, to 56.53 cents a gallon. The gains helped lift crude oil prices. Crude oil for March delivery gained 30 cents, to $18.39 a barrel.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, gold and silver prices fell on expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates today. Gold and silver are historically bought as a hedge against inflation. An increase in rates is aimed at containing future inflation.
Gold for February delivery fell $1.40, to $375.40 an ounce, while silver for March delivery slid 6.7 cents, to $4.663 an ounce, both three-week lows.

HEADLINE: Brown Bros. Appoints Top Official

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the nation's oldest and largest private bank, said yesterday that Anthony T. Enders had been appointed managing partner, a position akin to chief executive.
Mr. Enders, whose appointment is effective today, succeeds Terrence M. Farley. Mr. Farley, who has held the post since November 1983, will be 65 years old next month; he will remain as a general partner. 
 To an outsider, Brown Brothers seems an anachronism in the bruising world of Wall Street, where huge public companies with enormous amounts of capital compete to do business with clients that may be here today, but somewhere else tommorrow.
With assets of $1.55 billion and capital of slightly more than $155 million, Brown Brothers does not have terribly big shoulders when compared with its competitors. Instead, like most small creatures, the firm relies on quick wits and feet to survive and prosper.
"We try to focus on those businesses where demands for capital are not exorbitant, or beyond our ability to meet them," Mr. Enders, who is 57, said in an interview. "We try and focus on things we think we can do pretty well, and where we can get a good return."
The firm's performance more than met that standard in 1994. In a year when rising interest rates soured the bottom line at most Wall Street firms, Brown Brothers had its best year ever, Mr. Enders said.
In addition to commercial banking, Brown Brothers is an investment adviser, corporate financier and stockbroker. Over the last decade, Brown Brothers has also worked hard at expanding its custodial relationship business with the mutual funds industry.
The custodial business requires detailed knowledge of computers and operations, and Mr. Enders serves as chairman of the firm's Operating and Systems Management committees. "Early last year we had a significant increase in our global custody business," he said. "And because of the custody business, we have a proportionately large amount of money in short-term demand deposits. When rates go up, that helps us a bit."
In contrast to the career of Mr. Farley, who joined Brown Brothers as a clerk and went to the City College of New York at night, Mr. Enders's roots and rise to the top are more in line with the firm's patrician image and past.
Brown Brothers traces its roots to 1818, but its modern form emerged with the merger in 1931 of two private banks, Brown Brothers and Harriman Brothers. In addition to the Harriman brothers, E. Roland and W. Averell, past partners include Prescott Bush, the father of former President George Bush.
Born in Hartford and educated at Philips Exeter Academy, Harvard College and Harvard Business School, Mr. Enders joined Brown Brothers in Boston in 1962, did a four-year stint in London in the mid-1970's and was made a partner in 1981. He and his wife, the artist Elizabeth M. Enders, have four children.

HEADLINE: STATE DEPT. STUDY SAYS CHINA LAGS ON HUMAN RIGHTS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
In the latest setback to the Clinton Administration's 16-month strategy of engaging rather than isolating China, a State Department report on human rights has concluded that China made no progress in any major human rights area last year.
The human rights report coincides with a series of bitter confrontations with China over its trade practices, its export of weapons-related technology and Washington's upgrading of contacts with Taiwan. 
 The report, which is part of the State Department's global human rights survey to be issued on Wednesday, is particularly embarrassing for the Administration because it underscores its failure to nudge China into improving its human rights performance despite the unconditional extension of preferential trade privileges eight months ago.
At that time, President Clinton abandoned the annual ritual of linking renewal of trade benefits to improvements in Beijing's human rights performance. He argued that China's economic and strategic importance had grown so great that it would be unwise to impose the broad sanctions he had threatened.
Privately, Mr. Clinton and his aides had expressed the expectation that the Chinese would fulfill their assertion that in the absence of external threats, it would be much easier for them to make progress in the area of human rights. In particular, Commerce Secretary Ron Brown at the time touted his strategy of "commercial engagement" as crucial to improving China's behavior.
That was not to be the case.
"In 1994, there continued to be widespread and well-documented human rights abuses in China, in violation of internationally accepted norms, stemming both from the authorities' intolerance of dissent and the inadequacy of legal safeguards for freedom of speech, association and religion," the report states. "Abuses include arbitrary and lengthy incommunicado detention, torture and mistreatment of prisoners."
The report calls China an "authoritarian state" in which the Communist Party "monopolizes decision-making authority."
Further, it criticizes Chinese authorities for the detention of perhaps thousands of "prisoners of conscience;" an inadequate accounting of those who are missing or were detained after the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations; a crackdown on journalists; the routine arrest of dissidents during foreign visits; the denial of fair trials; and a requirement that prisoners work in labor camps.
Last year, the Administration tried to persuade China to give the International Committee of the Red Cross access to Chinese prisons, to release certain prominent and ailing political prisoners and to end the jamming of the Voice of America. None of those goals were accomplished, the report says.
The report also notes that forced abortions and sterilization occur in China, although such practices are not authorized by the Government. And it raises accusations that the Chinese have forced prisoners to donate their organs for transplants.
As for Tibet, the report concludes that the human rights situation has worsened there in the last year. In 1994, the Chinese authorities committed "widespread human rights abuses," including torture, arbitrary arrest, the detention and prosecution of monks and nuns who express dissenting views in public and rigid controls on freedom of speech and the press.
On the positive side, the report praises, among other things, the passage of a new law that gives Chinese citizens the right to sue the Government for improper treatment, although the law has yet to be carried out.
One of the Administration's goals before it extended trade benefits to China last year was that China begin discussions with Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama; on the contrary, the report notes that the Chinese authorities forbade party and Government officials from displaying his photograph, even in their homes, and removed his photographs from sale at bazaar shops.
In a diplomatic standoff that is expected to go down to the wire, the United States has threatened to impose punitive tariffs against $2.8 billion in Chinese exports on Saturday unless China cracks down on the pirating of American movies, music and computer software.
Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, said in a telephone interview today that the United States intends to proceed with the penalties . "We have made it clear to the Chinese that an agreement is absolutely necessary, that we are prepared to issue a final retaliatory list on Feb. 4 if we have no agreement," Mr. Kantor said.
Senior officials acknowledge that even if the United States goes forward with the punitive measure, it will take at least three weeks to carry out because goods already being shipped will not be affected.
The harsh report on China's human rights record did not come as a surprise. In a speech in Seattle earlier this month, Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said: "Frankly, on the human rights front, the situation has deteriorated. They're rounding up dissidents, harassing them more." In fact, Mr. Lord added, China "is a somewhat difficult partner these days."
Washington's frustration with Beijing is so intense that even the most ardent supporters of the policy inside the Administration acknowledge that they are deeply disappointed. These officials are also concerned that the policy setbacks will enhance the chances of leading Republican lawmakers, like Senator Frank Murkowski of Alaska and Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, to upgrade the Administration's relationship with Taiwan.
