HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON OFFERS $20 BILLION TO MEXICO FOR PESO RESCUE; ACTION SIDESTEPS CONGRESS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
In the face of widespread opposition, President Clinton today abandoned his effort to get Congress to approve $40 billion in loan guarantees to rescue the Mexican economy. Instead, he said he would use his own emergency authority to lend up to $20 billion to Mexico to keep it from defaulting on Government-issued bonds.
Caught between lawmakers who refused to cooperate and economic markets that threatened to swamp America's third-largest trading partner, Mr. Clinton ordered his aides to put together an international rescue package that would sidestep Congress and that could total about $50 billion. 
 As word of the White House decision flashed in seconds to trading screens around the world, the reaction was immediate. The peso strengthened dramatically to 5.75 to the dollar, after falling to 6.35 on Monday as doubts grew that Congress would act.
Mr. Clinton moved after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and other top aides warned him on Monday night that time had run out, and that a default by Mexico -- which seemed only days away -- could touch off a panic in large emerging markets around the world. [Page A16.]
"Time did not permit the education process that might have permitted Congressional action," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today, although many in Congress said no amount of time would have led to approval. "The situation was dire in Mexico."
After a night of emergency calls to finance ministers around the globe, the Treasury Department cobbled together a rescue plan that includes a commitment by the International Monetary Fund to lend Mexico $17.8 billion -- its biggest loan ever to a country in financial distress -- and loans of $10 billion from the Bank for International Settlements. Canada and Latin American nations agreed to contribute an additional $2 billion.
But the United States is by far the largest contributor, and Mr. Clinton assumes a far larger financial and political risk than he has at any time since the Mexican crisis began. Rather than simply co-sign Mexico's loans -- the heart of the $40 billion plan that failed in Congress -- Mr. Clinton has agreed to a $20 billion-package that could include direct loans and loan guarantees. As collateral, Mexico will put up $7 billion in annual oil earnings, which the United States can draw on if Mexico defaults.
While the President said Mexico would have to meet strict financial conditions, which are basically the same as the ones in the plan proposed to Congress, he decided to ignore Congressional calls to condition American aid upon obtaining Mexico's cooperation in restricting illegal immigration and fighting narcotics trafficking.
However, Mr. Clinton called Mexico's President, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon, from Air Force One this afternoon and said he would need cooperation on a range of immigration and other issues of enormous sensitivity in Mexico. Mr. Christopher said he believed that "today's action will enhance our ability to achieve good results in those areas."
Speaking to Democratic governors this morning, President Clinton defended his action, saying: "This is in the interest of America, contrary to what some of have said, not because there are large financial interests at stake, but because there are thousands of jobs, billions of dollars of American exports at stake, the potential of an even more serious illegal immigration problem, the spread of financial instability to other countries in our hemisphere, and indeed to other developing countries throughout the world, and the potential of a more serious narcotics trafficking problem."
To circumvent Congress, Mr. Clinton used $20 billion in a Treasury Department account called the Exchange Stabilization Fund, which is ordinarily used to stabilize the dollar on international exchange markets. The fund, created by Franklin D. Roosevelt in the Depression, has never before been used to make medium-term loans to other nations.
The relief shown by investors to the new aid package was nothing compared to that displayed in Congress, where members were delighted that they would not have to act on a measure of clear national importance that an overwhelming number of Americans -- more than 80 percent according to some polls -- think is a bad idea.
"Any time a Congressman or Senator doesn't have to vote on something, it's a great day," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, the general chairman of the Democratic National Committee and one of the few in Congress who supported the initial bailout plan.
Administration officials insisted today that with enough time and Presidential persuasion, Congress would have enacted the package. But there was little evidence to support that optimism after two weeks of withering criticism from members who claimed that Congress was bailing out wealthy investors and pension funds that bought Government-issued junk bonds and lost.
"If the issue had been brought to the Senate floor, it would have lost," said Senator William S. Cohen, a Republican of Maine, said today.
Mr. Clinton's action was endorsed by leaders of both parties. In a joint announcement with President Clinton, House Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate Majority Leader, Bob Dole, said, "This is an important undertaking and we believe that the risks of inaction vastly exceed any risks associated with this action."
But the statement provides Mr. Clinton with scant political cover. Critics of the effort were already claiming that Mr. Clinton had solved none of the defects of the original plan, other than getting other countries to share in the risk. Patrick J. Buchanan, a 1992 Republican Presidential contender and critic of the loan guarantees, called the new plan a "back-door raid on the American taxpayers." H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who led the drive against the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993, told a Senate committee today that the new plan "isn't going to work either."
The plan Mr. Clinton announced today is the third effort in five weeks to stem the crisis that began when Mexico was forced to devalue its currency. The devaluation was forced on the Government after investors grew increasingly nervous that the country had issued too many short-term bonds -- called tesobonos -- to cover its long-term debts. But that effort failed to calm investors who recognized that the peso was wildly overvalued, and soon both the peso and the Mexican stock market dropped like a rock.
Mr. Clinton first announced a short-term loan to Mexico, known as a swap facility, in hopes of restoring investor confidence. When that failed, he was forced to propose the $40 billion in loan guarantees, hoping that investors would return to the Mexican market if they believed that the United States would be the ultimate guarantor that the country would not default. That propped up the market for a while. But as objections rose in Congress, the markets turned south again.
Hoping to stave off further disaster, the White House publicly waved aside pronouncements from Capitol Hill that its $40 billion loan guarantee program was all but dead. Officials insist that as late as Monday afternoon agreement was near on final wording for a bill jammed with conditions.
But by early evening it had all fallen apart, and Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole told Leon E. Panetta, the President's chief of staff, that the effort was hopeless.
Mr. Clinton's only option for acting without Congressional approval was the Exchange Stabilization Fund, which currently contains about $25 billion -- not enough to make a bailout credible to investors. And the Treasury could not commit all of that amount, for fear it would not have enough reserves available in case it needed to defend the dollar or help stabilize another currency on the foreign exchange markets.
As a result, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, Lawrence Summers, turned to the International Monetary Fund, which had already committed far more to saving Mexico than its own investment guidelines permit. After all-night consultations that ended at dawn on Tuesday, the I.M.F. agreed to a package of $17.8 billion in loans, payable in five years. That should give Mexico a cushion to pay off its short-term bondholders and then issue longer-term securities that will ease its cash squeeze.
"Our hope is to lay $10 billion of that off on some other central banks around the world," said one senior administration official. That is an oblique way of saying that the Japanese and the Germans, who so far have been enormously reluctant to join in bailing out Mexico, will be asked to pay a large share of it.
But the Japanese say they are paying for the Kobe earthquake, and the Germans say they have their own huge drains reconstructing the former East Germany. "It will not be easy," one Administration official said this afternoon. "They have all made it clear that they view this as an American problem."
They got that idea from Mr. Clinton, who has argued for weeks now that he is acting to save 700,000 American jobs dependent on exports to Mexico -- exports that would dry up if the Mexican economy crashes. To further persuade Congress, the White House has also argued that a deepening crisis would lead to an influx of half a million more illegal immigrants, attracted by the prospect of earning dollars that are now 40 percent more valuable in Mexico than they were six weeks ago.
None of those arguments seemed enough, however. Nor was Congress moved by the Administration's contention that in the modern world of finance, where capital flies around the world at the push of a button, a default by Mexico would soon spread to any emerging market that depends heavily on international investment.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Risky Course for Clinton

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
On "very difficult issues, the Congress does the right thing" more often than not, President Clinton said Monday. The problem with that comforting maxim is that Congress and the President sometimes disagree on what is right, and so it was on the $40 billion loan guarantee for Mexico. Congress thought it was wrong, partly because it looked too much like a welfare program for Wall Street, and in effect killed it by delaying action until Mr. Clinton felt he could wait no longer.
Given a few more weeks, the White House insisted tonight, it could have pushed its proposal through the Senate and the House of Representatives. Very few people in leadership positions on Capitol Hill believe that. The loan guarantee was losing support, not gaining it, in the last few days. 
 What happened, most politicians here think, is that the President and his advisers misunderstood the political atmosphere. Some of the blame will inevitably attach itself to the new Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, one of the most sure-footed people in the White House during his two years as head of the National Economic Council. Former Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, a longtime Senator, might have provided a keener reading of the mood on Capitol Hill.
Furthermore, Congress is now controlled by the Republicans, the President has been rocked back onto his heels, a new populism is abroad in the land and Nafta -- the North American Free Trade Agreement, designed to encourage investment in Mexico -- looks far less appealing with recent peasant unrest there, continued illegal immigration and now severe trouble in the economy.
Especially but not exclusively on the House side, the newer, younger Republicans tend toward parochialism, taking a dim view of both international economic organizations and American economic commitments overseas.
The guarantee idea was no doubt difficult to sell in the time available. A senior United States official said that he was "always shocked by how difficult it is to explain economic issues to the public and to the Hill." But Nafta and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade were, if anything, more complicated, and Mr. Clinton still managed to assemble Congressional majorities for both of them in the last two years.
In fact, a leading Democrat on Capitol Hill said this morning, "You didn't really feel much heat from the President on this the last two weeks."
During his 81-minute State of the Union speech, Mr. Clinton devoted precisely two paragraphs to the financial crisis in Mexico, and at no point did his language suggest that the situation presented a dire threat to the United States, as Secretary of State Warren Christopher said this afternoon.
Speaker Newt Gingrich, ostensibly a supporter of the guarantee, was either unwilling or, despite his vise-like grip on his troops on most issues, unable to rally much backing for the White House plan. As late as Monday afternoon, his aides assured the White House that they were just a few hours away from a workable package. Then, on Monday evening, those signals were switched, and the White House was told that nothing could be produced in the near future.
The most likely explanation is that, like everyone else on Capitol Hill, Mr. Gingrich read the numbers in a Los Angeles Times poll, taken from Jan. 19 to 22, that showed Americans disapproved of the guarantee proposal by a huge margin, 81 percent to 15 percent. Most saw it as a bailout of the peso that would benefit mainly wealthy Mexicans and Wall Street big shots.
Conservative politicians jumped on the anti-guarantee bandwagon early, making life difficult for Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader. Among them were Jack F. Kemp, a leading Republican theorist; former Ambassador Jeane Kirkpatrick and, notably, Senator Phil Gramm.
Mr. Gramm, a Texan, is Mr. Dole's main rival at the moment for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination, which gave Mr. Dole every reason to avoid point duty for the White House. From the start, he said Mr. Clinton would have to produce more Democratic votes before the Republicans would join in.
Public antipathy may have been fed, in addition, by unpleasant memories of the tremendously expensive bailout of failed banks and savings and loans from 1988 to 1992. At any rate, the most important element in turning the electorate against the idea seems to have been the sense that once again, Wall Street and Washington were conspiring to pick the pocket of the little guy.
Nothing of the sort, the White House and much of Wall Street insists. But one prominent figure in the investment-banking community thinks the public has got it just about right.
"What you have here is Mexican government bonds paying huge interest rates," the banker said after insisting he not be quoted by name. "Junk bonds, in effect. But the guys who run the mutual funds and pension funds couldn't resist, so they took huge risks with the money of people who didn't really get what was at stake. It comes close to violating a fiduciary responsibility in some cases, and when the balloon went up, all they could do was run to Washington for help."
The ultimate blame may reside with the Mexican Government, which was unwilling to act to head off the impending crisis while the Mexican election campaign was on last summer, lest it lose power. But in the face of numerous warnings, the Clinton Administration did not really push the Mexicans terribly hard, partly because it wanted the Institutional Revolutionary Party to remain in office.
Now the Administration has been forced to embark on a course with far more risks, political as well as economic, than the one it originally charted. Not only is the United States providing loans rather than guaranteeing them, but Mr. Clinton is doing it without the protective cover of Republican backing.
There may have been no choice in the end, but if things go wrong, the penalty at the polls in two years' time could be very severe indeed.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: MEXICO CITY;
Mexican Financial Markets Rebound

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Mexico's stock market soared and the peso rose in value today as President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon declared that the White House's new rescue plan would help the country emerge from its worst financial crisis in a decade.
After weeks of anxiety and chaos in the financial markets, the badly weakened peso, which on Monday took a nose dive to its lowest point since the trouble began on Dec. 20, roared back 10.5 percent today to close at 5.75 pesos to the dollar. 
 Traders and institutional investors on Wall Street and in Mexico went into a buying frenzy for Mexican stocks as soon as the plan was announced in Washington. By the end of the day, the Mexican stock market had gained 10.3 percent, recouping much of the ground lost in the last four trading days as Congressional opposition rose to Mr. Clinton's first rescue plan.
The new plan combines credits from the United States, several other nations and international financial institutions to make available to Mexico about $50 billion to deal with its economic problems.
This new American-brokered package not only calmed the financial markets but was also welcomed by Mexico as far more politically acceptable than the earlier package, since it eliminated some of the conditions that were being discussed in Congress like requiring Mexico to change the way it runs its economy, limiting relations with Cuba and clamping down on illegal emigration to the United States.
However, Mexico will still have to meet a requirement that was part of the earlier package: that it put up oil revenue as collateral to be used if the loans are not repaid.
The American announcement today was the latest turbulent chapter in Mexico's economic crisis, which began six weeks ago when the Mexican Government ordered the peso devalued in response to the country's mounting debts.
The order caused investor panic, and with it a collapse of the peso. Since then, investors have been pulling their money from Mexican markets, draining the country's international-currency reserves and raising fears of a default.
Mexican officials said they hoped that President Clinton's new offer would let Mr. Zedillo gain control of the economic crisis and defuse criticism that he had accepted earlier conditions, which were seen at home as weakening Mexican sovereignty.
Mr. Zedillo said in a speech this afternoon that the new package "deals only with strictly financial operations that in no way threaten the sovereignty of the nation." In marches and demonstrations over the last few weeks, thousands of Mexicans had condemned the growing list of demands in Washington.
"It's not a package that solves everything," said Alonso Lujambio, a political scientist at the Autonomous Technological Institute of Mexico, "but it gives Zedillo some space to maneuver."
For all the expressions of relief, the new plan was not seen, by itself, as ending Mexico's recent financial crisis, nor ending the need for Mexicans to tighten their belts during the austere period of economic recovery that lies ahead. Political analysts also agreed that a United States-led rescue would hardly reduce deeply rooted concerns about Mexico's independence as a financial market or a sovereign nation.
"It is humiliating, the level of dependency we have reached," said Sergio Aguayo, whose civic group plans to hold a national referendum on whether Mexico should accept help from the United States. "This time, there is no official propaganda that can disguise the fact that we have been saved by the President of the United States."
The practical consequences of the package outlined by Mr. Clinton today are that Mexico can address its immediate crisis of having more than $20 billion in short-term debt that foreign and domestic investors are afraid to renew, officials said.
The new and expanded credit lines are seen here as sufficiently large to reassure investors that Mexico will not default on its obligations.
Financial analysts added that if investors could be persuaded to keep their money in Mexico's bond market, the calming effect could spill over to the Mexican stock market, which has been pounded relentlessly almost since the peso was first devalued on Dec. 20; it has lost 25 percent of its value in dollar terms since the beginning of the year.
A stable stock market could in turn ease the pressure on the peso, which likewise has continued to weaken since December. One peso is now worth about 17 cents, as against nearly 29 cents six weeks ago.
But foreign investors, who hold a majority of the expiring bonds and who once invested heavily in Mexican stocks, caution that there may be long-term aftereffects even if the current crisis subsides.
"Mexico and the emerging markets will have to be rated again in terms of risk," said Brian M. Barish, vice president for emerging markets at Lazard Freres & Company, in New York. "Six months ago, the risk didn't seem that bad. Now, it's considerably higher."
The Mexican Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, said in an interview today that the new package of credit lines was not as comprehensive as the previous plan, but it would do.
"If we had gotten the $40 billion on 5- to 10-year maturities as proposed, that would have given us more flexibility to do an immediate, drastic reduction of our short-term obligations," Mr. Ortiz said. "This plan gives us almost as much flexibility because the terms are almost as adequate."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mexican stock exchange jumped 7 percent in three hours yesterday after President Clinton ordered a large aid package to Mexico. Traders at the exchange in Mexico City shouted orders during the session. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: WORKERS;
Peso's Plunge Spurs Walkout at Factory In Northern Mexico

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Angered that the peso's plunge has cut the value of their wages, more than 2,600 workers at the Thomson Consumer Electronics plant in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, walked off the job this morning and blocked thousands of other workers in a second shift from entering.
The company, a French electronics giant that employs 5,600 at the plant across the Rio Grande from El Paso, said the workers struck without notice or the involvement of their union, the Workers Federation of Mexico. 
 Until now, twin-plant operations like Thomson's, which are coordinated with factories north of the border, have benefited from the peso's plunge because most of their labor expenses are in pesos while most of their revenues are in dollars.
The value of the peso has fallen about 40 percent against the dollar since December, and prices in Mexico are rapidly rising.
"We suspect this discontent is not necessarily directed at Thomson," said Richard J. Knoph, a Thomson spokesman, "but toward the general instability of the economy."
Workers on the first shift blocked buses and cars bringing workers for the second shift, Mr. Knoph said, and kept them from entering the factory. But there was no violence or sabotage, and no police were called.
Before the peso collapsed, the workers earned the equivalent of $2.25 an hour, including a 7 percent raise in December.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
For Pinball Artist, It's World Series

BYLINE: By Michael T. Kaufman 

 BODY:
GENTLEMAN Kai Bateman was one with the pinball machine. Obviously he was entirely aware of the tao of it. As the 32-year-old commercial artist from Colonia, N.J., rolled up mega numbers, a few of the adolescents at the Broadway Arcade at 51st Street turned away from their own games to watch him.
"He's a champion," one of the teen-agers, who probably should have been in school, shouted over the noise. "He's going to be in the World Series," said another, referring to the World Pinball Championships, which are to begin on Friday and end on Sunday at the Park Central Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 55th Street. 
 Gentleman Kai is indeed one of the major contenders in the upcoming tournament where players, largely the spawn of the nation's suburbs, will be battling for money prizes and trophies on the periphery of Times Square, which, like the modern pinball machine, is going electronic, digital and post-modern.
These days, mere electric lights and giant smoke rings can no more dazzle outlanders than a steel ball hitting a bumper can quicken the blood of the young. As for purely gravity-driven pursuits like Skee-Ball and pokerino, they have vanished, declared too boring in the new technologies of passing time.
But at the arcade the frenzy of mass amusement is cutting edge. The playroom looked more like a laboratory than a poolroom. No one drank. No one gambled. Few talked since it was hard to be heard over the electronic sounds. Mostly, people just fed quarters into slots and manned controls.
GENTLEMAN Kai ignored the admiring buzz, positioning himself in front of the Twilight Zone machine, one of his favorites. Earlier, in a back room, he had explained how he had played pinball since he was 8. He had dabbled at video games but stayed with pinball. He said he liked challenging physics more than programs.
He had tried to develop a style that drew upon ballet and Bruce Lee. He won the New York area championship three years ago but failed to advance to the top in the previous four world tourneys. He did not boast, but quietly he made you realize that referring to pinball as a pastime in front of him was like telling Boris Spassky that chess was just a game.
"When you do pinball, you have to be both relaxed and in control," said the unmarried man, who spends 15 to 20 hours a week practicing on various machines.
It is easy to see how he got his name, Gentleman Kai. He is reserved, polite. He has a business painting realistic portraits on denim and leather garments. He took off the one he wore, one with the heads of the singers in En Vogue, as he dropped a coin to start his game.
He crouched, right foot forward, bent slightly at the waist, his hands in front of him, keeping index and middle fingers on the flippers. "I'm the only one I know who uses two fingers."
IT seems to work for him. For more than an hour, he kept the steel balls in play doing what he wanted. Like the other better players, he knows the wiring of this and most other games, practically all of which are manufactured in Chicago. He knows what sequences will bring him the highest score. At times he flipped the balls from one flipper to another. He also called his shots, softly saying which ramp or hole or bumper he was going to hit, and then he did it.
"Watch this, I'm about to get into what this game calls the zone, which means that six balls are going to come out at one time," he said, and sure enough, lights started flashing as six balls began ricocheting down the sloping panel.
Later, when one ball fell between the flippers, he shook his head and declared, "That was a less than average ball." As if to motivate himself, he said: "Remember pinball is a one-ball game. One ball is all you need to get billions."
He got his billions, but he did not match the 2.4 billion he had scored on the machine some time ago to become the machine's Grand Master, with his name flashing on it every few minutes.
In fact, he had also been the Grand Master on the Shadow, another model at the arcade, but last week a player named Domenick, whom he knew, had beaten his previous high and replaced him. Apparantly Gentleman Kai was not happy about this, though he did not talk of revenge.
Still, with the crowd of spectators following him, he moved to the Shadow and dropped 50 cents to start it up. He said nothing, but you could see his intensity and desire. He flipped brilliantly with a great economy of movement. No showboating. No body English. Like DiMaggio. Like Manolete. When he passed four billion, the machine's voice announced that he was again its highest-scoring player. It invited him to write his name in place of Domenick.
Though he did not exult, you could see he felt good. He was focused, concentrating on the games ahead this wekeend when he would be going up against all those people coming to his turf from all the major malls in the world. He was ready.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: FINANCIAL MARKETS;
Wall Street and Its Latin Counterparts Respond With Relief and a Wave of Higher Prices

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Financial markets reacted with relief yesterday to President Clinton's decision to sidestep Congress and undertake a multibillion-dollar rescue operation for Mexico through executive authority.
Stock markets from Toronto to Santiago rallied after the President's announcement. In New York, stocks rose in heavy trading, bonds were up sharply, and the dollar surged. 
 Markets in Argentina and Brazil, which had been battered by the Mexican crisis, leaped on the news, rising 7 percent and 8.5 percent, respectively.
"The market wanted a large package with a long-maturity profile, and that is what it has got," said Joyce Chang, a Mexico specialist with Salomon Brothers.
Said Ricardo Peon at Baring Securities in Mexico City: "This is very positive. Yesterday there was talk of default or exchange controls. Now all that has disappeared."
The dollar, which had been caught in the backwash of Mexico's economic woes as investors moved into German marks, Swiss francs and Japanese yen, strengthened against those currencies yesterday, reaching its best levels in nearly two weeks.
The euphoria gave a boost as well to American depository receipts of Mexican companies, which are traded like shares, on exchanges in the United States. The A.D.R.'s of Telefonos de Mexico, a bellwether for the Mexican market, closed at $35.375, up $4.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was the second most heavily traded issue. Each A.D.R. is the equivalent of 20 shares traded in Mexico.
The new rescue package comprises not only $20 billion in American aid promised by the President but also assistance from the International Monetary Fund, the Bank for International Settlements, some commercial banks and a group of South American countries including Brazil, Argentina, Chile and Colombia.
The package will give Mexico a large pool of capital from which to repay its outstanding loans falling due this year. Mexico will then have between 3 and 10 years to repay to that pool, depending on the credit line of the lender, effectively stretching out the nation's debt.
James Colmenares of Morgan Stanley Asset Management said Mexico has about $55 billion in short-term obligations, known as tesobonos and cetes, due this year. Of those, about $30 billion are held by foreigners, who may not want to roll them over.
"It means the liquidity crisis is over," Mr. Colmenares said of the new package, referring to earlier market fears that Mexico would be unable to meet its payments.
The Clinton Administration appears confident that the International Monetary Fund will agree to raise its lending to Mexico from the $7.8 billion that it had announced earlier to the nearly $ 17.8 billion that is called for in the new rescue plan. But the sheer size of the loan may be questioned by some members of the fund's executive board.
"This is the largest loan the I.M.F. has ever made, by a wide margin, and some board members may not be happy with such proportion of the fund's resources going to one country," said Lisa S. Kaess of Geoffrey Bell & Company, a New York investment advisory firm.
She predicted that the fund's loan would infuriate Russia, which is still locked in uphill negotiations with the I.M.F. for a $13 billion loan to help stabilize the ruble. The loan to Mexico, she said, sets "a new precedent for developing nations as to how much the I.M.F. can give, if you have the right support."

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: CHRONOLOGY;
Slow-Building Despair Led to Decision on Aid

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The decision by President Clinton to assert executive authority on Mexico's behalf came at a late-night meeting on Monday in the Oval Office, when his top advisers told him that two weeks of trying and failing to persuade Congress to act had left him with no other course.
It was a path that the White House had previously rejected, partly because the advisers believed it essential that the President and the Congress present a common front to the markets and a wary public. But by Saturday, with the peso still plunging and the plan for action on Capitol Hill fading, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and other top officials concluded that it was time to review their options. 
 With the President's approval, they set Monday as the deadline by which Congress would at least have to settle on a bill. But by Monday night, at the end of a long White House day that began in hope and ended in despair, Mr. Rubin and the rest of the team had only bad news for Mr. Clinton when he returned to the White House from a political dinner.
Senior White House officials who provided an account of the decision-making today said that Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff, and other top advisers told Mr. Clinton that they believed it would be at least two weeks -- if ever -- before the Congress would approve the $40 billion loan guarantee package to which the President and Republican leaders had pledged their support.
That was too long to wait, the advisers said, and the President agreed.
"We could not allow the situation to continue in which we were just waiting for Congress to take action and watching Mexico collapse," said a White House official who took part in the session, which began about 11 P.M.
A crucial final detail of the package did not fall in place until after dawn today, when Lawrence Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury, received word that the International Monetary Fund would put up the additional $10 billion in loan guarantees that the White House thought necessary. And the go-it-alone plan did not become official policy until Mr. Clinton met with Congressional leaders early this morning to hear first-hand of their pessimism.
But even Speaker Newt Gingrich, who had become increasingly candid about the opposition the package faced, knew when Mr. Panetta called him late Monday night that the die had been cast. If Mr. Clinton went ahead and took sole responsibility for the rescue plan, the Speaker told Mr. Panetta, he would hear from the Congress "a huge sigh of relief."
The story of how the President finally decided to devote $20 billion from an obscure Treasury Department fund to prop up Mexico's economy is in part the story of a White House reluctant to use its authority for an unpopular purpose. But it is also the story of a new era in which a Democratic President and the Republican leaders of Congress could not -- despite 18 days of joint effort -- rally their followers behind a $40 billion loan guarantee that they declared fundamental to American interests.
Asked tonight whether the White House was blaming recalcitrant Republicans or Democrats, a senior official replied: "I think this is one you probably have to lay on both sides. You really do."
Since Mr. Clinton first met with his advisers on Jan. 12 for a formal discussion of the Mexican crisis, the White House had recognized that it had the power to step in and provide the loan guarantees the President's advisers believed necessary to avert a collapse.
But the emergency stabilization fund on which Mr. Clinton finally relied had never been used for that purpose, and it contained only about $20 billion, a sum the White House feared would be inadequate.
Still, the more central reason for the reluctance was related to politics. With Republicans holding sway in Congress, Mr. Clinton's advisers worried that action by the President alone would be laughed off by the markets and scorned by the public.
Yet even after winning agreement from Mr. Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, to push for a full-scale $40 billion plan, the White House remained apprehensive. As a member of Congress, Mr. Panetta had watched how controversial rescue plans for New York City and the Chrysler Corporation had generated opposition in the 1970's, and top officials said they were on his mind as he worked the telephones trying to line up Democratic support for a plan that opinion polls and Congressional reaction was quickly showing to be almost as unappealing.
Mr. Rubin, who was sworn in as Treasury Secretary just as the battle began, also made the quest for passage of the plan a personal cause, spending nearly every day on Capitol Hill.
The Administration also got an unusually public declaration of help from the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, who went before Congress several times to express support for the package.
But by last Wednesday, mounting pessimism within the Administration -- fed by evidence from Capitol Hill and around the country that sentiment against the $40 billion plan was hardening -- led the department to begin to give the go-it-alone option another look.
Still, the White House was far from giving up hope. The meeting on Saturday at which Mr. Panetta, Mr. Rubin and others, including Samuel R. Berger, the deputy national security adviser, agreed to set a deadline, was filled with hope that it could be met. And on Sunday, when Mr. Clinton placed after-church telephone calls to Senator Dole; Speaker Gingrich; Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate minority leader, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, he was assured by each that they would do their part.
On Monday, the White House set its sights on the House as the pressure point. But while Mr. Gingrich expressed enthusiasm in a noontime telephone conversation with Mr. Panetta, that soon gave way to silence as the Speaker met with Republican governors and then with Mr. Dole to try to find a package that they, too, could support.
Mr. Panetta and Mr. Rubin had expected to go to the Capitol by late afternoon to work with Mr. Gingrich on a final proposal. But as they waited anxiously, Mr. Panetta heard first from his Mexican counterpart, who said that the situation there was worsening. And when he finally heard back from the Speaker, more than two hours after he left an urgent message with an aide, the news was just as bad: Mr. Gingrich said he now believed that it would be mid-February at the earliest before the Senate would be ready to vote.
As Mr. Panetta and his colleagues saw it then, that left them no choice but to act alone.
As they worked late into the night in his office to draft a fallback plan for the President, a senior official said today, their consensus was that, for Mexico, any alternative would have meant "chaos -- a total unraveling."

HEADLINE: On Peru Border, Strife Is Yearly Event

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PAPAYAL, Peru, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The ammunition boxes covered with vines, the ancient army trucks sending up clouds of blue diesel smoke, the draftees from the highlands sweating in the lowland equatorial heat -- Inocencio Loayza Rujel says he sees it every January.
"Each year it's the same," grumbled Mr. Loayza, a heavyset banana grower. "The army comes in. They knock down our banana plants for defenses. Nothing happens. Then they go away." 
 This frontier town, a banana's throw from Ecuador, usually sees war tensions build with the approach of the anniversary on Jan. 29 of the 1942 treaty that signed almost half of Ecuador over to Peru. But last weekend the border tensions hit a 14-year peak, with fighting that claimed the lives of nine soldiers.
There have been no more reports of fighting since Sunday. Today, the two sides moved toward a cease-fire and mediation by diplomats from Argentina, Brazil, Chile and the United States, the four guarantors of the treaty. Talks began today in Rio de Janeiro and are to continue on Wednesday.
"The guarantors should wring the Ecuadoreans' necks," continued Mr. Loayza, a farmer who has spent all of his 41 years in this rustic universe of burros and roosters. "They wouldn't stand eight hours of pressure. We get along marvelously with Brazil, with Bolivia, with Colombia, even with Chile. Why can't the Ecuadoreans leave us alone?"
Why would Ecuador, a country the size of Colorado, regularly pick a fight with Peru, a country the size of Texas and California combined?
The answer lies partly in Ecuador's sense of victimhood. Over the last 150 years it has seen its territory whittled to the point where it is now the smallest country in the Andes, a buffer country between the region's two powers -- Colombia and Peru. With fights over arable land an increasing problem, Ecuador today is South America's most densely populated nation.
In schools, Ecuadoreans study maps that ignore the 1942 treaty and show large chunks of present-day Peru to be part of Ecuador.
"Any politician who wants to go anywhere in Ecuador says Tumbes, Jaen, Maynas are Ecuadorean," Mr. Loayza continued, reciting a mantra of Peruvian place names heard regularly on Ecuadorean television.
On Friday, students marched outside the Presidential Palace in Quito, protesting the economic policy of Ecuador's President, Sixto Duran Ballen. On Monday, after the weekend fighting, students marched again outside the palace -- this time to cheer the President.
On the Peruvian side, militarism is never far from the surface. Every main square in Peru seems to be called the Plaza de Armas. Every airport seems to carry the name of an aviator said to be martyred in the 1941 war.
Papayal's Plaza de Armas is bounded on one side by a Roman Catholic church and on the opposite side by the Jose Lishner army garrison.
"Sergeant Lishner fell in combat in 1941," a noncommissioned officer explained today. Noting that the front lines are separated by only a 100-yard-wide border ravine, the soldier added, "We don't even need binoculars to see the Ecuadoreans."
Eleven months of the year, the banana growers here cross to Chacras, the sister village in Ecuador, where prices are cheaper. On Saturday afternoons there are soccer games, and in the evenings dances. Binational couples are common.
"They look like us," said one peasant, Jose Luis Oyola. They talk like us. They only swear a little differently."
Then January rolls around, local residents say, relations become tense and spouses go back to their original sides of the border to stay with relatives.
With these humid lowlands emerging as Peru's main banana growing area, many growers and workers complained today about the economic cost of their annual forced vacation. Citing "national security," the local military commander bans farmers from entering the fertile border lands, which produce a sweet banana known locally as the silk plantain.
"We take one million bananas a day from here," a truck driver complained, nervously flicking his Volvo keys in his hand. "We bring bananas to Lima, Tacna and Arequipa."
With his high-walled banana truck beached until the end of the hostilities, the driver said he might plan his annual vacation around next January's anniversary of the border treaty.

HEADLINE: To Fight Mob, Giuliani Proposes Takeover of Fulton Fish Market

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Acknowledging that Federal intervention had failed to eradicate Mafia influence and business abuses at the Fulton Fish Market, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is proposing new laws to permit New York City to take control of the market.
Under the proposals, the city for the first time would investigate, license and regulate all businesses and employees at the market, in lower Manhattan. And in an attempt to sever suspected Mafia ties to merchants and companies, the city would also have the power to conduct background investigations of companies and their employees and bar those involved in wrongdoing. 
 According to Federal investigators, the city has virtually abdicated responsibility for administering the market during the last 50 years. It relied primarily on Federal efforts to regulate the market and crack down on organized crime.
But despite these periodic crackdowns, the market has remained a rough, insular arena, workers and merchants say, in which organized-crime figures thrive on extortion, secret deals, illegal gambling and loan-sharking.
Although most of the market is on city property along the East River near Fulton Street, the business has been run for decades by two associations representing wholesale dealers and by a group of companies that unload and deliver the 125 million pounds of fresh fish and seafood sold there every year.
Details of the legislative proposal are expected to be announced today by Mayor Giuliani and Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council. Randy M. Mastro, the Mayor's chief of staff, said one of the city's first steps would be to renegotiate the leases of wholesale dealers, whose rents on city property have been unchanged for at least 13 years.
Previous mayoral administrations have been reluctant to seek rent increases for the city because of the possibility that they might be signing long-term contracts with mob-tainted companies.
Mr. Mastro said he hoped the stricter regulations would encourage more companies to ship seafood to the city, and result in lower prices for consumers.
"The city never had an active role in the past in running the market," Mr. Mastro said. "This is the first comprehensive plan to grapple with the crime problem and to improve the business climate in an orderly fashion."
Aides to Mr. Vallone said yesterday that he would probably support the proposals. Mr. Vallone's support on the Democratic-controlled council is considered vital. "Hopefully, this effort will go a long way toward cleaning things up," Mr. Vallone said in a statement.
A vital economic asset to the city, the market generates sales of $800 million to $1 billion annually, and provides more than 800 jobs. Most of the seafood sold at retail stores and served in restaurants in the region is distributed through the market.
Although it is the largest such market in the country, City Council hearings in 1992 found that because of bribes, fraud and threats of violence, the city was losing business to other East Coast markets, especially in Philadelphia and Boston.
The city now receives about $268,000 a year in rent from about 60 wholesalers, but a study for a Federal investigator in 1992 found that the fair market value of the leases was about $3 million. Mr. Mastro said the city's Economic Development Corporation would take over the role of landlord in March and would seek higher rents.
Mark Rudes, president of the Fulton Fish Mongers Association, one of two trade groups that represent the largest dealers, said the current rents were appropriate because the city had not made structural improvements for more than 20 years. Vincent Tatick, head of the other trade group, the New York Wholesale Fish Dealers Association, did not return telephone calls yesterday.
A major goal, Mr. Mastro said, was to eliminate wholesale dealers called "phantoms," who illegally sublease space and sometimes disappear after running up expensive bills with out-of-town companies that have supplied them with seafood.
Last year, the Business Services Department said it had a list of about 60 known tenants in the market, but that as many as 170 wholesale companies were actually doing business there.
Mr. Mastro said the background investigations of companies and employees would be made by the city Department of Investigation. The inquiries, he said, would include examining financial records of companies to determine their true owners, if there are improper payoffs and if there are attempts to evade taxes.
Mr. Mastro also said the campaign would overhaul methods of loading and unloading seafood. Truckers at the market now have no right to determine how their supplies are unloaded. A group of six companies, known as unloaders, have historically arranged among themselves how the supplies are moved.
Because seafood is perishable, truckers and dealers say that the unloaders have an economic stranglehold over them by demanding bribes for fast service.
Similarly, retail merchants or restaurateurs who shop for supplies are assigned parking spots by a group of 11 unlicensed companies, known as loaders. The loaders charge a parking fee and by tradition claim the exclusive right to transport the supplies to the purchasers' cars or vans.
All of the assigned parking spots are on city property, and the loading companies pay about $40,000 a year to the city. But a Federal analysis in 1992 estimated that the city should be getting about $310,000 a year for the parking rights alone.
Gerald J. McMahon, a lawyer for most of the unloading and loading companies, yesterday denied any wrongdoing by these groups. Commenting on the city's licensing plans, he said, "It sounds like the 49th announcement in which politicians are going to come in and clean up the market when it does not need to be cleaned up."
Since the late 1930's, Federal and state investigations have asserted that the Genovese crime family controlled the market through threats of violence and labor slowdowns. Federal authorities said the convictions of controllers of the market had little affect on improving conditions because they were simply replaced by other Genovese members.
In 1986, when Mr. Guiliani was the United States Attorney for the Southern District, he embarked on a new approach to improve conditions at the market. Saying that the city had largely abandoned its oversight responsibilities, Mr. Giuliani obtained the court appointment of Frank H. Wohl as a Federal administrator to monitor the market and to recommend changes.
But the United States Justice Department in 1992 began phasing out Mr. Wohl's role on the ground that supervising the market was a city problem, not a long-range concern for the Federal Government.

HEADLINE: Henry Kraus, Labor Historian And Writer on European Art, 89

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Henry Kraus, the first editor of the United Automobile Workers' national newspaper, a labor historian, an authority on European art and a recipient of a MacArthur Foundation Fellowship, died on Friday in Paris, where he had lived since 1956. He was 89.
The cause was cancer, said his wife, Dorothy. 
 Mr. Kraus's seventh and most recent book, "Heroes of Unwritten Story," a personal history of the U.A.W. from 1934 to 1939, was published last year by the University of Illinois Press.
Acclaimed as a chronicler of the American labor movement, Mr. Kraus was also celebrated for his studies of medieval art, which led to such books, sometimes written with his wife, as "The Living Theater of Medieval Art," "Hidden World of Misericords," "Gothic Stalls of Spain" and "Gold Was the Mortar: The Economics of Cathedral Building."
In 1984, Mr. Kraus received a five-year MacArthur Foundation Fellowship, often described as a genius grant, which helped him return to Michigan to conduct research for "Heroes of Unwritten Story" at the labor archives at Wayne State University in Detroit.
Born in Knoxville, Tenn., as a son of immigrants who were active trade unionists, he grew up in Cleveland in a socialist atmosphere. He attended the University of Chicago and Western Reserve University in Cleveland, where he received a master's degree in 1928.
For a time he taught high school mathematics, but in 1930 he began his career in labor journalism, offering his services to publicize the fledging union of auto workers preparing to strike the White Auto Company. His efforts led to the founding of the United Auto Worker, a newspaper circulated among locals in several states, and, later, to his appointment as editor of the U.A.W.'s official publication, the United Automobile Worker.
His involvement with the union led to his study of the Flint, Mich., sit-down strike of 1936-37, "The Many and the Few," which was first published in 1947.
In the mid-1950's, the Krauses moved to Paris, where Mr. Kraus worked as a European correspondent for World Wide Medical News Service. There they renewed their studies of medieval art, particularly of the misericords, carvings on the backs of pews and seats that depicted the daily lives of the craftsmen who created so much of the religious art of Europe's cathedrals and churches.
He is survived by his wife.

HEADLINE: Governors Agree Children Must Be Protected No Matter What Shape Welfare Takes

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The National Governors' Association said today that the states ought to have far more power to design their own welfare programs, but the governors could not agree on how much power the Federal Government should retain.
In any event, they said, "Children must be protected." 
 At the end of a four-day meeting here, the governors hailed Federal efforts to give them more control over millions of dollars worth of welfare programs. But Republican governors could not obtain the three-fourths majority needed to put the organization on record in support of their proposal to give states a lump sum of money, or block grant, to take care of poor people.
The main Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, created 60 years ago, is an entitlement program. Anyone who meets the eligibility criteria set by Federal and state laws is entitled to monthly cash payments, regardless of the number of people who apply or the total cost. In hard times, when more people are unemployed, the amount of Federal aid automatically increases.
The governors' association adopted a new policy statement saying: "Governors have not yet reached consensus on whether cash and other entitlement assistance should remain available as Federal entitlements to needy families or whether it should be converted to a state entitlement block grant. Governors do agree, however, that in either case states should have the flexibility to enact welfare reforms without having to request Federal waivers."
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, the Democrat who is chairman of the governors' association, said, "This policy will allow us to participate in the Congressional debate on welfare reform, but doesn't commit us to a specific course of action."
The association's statement says that "children must be protected throughout this process" if Congress decides to convert the existing welfare program to a block grant.
The governors arrived at their new policy through difficult negotiations after it seemed that partisan disputes might shatter the organization's tradition of bipartisan cooperation. The governors appear to be less ideological and more pragmatic than many members of Congress, and they can usually arrive at consensus without great difficulty. Mr. Dean said the governors' experience this week "foreshadows the difficult debate that Congress will have over welfare reform."
In their statement, the governors said states should not be required to put up any of their own money if Congress decided to establish a Federal block grant. Under the current program of Aid to Families with Dependent Children, states must match Federal contributions, and affluent states must put up more of their own money for each Federal dollar.
The 50 states contribute a total of more than $10 billion a year. Under the governors' proposal, there would be no requirement for states to continue such spending, but many governors said they would do so voluntarily.
In back-to-back speeches, President Clinton and the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, outlined their ideas on welfare and domestic policy generally. Mr. Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, told the governors: "I want to liberate every one of you to sit down with the people of your state, to ask yourself what can we do to save the children today? Not five years from now, not 10 years from now, not after 22 studies -- today."
Gov. Thomas R. Carper of Delaware, a Democrat, said, "We don't agree among ourselves as to whether the block grant approach or the individual entitlement is best."
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, a Republican, said the bipartisan compromise was "not everything I would like." Mr. Thompson and two other Republican Governors, John Engler of Michigan and William F. Weld of Massachusetts, have proposed consolidating 298 programs worth $119 billion a year into eight block grants. The programs include welfare, food stamps and child nutrition programs.
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has denounced the Republican proposal for block grants, saying it "gives each state a fixed pool of money and leaves the states with virtually complete autonomy to decide who gets support and when."
In a recent memorandum to President Clinton, Dr. Shalala said, "Block grants fail to protect vulnerable children, will not result in real welfare reform and will not protect the states from economic changes."
But the governors said Congress could address such concerns. "An additional amount should be set aside each year for automatic and timely distribution to states that experience higher-than-average unemployment, a major disaster or other indicators of distress," their statement said.
The governors endorsed the principle that welfare should be a transition to work and that there should be time limits on the payment of benefits. But they said states should be free to decide the details for themselves.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN;
Mexico's Ripple Effects: Subtle Risks for Americans

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:
Banks, Wall Street speculators and import-export companies are not the only groups with a stake in the outcome of Mexico's financial crisis. Many ordinary Americans have money on the line and may not realize it. Here are some ways Mexican developments may touch family pocketbooks.
 
Mutual Funds -- Vulnerable funds are not limited to those that specialize in Latin American or emerging-market securities. Many funds whose names and goals give no hint of Latin American or emerging-market exposure nonetheless have made major bets in Mexico and other Latin economies. A few asset-allocation, cash-management and balanced funds had as much as 40 percent of their assets in Latin American stocks and bonds last fall before the peso crisis began.
 
401(k) Plans -- A large part of 401(k) plan assets are invested in mutual funds, so their vulnerability is similar to that of direct mutual fund investments. Even when a plan includes no Latin specialty fund as an option, the broader funds that the plan does include may have substantial Mexican holdings.
 
Pension funds -- Pension funds tend to be more risk-averse and less eager for short-term returns than mutual funds. They generally have only very small parts of their portfolios -- usually less than 10 percent -- invested anywhere abroad; emerging markets like Mexico get only a tiny share.
 
Insurance companies -- The American insurance industry invests less than 10 percent of its assets overseas, and its Mexican exposure is insiginficant. A few smaller companies may have Mexican holdings enough to affect their financial health, and thus their ability to pay claims and dividends; poor investment decisions have sometimes undone individual companies in the past.
 
American employers -- Many major American companies have significant business interests in Mexico, among them consumer products makers like Procter & Gamble, food companies like Pillsbury and all three Detroit automakers. Many more export products to Mexico; the falling peso makes their products much more expensive there. To the extent that profits are affected by the turmoil, profits could filter through to employees directly in layoffs and depressed wages and layoffs, and indirectly through employees' investments in company stock.
 
Mexican employers -- Some, among them Vitro S.A., the giant glassmaker, have major operations and payrolls in the United States. As long as the operations remain profitable in dollar terms, they should not be threatened. But if the Mexican parent has difficulty raising money, expansion plans and capital investment for the United States operations may dry up. PATRICK J. LYONS

HEADLINE: Rescuing the Rescue Plan

 BODY:
Fearing imminent Mexican bankruptcy and Congressional inaction, President Clinton made the right call yesterday to rescue the Mexican economy himself. He ditched a $40 billion plan, which Congress was not going to approve anytime soon, in favor of a stripped-down program to provide Mexico $20 billion in loans and loan guarantees that require no Congressional action. The Administration also announced that the International Monetary Fund would lend Mexico up to $17.8 billion to pay back creditors and $10 billion from central banks to help stabilize the peso.
The President's action was justified by a looming financial emergency: Mexico could have defaulted within days, cutting it off from foreign investment and plunging its economy into recession. Millions of Mexicans and tens of thousands of U.S. workers in export industries would have been hurt. And financial turbulence could have spread through Latin America. 
 Mexico's crisis was driven by foreign investors who wanted their money back rather than risk their investments to further depreciation of the peso, let alone default. Mr. Clinton's original idea was to provide Mexico with $40 billion in loan guarantees -- more than enough to reassure investors that their loans were safe. The centerpiece of the plan was a pledge by Mexico to put future oil revenues in escrow so that the U.S. would never need to use its own money to pay back Mexican creditors. Indeed, U.S. taxpayers would come out ahead, since Mexico would pay fees for the use of the guarantees. Mexico would also agree to stringent restrictions on its monetary and fiscal policy that would assure investors of the economy's long-term health.
The new plan is built along the same smart lines -- though investors might be disquieted that some of the loans would be for a shorter term than Mr. Clinton originally proposed. The U.S. money, in the event it were needed, would be drawn from a Treasury fund that is used, at the Administration's discretion, to stabilize the value of the dollar; the possible use would pose no threat because the Government has other resources for currency intervention. Mexico is still expected to put up oil revenues as collateral and rule out fiscal and monetary excess.
The new plan leaves some important questions unanswered. Will the I.M.F. place impossible hurdles between its money and Mexico? Will the conditions on Mexican monetary policy be tight enough to reassure skittish investors? Is the U.S. politically prepared to keep Mexico's oil revenues in the unlikely event that Mexico defaults?
Mr. Clinton's first plan hit opposition in Congress because it was unfairly depicted by opponents as a bailout for Wall Street financiers. Mr. Clinton failed to make a persuasive case that many of the creditors who would benefit from stabilization of the peso would be American workers with pension funds and mutual funds invested in Mexico. That is still the case.
Decisive Presidential action always risks subordinating the appropriate Congressional role in the commitment of Federal resources, and this case should not be a model for Mr. Clinton. But there was no time for delay, and he did not move until he got the approval of both Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders.
The Administration can be faulted for lying back when Mexico was running through its reserves last year. It can be faulted for ineptly presenting a smart first rescue plan to the American public. But it deserves credit for coming to Mexico's rescue when there was no time left to navigate a bill through Congress.

HEADLINE: Everybody's Nest Egg

SERIES: SOCIAL SECURITY'S FUTURE -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By James Gollin; James Gollin has written about Social Security for 15 years.

DATELINE: POUND RIDGE, N.Y.

 BODY:
To its supporters, Social Security is a sacred cow. To its critics, it's designed to mulct the young for the benefit of the old. The debate has been less than illuminating.
Proponents of the present system -- and that includes pretty much everyone in Congress and the Administration -- argue feverishly that tampering with Social Security benefits would be a gross injustice to the elderly. 
 The system has no overt opponents. Even Newt Gingrich has repeatedly declared Social Security off limits, on the sensible ground that Americans don't trust any politician enough -- yet -- even to listen to any proposal to tinker with it. The operative word, of course, is "yet."
Mr. Gingrich & Company evidently believe that if they are still in power in six years, they will have have won the electorate's confidence so entirely that they can privatize Social Security, devolve it to the states or otherwise "strengthen" it.
Never mind the cries of the one in five Americans now drawing benefits. The ecstatic applause of millions of baby boomers and their successor generations will be far louder. They loathe Social Security taxes. They ask: Why should we pay? We'll never see a dime's worth of benefits.
Besides, every American knows or should know that "privatize," "devolve" and "strengthen" are transparent euphemisms for "dump."
Serious debate should start with the reality that Social Security provides advantages to both young and old. First, it is a bloodless way to help ease older people out of the work force and make room for younger workers. With the good-paying jobs that politicians prattle about in short supply and likely to continue to be so, this is no small virtue.
Nor does one have to be a master of multiplier economics to recognize that $292 billion a year in Social Security benefits generates a huge amount of economic activity, to the gain of Americans of all ages. Or to understand that it's less of a drag on one's household economy, and psyche, to pay taxes over many years for the support of old people -- read "mom and dad" -- than to have to start doing it out of pocket when mom and dad are old.
Serious debate should continue with the awareness that today's retirement program cannot and must not be immunized against change. In 1937, when Social Security was introduced, only workers in industry and commerce were covered; today, virtually everybody is. It has a history of change, marked by aggressive expansion of coverage in the 1950's, 60's and early 70's.
Both political parties have long enthusiastically supported the growth of Social Security. After Barry Goldwater's disastrous "make it voluntary" remark blighted his candidacy in 1964, Republicans outdid Democrats in the expansion race.
By 1980, the glory days were over. How to pay for it all was beginning to worry even devotees. That year, President Jimmy Carter's advisory commission on pension policy delicately suggested that the Government raise the normal retirement age to 70 from 65, sharply cut the income benefit for early retirement and try to think of ways to create or keep jobs for people in their 60's despite a growing tendency to push them out of the work force.
Nobody advocated privatization or devolution. The Goldwater debacle taught conservatives their lesson: throughout the 80's, the Reaganites left Social Security alone.
The Gingrich crowd will not follow suit. They will base their argument for getting Social Security off the backs of the people on the conjecture that the "dependency ratio" -- the proportion of active to retired workers -- will go from about 3 to 1 now to 2 to 1 by the year 2030. They argue that because Social Security is a pay-as-you-go program, either this will impose a monstrous tax burden on the young (which they will vote not to pay) or the system will run out of money.
But is this shift in ratio -- assuming it happens -- really so significant? Productivity matters more: the total income that workers generate in relation to the costs of the benefits is more important than the mere number of workers in relation to the number of retirees. If people produce more and earn more, as seems likely -- and the politicians don't bid up the benefits -- maybe the cost burden won't be intolerable after all. May we won't have to privatize support of the elderly, even if that makes life insurance companies unhappy.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Shell Game

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is galloping toward (she hopes) the Republican Vice-Presidential nomination. It's an excellent adventure that could end with the bold, aggressive and politically astute Mrs. Whitman becoming the first woman President of the United States. There is, however, a flip side to Mrs. Whitman's quest. To the chagrin of many people in New Jersey, it is already resulting in the trampling of that state's long-term economic interests.
In her nationally televised response to President Clinton's State of the Union address, Mrs. Whitman said, "Just yesterday, I announced a third wave of income tax cuts -- another 15 percent -- taking us to a 30 percent reduction." 
 Just yesterday. Just like that. It's a remarkable formula Mrs. Whitman has developed. When she slipped behind in the polls in the final weeks of her gubernatorial race against Jim Florio, Mrs. Whitman turned things around by dramatically announcing she would cut the state income tax by 30 percent over three years. The next thing she knew she was Governor.
Then, amid all the talk about what an asset she'd be on a G.O.P. Presidential ticket, Mrs. Whitman was asked to deliver the Republican response to the State of the Union address. Suddenly the 30 percent tax cut over three years was changed to 30 percent over two years. Just like that. "Just yesterday . . ."
While this cut-at-will policy is great for Mrs. Whitman's ego and ambition, it has some dire consequences for New Jersey. The income tax is not a problem in that state; the property tax is. And while Mrs. Whitman is dismantling the income tax in the service of her political career, property taxes throughout the state are soaring.
"New Jersey is more dependent on the property tax than any other state in the Union," said Joseph Roberts, a Democratic assemblyman. "Last year the average income tax saving was $40, but the average property tax increase was $170. It's the property taxes that are driving people out of their homes, and affecting our senior citizens, and hurting the middle class."
Mrs. Whitman gets to say on national television that she cut taxes, and she is right. What she doesn't mention are the consequences of her tax cuts.
"The income tax reductions are returning the entire burden of education in the suburban districts right back to the shoulders of the property owners," said Rhua Ernst, business administrator for the Wayne Township school district. "In terms of property owners, there are no tax cuts. There are tax increases."
Similar complaints can be heard throughout the state. James Murphy, president of the New Jersey Association of School Administrators, said: "We think the amount of money that's being given in [income] tax cuts is more than offset by the increase in local property taxes due to a loss of state aid to many local districts. All polls will tell you that the thing that hurts is the property tax."
Meanwhile, there's the matter of the public employee pension funds. When Mrs. Whitman applied her ax to the income tax, she had to find alternate funds to balance the state budget. With a sly gleam reminiscent of Willie Sutton's whenever he saw a bank, Mrs. Whitman's gaze rested on the billions of dollars in the pension funds. It didn't take long to decide. They would be raided.
This was done by drastically reducing the state's annual contributions to the funds. In effect, billions of dollars' worth of pension obligations are being put off to a much later date. Some future governor will have to raise taxes (or cut pension benefits) to satisfy these obligations, not Mrs. Whitman.
New Jersey had been following a conservative, extremely prudent approach to fulfilling its pension obligations. It was analogous to new parents putting away a certain amount of money each year to cover the eventual cost of their children's education. Mrs. Whitman has turned that approach on its head. She needs cash now, and if mortgaging the state's future is the way to obtain it, so be it. She needs to cover her tax cuts. She wants to be Vice President. When the bills ultimately come due, as they will, she will be gone.
She hopes.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Yeltsin's Economic Chechnya

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
During a seminar on Russia at the Davos Economic Forum, Russia's Minister of Economy, Yevgeny Yasin, was extolling Boris Yeltsin's economic policies. As he spoke in Russian, the audience listened raptly to the translation through headsets, but after a few minutes they began to suspect that something was wrong. They were right. Somehow the translation from a Japan seminar next door got switched with Mr. Yasin's translation, and the audience was hearing the Russian minister extol the virtues of the Japanese auto industry.
Now, you could confuse Boris Yeltsin's economics with a lot of things, but the Japanese economy isn't one of them. Unfortunately, real economic reform isn't one of them either. And that's the problem. 
 Mr. Yeltsin has not only lost his way in Chechnya, he has lost his way in economics as well. And for the same reasons: too much vodka on his desk, too few reformers at his side and too many idiot apparatchiks around him all the time. While TV has focused on the dramatic battering of Grozny, it has missed the mundane but even more devastating battering that Mr. Yeltsin's policies have been delivering to Russia's ruble, budget and foreign investors.
It is too late to save Chechnya, but it may not be too late to save Russian economic reform. To do so, though, requires giving Mr. Yeltsin shock therapy. For months now Boris has been blackmailing us with his weakness, saying in effect: "I am fragile, don't push me too hard. If I fall, you will have to deal with really crazy people." I'm not for toppling Mr. Yeltsin. But by being so worried about what comes after him, the Clinton team has lost sight of what has happened to Mr. Yeltsin himself -- and made Washington a hostage of his weakness. His weakness is his strength only if we let it be, and it's time we stopped letting it be.
What's the problem? Inflation, which was 4 percent a month in August, is now roaring along at 16 percent a month, because the Russian Central Bank has lost control of the money supply. The 1995 Yeltsin budget is as phony as a rubber ruble, particularly its assumptions on inflation and the deficit. Mr. Yeltsin rattled investors by appointing and then sacking a complete incompetent to run the key privatization ministry. Foreign portfolio investment in Russia fell from $500 million in July to $20 million in December.
There were basically two views on Mr. Yeltsin among the global investors and experts gathered at the Davos forum -- those who think he is irredeemably lost and those who think he is just lost.
Those who think he is irredeemably lost included people like the financier George Soros, who argued that Mr. Yeltsin had thrown in his lot with the security apparatus and military-industrial complex against the new entrepreneurial class -- a confrontation that makes for bad economics and dangerous politics. "Yeltsin has been captured by a bunch of people who want to restart a dictatorship," said Mr. Soros, whose foundation has financed Russian reform programs. The West, he adds, should be "very leery" about putting any more money there now. Boris Fyordorov, Mr. Yeltsin's former Finance Minister, was even more blunt: "If the West is ready to help this guy now, then it doesn't understand what is happening in Russia."
Those who thought Mr. Yeltsin was badly lost but maybe redeemable included many European and Russian businessmen, who reported that the factories they have opened in Russia are actually doing quite well -- thanks to past Yeltsin reforms -- but are now in need of a more stable economic environment. They argue that because Mr. Yeltsin is such a forceful personality, if he could be redeemed he could provide far stronger economic leadership than the whiny liberals or corrupt ministers who now oppose him.
I agree. Mr. Yeltsin may be too far gone, but it's worth one last check of his pulse. We should do that by telling him we will only help save him if he first saves himself. The I.M.F. is now negotiating a $12 billion loan package with Mr. Yeltsin. Washington should bluntly tell Boris that it will block that I.M.F. loan until his budget is demonstrably under control, real reformers are restored to his office and Central Bank, corrupt ministers banished and the Chechnya conflict ended. That's the only way out for him and Russia, so why mute our voices any longer?
If we're not going to give the guy any money, the least we can do is give him the truth.
