HEADLINE: We Must Be Ready When the War Bell Rings;
Pentagon Overkill

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Pentagon's Trap Doors" (editorial, Jan. 24) and "Grasping the Obvious" (editorial, Jan. 11) make a strong case against the powerful political forces that are attempting to maintain and even increase our military expenditures in a post-cold war world. The case can be made even stronger by looking at the competition. 
 The Pentagon has argued that it needs sufficient strength to fight and win two wars simultaneously. Which countries are considered potential threats to United States security?
The leading candidates and their estimated annual military expenditures (in 1993) are Russia, $29 bil lion; China, $22 billion; Iraq, $9 billion; North Korea, $2 billion; and Iran, Syria and Cuba, $1.2 billion each.
The largest of these countries, Russia, is finding it difficult indeed to subdue Chechnya, a tiny rebellious republic within its borders.
It is also worth noting that the total military spending of these eight countries is $66 billion, less than one-fourth the $277 billion spent on defense by the United States in 1993.
Let's look now at our real competition, namely the world's top 10 military spenders.
The United States is No. 1 with $277 billion in 1993. Far behind in second place is Japan with a measly $40 billion, one-seventh of the United States level. France, Britain and Germany follow with $36 billion, $35 billion and $31 billion, respectively.
Russia and China are next and are followed by Italy, Saudi Arabia and South Korea with, respectively, expenditures of $17 billion, $16 billion and $12 billion.
So, the other nine nations in the top 10 in 1993 spent only $238 billion, or $39 billion less than the United States.
This should leave no question in anyone's mind, Republican or Democrat, that the United States is the superpower many times over. Moreover, with the exception of Russia and China, all military spending by top-10 countries was by the United States and its allies for a total $454 billion. This outstrips sevenfold our potential enemies with $66 billion.
It is hard to believe that President Clinton and Congress are planning to increase military spending. We are so powerful that no set of countries threatens our security in the least over the foreseeable future. Our national welfare would benefit if a good share of resources now going to defense were used to meet civilian needs and to reduce our budget deficit.
 
FRANKLYN D. HOLZMAN
Lexington, Mass., Jan. 25, 1995
The writer, a retired economics professor at Tufts, is a fellow at Harvard's Russian Research Center.

HEADLINE: A Hollywood Role for a Capitol Star?

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich likes to talk about renewing civilization, but did he mean Hollywood, too?
Some in Hollywood think so. The movie moguls want to bring him out. Not to star in a picture, at least not yet. But to star at a gala dinner to give a lift to conservatives in Tinsel Town. 
 "Newt is a huge celebrity," said David Horowitz, an author and former lefty who turned right in the early 1980's and now promotes conservative views in Hollywood through his nonprofit Center for the Study of Popular Culture.
Mr. Horowitz dropped in on the Speaker's press secretary the other day. Mr. Horowitz met Mr. Gingrich a few years ago, after Mr. Horowitz wrote a book called "Destructive Generation," a critical look at the 1960's. Mr. Gingrich read the book and invited him and his co-author, Peter Collier, to Washington for lunch. "In June, I want to bring Newt out to Hollywood," Mr. Horowitz told the press secretary, Tony Blankley, last Friday.
Mr. Horowitz said he wants Mr. Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, to be the star attraction at a dinner with Arnold Schwarzenegger, Kevin Costner, Delta Burke, Cheryl Ladd, Gerald McRainey, other actors and scores of "wheeler-dealers" whom Mr. Horowitz said he could not identify but nonetheless are eager to celebrate the Republican revolution on Capitol Hill.
"Sounds fabulous," said Mr. Blankley. "Let's talk."
Mr. Blankley had no trouble adopting the mogul lingo, having grown up in Hollywood and worked as a child actor in such movies as "The Harder They Fall" with Humphrey Bogart.
"Hollywood is moving like crazy," Mr. Horowitz went on. "The liberals are all fed up with Clinton. Clinton is over. It's happening. We'll do Power Rangers. We'll have Newt. It's a way of saying, 'This is the new establishment, this is the new world.' "
As it happened, Mr. Schwarzenegger -- in town to promote the Inner City Olympics for poor youths -- dropped in on the Speaker today. He said he chatted with Mr. Gingrich, whom he called "our leader," about the program.
During a picture-taking session before the two went behind closed doors, Mr. Schwarzenegger was asked what fitness advice he might have for the Speaker. He said he was glad Mr. Gingrich was swimming every day. The Speaker said that if he did not exercise he would soon be starring in a movie called "The Last Couch Potato."
"There were two radical movements in the 60's," Mr. Horowitz said in an interview after leaving Mr. Blankley's office. "One of them nobody ever writes about, and that's the one Gingrich came out of. Now, all those people are in charge of the House."
Mr. Horowitz sees the new Speaker as the "breakthrough" personality who can "get the attention of nonpolitical people."
"It's exactly the reverse of when Jane Fonda committed treason and came back and won an Academy Award," he said, referring to her visit to Hanoi during the Vietnam War. "That was a very significant moment in Hollywood. It made it acceptable to be extreme left. That ushered in the era of the Oliver Stones."
"We want equal time," he continued. The Republican takeover of Congress and the elevation of Mr. Gingrich to the Speakership, he said, "is the breakthrough for a persecuted group of people who've been driven underground."
Mr. Horowitz was accompanied by Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a California Republican and one of two members of the House who are surfers, and later had lunch with Representative Christopher Cox, another California Republican.
Hollywood's interest in the Speaker comes at a time when the Speaker is demonstrating a strong interest in California, as does anyone with an eye on electoral politics. Mr. Gingrich has appointed a special California task force made up of Republican members of Congress from California.
"Politically, culturally and economically, California is pivotal to influencing the direction of the country as a whole," said Mr. Rohrabacher. "Newt wants to make sure he's not behind the curve. He's setting up his structure so he has input."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
As expected, the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point. The increase, the Fed's seventh in 12 months, prompted large banks to follow suit immediately, causing borrowing costs to rise for millions of Americans. [Page A1.]
 
Orange County bondholders are worried as a shortfall looms for bond payments. Warnings by officials of the California county that they will not raise taxes to solve the problem undermine a basic tenet of municipal bonds: borrowers are obligated to repay their debts, even if it means cutting services and raising taxes. [D1.] 

A bill to end price controls for cable television after one year and let the regional Bells enter the long-distance market after three years was proposed by Senate Republicans. [D1.]
 
The Government's main economic forecasting gauge rose slightly in December. Construction spending gained 1.1 percent. [D4.]
 
Florida is worried that the baseball strike will batter its economy. Spring training brings $315 million to the economy a year. [A14.]
 
Companies
 
William J. Agee is leaving Morrison Knudsen, without having attained the turnaround he had sought since 1988. His departure comes as Morrison has suffered setbacks in both in its traditional construction business and in railroad equipment. [D1.]
 
Where is the auto market headed? Changes by auto makers in the way they tally sales have made it almost impossible to tell. The confusion could not come at a worse time: investors are nervous because of ambiguous signs of a slowdown and are desperate for a sense of what is happening in auto showrooms. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Umbrella Credit Union Seized by Regulators

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The Capital Corporate Federal Credit Union, the latest victim of a bad bet in derivatives, has been seized by Federal credit union regulators.
The move by the National Credit Union Administration late Monday to take over the day-to-day operations of Cap Corp, as it is known, came after Cap Corp, based in Latham, Md., incurred $100 million in losses on its huge portfolio of collateralized mortgage obligations. Cap Corp is one of the nation's largest umbrella credit organizations, covering more than one million individual members. The takeover is the first since the N.C.U.A. was established in 1970. 
 These securities, known as C.M.O.'s, are considered derivatives because they are created out of pools of home mortgages.
Some analysts said they expected that the decision to place Cap Corp into conservatorship would be merely the first step to eventual liquidation.
But regulatory officials and other credit union representatives said that since capital ratios at the nation's 12,500 credit unions were at record highs, there was little likelihood that individual members would lose money as a result of Cap Corp's problems.
In a statement issued yesterday, regulatory officials asserted that all 483 member credit unions "will have full access to their funds."
In the statement, Norman E. D'Amours, chairman of the National Credit Union Administration, said: "The daily financial lives of credit union members will not be noticeably affected by our actions. For credit union members, it will be business as usual."
Like Orange County, Calif., over the last three years Cap Corp had employed an increasingly high-risk investment strategy based on leverage and C.M.O.'s.
As long as interest rates fell, the strategy paid off. But when the Federal Reserve Board started to push interest rates higher in February 1994, the value of Cap Corp's portfolio began to fall. Cap Corp compounded the problem by borrowing against its securities to buy more C.M.O.'s.
The magnitude of Cap Corp's crisis was exposed nearly two months ago, when, unable to liquidate below-market investments, it could no longer meet liquidity needs of its member credit unions without violating the Federal borrowing regulations. Consequently, on Dec. 7 the Cap Corp board froze accounts for 60 days. The freeze is scheduled to expire on Monday.
Robert E. Loftus, a spokesman for the Federal agency, said deposits of the individual members of Cap Corp's 483 member credit unions were insured up to $100,000 by the National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund, a Government-backed agency.
The Federal agency said that capital ratios of the nation's credit unions averaged 9.8 percent. "They are almost embarrassingly strong," said Bill Hampel, chief economist at the Credit Union National Association. "They could afford a few knocks and still be in decent shape."
The negative effect of the $100 million loss will also be softened by $37 million in reserves on Cap Corp's books.
Cap Corp is one of 45 special credit unions, known as corporate credit unions, that were created to invest excess cash or supply funds quickly to their member institutions, depending on loan demand.
Traditionally, corporate credit unions have invested in Treasury and other low-risk, highly liquid securities. But when interest rates began falling, some corporate credit unions ventured into derivatives, and Cap Corp was more aggressive than most: at the end of November, when its liquidity crisis struck, some $1.09 billion of its $1.9 billion investment portfolio was made up of C.M.O.'s. They had not defaulted, so theoretically Cap Corp could have held them until they matured at face value.
But loan demand at the credit unions that own Cap Corp rose during 1994, so they asked Cap Corp for their money. Rather than sell off investments at a loss, Cap Corp began borrowing. By the end of November, its borrowings totaled $867 million, close to the permissible ceiling. So, Federal officials, making it clear they would not permit further borrowing, recommended Cap Corp seek a merger partner. Its attempts were not successful.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Drop After Fed's Rate Move

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday, following the awaited move by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates by half of a percentage point.
The bond market for weeks had been expecting the central bank's seventh rate increase in the last year, traders said. But yesterday's selloff was not necessarily a sign of displeasure, but rather the act of investors who had bought securities on the bet that the Fed would raise rates, and now were selling to take profits. 
 And as so often happens, investors immediately began focusing on future events after the Fed's rate increase was announced yesterday afternoon and these new concerns helped drive prices lower. Tomorrow the Government will release the closely followed monthly employment numbers for January. If they are strong, many investors will begin worrying about another Fed rate increase. And next week the market will have added supply when the Treasury sells $40 billion of new securities during its quarterly auction.
By late in the day the 30-year bond bond was down 20/32 of a percentage point, to 97 5/32 , for a yield of 7.74 percent, up from 7.69 percent on Tuesday. For investors it meant the loss of $6.25 for each $1,000 invested.
Shorter-maturity bills and notes also came under pressure, with the rate for three-month and six-month maturities up five basis points, to 5.87 percent and 6.16 percent, respectively. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
The Fed raised the discount rate to 5.25 percent from 4.75 percent, and the Federal funds target rate to 6 percent from 5.50 percent. Even more critical to the market is concern that the latest move is not the last.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said that "at this point the Fed does not know if recent signs of slowing will continue, and if so, to what degree." He continued, "While it is clear that a slowdown in the economy should be expected after the torrid pace of the last three quarters of 1994, it is the timing and extent of moderation that will determine future Fed policy decisions."
The Fed, he added, was likely to be in a tightening mode until year-to-year economic growth is 3.5 percent or less and heading toward a desired 2.5 percent. This means another rate rise, Mr. Fine said, at or before the scheduled Fed policy-making meeting in May; he expects the Federal funds rate to rise to 6.50 percent.
Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said the move by the Fed yesterday was good for the economy because it was needed to slow growth. "But for the U.S. credit market," he said, "I think it may have needed a 75-basis-point adjustment to assure it that the Fed was quite serious about eradicating both current and future inflationary trends."
Bond prices slid in early trading ahead of the Fed's announcement on some early economic reports. There was some slippage on a strong construction spending report showing a rise of 8.7 percent in 1994, the biggest increase in 10 years, as borrowing costs failed to slow demand. December construction spending was up 1.1 percent.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index came in at a higher-than-expected 57.9 for January, compared with a revised 57.5 for December, while the Commerce Department's index of leading indicators rose a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in December after a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in November.
The volume of trading remained moderate until the afternoon, as key market investors and dealers awaited the policy statement by the central bank. Not long after, the Treasury announced the size of its quarterly refunding for next week. The auctions begin with the sale of $17 billion in new 3-year notes on Tuesday, $12 billion in 10-year notes on Wednesday and $11 billion in 30-year bonds on Thursday.
In when-issued trading ahead of these auctions, the 3-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.55 percent, the 10-year notes at a price to yield 7.66 percent and the 30-year bond at a price to yield 7.70 percent.

HEADLINE: Confusion Reigns in Auto Sales

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1

 BODY:
One might think it a pretty straightforward act, toting up car and light-truck sales.
But many of the world's auto makers tried to tally their January sales today, and the result was chaos that made it impossible to determine for sure if the market is headed up, down or sideways. 
 The auto makers could not even agree on how many days last month their dealers' showrooms were open. Subaru said there were 24 sales days. Mitsubishi said there were 26 sales days. Honda counted 25. And Ford said it would not report its sales until Friday.
The confusion could not come at a worse time. Investors are already nervous because of ambiguous signs that the auto market is softening. As vehicle sales data, once a venerable economic indicator, disintegrated, analysts were left groping for some sign of the market's condition, and grappling with something of an existential crisis.
"I don't know what to believe," said John Casesa, auto analyst with Wertheim, Schroder & Company in New York. "You're probably going to ask me how I'm going to analyze this stuff, and I have no idea."
Early today, the Ford Motor Company said it earned a record $1.56 billion in the fourth quarter. That meant the Big Three made more money in 1994 -- almost $14 billion -- than ever before. [Page D3.]
Also today, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates again, confident the economy is growing too fast for its taste. But all one could infer with certainty from January's vehicle sales is that auto makers badly need to polish their green eyeshades.
January sales figures became blurry because most auto makers changed the way they report sales. They switched from reporting on the third business day of the month to reporting on the first business day, today. The auto makers that switched say they did so because computerized systems allow them to report faster.
But those that did not make the switch say that sales reports from dealers can take several days to trickle in after the sales are made. That means the auto makers probably failed to count some sales from the last days of January.
Still, no one knows how bad the undercount is. Both the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation switched to the new system, and both said that sales fell during the month. But it was difficult to determine how much of the shortfall was caused by too few customers and how much by too few reporting days.
Ford, which did not switch, predicted today that when it does release its numbers, they will show sales increased in January. The Nissan Motor Company was the other major auto maker to hold out against the new system.
Meanwhile, the Toyota Motor Corporation said that its January sales rose strongly. But perhaps the company did even better than it thinks.
"There's too much noise in these numbers, and it would do more harm than good to try to draw any conclusions from them," said Harvey Heinbach, auto analyst for Merrill Lynch in New York. He said he preferred to ignore them, but "I realize the market's not going to let us."
The reason the stock market is so insistent is that investors are desperate for a clear sense of what is happening in auto showrooms. Auto makers have been increasing rebates and cutting production, possible signs of softening demand. There's no indicator of actual demand, however, like sales.
The reporting change is likely to distort January sales reports most egregiously. In future months, however, the sales numbers will still not be truly comparable to the previous year's results.
Faced with this confusion, analysts sought guidance from dealers. The trouble was that they offered no consensus. Sales "weren't as good as last January, and not as good as they should be," said Linda Schwarz, new car sales manager at Integrity Chevrolet-Geo in Parma Heights, Ohio. She blamed rising interest rates for the slowdown.
Other dealers said the rates were not biting yet, and that any apparent softness in the market was normal for the winter. "We're about 5 percent up over last January," said Manly Eubank, president of Palmetto Ford in Charleston, S.C. "January and February are typically slow."
Caveats aside, G.M. said today that its vehicle sales in January fell 5.5 percent, to 329,515. While cars fell 11.6 percent, G.M. said, trucks gained 4.0 percent. At Chrysler, vehicle sales slipped 6 percent, to 148,638, with light trucks dropping by 9 percent while cars fell by 1 percent.
Honda's sales slipped 5.6 percent, to 46,442. But Toyota said its sales soared by 18.5 percent, to 79,717. Mazda said its sales plunged 23.8 percent, to 18,860.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops Despite Rise In Interest Rates by the Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most leading currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by half a percentage point, a move many currency dealers had expected.
"It was a case of 'Buy the rumor, sell the news,' and the selling was completed quickly," said Jerry Egan, managing director of foreign exchange at the MTB Bank in New York. 
 The dollar slumped after the Fed announced yesterday afternoon that it had raised the rate for overnight loans among banks to 6 percent from 5.5 percent.
While higher rates often bolster the dollar by making United States deposits more attractive, many market participants had already bought dollars expecting the Fed move, traders said.
"When the dollar didn't rise after the rate increase, everybody wanted to be the first one out the door," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5180 German marks from 1.5238 marks on Tuesday and to 1.2840 Swiss francs from 1.2855 francs. The dollar fell to 99.20 Japanese yen from 99.57 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5827 from $1.5795.
On Tuesday, the dollar surged after President Clinton announced an international rescue plan that could total $50 billion to stabilize Mexico's battered financial markets.
The rescue plan makes it less likely that Mexico's crisis will hurt the United States, traders said. The Mexican peso strengthened for a second day yesterday, rising to 5.38 pesos to the dollar from 5.75 pesos Tuesday.
"I'm truly surprised the dollar hasn't risen," said Varick Martin, foreign exchange manager at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York. "This could be an aberrational movement. I find it hard to believe that after today and yesterday, we would see anything but a strong dollar."
Yesterday's increase is the Fed's seventh in less than a year. The United States discount rate is now higher than Germany's 4.5 percent discount rate and Japan's 1.75 percent rate.
Though rates are higher in the United States, many investors still prefer marks and yen because of concerns stemming from the Mexican crisis.
"The most important factor for the dollar is Mexico," Mr. Egan at the MTB Bank said. "The progress of the rescue package is key."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Casino Panel in Louisiana Lifts a Ban on Bally Gaming

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Bally Gaming Inc. won permission from Louisiana regulators today to supply gaming equipment to a casino of the Harrah's Jazz Company, reversing a ban imposed by the casino commission's executive director.
Although a $6.2 million contract with Harrah's Jazz was the immediate stake in the decision, Bally Gaming officials had said that if the ban was not lifted, it could affect the company's gambling licenses in 17 other states. 
 Wilmore Whitmore, the top administrative officer of the Louisiana Economic Development and Gaming Corporation, banned Bally on Jan. 12 after Federal prosecutors named it as the victim in what the prosecutors said was a scheme by three organized crime families to infiltrate Louisiana's video poker industry through two companies, Worldwide Gaming of Louisiana and Louisiana Route Operators. Mr. Whitmore said Bally Gaming had not done enough to avoid questionable ties.
The commission lifted the ban today after refusing to hear from a defendant in the Federal case. The decision allows Bally to sell slot machines and a computer to a temporary casino that Harrah's plans to open in April.
However, the decision was only a partial victory for Bally's. Before Bally Gaming can do business with the permanent casino of Harrah's Jazz, expected to be the world's largest, it will have to reapply to the commission for permission. The casino will be the only land casino in Louisiana.
Bally Gaming executives testified that they advanced Worldwide Gaming and Louisiana Route about $3 million and provided a $25 million credit line to set up a video poker operation in 1991 and 1992, but later withdrew after they became suspicious of the two concerns.
Bally Gaming executives have blamed a former company president, Alan Maiss, for the company's involvement. Mr. Maiss has pleaded guilty to a Federal charge of having video poker dealings with a person who was not licensed to conduct gambling business in Louisiana. The person was Christopher Tanfield, a founder of Worldwide Gaming.
Bally, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., is also licensed to sell video poker machines and slot machines to Louisiana riverboat casinos. Those licenses are cleared by different regulatory agencies.
Mr. Tanfield, one of 17 people facing Federal charges in the video poker case, offered today to testify before the commission. His lawyer, Patrick Fanning, said Mr. Tanfield would tell what he knew concerning Bally Gaming and the two Louisiana companies.
The commission's chairman, Max Chastain, said Mr. Tanfield's testimony could be raised when Bally's applied for a license to supply equipment to the permanent casino. For now, the commission decided to vote on the evidence already before it.
Bally Gaming is no longer connected with the Bally Entertainment Corporation, a casino operator based in Chicago that spun off the slot-machine unit in 1991.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Forecaster Of Economy Up Slightly

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Government's main economic forecasting gauge rose slightly in December while construction spending ended the year on a high note, possibly a result of the unusually warm weather.
Analysts said there might be mixed signals in the latest Government data issued today by the Commerce Department. But as the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates for the seventh time in a year today, they said the economy appeared headed for a slowdown. 
 The index of leading economic indicators rose a mere one-tenth of a percent in December after climbing three-tenths of a percent the previous month. The index declined one-tenth of a percent in October for only its second drop in 17 months.
The gauge "was basically flat during the fourth quarter, pointing to an early 1995 slowdown," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
The index is aimed at predicting activity six to nine months down the road. Three straight moves in the same direction are considered a good gauge of where the economy is headed.
In another report, the Commerce Department said construction spending increased 1.1 percent in December and rose 8.7 percent for 1994, the biggest gain since an 18.3 percent rise in 1984. Spending on residential, nonresidential and government projects in December totaled $530 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate.
But analysts attributed the December gain to warmer-than-normal weather and predicted slower growth ahead.
Adding to the mixed economic signals, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that the manufacturing sector of the economy grew for the 17th straight month in January and at a slightly faster pace than in December.
 Its purchasing managers index rose to 57.9 percent in January, from a revised 57.5 percent in December. A reading above 50 percent suggests expansion in manufacturing and any figure above 44.5 percent indicates growth in the economy.
 The Federal Reserve, as expected, raised short-term interest rates a half percentage point today. The previous six increases have had only limited impact, but analysts said the full effect of higher rates will be felt this year. The Fed has now raised rates three percentage points in 12 months. Some analysts worry that further increases could send the economy into recession.
The economy grew 4 percent in 1994, its best showing in a decade, and closed out the year by advancing at a robust 4.5 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter. Analysts had predicted the index of leading economic indicators would rise two-tenths of a percent in December.
Six of the 11 components tracked by the gauge rose and four fell. One was unchanged.
The positive components, listed according to their impact, were more unfilled orders for durable goods, rising consumer expectations, more new orders for consumer goods, fewer weekly initial claims for unemployment insurance, increased building permits and slower business delivery times that usually are a sign of rising orders.
The four components that made negative contributions to the index were fewer business orders for plant and equipment, falling stock prices, lower money supply and declining raw material prices.
The average workweek was unchanged.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper Hits 2-Month Low In Wake of Rate Increase

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Copper prices tumbled to a two-month low yesterday on fears that the latest increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve may jeopardize the economic expansion that has been a boon to the market.
On other commodity markets, cotton prices fell sharply, while crude oil rose. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.36 point, to 232.42. 
 Copper prices fell to their lowest levels since November as speculative commodity funds pulled out of a market that had risen steadily since October 1993.
On the Commodity Exchange of New York, copper for March delivery fell 4.1 cents, to $1.322 a pound, its lowest close since Nov. 28.
Copper prices fell initially on options-related activity in London and later in New York as speculators liquidated their positions, said Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
"The interest rate saga, with the Federal Reserve again hiking the Federal funds rate 50 basis points as anticipated, also served to depress the copper market," she said.
The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by half a percentage point, its seventh increase in 12 months, in an effort to slow economic growth and keep inflation from accelerating.
Copper has led a boom in prices for industrial metals, including nickel, tin, lead and aluminum, as economies in Europe and the United States have recovered. Copper is used in building and by auto makers and other manufacturers. So far, copper consumption has climbed faster than production.
But higher interest rates are expected to damp demand for homes, cars and other big-ticket items. A slowing, combined with a pickup in mining output, could spell an end to the copper rally.
"It may now be that the metals are at a turning point," said Kanak Patel, an economist at Magdelene College at Cambridge University in Britain.
Cotton prices fell sharply in largely technical trading.
March cotton fell 1.37 cents, to 92.10 cents a pound, on the New York Stock Exchange, its second drop after reaching a 14-year high of 94.35 cents a pound on Monday.

HEADLINE: Orange County Faces Bond Payment Shortfall

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Two months after Orange County, Calif., declared bankruptcy, the county has done little to reassure its bondholders that they will get their money back, and bondholders are becoming increasingly restless.
Some $1.2 billion in Orange County bonds, held primarily by individuals and mutual funds, come due from June to August and must be paid back. The county says it has no money to repay those bondholders and, in their eyes, is doing little to change that. 
 Only one proposal has been floated so far, and it is hardly the comprehensive solution that bondholders seek. Some county officials have suggested diverting part of the county sales tax of 7.75 percent that normally goes to the county's general fund and use the money to issue new bonds to pay off the old ones. Such a diversion still faces many legal hurdles and even if approved, might not provide enough money.
Orange County declared bankruptcy last Dec. 6, after sustaining losses in an investment fund that bet interest rates would fall. The losses have amounted to $1.7 billion, and the financial crisis that followed has made it difficult, if not impossible, for the county to repay the investors who bought Orange County bonds in recent years.
As the bonds' repayment dates near, bondholders are becoming worried by statements from county officials. The officials have consistently warned that they will not raise taxes to solve the problem and that bondholders may have to delay getting paid back or take less than what they are owed. Even more troubling, county officials have not ruled out a default on the obligations entirely.
"The county does not have funds now to make all these payments," said Bruce Bennett, the county's bankruptcy lawyer. "It is now exploring every conceivable method of dealing with these bonds without defaulting.
"We are looking at refinancing and at renegotiating with existing bondholders," he added. "The unilateral nonpayment of these bonds, defaulting on them, would be the absolute last resort."
Such talk alarms the world of municipal finance. It undermines the basic tenet on which the municipal bond market is built: that municipal borrowers like Orange County are morally obligated to repay their debts, even if it means cutting services and raising taxes.
Outright defaults are extremely rare in municipal finance and many municipalities with financial problems, like New York City and Philadelphia, solved their problems by raising taxes and taking other hard steps to prevent a default.
Should Orange County default on its outstanding bonds, it would most likely be unable to ever borrow again in the municipal markets. That has been the fate of the handful of other public borrowers that have defaulted on their bond obligations.
What is more, it would make investors think twice about lending to all other municipalities and could force municipal borrowers to pay more to entice investors to lend to them.
No other large municipality has ever declared bankruptcy and none has been as adamant in saying it will not raise taxes to resolve its crisis. The anti-tax stance of the county's board of supervisors has not softened since the crisis began, much to the consternation of bondholders.
"It's atrocious," said Joe Mysak, editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer. "Orange County has crossed the line and gone into the unspeakable. It was one thing to declare bankruptcy. But the talk about deferring debt payments takes this into the beyond. It's revolutionary and it will stand municipal finance on its head.
"The idea that a county as wealthy as Orange County is suddenly balking at making debt payments and is being intransigent on raising taxes has really damaged them in the marketplace. They are saying, 'We won't pay.' And the market is going to say, 'Oh, really?' "
David MacEwen, senior municipal portfolio manager at the Benham Group, added: "They might as well be Mexico. The people in Orange County don't feel that this is their problem and they shouldn't pay. The fact that this is a wealthy county doesn't help if you can't tap the wealth. "
Angry bondholders have scheduled a meeting for Feb. 7 in Anaheim, Calif., to air their grievances. The $1.2 billion in debt includes a $600 million short-term note that matures on July 10 and more than $644 million in a number of revenue and property tax anticipation notes that mature in June and July.
Bondholders were particularly troubled by a decision by the county last month to halt payment of $53 million into a special reserve fund used to pay coming bond obligations. That action put many of the county's bond issues into technical default.
"Orange County is waiting for someone else to solve their situation," said James E. Spiotto, a bond lawyer with Chapman & Cutler in Chicago. "They won't raise taxes. They want to share the pain with others and they want to borrow. That's nice, but I'm not sure the world is made that way."
Most troubled municipalities have escaped their problems by converting their short-term debt to long-term debt and coming up with new sources of revenues -- usually new taxes -- to finance the payments on the new debt. The county recently hired Goldman, Sachs & Company and A. G. Edwards & Sons to underwrite any new long-term bonds.
Several factors, however, will make new bond underwritings difficult. First is the amount of borrowing that will be needed -- several hundred million dollars. Second, the county's bonds are now rated as "junk" -- below investment grade -- increasing borrowing costs. And finally, and most importantly, there is the question of how the county will support these new borrowings without new taxes.
"The county is going to have to show it has some sort of earmarked tax against this new debt or it will have problems convincing investors that they will get paid back," said Jane Eddy, an analyst with Standard & Poor's Ratings Group.
The lone proposal afoot is to divert 1 percent or so of the county's sales tax to meet the payments on new bonds. Some estimate that could raise up to $140 million a year to cover the new bond payments. Not only is it unclear whether that would be enough to support new borrowings, but that is also money that would otherwise pay for county services.
"When you live without this revenue source in the budget, it has implications for people's lives," said Karen Kropp, an analyst with Moody's Investors Services. "I'd love to know how the county is going to come up with more funds."
The diversion would come at a time when Orange County is already facing a budget crisis. From now until July, the county faces a shortfall of $172 million in its general fund budget because of its investment losses. In the fiscal year starting next July, the county is expected to come up short by another $154 million.
So far, the county has proposed cuts of only $40 million from its budget, and some modest other cuts have been suggested. County supervisors have said they will seek state approval to lower wages on public projects and cut welfare and health programs.
What about help from the State of California?
Orange County officials have long stated that they will not seek a state bailout. The State Treasurer, Matthew Fong, said he would be inclined to support the sales tax diversion proposal because it did not put state money at risk.
"I'd be concerned that you'd set a precedent that if a local government makes a bad decision, they'll be bailed out by the state," Mr. Fong said. "The state does not want to reward bad performance."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Does raising the minimum wage inevitably mean a loss of jobs?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON is maybe, sort of, leaning in favor of an unspecified increase in the minimum wage. Details to be announced, provided the House majority leader, Dick Armey, promises not to sneer . . .
That's not just a cheap shot at a President already lampooned as a waffle. It is also a joke on economists in and outside the Administration who no longer know what to think about the impact of a higher minimum wage on joblessness. 
 Conventional economic theory still argues strongly against using the minimum wage as a weapon to help the working poor. But two widely respected labor economists, David Card and Alan Krueger of Princeton University, contend the numbers support the opposite conclusion. Their forthcoming book, "Myth and Measurement: The New Economics of the Minimum Wage" (Princeton University Press), is bound to puzzle and irritate policy types who thought this issue was settled long ago.
"It's always worth stirring the pot," said James Heckman, an economist at the University of Chicago. "The big question is whether they'll get anything out of it."
The heretofore solid front against minimum wages is really part of a long-running argument over the virtue of manipulating prices to achieve social objectives.
Farmers in trouble? No problem, explained presidents from F.D.R to George Bush: guarantee them a minimum price for their crops. And if you thought such ideas went out of fashion with the last Congressional election, think again. In one of his first speeches after the victory, House Speaker Newt Gingrich proposed to give the poor a cheaper ride on the information highway by giving them $1,000 discounts on laptop computers.
But messing with market-determined prices, economists respond, distorts incentives to use resources efficiently, thereby reducing the total size of the economic pie. And for decades, the minimum wage has been exhibit No. 1.
In the rich welfare states of northern Europe, where minimum compensation including government-mandated fringes approaches $10 an hour, unemployment seems stuck near double-digit levels. In the United States, the minimum wage has never bitten so sharply. But until recently, there was still nearly unanimous agreement among economists that any increase would cost jobs.
Mr. Card and Mr. Krueger have never been excessively respectful of received wisdom, though. And their own research -- much of it done with Lawrence Katz of Harvard -- has blown gaping holes in the consensus.
In one study summarized in their new book, they compare employment in fast-food restaurants in New Jersey (which raised the minimum wage in 1992) with restaurants across the river in Pennsylvania (which did not). The New Jersey restaurants apparently responded by hiring workers, not dropping them.
This startling result was echoed in other studies by the authors. After the mandated wage increase, one would have expected less growth in employment in New Jersey restaurants that paid the bare minimum than in restaurants that paid considerably more. In fact, they found the opposite. One would have expected the 1990 and 1991 increases in the Federal minimum wage to have led industries using lots of low-cost labor to substitute machines for people. But no such effect is evident in the before-and-after numbers.
The Princeton economists also look at countries where the minimum wage is much closer to the average -- and thus ought to have sharper impact on employment. While they did not come up with anything as startling as the New Jersey numbers, findings for Canada, Puerto Rico and Britain apparently do not support the view that higher wages lead to joblessness.
What could be going on here? Economists assume that the demand for labor falls as the price of labor rises. The only condition under which that iron law is likely to be violated, suggests Daniel Hamermesh of the University of Texas, is where individual employers' actions noticeably influence the going wage. If, for example, an employer is afraid to hire a 10th worker at $5 an hour because he will have to raise the wages of the other nine to match, a rise in the legal minimum wage of $5 would remove the impediment.
The catch, Mr. Hamermesh argues, is that this phenomenon should be short-lived in any reasonably well-behaved labor market. While the local Burger King may be able to pay less for a while, it won't be long before workers will find out about the higher wages offered by the Taco Bell 20 miles down the highway.
So where does that leave economists? Between the rock of new empirical research and the hard place of as-yet-unsullied economic theory. Mr. Hamermesh, for one, is not ready to give up on the traditional belief. "You can't abandon an old idea for no idea," he insists.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners' Proposal Isn't New, Players Say

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
In a hotel room about a mile from the White House, where its primary occupant is watching them closely, negotiators for baseball's striking players and owners returned to the bargaining table today after a 40-day absence. But they maintained their distance.
The owners made a new payroll-tax proposal that John Harrington, chairman of the negotiating committee, termed a "significant step," only to have the players privately shake their heads and, in the words of one, say, "It doesn't look a whole heck of a lot different." 
 The luxury tax proposal, which was contained in a comprehensive proposal covering noneconomic issues as well, was different in that it included two significant changes from the clubs' previous tax proposals.
But the players nevertheless saw the same kind of problems that were presented by the previous tax plans and the salary cap the owners implemented Dec. 23.
The owners would tax payrolls over $35 million in two tiers: 75 percent for the segment between $35 million and $42 million and 100 percent for the portion beyond $42 million.
Unlike previous plans, the rates would not be adjusted each year until the players' share of industry revenue dropped to 50 percent, but the thresholds would remain fixed at $35 million and $42 million, no matter how high revenues go, meaning the players' share could drop below 50 percent.
Talks resumed under the scrutinizing eye of President Clinton, who has threatened to begin exerting serious outside pressure if the two sides don't reach agreement or at least make substantial progress by Monday.
That pressure would come in the form of a proposal from the mediator, Bill Usery Jr., whom the White House sent into the talks in October, a month after the dispute had forced the World Series to be canceled for the first time in 90 years.
"There was a recognition by both sides," Donald Fehr, the union leader said, "that there is pressure being applied now and if we didn't resolve it, there would be more."
Harrington said: "We hope the President's interest will help keep us focused on the most important thing, and that is to get the game back on the field. Today we believe we honored the spirit of the President's press release the other day."
Fehr, at a news briefing, declined to discuss the new proposal or even characterize it, saying the union wanted to study it before commenting. But one player, who has been closely involved in the negotiations, lamented, "It's going to be a long week."
Previous tax proposals would have assessed the rate of tax on a club's entire payroll; this plan would tax only the part of the payroll that exceeds the first threshold, $35 million. The resulting payment would be less, but the players feel it would still be sufficiently steep to inhibit clubs from exceeding the first threshold and certainly the second, thereby restricting player salaries.
The thresholds would not take effect until the fourth year under a transition plan, but if the plan had been in full effect during an uninterrupted 1994 season, the Detroit Tigers would have paid $20 million in tax on their major league-high $56.8 million payroll. That's far less than the nearly $44 million they would have paid under a previous tax plan, but it still might prompt the Tigers to reduce their payroll.
It also contrasts with the $2.6 million tax the Tigers would pay under the tax plan the union proposed Dec. 22.
The Yankees would have paid $14 million in tax last year on their $50.7 million payroll. The tax assessor would have extracted nothing from the Mets because they had a $34.4 million payroll.
The idea of the transition period is to give the clubs time to reduce their payrolls so that they could avoid taxes completely or at least significantly. The owners disagreed with the players' view that the tax would affect clubs' offers to players.
"I think you'll find X number of clubs budget enough money for payrolls and tax, especially if they want to be in the World Series," Jerry McMorris of the Colorado Rockies said.
McMorris said he believed the plan was "very much different" from previous proposals "because there's not a trigger mechanism that gets you to 50 percent," meaning the share of the clubs' revenues the players would have received under the other plans. "Somebody who wants to spend money can still spend money," he added. "A cap is a cap."
Asked about the clubs' long-stated goal to attain cost certainty through a salary cap, Harrington said: "We have kind of departed from the cost certainty. We're hoping to achieve an objective of cost control."
The money raised by taxes, if anyone winds up paying taxes, would be used for the owners' payment to the players' pension and benefit plan. If taxes don't provide enough money -- payments have been $57 million a year -- the clubs would have to make up the shortfall, Harrington said.
The owners' revenue sharing plan, adopted a year ago contingent on the players' acceptance of a salary cap, would take effect if this proposal, or one negotiated from it, replaced the implemented cap system.
"We made it clear all of the aspects of our proposal are negotiable," Harrington said. "We hope while we're here we will receive a counterproposal from the players."
The players, who went on strike Aug. 12, which ended the 1994 season, conceivably could make a counterproposal based on the same structure as the clubs' plan. But it would be as much to the owners' dislike as this plan is to the players'.
In the new proposal, the clubs changed some of the minimum salaries for the first four years, raising the first year from $115,000 to $125,000, the second from $175,000 to $190,000 and the third from $275,000 to $290,000. The fourth year minimum remained $500,000 or $750,000, depending on a player's rank.
The clubs eliminated the provision that would give players on the disabled list half credit for service time instead of full credit, and they altered the provision that would have allowed them to release a player at any time for any reason, including economic. The new provision would allow a team to release a player for economic reasons only in spring training.
The clubs would still eliminate salary arbitration and provide restricted free agency for players with between four and six years of major league service, but they offered the additional inducement of eliminating repeater restrictions for all free agents.
The owners also went along with some of the ideas the players presented last month, creating an industry growth fund with each side contributing $30 million and giving the players input on such matters as expansion and baseball operations.

HEADLINE: THE PATAKI BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
PATAKI PROPOSES BROAD REDUCTIONS IN STATE SPENDING

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Taking the first step toward fulfilling his vision for a smaller state government, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed a $ 32.4 billion state budget today that would reduce taxes for almost all New Yorkers and cut spending across the board.
In presenting his budget, Mr. Pataki became the first New York governor since 1943 to call for less spending than in the previous year, proposing a $ 1.1 billion, or 3 percent, reduction. He also proposed income-tax cuts that would total $ 1 billion, the first step in a four-year plan to reduce the top tax rate by one-quarter and save taxpayers $ 6.8 billion a year. The top tax rate this year would fall to 7.59 percent, from 7.87 percent last year. 
 The budget from Mr. Pataki, a Republican, seizes on a projected $ 5 billion gap as an opportunity to refashion government to meet his goals, to make it smaller, to control costs and to put welfare recipients to work.
"Throughout the nation, the American people have demanded spending cuts, tax cuts, government that is more efficient and more effective," he said to an audience of more than 300 legislators, reporters and lobbyists. "The citizens of New York are demanding that their state government join the march."
The proposed cuts include reducing by $ 128 million state appropriations for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has already suffered a $ 113 million cut in aid from New York City. Transit advocates said the additional state cuts would make a 25-cent to 50-cent fare increase for subway and bus riders virtually inevitable this year.
"A fare hike is a tax hike for the more than four million moderate-income and working people who use city subways and buses every workday," said Gene Russianoff of the Straphangers Campaign, a transit riders' group. But M.T.A. officials said it was too early to comment about a fare increase.
Mr. Pataki said he would close the $ 5 billion shortfall, $ 1 billion of which would stem from the tax cuts, in three steps. First, he would reduce spending on welfare and Medicaid, the health program for the disabled and the poor, by $ 1.9 billion.
Second, he would cut spending by state agencies by $ 2.5 billion, eliminating or consolidating programs and reducing the work force by 11,400, a 5 percent cut.
Finally, breaking a campaign pledge to not use "gimmicks" to balance the budget, he would use $ 650 million in nonrecurring, or one-time, revenue measures like borrowing from other funds and selling state property.
Reactions to Mr. Pataki's plan were swift, strong and partisan. The majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Brunswick, praised the plan as a declaration of war between liberal spenders and conservative tax-cutters. "This is a budget of job creation and job retention," Mr. Bruno said.
Daniel B. Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York State, called the budget a giant leap toward economic growth.
But an array of advocates for groups that would be affected -- such as welfare recipients and teachers -- attacked Mr. Pataki's budget as potentially devastating to essential services. The advocates said, for example, that the cuts would lead to $ 1,000-a-year tuition increases at the state and city universities.
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan, who will lead the legislative fight to hold back the cuts, called Mr. Pataki a "negative Robin Hood" who was seeking to finance tax cuts for the wealthy on the backs of the middle class and the elderly.
Cindy B. Green, vice president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses, lauded Mr. Pataki for "bringing under control what had previously been uncontrolled expenditures." But she warned that the tax-cut plan, which would cost $ 700 million this year and grow to $ 6.8 billion a year by 1998, is likely to lead to budget shortfalls.
"They are backloaded," Ms. Green said of the proposed cuts. "They balloon. We have a lot of concern about whether this all leads to truly balanced budgets down the line."
Besides reducing the top rate, the tax-cut plan would increase the deduction for married couples this year from $ 9,500 to $ 10,800. In addition, families earning less than $ 25,296 a year could begin claiming an earned-income tax credit worth 10 percent of a similar Federal credit.
The spending cuts would be spread so widely across the landscape of state government that they would be likely to touch most New Yorkers in ways large and small. The cuts would affect virtually every agency and every region.
Welfare stipends for more than one million people would be reduced. Scores of road and bridge repairs would be canceled or delayed. Prisoners in maximum-security prisons would double up in cells, and sports stadiums on Long Island and in upstate towns would not be built.
Mr. Pataki also suggested several cuts that although relatively small were rich in symbolism. He would sell the $ 675,000 mansion that the State Education Commissioner occupies. The present occupant, Thomas Sobol, is planning to retire because of conflicts with Mr. Pataki.
The Governor would also cut 300 administrators from the Education Department. He would sell the governor's airplane, which he said his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, used to excess.
Another feature would eliminate $ 48 million in "member's items," which lawmakers traditionally use to promote certain organizations in their districts.
The $ 32.4 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning on April 1 represents the amount of money to be raised from state taxes and fees. When Federal funds are added, mostly for welfare and Medicaid, the budget grows to $ 62.6 billion. The combined budget proposed by Mr. Pataki, known as the all-funds budget, is $ 415 million, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, larger than the current all-funds budget.
Although no governor since World War II has proposed spending less than in the previous year, the Legislature in late 1990 had to enact midyear cuts because of the recession that caused spending to fall below 1989 levels.
In closing a $ 5 billion shortfall, Mr. Pataki would pay for $ 1 billion in income-tax cuts and bring down costs $ 4 billion from where they would be projected to rise because of the growth of government.
The Governor said the shortfall was mainly a result of the rapid growth of Medicaid, mental health and other social programs, as well as growing interest payments on debt. He also said the Legislature and Mr. Cuomo, just before the elections in November, enacted $ 1.1 billion in construction and education programs that the state could not afford.
Making a point of trying to eliminate many of those programs, Mr. Pataki said he would, for example, cut $ 97 million for sports stadiums, including a $ 24 million swimming pool in Nassau County. And he called for ending a $ 50 million scholarship program championed by Mr. Cuomo.
To reduce the work force by 11,400, Mr. Pataki said he hoped that up to 6,000 positions could be eliminated through attrition. Most of the remaining jobs could be cut through buyouts, he said.
But he held out the possibility that he would have to lay off up to 6,900 workers if the buyout program was not approved by the Legislature or by unions, which would finance the program through contract givebacks.
As another measure to close the gap, Mr. Pataki resurrected an old Cuomo proposal, a keno lottery game that he said could generate $ 115 million a year. Mr. Silver called that figure unrealistically high.
Officials from the state and city universities said the plans to cut money for higher education, $ 290 million for the State University of New York and $ 158 million for the City University of New York, would lead to higher tuitions, larger classes and faculty layoffs.
"It presents budgetary problems of historic proportions for the State University," said the SUNY Chancellor, Dr. Thomas A. Bartlett.
The $ 650 million in nonrecurring revenues that Mr. Pataki would use to close the gap include $ 220 million from an M.T.A. surplus account, $ 63 million from a settlement to clean up the Love Canal near Niagara Falls and $ 110 million from a special fund to augment pension payments for retired state workers.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, said he would sue to block the use of the pension money, calling it a gimmick.
Among the social-service cuts, Mr. Pataki would reduce Medicaid spending $ 1.2 billion by trimming payments to health-care providers, mandating managed care and sharply reducing services to elderly people at home. He also called for cutting services for the mentally ill, mentally retarded and drug and alcohol addicts.
To save on the costs of prison guards, the Governor said he would require maximum-security prisoners to be placed two to a cell, an idea that advocates for inmates said would lead to increasing violence.

HEADLINE: Congress Limits Federal Orders Costly to States

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The House of Representatives brought a prolonged debate to its foregone conclusion today and overwhelmingly passed legislation making it harder for Congress to impose new requirements on the states and cities without providing Federal money to pay for them.
The legislation, which passed the Senate in similar form last week and has President Clinton's endorsement, is the first major step in what the new Republican majority in Congress is promising will be a steady shift of power from Washington back to the local governments. 
 "This is really the first debate we have had on the New Federalism," said Representative William F. Clinger, Republican of Pennsylvania, as the debate ended. It had consumed most of three weeks, including several nights when the House worked past midnight as Republicans fought off Democratic amendments. The bill was finally passed in a bipartisan vote of 360 to 74.
It was the second piece of the Republicans' campaign manifesto, the Contract With America, to have been approved by both chambers of Congress, each winning bipartisan support. President Clinton has already signed the first, which eliminated Congress's exemption from 11 Federal labor laws.
But the third such proposal to pass the House, which would amend the Constitution to require a balanced Federal budget, is far from the day of decision in the Senate, where debate continued inconclusively today.
In the House, Democrats argued today until the very end that the bill limiting what are known as "unfunded mandates" was misguided, and that it would result in loosening environmental and other protections. But more than 60 members of their own party consistently sided with the Republicans, and in the end most Democrats voted for the bill, which is widely popular among governors and mayors.
Representative Cardiss Collins, Democrat of Illinois, said the Republicans' consistent refusal to exempt environmental and other laws from the new restrictions "reveals a mean-spirited effort to abandon those who are most in need."
In fact, the measure does not prohibit the Federal Government from imposing new requirements on states and cities. But it does require Congress to study the costs of most such laws, and to find ways to pay those costs -- or to decide in a separate vote to waive that requirement.
Although there are a few minor differences between what the House passed today and what the Senate passed last week, they are expected to be easily resolved and the bill will then go to President Clinton. It will not take effect until later this year, and does not reverse any mandates imposed on the states by past legislation.
But it is likely to be felt right away by Congressional committees that are only now beginning to work on substantive legislation on pollution and other issues. They will be discouraged from drafting anything that contains unfinanced requirements, since by the time these bills come to the floor late this year there will be new procedural barriers to proposing them.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, said the action on the three pieces of the Contract With America "shows that we are on schedule," even though debate on the bill on unfinanced requirements took longer than Republican leaders had expected.
"In order to make big changes, you have to work hard," Mr. Armey said. Republican leaders have promised to vote on the entire 10-point manifesto in the first 100 days of the new Congress.
On Thursday, the House plans to take up the next part of the program: a measure giving the President the right to selectively veto individual programs established by Congress without having to veto entire bills.
Several other bills backed by Republicans are working their way through committees.
In the Senate, a Judiciary subcommittee approved a proposed constitutional amendment to impose term limits on members of Congress. Senators would be barred from serving more than two full six-year terms and House members would be barred from serving more than six full two-year terms.
In the House, meanwhile, the Judiciary Committee approved a bill to provide states with $10.5 billion for prison construction -- $2.5 billion more than in last year's crime bill. Half the money would go to states that do not release violent criminals from prison before they have served at least 85 percent of the imposed sentences. The other half would go to states that have increased the imprisonment of violent criminals.
As the Senate debated the proposed Constitutional amendment on a balanced budget, with Democrats calling for a detailed explanation of how that would be achieved, a House committee examined tax cuts favored by Republicans.
The House Ways and Means Committee issued a new estimate showing that the tax provisions of the Contract With America would reduce Government revenue by $196.3 billion over the next five years. The projection, prepared by the staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on Taxation, is similar to one published last fall by the Republican staff of the House Budget Committee.
The most costly item, the new figures showed, would be the proposal for a $500-per-child tax credit, which would reduce revenue by $117.5 billion over the period. Various reductions proposed in capital gains taxes would result in the loss of $48.7 billion.
The capital gains estimate was made in the traditional fashion rather than under a new method favored by some Republicans that would take account of what they think would be overall economic improvement resulting from a lower capital gains tax.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, promised that all tax reductions would be offset by reduced spending, but he did not identify what spending cuts he was talking about.


GRAPHIC: The Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations, a bipartisan body created by Congress in 1959 to monitor Federal-state relations, says there is no way to calculate exactly what costs the Government has pushed on to states and localities. But the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the cumulative cost of Federal regulations that localities must pay for between 1983 and 1990 is between $8.9 billion and $12.7 billion.
Chart: "FOR EXAMPLE: Burdens on States and Cities"
Here are some examples of such "unfunded mandates." The new legislation that has passed the Senate and the House would apply only to new laws and does not change the obligations of state and local governments under existing requirements.
 
Family and Medical Leave Act of 1991 -- Requires employers to provide family and medical leave to their employees. As employers, state and local governments are responsible for any costs associated with providing the leave.
 
Handgun Violence Protection Act of 1993 (Brady Bill) -- Requires a five business-day waiting period and background check before a person can buy a handgun. Costs are incurred by the tracking, checking and record-keeping requirements.
 
National Voter Registration Act of 1993 -- Directs states to implement a variety of programs to make it easier for states to register voters. States are required to allow mail-in voter registration and to provide registration forms at a variety of state offices including motor vehicle offices and welfare offices.
 
Asbestos Hazard Emergency Response Act of 1986 -- Requires local school systems to inspect for and remove hazardous asbestos materials from school buildings.
 
Safe Drinking Water Act Amendments of 1986 -- Sets standards and timetables for removing contaminants from tap water; requires states to monitor their groundwater supplies, and tightens enforcement and penalties for water systems that do not comply.
 
Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 -- Imposes strict deadlines and requirements dealing with urban smog, municipal incinerators and toxic emissions.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;
Aid for Mexico Gives Economy Shot in the Arm

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1

 BODY:
One day after President Clinton's rescue plan brought a respite from its financial crisis, Mexico turned today to the task of rebuilding its shattered economy as officials and economists warned of a long year ahead of austerity, disappointment and anger.
The $50 billion international package of loans and loan guarantees announced in Washington on Tuesday brought a temporary euphoria to the markets and the business community, which the newspapers were terming the "Clinton effect." 
 The peso rose a bit more today, closing at 5.37 to the dollar, about a 7 percent increase over Tuesday's rate. Interest rates on the 28-day Government treasury certificate fell to 32.57 percent, more than 4 percentage points below last week's rates, another sign the financial situation was stabilizing.
But in Washington, critics in Congress and even some supporters worried whether the bailout would lead to any long-term progress in Mexico's economy. [News analysis, page A12.]
While the package assembled in Washington could go a long way toward resolving Mexico's immediate crisis, analysts noted that the nation still faces serious economic and political problems that threaten its long-term stability, with many implications for the United States.
"In the short term we may have left behind the chaos," said Guadalupe Loaeza, a writer in Mexico City who has led marches to the doors of the Mexican White House condemning the Government's economic policies. "But we are facing a year in which we will have to confront a sad reality, that we are a very poor country with many problems."
Financial analysts said that in spite of the new financial backing, many foreign investors remain wary of putting their money in Mexico, which still has $23 billion in debt due this year.
There are indications that Mexico may be sliding toward an unavoidable recession. Many analysts also said President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon's plan to limit price and wage increases, originally triggered by a loss of one-third of the peso's value, has become harder to manage after six weeks of financial instability.
President Zedillo told Mexicans on Tuesday that the assistance in no way implies a lessening of the discipline required to get the economy back on track. But workers, business executives and just about everyone else here are growing angrier by the day that the battered peso, despite recent gains, still cannot buy anywhere near what it bought before the crisis began.
In a sign of potential problems, 4,000 workers stayed off the job for a second day at a Thomson Consumer Electronics Company plant across the border from El Paso, complaining that they cannot survive on salaries diminished by the weakened peso.
On Wall Street, analysts expressed doubts about Mexico's commitment to control spending, limit the amount of money it prints, or reject the kind of unfettered borrowing seen as leading to inflation, instability and the current debt crisis.
"The Mexican Government now has to re-establish a track record," said Chip Brown, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York.
President Zedillo, in office two months today, also faces pressing political problems, political commentators said. Among the most pressing are unruly factions of his own party, a still unresolved guerrilla uprising in Chiapas and five state elections in 1995 that his party stands a good chance of losing.
"Mexico right now is in a clearing," said Neal M. Soss, an economist in New York. "But it's a wide enough clearing so that no one can be sure if there's more woods on the other side."
There were several other signs of stability in the markets, although analysts said the decline in interest rates on the Government treasury certificates was significant because they are important indicators of trends on interest rates for consumer and business loans.
Not every economic indicator was favorable, but even a 4.6 percent drop in stock prices was seen as a sign of normalcy, because investors were simply selling off securities for quick profits after a 10 percent market rebound on Tuesday. Analysts also said some investors were selling stock to buy Government bonds.
"What happened today on the market is not worrisome at all," said Pablo Riveroll, director of analysis at Bursamex, a Mexico City brokerage firm. "When markets move so much, it's only normal that people are there to take profits."
Mexico plans to use the $50 billion pledged by the United States and other countries to help pay its debts until it can refinance existing obligations. Mexican officials said that in the next week or so, they will offer longer-term bonds, backed by the new American credits.
Finance Minister Guillermo Ortiz said the amount of outstanding Government bonds has been reduced from $29 billion to $23.5 billion, about half of which is held by foreigners, many of them Americans.
"It's going to be a very difficult year," said Raul Munoz Leos, president of Du Pont of Mexico. "The fact that we won't have an economy that is growing is bad for business so we'll have to look for export opportunities."
As part of its recovery plan, Mexico said it would reduce by more than half the existing $30 billion deficit that resulted from importing far more than it exported in 1994. If it is successful,
Mexican officials are relying on the devalued peso to make Mexican exports cheaper and imports from other countries, including the United States, more expensive. But economists said such hopes would come undone if Mexico fails to control inflation. By pushing up the price of Mexican labor and other costs, inflation pushes up the price of Mexican exports.
As part of its anti-inflation program, the Government signed a pact with labor and business on Jan. 3 to control wages and prices. But since then price increases have been routinely exceeding targets. And while labor originally agreed to wage limits, workers are increasingly unhappy.
One example is the Thomson plant, in Ciudad Juarez. Workers walked off the job Tuesday afternoon, complaining that the peso's problems had cut deeply into their salaries. The Mexican Department of Labor sent negotiators to the plant today to meet with the local union and state officials.
Most of Mexico's emergency economic measures are laid out in a memorandum of economic policies that Mexico signed with the International Monetary Fund, which is lending Mexico $17.8 billion.
In the memorandum, Mexico agrees to limit any increases in internal credit in 1995 to 10 billion pesos, or about $2 billion at the current exchange rate. The Government agrees to try to stabilize the peso at 4.50 to the dollar, and to keep inflation below 19 percent.
All those goals will be difficult to reach, said Mr. Soss, the economist, especially if there are any shocks in the coming months like the assassinations or political turmoil that Mexico experienced in 1994.
"For at least the next year," Mr. Soss said, "Mexico will have to keep a low profile."
