HEADLINE: A Deficit Reins In Sweden's Welfare State

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM

 BODY:
In the last six decades, Sweden has built one of the world's most generous and successful social welfare systems, providing its citizens with a lifelong array of benefits that help them maintain a high standard of living through good times and bad.
But now, unable to afford the bill, the country is being forced to pare social welfare spending. Although the cuts have so far hardly been Draconian, there is widespread anxiety that the system, long seen as the model for combining socialist welfare policies with vibrant capitalism, could collapse under its own economic weight. 
 The strains are already beginning to show. Despite Sweden's commitment to universally available child care, local authorities in some areas have had to reduce spending on subsidized day-care centers.
In the last few years, reductions have been made in unemployment insurance and in payments to workers injured on the job. Among a number of proposals likely to be enacted in coming months is a $ 17 reduction in the $ 100 monthly payment provided to every family for each child regardless of need.
Nearly every industrialized country is seeking to overhaul its social welfare system. As in the United States, the issue is moving to the political forefront across Western Europe, where the high costs of maintaining generous benefits are increasingly seen as a drag on the economy.
But no major Western nation faces financial pressure as intense as that of Sweden, where citizens remain downright coddled by American standards. Still, it is particularly unsettling to many Swedes that the most recently proposed cuts, the deepest so far, are being carried out under the party that built the system, the leftist Social Democrats.
The party, the dominant political force since the 1930's, regained power in elections last fall after three years in opposition, in part because voters felt that the conservative Government had gone too far in dismantling Sweden's liberal system.
"We are just nine million people, and we should be able to take care of each other," said Annelie Drevstam, an assistant at a Stockholm photo agency. "It's a new problem for Sweden that we have people living on the streets, and if I have to pay more in taxes or get less child allowance to help, I'm willing to do it."
Yet Sweden already imposes one of the world's heaviest tax burdens to pay for its social largess, with total Government receipts in 1993 amounting to 58.3 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 31.1 percent in the United States.
As a result some Swedes, including Ms. Drevstam's husband, Mika Laitanen, say their commitment to social welfare has its limits.
Since the family is hoping to buy a house, Mr. Laitanen would like to see the Government do more to bring interest rates down, maybe even at the expense of cutting welfare, and he supports the tax-cutting philosophy of the conservatives.
"I would rather decide what I do with my money," said Mr. Laitanen, an electrician for the Swedish military.
The Swedish system provides, among other benefits, a guarantee of close to a full income indefinitely in cases of sickness and unemployment. It covers medical care and subsidizes educational costs, sets minimum retirement income and provides paid leaves of absence for new parents.
But faced with one of the developed world's worst budget deficits and plagued by a stubbornly high unemployment rate of 13 percent, Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson has had little choice but to push for spending cuts.
In January the Government proposed a four-year, $ 15 billion program of spending cuts and tax increases, by far the biggest austerity package in the country's history, in an effort to stop the growth in the deficit and to bring down punishingly high interest rates.
The deficit surged from 7.4 percent of gross domestic product in 1992 to 13.5 percent in 1993. Although it dropped slightly by some measures last year, it remains more than three times as high as the average ratio of 3.8 percent for the world's largest industrial countries.
Mr. Carlsson said he was confident of getting his package through Parliament, despite complaints from the left that the cuts were too deep and from the right that he was relying too much on tax increases. By 1997, he said, the deficit should be down to around 7 percent of gross domestic product.
Mr. Carlsson said his plan would bring financial stability to Sweden without forcing any wholesale changes in a system that extends far beyond providing a safety net for people who need help to recover from misfortune.
Under Mr. Carlsson's plan, for example, Swedish women would continue to be encouraged to take a year off from work after the birth of a child, but they would be paid 75 percent of their former salary for the year, down from 80 percent.
"We're trimming the system, not dismantling it," Mr. Carlsson said in an interview. "It's very clear to me as a Social Democrat that if we want a social welfare system, we have to have the income to pay for it. The condition for this is to strengthen the Swedish economy, and that's exactly what we are doing now."
The slimming of the welfare state began under the previous, conservative Government, led by Carl Bildt. In three stormy years as Prime Minister, he sought to impose a Thatcherite revolution on Sweden by cutting taxes, introducing free-market economic policies and asserting the need for more individual responsibility.
But Mr. Bildt's tenure coincided with the worst recession in Sweden since the 1930's. The jobless rate went from almost nothing in 1991 to 13 percent last year.
With the economy foundering and unemployment benefits and other welfare payments surging, Mr. Bildt's tax cuts led to a rising deficit. The problem was compounded when he was unable to find consensus in his coalition Government for large-scale spending cuts.
Mr. Carlsson's budget strategy has set off protests from some of those affected, including several thousand students who marched in Stockholm in January to protest cuts in their grants.
Many business executives and economists contend that the Government has been too timid in its cuts, though.
"In our view the proposed measures will not be sufficient, either in scope or direction, to achieve the necessary correction in state finances or the growth for which the Government is striving," the chairmen of eight of Sweden's largest companies -- including Volvo, Electrolux and the technology giant Ericsson -- said in a letter to Mr. Carlsson.
Some analysts say that rather than snip around the edges of the benefit programs, the Government needs to engage in a wholesale reassessment of Sweden's priorities.
"Inevitably, the debt burden will force Swedes to make large-scale modifications to their public benefit programs and accept slower growth in their standard of living," said a report from Moody's Investors Service, which analyzes the financial condition of countries and companies.
The need for a shift in public policy, Moody's said, "has not yet been accepted widely by the full population."
Sitting around their kitchen table in Skarpnack, a Stockholm suburb, Barry Andersson and his wife, Majvor Hansson, said the change that would be most widely felt -- the $ 17-a-month reduction in child benefit payments -- would not dent their comfortable middle-class life, even though they had two children.
"It's only because we've had such good times in Sweden that these small problems sometimes seem very big," Ms. Hansson said.
Mr. Andersson, a chimney sweep, and Ms. Hansson, who works in a psychiatric clinic, said they were confident that the Social Democrats would try to keep the social welfare system intact. They expressed a vague unease that Sweden might be lurching toward much bigger changes, but they made clear that they still expected a lot from their Government.
Mr. Andersson said he wished the Government would do more to reduce unemployment. Ms. Hansson said she wished the Government would come up with a program so that someone who was unemployed could take her job and she could take a year or two off -- with pay.

GRAPHIC: Photo: State cuts in Sweden coincide with a leap in the jobless rate to 13 percent. Women hunted for work at a job center in Stockholm. (Charlie Dreustam for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE RAISES ITS RATES 7TH TIME IN A YEAR

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve pushed up short-term interest rates today for the seventh time since last February, when it set out to tighten credit and smother any resurgence of inflation.
The Federal Reserve increased by a half-point two important short-term lending rates it controls, placing its key lever over the economy at 6 percent, double the level of a year ago. 
 The action prompted major banks to follow suit immediately, causing borrowing costs to rise for millions of Americans. Banks raised their prime lending rates, which serve as a benchmark for various consumer and business loans, by a similar one-half point, to 9 percent. A year ago, the prime rate at most banks was 6 percent.
Many home equity and credit card loans are tied to the prime, as are certain business loans, especially for small- and medium-sized companies. Adjustable-rate mortgages, which are affected by changes in short-term rates, are also likely to go up.
The Federal Reserve acted, it said, because its yearlong effort to restrain the economy by raising interest rates had so far produced only tentative signs of a moderation in growth. While it usually takes at least six to nine months for any rate increase to work its way through the economy, Federal Reserve officials have repeatedly expressed surprise at the strength of the economy over the year. Worried that unrestrained growth may set off another wave of inflation, they have lifted rates in a step-by-step fashion in hopes of slowing the economy without killing off the expansion.
The Clinton Administration once again declined to criticize the Federal Reserve for raising rates. But various business officials and members of Congress of both parties lashed out at the largely independent agency, saying it was unnecessarily risking overkill that could bring on a recession.
"We're getting to the point where we're going to push this economy right over the brink," said Martin A. Regalia, chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat, said in a speech on the floor of the Senate that officials bankers at the Federal Reserve "ought to have their collective heads examined" for tilting so hard at "imaginary" inflation.
But House Speaker Newt Gingrich, a Republican, defended the Federal Reserve's action as necessary to minimize inflation and protect the value of the dollar. "We don't want to go back to having the kind of inflation we had in the late 70's," Mr. Gingrich told reporters.
Financial markets, getting the half-point increase that was generally expected, took the move largely in stride. Bond prices and the dollar weakened somewhat as traders moved to take some of their profits and the stock market shed most of its early gains.
There are some signs that the economy is finally beginning to respond to the credit tightening, but the central bank, private analysts said, seemed to leave open the possibility of at least one more increase, perhaps in May. The timing of any further rate increase, if it comes, is likely to depend on how soon a slowdown in the economy becomes unmistakably clear. In a statement today, the Federal Reserve noted that indicators of inflationary pressure -- like low unemployment rates and factories operating at close to their limits -- remained at potentially dangerous levels.
In its statement, the Federal Reserve said that "despite tentative signs of some moderation in growth, economic activity has continued to advance at a substantial pace while resource utilization has risen further. In these circumstances, the Federal Reserve views these actions as necessary to keep inflation contained and thereby foster sustainable economic growth."
The board of governors voted to raise the discount rate, a mostly symbolic rate used for emergency borrowing by banks, to 5 1/4 percent from 4 3/4 percent. The vote was 7 to 0, meaning that both Clinton appointees concurred.
More importantly, the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee agreed that this rise should be fully reflected in the rate banks pay when they borrow from each other for very short periods. This rate, known as the Federal funds rate, climbed to 6 percent from 5 1/2 percent, leaving it exactly double what it was a year ago.
Echoing the Federal Reserve, the Minneapolis-based Norwest bank led the parade of banks that raised the prime rate, followed by Chase Manhattan, Citicorp, BankAmerica and others.
While many politicians and business people lamented the continued rise in rates, which is just beginning to take a toll on housing and on the auto industry, economists tended to side with the Federal Reserve in their assessment of the economy and the inflation risks it posed.
"They responded to the fact that the economy is growing too fast for its own good," said John R. Williams, chief economist at the Bankers Trust Company. "My guess is that there's one more tightening yet to come."
The Clinton Administration's response came in a joint statement by Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
"The Administration respects the independence of the Federal Reserve and neither endorses nor criticizes its actions," the statement said.
The Federal Reserve's task, as it sees it, is to bring the economy's growth rate, which was at a 4 1/2 percent annual pace in the final three months of 1994, down to the 2 1/2 percent or so that can be sustained without putting upward pressure on prices. Ideally, it would like to help glide the economy to a "soft landing." But Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has said he would prefer to err by tightening credit too much rather than too little and thereby unleashing inflation.
The Federal Reserve, however, is finding it harder to justify rate increases to opponents, who are pointing to employment costs that are showing their skimpiest increases on record and consumer inflation under 3 percent for three straight years, the best record in three decades.
Moreover, the evidence that growth is slackening, though certainly not yet conclusive, is mounting daily. Some automobile plants have temporarily shut down, homebuilders report poor customer traffic, inventories of unsold goods have risen sharply for three straight quarters and huge increases in installment debt suggest consumers have become financially stretched.
Since raising rates last year in February, March, April and May, the Open Market Committee has followed a pattern of making subsequent increases only after intervening sessions at which no action is announced. It thus raised rates in August, November and February, skipping July, September and December. If the central bank continues to follow that pattern, there would be no increase at the March 28 meeting, delaying another increase, if that proves necessary, to May.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: WASHINGTON;
Rescue: Durable Or Brief?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton's move to sidestep Congress and order emergency credits to Mexico halted a monthlong run on the peso, but it left Congressional critics and reluctant American supporters worrying that the bailout's success would prove temporary.
A debate over the solidity of the plan arose today as the International Monetary Fund met into the night in Washington and finally approved an emergency $17.8 billion in medium-term loans. 
 Officials said the money would be available immediately to help the Mexican Government keep from defaulting on $40 billion in bonds and other liabilities that come due this year. Approval came dispite bitter complaints by Germany and France that they had not been consulted by the White House and that the money might come out of aid to Eastern Europe and Russia.
On Capitol Hill, opponents of any American involvement in Mexico's bailout threatened hearings, focusing on what the Administration knew about Mexico's distress last year and how President Clinton diverted $20 billion in Treasury Department funds -- intended to stabilize the dollar on world markets -- to provide Mexico with emergency loans.
Not surprisingly, some of the harshest criticism came from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist and the leader of the effort to kill any aid to Mexico.
"The looting of America, on behalf of the new world order, has begun," said Mr. Buchanan, who also opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada a year ago. "Never again should a President be allowed to disregard the will of Congress to raid the U.S. Treasury to bail out Wall Street banks or a foreign regime."
Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican and an expected contender for his party's nomination for President in 1996, said Mr. Clinton was "filling a bucket that is full of holes."
But the President's action was defended by an unlikely ally: Newt Gingrich, the Speaker of the Republican-controlled House of Representatives.
"The President exercised his authority," Mr. Gingrich said today. "He took a tremendous burden on his shoulders. He did what key leaders felt was necessary.
"I think people at a minimum should recognize the President had the courage to do what he was being told by the very sophisticated experts was vital to reinforce international markets."
To sell the President's action, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin assured skeptical Republicans and Democrats on Capitol Hill that Mexico had agreed to fundamental economic reforms and would be held to those commitments.
The reforms, spelled out in a letter from Mexican officials to the I.M.F. last week, include a more independent central bank, controls on credit expansion, continued privatization of Government-owned industry and relaxation of many of economic controls, including prohibitions on foreign investment in Mexican banks.
But Treasury officials acknowledged today that while they had talked about the loan conditions in general terms with Mexico, there was nothing on paper. Already the conditions are being described in Mexico in far more lenient terms than they are in Washington.
For the American economy, the most important question is whether the bailout strengthens the peso. Its current level makes American goods 35 percent more expensive in Mexico than they were in December, and Mexican goods that much cheaper in the United States.
The current rate also seems to many economists to be likely to encourage far more illegal immigration across the border as Mexicans seek jobs that pay in dollars.
Mr. Clinton offered one of his most impassioned defenses of his action on Tuesday night in Boston.
"I know the surveys say that by 80 to 15, or whatever they said, the American people either didn't agree or didn't understand what in the world I'm up to in Mexico," he declared. "But I want to say to you, it might be unpopular, but in a time of transition it's the right thing to do."
Some of the harshest criticism of the Administration's action today came from European capitals, which were taken by surprise by the International Monetary Fund's decision -- under strong pressure from the White House -- to add $10 billion in aid to Mexico. That is in addition the $7.8 billion that the I.M.F. approved last week.
An I.M.F. official in Washington said some European governments were concerned that the fund's remaining resources might not be enough to deal with crises in other parts of the world.

HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUE PLAN: THE RATIONALE;
Two Views of the Peso Bailout: Wall Street vs. Main Street

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
If Washington won't bail out Orange County, why should the taxpayers risk billions on Mexico? If American communities, not to mention corporations with thousands of employees, must look to their own devices in a financial crunch, why are foreigners being held to a lesser standard?
President Clinton didn't have the answers, forcing the Administration to abandon a program of loan guarantees needing Congressional approval for a hastily pulled together package for Mexico totaling nearly $50 billion from international lenders and an obscure United States Treasury account. Indeed, the sense that the original rescue package was a bailout for Wall Street -- an unavoidable side-effect of restoring the health of the Mexican economy -- is what turned Main Street against it. 
 But many economists have no difficulty justifying the difference in treatment.
"What's needed in both cases," argues Barry Eichengreen, an economist at the University of California, "is help in preventing a financial crisis from spreading into the productive economy." And Orange County, unlike Mexico, can make use of Federal bankruptcy laws to minimize the impact on jobs and output.
The more troubling question from economists' view is why the bailout rationale for Mexico is not more broadly applied. "If Mexico, why not Russia or Ukraine?" asks Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard University.
Paring the story to basics, Orange County speculated that interest rates would not go up, in hopes of earning more than the three or four percent available in much less risky investments. When its highly leveraged bets in the Government securities markets went sour, the county's investment fund found itself $1.7 billion in the hole.
Once the county declared bankruptcy, though, creditors could not shut off the electricity or repossess the fire trucks. The courts will assure that essential services are delivered until the county figures out a way to refinance its debts at less than extortionate rates.
Mexico's financial sins, by contrast, were more ambiguous, while its safety net was gossamer-thin.
The Mexican Government, along with private banks and many businesses, borrowed tens of billions of dollars abroad in order to finance the economy's rapid modernization without reducing Mexican living standards in the interim. When lenders' confidence waned last year, the Government quickly exhausted a $25 billion war chest amassed to defend the exchange rate of the peso. What's more, as Miguel Mancera, the Governor of Mexico's central bank, conceded on Tuesday, the Government made the problem worse by expanding local credit last fall to offset the squeeze created by the rush to exchange pesos for dollars.
By every possible measure Mexico's assets far exceed its liabilities to foreigners. The problem, at least until the rescue package was stitched together, is that Mexico doesn't have liquid assets to pay off debts linked to foreign currencies.
If Mexico were an American corporation (or a county in California), it could declare bankruptcy and maintain business almost as usual. It could even borrow at reasonable interest rates to pay for essential goods. With the court's permission, a bankrupt enterprise can attract money by assigning a new creditor priority over the old ones.
But there is no equivalent to bankruptcy for nations, no off-the-shelf method for sorting out the competing claims of creditors in the midst of a panic. And without help from foreign governments, Mr. Eichengreen notes that Mexico would have faced some wretched choices when the latest wave of its short-term bonds, called tesobonos, became due for payment.
The Government might have refinanced its foreign debts at 20 to 30 percent interest rates -- rates demanded by lenders to compensate for the risk of default. The interest charges, however, would have pushed the Government budget deeply into deficit, reinforcing the sense that Mexico was trapped on a downward financial spiral. As important, argues Mr. Eichengreen, "it would have led to a meltdown of the private banking system," as big borrowers were unable to raise the cash to meet payments on their loans. No business, after all, could afford to pay such rates.
The more likely alternative, suggests Mr. Eichengreen, was a Government default on its foreign debt. Judging from Mexico's 1982 experience with default, however, that would have blocked the country's access to fresh foreign capital for many years and pushed the economy into depression.
It is an open (and now moot) question whether other Latin American economies struggling to remake themselves in the free market image -- notably Argentina -- would have followed as foreign investors rushed for the safety of American dollars or German marks. That, however, is certainly what happened in the 1980's and what was widely expected before yesterday. "The Mexico crisis brings home the interdependence with a vengeance," argues Robert Hormats, a former Treasury official who is vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
In the best of plausible worlds, the mere availability of $50 billion from the United States Treasury, the International Monetary Fund and the Bank for International Settlements will make it unnecessary to use. The Mexican Government will seize the opportunity to stabilize the peso at an exchange rate that everyone agrees makes Mexican goods a bargain on world markets. And it will do what is necessary to prevent the higher cost of imported goods from triggering inflation.
Private lenders will, hopefully, respond by trading in their short-term Mexican securities tied to the dollar for longer maturity obligations at reasonable interest rates. New foreign capital, tempted by the enduring opportunities to profit in Mexico's virgin markets, will flow in -- though not in the torrent experienced in the early 1990's. And while some domestic banks and businesses will still fail, the crisis will be contained.
"With any luck," predicts Mr. Sachs, "Mexico will have one terrible year" followed by a return to a stable growth path.
What frustrates some economists is not that Mexico has been thrown a lifeline, but that other emerging free market economies have not been accorded equal treatment. It is no secret that American investors and exporters with big stakes in Mexico pressed Washington to intervene. Many other countries, however, have not been so lucky.
Chile, a shining example of a successful transition economy (though, admittedly, not a democratic one), was left to its own devices in its 1981 currency crisis. It took years to repair the damage. More recently -- and far more importantly -- Russia was denied access to funds needed to stabilize the ruble and embark on the long hard climb to capitalism.
Mr. Sachs notes that both Macy's and Russia suspended payments on their debts in January 1992. Three weeks later Macy's was able to arrange a $600 million transfusion from commercial banks -- so-called "debtor in possession" financing guaranteed by the bankruptcy court in order to keep fresh goods on the shelves.
By contrast, it took Russia a year to negotiate a "standstill" agreement with its foreign government creditors, and another year to see even modest amounts of fresh capital from multinational lenders.
The window of opportunity for using foreign capital to stabilize the ruble may have closed. But the drama may soon be repeated in Ukraine, which has a new government eager to join the community of open market economies. And while money may yet be forthcoming from multinational lenders, there has been no rush to help.
Why the deliberate pace? "No investment banker's Christmas bonus ever depended on Russia's financial stability," argues Mr. Sachs. Nor, presumably, will it depend on the taming of inflation in Ukraine.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
I'll Sleep on the Idea, But Must I Vote on It?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The best thing about President Clinton's new plan to rescue the Mexican economy, Senator Bob Dole said on Tuesday, is that Congress will not have to vote on the matter.
Mr. Dole, the Senate Republican leader, was only half joking. Senators and representatives are always looking for ways to avoid casting votes that can be used against them in their next election. 
 That is why the sponsors of the constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget are insisting on language that would mandate roll-call votes in the House and the Senate before taxes or the ceiling on the Federal debt could be increased.
"We want to make sure that people stand up and get counted if they want to raise taxes," said Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho, a chief Republican strategist on the issue.
Over the years, Congress has devised countless techniques to enable its members to dodge tough votes. For instance:
*A commission was created to decide which military bases to close so that Congress would not face the pain of voting on them base by base.
*Under procedures adopted a few years ago, the House automatically agrees to raise the statutory ceiling on the Federal debt when it approves its annual budget resolution. That avoids what used to be an embarrassing debate and vote that forced representatives to address directly how large the debt had become.
*Under a 1989 law, lawmakers are entitled every year to a cost-of-living pay increase. The notion was that they would no longer have to vote one for themselves. Unfortunately for them, this sidestep has failed the last two years. One lawmaker or another has suggested declining the raise, and his colleagues have accepted pay frozen at $133,600 a year rather than vote on the matter.
*The House considers the appropriations bill providing money to run Congress under procedures that allow only designated amendments. That means dicey topics like money to finance the Congressional franking privilege are not subjected to votes.
The desire to avoid votes is most intense when tax increases are at stake.
In the Senate, tax issues are often settled by votes to table legislation. "Table" is just another word for "kill."
For example, in the 1993 debate over Mr. Clinton's deficit-reduction plan, Republicans offered amendments that would have eliminated provisions to raise the tax on gasoline and increase the proportion of Social Security benefits subject to income taxes.
Those tax increases were central to the Clinton plan. Most Democrats supported them. But a direct vote was viewed as politically costly. So the Democrats, then in the majority, quashed the amendments by voting to table them. That made it appear as if they were voting on a procedural matter, not specifically on raising taxes on motorists and the elderly.
In the House, tax bills are always considered under what are called closed rules. That means no amendments, or only specified amendments, are allowed.
Ostensibly, the reason for the closed rules is that the tax code is so complicated that representatives cannot possibly understand the consequences of amendments they might offer. There is some truth to that.
But the more basic reason is that closed rules protect lawmakers from having to decide between good politics and good tax policy. This way, when a lobbyist with deep pockets asks a Congressman for a tax break, the Congressman can plead that he is helpless in the face of the rules.
The balanced-budget amendment that was passed by the House last week and is now before the Senate would require a three-fifths majority of each house before the Federal debt ceiling could be increased, and would also require what is called a constitutional, or absolute, majority to raise taxes. This means 60 votes in the Senate and 261 in the House to raise the debt ceiling, and 51 votes in the Senate and 218 in the House to raise taxes, regardless of how many members are present and voting.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, objected to those provisions. "Senators who don't even show up to vote have the same power to affect the outcome as if they were present to cast a 'no' vote," he said. He said he did not understand why a tax measure should require more votes than a declaration of war, which requires only a majority of those present and voting -- a so-called simple majority, frequently declared on the basis of a voice vote.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, who is leading the Republican drive for the amendment in the Senate, explained the rationale this way: "Right now, many times when we increase the deficit in this country, we do not vote at all. We just have a voice vote. Nobody knows who are the people that have put us into debt or put us into further debt. From here on in, in both cases, that of increasing the debt or increasing taxes, we are going to have roll-call votes."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senators Jon Kyl of Arizona, Fred Thompson of Tennessee and Olympia J. Snowe of Maine appeared at a news conference yesterday to discuss the balanced-budget amendment. If they and other Republicans have their way, roll-call votes will one day be required in both the House and the Senate to raise taxes or the debt ceiling. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Battling the Contract, Gephardt Offers a Code

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Searching for a political counterweight to the Republicans' Contract With America, the House minority leader today unveiled a new economic strategy for his party: what he called a Best Practices Code of Conduct for American business, an approach that focuses on promoting the well-being of middle-income workers.
"For Democrats, the single, simple, fundamental task of our party -- in this Congress, in this decade, in this generation -- is to fight for the standard of living of working families and the middle class," the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said in a speech to the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal group of economic policy experts. "Everything else is secondary to that goal." 
 Mr. Gephardt and other House Democrats promoted his speech as the opening salvo in their efforts to regain control of Congress and win back support of the voters. But there appeared to be another purpose as well: to demonstrate to the White House, which received no advance notice of the talk, that Congressional Democrats were prepared to reach out to the electorate on their own rather than invariably follow the Administration's lead.
Mr. Gephardt's message was short on details, which he promised would be laid out in the coming weeks and months, but long on criticism of the Republicans and their Contract, which he called "a nice academic exercise" but "irrelevant."
"Republicans think it's better to just give the middle class a psychic punching bag," Mr. Gephardt said, "to let them vent all their anger and frustration on government and politicians, to let them lash out at those who have the least and need the most, even if that does nothing to actually improve their lives."
At the heart of the new Democratic economic strategy is the championing of causes like a substantial increase in the minimum wage, now $4.25 an hour; a health care overhaul; a middle-class tax cut, and President Clinton's Middle Class Bill of Rights, which includes calls for expanded individual retirement arrangements and tax breaks to help Americans pay for education.
Mr. Gephardt called on American business to get behind the new Democratic program.
"We can't force the business community to put people first, even though it's right both morally and economically," he said. "But we can condition any tax break to business on the adoption of the Best Practices Code of Conduct -- not just in America, but wherever our companies do business. We can condition the adoption of every single trade agreement" on the other nation's "adoption of the Code of Conduct or a similar commitment to their working people."
At another point, Mr. Gephardt said he would propose legislation to create "a brand-new class of stock that can be issued by companies that follow the Code of Conduct, so that individual investors can build a Best Practices portfolio so that they have a way to get involved, to help build a stronger economy for all of us."
As with most of the ideas he advanced in his speech, Mr. Gephardt did not elaborate on this one. And his spokeswoman, Laura Nichols, said later that she was not sufficiently familiar with it to answer questions.
Mr. Gephardt's talk had the flavor more of a stump speech than of a party policy statement.
"For several years now," he said at one point, "I've traveled this country, meeting with the C.E.O.'s and managers, the programmers and line workers, the salespeople and secretaries, who are making these companies succeed when so many others are falling behind."
Some of the 100 people in attendance seized on references like that one. Indeed, a brief question-and-answer session after the speech produced an awkward moment for the Congressional leader when one person in the audience asked, "Shouldn't you be running for President?"
"I'm happy to be minority leader and hoping to be the majority leader or Speaker," replied Mr. Gephardt, who has sometimes been mentioned as a possible rival to Mr. Clinton for the 1996 Democratic Presidential nomination.
Mr. Gephardt's spokeswoman, Ms. Nichols, said the Code of Conduct was a Democratic Congressional initiative that had been drawn up without help from the Administration. But she said it paralleled the President's New Covenant.
Ms. Nichols also said Mr. Gephardt had scheduled a series of speeches across the country over the next few months to promote the new economic strategy and to try to stir grass-roots support before introducing any legislation in the House.
A White House spokeswoman said that the Administration had had no advance knowledge of Mr. Gephardt's new initiative but that his efforts were welcome.
"As he talked about in the State of the Union, the President thinks that the American public has sent a message that they expect more of their Government," said the spokeswoman, Ginny Terzano. "I think what Congressman Gephardt addressed today is much of the same issues."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard A. Gephardt, House minority leader, offering a new Democratic economic strategy in a speech to the Economic Policy Institute. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Sincerity Cannot Tell The Future

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
THE Governor of New York is earnest and friendly as he sits in his office minutes after proposing his budget. Speaking in that reedy voice of his about reviving the work ethic and encouraging the entrepreneurial spirit and cutting taxes no matter what, he seems to suggest that that if the state would just listen to him, its problems would go away and New York could become North Carolina. Or even New Jersey.
In the new world of George E. Pataki, people on welfare will work. 
 Long-abandoned manufacturing plants will reopen.
The 400,000 jobs lost in the last decade will return.
The elderly, poor and disabled will adjust to Medicaid cuts. So will hospitals and nursing homes.
New York City's schools will cope with up to 20,000 more students and less money.
The homeless who are mentally ill will manage, despite reductions in aid for housing and community services.
Laid-off state workers will find new jobs.
THIS partial list is not offered with sarcasm. It is meant as a genuine reflection of the Governor's philosophy of government. He reiterated today what he said during the campaign -- that cutting taxes and government regulations will make the state more competitive, which will make it more attractive to businesses, which will lead them to stay in New York rather than leave, or even move back, which would stimulate the economy, which would benefit everybody.
Mr. Pataki sounds so sold on his philosophy that he might well have proposed the same budget even if New York were thriving. "It is driven by policy," he said of his plan. "There are very important policy changes I think we need in this state. We've been noncompetitive for a long time."
But is it so sure that if the Governor says it, it will happen? Does government ever work in so neat a fashion?
Maybe it will, but it never has before. Policy changes in government work in fits and starts, and rarely in the way their authors said they would. That is probably especially true for these cuts, which weigh so heavily on the people who need government the most. By the Pataki administration's own accounting, 40 percent of its proposed cuts are in social services -- in Medicaid, welfare, in services for the mentally ill and the drug- and alcohol-addicted.
"The question is, where is he creating jobs in the public sector for these people to be employed?" asked Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, wondering about the jobs that those on welfare are supposed to get if the Governor's proposal for workfare wins legislative approval.
MR. SILVER, Democrat of Manhattan, might be expected to sound the alarm. He is, after all, the loyal opposition. But Mr. Pataki's own Social Services Commissioner, Mary E. Glass, voiced concerns of her own about the proposed welfare cuts in a lengthy letter to the Budget Director that was never meant to go public. It was leaked, though, and now Ms. Glass claims that Mr. Pataki has made changes enough to satisfy her.
A reading of her letter would suggest otherwise. She worried, for instance, that a 15 percent decrease in the basic grant for those who receive Aid to Families With Dependent Children could increase the number of the homeless. The decrease is still in the plan, and while the proposal to increase the amount a welfare recipient could earn without losing benefits might soften the impact, it is difficult to assume it will make up for it entirely.
"I cannot in all honesty say people will not be negatively impacted by this budget," says the Governor. But many people are hurting now, he noted, citing the lives of poor children in Harlem that were portrayed in New York Times articles that ran during last fall's campaign. "Are those people doing well?" he asked.
The question is rhetorical; of course they are not. The central issue confronting New York on the day Mr. Pataki has released his budget is more complex. It is whether government is really the enemy, and whether policies that affect people living on the edge of society will pull them back, or push them over.

HEADLINE: A Rose or a Thorn for East Harlem?;
Sentiment Is Divided Over a Proposal for a Huge Supermarket

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
To the residents of East Harlem, the announcement last September that a nonprofit development corporation had raised millions of dollars to help build a giant Pathmark supermarket on 125th Street was the answer to years of prayers.
Like people in countless communities with large minority populations in the city and across the country, they had watched as the chain stores shunned their neighborhood and consigned them to shopping in smaller stores, often with higher prices and inferior merchandise. 
 But now, with a final vote on the project only a few weeks away, the plan has run into aggressive opposition from local merchants and divided the community along ethnic and cultural lines, pitting Hispanic bodega owners who worry about the competition against black residents who see the new supermarket as a source for jobs.
Under the plans, a consortium of nonprofit developers would buy a block of city-owned land on 125th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues and use $12 million they have raised to build a store.
Pathmark has promised to take a long-term lease on the store and employ about 200 local residents. But the East Harlem store owners say the project would ultimately cost more jobs than it created, as smaller markets wither. They object to the size of the proposed supermarket, which at 53,000 square feet would be about the size of a football field, as well as the tax breaks Pathmark would get for creating jobs in the newly designated Federal Empowerment Zone.
"A 20,000-square-foot Pathmark would be O.K., even though it would be twice the size of any supermarket in the area," said Alfredo Rodriguez, who owns two Associated Foods stores in East Harlem. "Competition is fine, but the subsidies they are getting make it unfair competition."
Pathmark has said it is not interested in opening a smaller market, and many residents say they welcome a store on the scale the developers are planning. Proponents say that the large store is desperately needed and that it will draw shoppers and other retailers to the area.
"Why should we stop the project just because there's a few business people who want to have it scaled down for their own purposes?" said Ronald Thompson, chairman of the economic development committee of Community Board 11, which includes 125th Street. "It could revitalize not only 125th Street, but the whole East Harlem area."
The 45-member community board is divided along ethnic and cultural lines over the project, with black supporters in a narrow majority. Many market owners are Dominican and are joined by other Hispanic residents in charging that the black leaders on the development team are excluding them.
In turn, blacks complain about Hispanic store owners' hiring practices. "The supermarkets that we have now do not hire African-American employees, and East Harlem is 39 percent African-American," Mr. Thompson said. "There's a lot of bad feelings over that."
Hispanic people make up 53 percent of the district, which runs from 96th Street to 142d Street, east of Fifth Avenue.
But not everyone is lining up by race or ethnicity. Eddie Baca, the chairman of Community Board 11, who is Hispanic and Pathmark's main supporter, said that only a handful of family-run bodegas might be hurt by the supermarket, and that he is seeking city subsidies for them.
"It's basically a Dominican interest outside of East Harlem that is behind the opposition campaign," he said. "Their concern is that they think this is an African-American project. They are just hiding behind this issue about the size."
Although the main developer of the project is the Abyssinian Development Corporation, an arm of one of the city's most prominent black churches, the Abyssinian Baptist Church, Mr. Baca contended that everyone in the neighborhood would benefit from it.
For instance, he said, a Puerto Rican development group is trying to build 100 units of housing on the second floor of the Pathmark store.
The champion of the small merchants is Councilman Adam Clayton Powell 4th, whose political base lies with the Hispanic residents of East Harlem and who contends that the tug-of-war is solely economic rather than ethnic or cultural.
"It is not fair," Mr. Powell said, "for this huge, multibillion-dollar institution to come in with our taxpayer dollars and destroy businesses that have been passed on for generations and generations."
Despite the heat, the project, which has been stalled in the past by changes in sponsorship, has been moving forward steadily. Last September, the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a community development group started by the Ford Foundation, announced that it had raised $24 million to help finance the Pathmark store and others like it in inner-city neighborhoods across the country.
About $4 million was earmarked for the Harlem project, giving it a significant boost.
Fine points of the $12 million deal are being negotiated as planners await a vote, most likely in March, by the Manhattan Borough Board, which must approve the sale of city land to the developers.
The board consists of Manhattan's 10 City Council members, the chairman of the affected community board -- in this case Mr. Baca -- and Borough President Ruth W. Messinger, who is the chairwoman of the board and supports the project but will vote only in case of a tie.
Most of the 10 City Council members say they are still undecided. But three of them -- Mr. Powell, Guillermo Linares and Antonio Pagan -- publicly oppose the project and are trying to coax colleagues to reject it.
Councilmen Linares and Pagan said they had bad experiences when Pathmark moved to their districts. "What it did in the beginning," said Mr. Pagan, who represents the Lower East Side, "was out-compete everyone else, run out of business all the small stores and then, after monopolizing the market, has run a noncompetitive operation. Everyone was expecting Shangri-La."
But Burt P. Flickinger 3d, an analyst who follows supermarkets for A.T. Kearney Consultants, said the Pathmark stores in Washington Heights and on the Lower East Side had raised the standard of living in those areas. Complaints and fears from smaller store owners, he said, were "overstated."
"When New York City first asked Pathmark to move into the Washington Heights section, a lot of the small markets and bodega owners screamed with determination and passion," Mr. Flickinger said. "But 15 years later, Pathmark's huge superstore on West 207th Street coexists extremely well with all of the Hispanic bodegas in that neighborhood."
Still, the approval by Council members appears far from certain. Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields said she gets frequent telephone calls from Housing Authority tenants who want the new supermarket. She supports the project but said she is "open to listening to all sides."
As the vote nears, both sides are stepping up their lobbying efforts. The Harlem opponents and their hired consultant plan to appeal to each council member in person.
Mr. Baca said the community board would hold a reception for the Council members and make a presentation in Pathmark's favor, and other sponsor groups, including the Local Initiatives Support Corporation and the city's Economic Development Corporation, are also working to promote the deal.
If it passes, the project will still need the approval of Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani. If it is built, the supermarket will be the largest in upper Manhattan and will include a pharmacy, flower shop and delicatessen.
"This will be a regional shopping center, offering the same type of shopping that people in suburban communities have," said Karen Phillips, project manager for the Abyssinian Development Corporation. "We think that is exactly what Harlem residents deserve."

HEADLINE: It's One Strike and You're Out in Florida

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORT MYERS, Fla., Feb. 1

 BODY:
After its grand opening this week, the Shooters restaurant here was counting on baseball's exhibition season for a marketing blitz. Among the plans: ticket giveaways, visits from big-name players, advertisements flown over two gleaming stadiums.
Now, with the baseball strike threatening spring training, which is supposed to start in the third week of this month, the restaurant has started looking into a fishing motif. 
 "The emotional loss is the real loss," the owner, Robert Cox, says of a winter without major league baseball. "Spring training is an event. It's a lot of fun. It cultivates interest and excitement."
For Florida cities like Fort Myers, where the Boston Red Sox and the Minnesota Twins are based, the exhibition games also mean thousands of tourists in roughly six precious weeks. Local officials estimate the two teams bring in about $28 million each year.
But at a time when this city on Florida's west coast would be preparing to welcome three times as many visitors as its population of 50,000, it does not know whether to expect relief or disaster. The strike negotiations resumed today, with both sides trying to avoid a Government-imposed settlement. President Clinton has set next Monday as a deadline for the two sides to show some progress in the talks.
Twenty of the 28 major league teams train in Florida, and state officials say the season brings $315 million to the economy a year, mostly on lodging, food, transportation and other spending by fans, the teams and journalists, among others. A cancellation would mean damage "not unlike that of a natural disaster," Gov. Lawton Chiles told President Clinton in a letter urging him to help settle the strike.
In Arizona, where the rest of the teams train, state officials say the season brings in $265 million a year.
In spring training cities there is hope that at the very least the season will go on with replacement players and still attract fans. The Red Sox and the Twins are already planning to hold tryouts in Fort Myers for minor league players and former baseball players.
But the uncertainty has had an effect. One tour operator, Major League Vacations Inc. in Philadelphia, which handles only sports-related packages, says travel from the Northeast to Florida is down 40 percent. Most stadiums are reporting a 10 percent to 20 percent drop in ticket sales, said Mayor Wilbur Smith of Fort Myers, who as head of a baseball task force for the United States Conference of Mayors is sitting in on the strike negotiations.
Some cities -- like Melbourne, where the Florida Marlins train -- would lose less than others because the team, not the city, gets the stadium revenue, according to a survey last November by the United States Conference of Mayors.
Cities like Fort Lauderdale, where the New York Yankees train, say that local businesses would not be hurt because other attractions in the area draw tourists.
But some cities, like West Palm Beach, said they stood to lose more than $1 million a game in tickets and concessions, taxes and local business revenues, the survey found.
For the most part, spring training has been used by small towns, like Lakeland and Dunedin, to woo tourists who would otherwise go to more popular destinations, like Orlando and Miami. Officials say the teams, playing in the Grapefruit League in Florida and the Cactus League in Arizona, have attracted tourists, residents and businesses.
With prestige and development at stake, the cities have spent millions to steal teams from one other, often offering state-of-the-art stadiums at low rents and relinquishing revenue from ticket sales, concessions, parking and paid advertising in favorable deals for the teams. Since the 1920's, Fort Myers has been host to six different teams.
In 1987, Lee County officials let the Kansas City Royals leave Fort Myers, the county seat, for Haines City near Disney World after refusing to make $1.5 million worth of renovations to a stadium. In 1991 they paid $22 million for a new 80-acre Lee County Sports Complex, including an 8,500-seat stadium, to lure the Twins from Orlando.
Two years ago, Fort Myers wooed the Red Sox from Winter Haven with a $24 million 7,000-seat stadium, City of Palms Park, built with money raised by a bond issue. It pays $1.7 million a year on the debt; it gets $210,000 in rent from the Red Sox, $110,000 through a ticket surcharge and $50,000 in parking fees.
It will not break even for 10 years, Mayor Smith said.
But the two teams draw 200,000 fans to mostly sold-out games for the season, among the highest attendance among all teams. Mayor Smith said the publicity the Red Sox generate -- their games are televised in New England -- attracts snowbirds to Fort Myers. He also credits the team with sparking the construction or renovation of three major hotels and a high-rise condominium.
Now, with the season in question, many here say they expect minimal impact because there is already a market of visitors who come as much for baseball as for the beaches and warm weather. Some business owners note that many fans would not care if replacements are used because it is baseball that they miss.
"There are only two or three stars on a team; the rest are just ballplayers," said Michael Potts, of Potts' Sports Cafe near the Twins' stadium. "They can get a lot of new stars."
At the City of Palms Park today, ticket sales were so slow, said Bill MacKay, the director of Florida operations for the Red Sox, that the team was considering cutting ticket prices -- $9 for box seats, $8 for reserved seats -- in half.
The first game is scheduled for March 3, against the Twins.
At the box office, three workers languished behind the glass windows. Philip Cox, 71, a retiree from Indianapolis, was the lone ticket buyer in almost an hour. He said he had come to Fort Myers for the last three years for baseball and the weather. He bought tickets for a game scheduled for March 27, although it was not certain that the Red Sox or their opponent, the Baltimore Orioles, would show up.
He said he would hold off on more ticket purchases. "I'm really disgusted with the players and the owners for not settling it," he said. "It's ridiculous, these multimillion-dollar crybabies."

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Russian Army Violated Human Rights in Chechnya

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Administration accused Russia today of human rights abuses, saying Moscow had violated international agreements when it sent troops into Chechnya, the secessionist republic, to attack civilians.
It also accused Russia of making arbitrary arrests, beating prisoners and allowing military recruits to be abused in systematic hazing. 
 In the State Department's annual human rights report, the Administration cited statements by Russia's own rights commissioner citing violations on a "massive scale" in Chechnya.
The report criticized Moscow for carrying out air strikes that killed and injured hundreds of civilians and destroyed most buildings in Grozny, the capital, including hospitals and an orphanage.
Assessing human rights in more than 160 countries, the State Department reserved its harshest criticism for perennial adversaries, including Iraq, Iran, Cuba and North Korea.
The department said Iraq had amputated ears and branded foreheads of criminals, and had tortured people to death.
The report also had tough words for nations friendly to the United States, including Mexico, Egypt, Guatemala, Indonesia and Turkey.
Just a day after President Clinton announced almost $50 billion to rescue Mexico's economy, the report used stinging language to assail electoral fraud in Mexico, killings by the police, widespread torture and discrimination against indigenous people. In particular, the report cited abuses by the military in countering a peasant uprising in Chiapas.
The report praised Mexico for setting up a commission for human rights, but said, "By year's end however, it had tried and punished few human rights abusers, and abuses remained widespread."
Administration officials say they hoped the report would put some pressure on Russia, Mexico and other nations, though such reports have rarely succeeded in doing that since the department began publishing them in 1977.
While praising many of the conclusions, Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, said today, "The report is honest but irrelevant, in that there has been a systematic failure to translate its observations into U.S. policy."
The State Department said China's performance had deteriorated in the year since President Clinton reversed his policy and granted China preferential trade benefits in the hope that would cause Beijing to improve human rights.
John H. F. Shattuck, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, defended this policy, saying open trade can encourage freedom by strengthening independent institutions. Still, he said, "trade relations by themselves are no substitute for vigorous human rights advocacy."
In criticizing Russia, the report focused on far more more than Chechnya. It accused President Boris N. Yeltsin of issuing decrees in conflict with constitutional rights against arbitrary arrests and illegal searches and seizures, and noted that Russian courts rarely challenge the executive. "The concept of the rule of law has yet to be institutionalized and implemented," it said.
The State Department said that Russia's law enforcement officials often beat prisoners and that prisons are overcrowded and teeming with disease. The report harshly condemned the practice of sending lesbians to hospitals where they are often given chemical treatments.
While the report praised Russia by saying there were no known political killings by agents of the Government, it noted that several journalists and legislators had been gunned down. "The line between politically motivated killings and criminal activities has become difficult to distinguish," it added.
For the first time, the State Department report reviewed the new Palestinian Authority in Jericho and Gaza, and it did not give the authority high marks.
The report levels many of the same criticisms that it has leveled at Israel, saying both the Palestinians and the Israelis imposed censorship and mistreated detainees. The report also said there were credible reports that the Palestinian police on occasion had used excessive force.

HEADLINE: Foreign Aid, in Moderation

 BODY:
Foreign aid, never very popular with Americans, is on the chopping block. It is not easy to argue the merits of Federal spending to diminish poverty, hunger and disease abroad when budget cuts mean inadequate funding for those problems at home. But some substantial benefits for the U.S. can be secured by relatively inexpensive foreign aid programs that are carefully selected and managed.
Aid that directly attacks the causes of global insecurity like poverty, disease, overpopulation and environmental degradation can prevent the sort of political instability and humanitarian disasters that ultimately require more costly American involvement. If the budget-cutters are not careful, they may shortchange aid to those who need it most and where it may do the most good. 
 Of the $12.3 billion in the current aid budget, more than half goes to programs that directly reduce risks to U.S. security -- $3 billion to Israel and $2.1 billion to Egypt to promote peace in the Middle East, and $1.2 billion to the former Soviet bloc to encourage transitions to democracy and markets. Republican leaders in Congress have pledged to sustain these efforts.
If that position prevails, most of the cuts will come from the $4.2 billion that benefits the poorest of the poor, especially in Africa, and has helped turn around countries like Zimbabwe and Botswana.
That aid is being redirected to small projects, often disbursed by development banks or non-governmental organizations, to better the lives of millions -- like immunizing children in Kenya and Honduras and introducing new agricultural techniques that may yet allow Bangladesh to feed itself. If carefully targeted, aid can help promote peaceful transitions in South Africa and Zaire.
Critics stress the low growth rates attained by aid recipients and the failure of aid to promote democratic, market-oriented development. That is hardly a surprise since in the past most aid went to prop up cold-war clients like Turkey, Greece, Pakistan and Indonesia, some of which were governed by unsavory regimes. The development objectives of that aid were overridden by security considerations -- often with the support of today's critics.
It is too soon to judge the results of more recent strategies to broaden participation in development projects that spur economic growth or educate women to reduce birth rates. That suggests the need for modesty, both in the claims made for foreign aid and in the amounts allocated to it. It does not mean slashing the aid effort indiscriminately.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Cut, but Be Fair to the City

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki has crafted a budget that follows his campaign promises, but also threatens to deal punishing blows to New York City. Indeed, the Governor's cuts in state aid to the city's schools, subways and hospital and welfare programs are so sweeping that political opponents in Albany seemed stunned. Mr. Pataki needed to limit spending, of course, to close the deficit and at the same time make good on his promised tax cuts. Given the reality that he has the political strength to redistribute revenues in this way, questions of fairness -- in sharing the pain of budget reductions and the rewards of the tax breaks -- become foremost.
Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, said the $5 billion in spending reductions was "significantly, purposefully targeted at New York City." He foresaw a $100 million loss to schools, a 25- or 30-cent subway fare increase and several hundred million in losses for the Health and Hospitals Corporation. In other words, he portrays the Governor as contemplating an unfairly brutal blow to the social-services infrastructure of a city with over half of New York State's welfare population. 
 Governor Pataki, with equal force, argues that the city will not be hurt or treated unfairly. Moreover, he said, it is a budget "driven by policy." One central policy -- "changing welfare to workfare" -- is hard to argue with. So, considering his mandate, is the macroeconomic rationale behind the budget. He says that New York, a state untouched by the economic recovery of the 90's, must cut taxes on individuals and business in order to attract jobs.
The conflict between Mr. Pataki and New York City Democrats, then, will be over questions of balance and equity. The tax cuts he proposed are more progressive than one would have expected; 400,000 low-income taxpayers will be relieved altogether of state income taxes. But 50 percent of the overall benefits of the tax plan still go to people making over $100,000. That is unseemly at a time when elderly and disabled people are seeing decreases in their paltry monthly allowances.
Close analysis is needed to show if the cuts in social spending will be as hard on New York City as they appear at first glance to be. If so, city politicians have no choice but to battle for a better deal within the parameters of the Governor's generally sensible budget strategy.
This brings us up against a harsh political reality. Because New York City's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, is already in trouble with his party over the fall election, he is limited in his ability to oppose the Governor. That means a heavier responsibility for Republicans like Senator Roy Goodman and Democrats like Mr. Silver.
This is an ideological budget that threatens to shift taxes to local governments in years ahead. The city must push back to insure an even distribution of sacrifice. Governor Pataki, for his part, deserves credit for shaping a budget that is clear in its goals and true to his mandate. But in the days ahead, he and the Legislature need to review the arithmetic, keeping in mind that punishing the city will not contribute to the long-term prosperity of the state.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Singapoverty

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Never in history has there been widespread famine in a democratic country with a political opposition and a free press. Starvation by the millions takes place only under tyranny or in anarchy.
Communist Russia was decimated by famine in the 1930's; in Communist China, starvation took 30 million lives after the "great leap forward" three decades ago; in this generation, we see famine sweeping anarchic and despotic states in Africa. Contrariwise, in India -- where famine seemed inescapable under sultans, nizams and colonial rule -- no famine has struck since democracy began in 1947. 
 Why? Because rulers never go hungry. Where there is no accountability at election time, nor uncensored criticism of failure to anticipate the effects of flood and drought, a king or dictator faces no political penalty for the catastrophe that kills millions of "his" people. Democracy, on the other hand, puts in place an early warning system of the free media and a powerful political incentive to avert disaster.
This was the stunning argument put forth last weekend by Amartya Sen, the Indian philosopher who now serves as president of the American Economic Association, at a panel of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.
The topic goes to the heart of the controversy that will affect China after Deng Xiaoping dies: "Freedom and needs: Do political rights or economic basics come first?"
Hard-line Communists in Beijing, eager to capture the fruits of capitalism while denying the political freedom at its roots, point to "the Singapore model": a state that enshrines order at the expense of liberty.
Singapore's dictator, Lee Kuan Yew, justifies his repression of dissent by equating opposition with crime, turning his judicial system into black-robed enforcers of conformity. And the money flows in: He rationalizes his old-fashioned despotism by exalting the prosperity that comes with his ruthless enforcement of stability.
The dictator, who shows his contempt for modernity by anointing his son to be successor, dresses up this return to Mussolini's boast of making the trains run on time as an assertion of uniquely Asian values. His acolytes condemn as decadent a Western respect for individual dignity; they hail their leader's claim that Asian culture prefers putting "society" first, as if Asians were genetically designed to kiss the cane.
Western bankers lap up this claptrap because it seems to guarantee them a secure, business-friendly environment; they are blind to any risk of expropriation in a coup by the next Singapore strongman. Beijing big shots embrace the corporate statist model, too, because it enables their family members to use Communist Party influence to enrich themselves in the "open" market.
In the Davos meeting, the job of giving the old Fascism a fresh cultural face fell to Kishore Mahbubani, Permanent Secretary of Foreign Affairs of Singapore. "Please do not advise us what to do about the freedom of the person," he told Westerners, "and we will not advise you. Allow history to be the judge."
Nadine Strossen, the feisty new president of the American Civil Liberties Union, countered by pointing to the universality of declarations of human rights; Asian nations are signed up, too. Ominously, the Permanent Secretary replied: "All human rights covenants were created when the West was in power. In the future, these agreements will assert the rights of society over the rights of individuals."
That's what makes reversal of the verdicts of the island shopping center so important. Singapore's false message -- that human rights are a luxury that emerging nations cannot afford -- is what the faction that urged the killings of Tiananmen want to impress on 1.2 billion Chinese. Nothing should chill the free world's response to Singapore's systematic humiliations.
After the meeting, the Permanent Secretary noticed the name on my credential and cordially invited me to revisit his country. I asked what would happen if I wrote while there that the dictator's despo-nepotism was protected by a battery of power-corrupted judges.
An honest answer broke through: "You'd probably go to jail." Which is why you won't soon see this column under a Singapore dateline.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: CHINA (94%); SINGAPORE (94%); INDIA (92%); AFRICA (92%); SWITZERLAND (90%); UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Let's Look at Biases in the History Standards

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re Frank Rich's "Eating Her Offspring" (column, Jan. 26): Mr. Rich attempts to whitewash a seriously flawed document and to portray the proposed National History Standards as a "middle-of-the-road committee product." 
 Yet no impartial reader is likely to agree that the controversy over the document should be dismissed as political rhetoric. It contains far too many loaded phrases like "the old Protestant European American's sway over the diverse peoples of this nation"; loaded questions like "Why have many American cities today become 'reservations for poor people'?", and one-sided questions like "What major grievances have been advanced by spokespersons for African-Americans, Asian-Americans, Hispanic Americans and native Americans?", with no corresponding questions asking, for example, how Asian-Americans have advanced educationally and economically and the reasons for their intermarriage rates.
That so many academic historians, high school teachers and professional organizations created or approved such a biased document is the real story in this controversy. What must be insisted upon is full public discussion and approval of any proposed standards before they are handed out to educators and publishers.
 
SANDRA STOTSKY
Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 29, 1995
 
The writer, a research associate at Harvard's Graduate School of Education, is on the Committee to Review National Standards, an American Enterprise Institute project.

HEADLINE: In Russia, Another Time, Another Boris

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Strains of Chechnya War Setting Russians on Edge" (front page, Jan. 29) states that the 17th-century Time of Troubles in Russia was caused by a religious schism. 
 This assertion contains a major historical error that in turn causes missing the reason for its contemporary relevance.
In the 1660's a split over liturgical matters in the Russian Orthodox Church gave rise to the sect of Old Believers and came to be called the Great Schism.
The Time of Troubles occurred 60 years earlier and resulted from Ivan the Terrible's disastrous policies and the end of the 800-year-old Riurikid dynasty.
It was indeed, as mentioned, a time of "social and political chaos" -- economic collapse, rebellion, pretenders to the throne, foreign invasion -- and ended with the elevation of the Romanovs to the throne in 1613.
A major figure in and cause of the Time of Troubles was another Boris, Boris Godunov, and Russians are quick to make the connection with President Boris N. Yeltsin's problems -- as I discovered last year when I lectured in Moscow on the topic.
 
CYNTHIA HYLA WHITTAKER
Professor of History
Baruch College and
CUNY Graduate Center
New York, Jan. 29, 1995

HEADLINE: Let's Look at Biases in the History Standards;
Skewed Economics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Frank Rich's claim (column, Jan. 26) that the National History Standards are "middle of the road" is not sustained by a reading of their economic history. A telling example is the standard on the causes of the Great Depression, which is quite outside the contours of the debate among economic historians. 
 The Federal Reserve is not mentioned, eliminating the monetarist side of the debate. The standard setters ignore the massive joint work of the Nobel laureate Milton Friedman and Anna Schwartz, a distinguished fellow of the American Economic Association.
Moreover, the Keynesianism presented is not credited by modern Keynesians. Although various factors are mentioned, the standards' chief explanation of the Depression is what they dub the "trickle down" economics of Calvin Coolidge.
According to the standard, the 1920's unequal distribution of income and wealth somehow led to the Depression, presumably through some crude, undersconsumptionist mechanism. But as shown by Peter Temin of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a leading Keynesian historian of the Depression, this "imagined cause" could account for no more than a minuscule fraction of decline in gross domestic product.
The standard is out of step with both Keynesian and monetarist research over the last few decades. The authors' focus on distributional issues has clouded their treatment of the Depression's causes, much as it has distorted the economic history elsewhere in this imbalanced document.
 
ROBERT M. COSTRELL
Chestnut Hill, Mass., Jan. 29, 1995
 
The writer is a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts and a member of the Committee to Review National Standards.
