HEADLINE: Apache Tribe Rejects Move to Store Nuclear Waste on Reservation

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 1

 BODY:
Wendell Chino, the president of the Mescalero Apache tribe in southern New Mexico, had hoped to convince his people that their role as stewards of the earth included tending to the tons of highly radioactive nuclear waste that accumulates daily at the nation's electrical generating plants.
He spoke solemnly of "ghost bullets" -- invisible shards that were deadly if mishandled, but something that could earn millions of dollars a year if treated with respect. 
 But, finally, his people said no.
Today the votes cast in a tribal referendum on Tuesday were tabulated, and the Tribal Council announced that the Mescaleros had overturned a tentative agreement that would have allowed 33 utility companies to store thousands of tons of spent fuel rods on the reservation until the Department of Energy could find a permanent repository for the waste.
Tribal officials had estimated that the Mescaleros could earn about $ 250 million by taking on the radioactive burden for 40 years.
"Right or wrong, they made a decision," Mr. Chino said. "I don't have a problem with it. I just recognize the fact that the people have shut the door on themselves in not accepting a great opportunity."
The result came as a surprise to a community in which discord is frowned upon and following the lead of the tribal president is considered good citizenship.
Mr. Chino has been president of the tribe for three decades. Though the Mescaleros have an estimated unemployment rate as high as 36 percent, the tribe has prospered under his leadership. The Ski Apache resort and the Inn of the Mountain Gods are big money-makers.
"The Pueblos make pottery," Mr. Chino is fond of saying. "The Mescaleros make money."
The dispute over accepting the wastes divided descendants of two of the tribe's most honored leaders, Geronimo and Cochise. Silas Cochise, the great-grandson of the chief of the Chiricahua group of Apache, was the manager of the waste project; Joseph Geronimo, a leader of the opposition, is a grandson of the legendary Apache warrior.
Mr. Chino said that under tribal law, a referendum was not really necessary; he and the council, which signed a nonbinding agreement with the utilities in December, could have gone ahead on their own. He also said that though he would abide by the decision, he did not consider the vote to be decisive.
The turnout was the largest of any election in recent years -- about two-thirds of the tribe's 1,200 eligible voters. The vote was 362 for the waste site and 490 opposed.
The plan was opposed by both of New Mexico's Senators, Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat, and Pete V. Domenici, a Republican. The New Mexico Legislature and environmentalists also opposed it.
A main concern of opponents was that without a firm commitment by the Federal Government on a final storage place for the spent fuel rods, a temporary site could end up being permanent. The Department of Energy has been studying the possibility of opening a permanent repository at Yucca Mountain in Nevada, but it is not even certain yet if the site is geologically suitable, much less politically feasible.
While the search for storage sites drags on, utilities are keeping their spent fuel at their reactors. The Nuclear Energy Institute, a trade association, estimates that within three years 26 plants will run out of room.
Phillip Bayne, the group's president, said today that the Mescalero vote "closes out the opportunity to build a private storage site." He said the industry would now concentrate on pressing the Government to open a permanent repository.
Critics of the plan maintain that New Mexico is a particularly inappropriate place for a temporary repository because it is not a major transportation hub and is not near the utilities generating the waste, increasing the danger of a highway accident involving nuclear material.
Gwen Wardwell, chairwoman of the Rio Grande chapter of the Sierra Club, which covers New Mexico and El Paso, said, "When it's a decision between money or the environment, people will come down on the side of the environment."
But much of the opposition to the Mescalero plan came from people who believe that nuclear waste was bad for business. In nearby Ruidoso, population 4,600, the Village Council and the Chamber of Commerce opposed the disposal site.
"I don't fault the Mescaleros for wanting to improve their standard of life," said Joan Bailey, executive director of the Ruidoso Valley Chamber of Commerce. "But this was such a scary proposition. Our economy is 99.9 percent based on tourism. It's not a comfortable mix. I don't quite trust the powers that be who keep saying that it's safe."
More persuasive to the Mescaleros themselves were the arguments of tribal members like Rufina Marie Laws, who ran against Mr. Chino in the last election in 1992. Ms. Laws spoke of a dream of iridescent water running down the mountain and poisoning the people.
In radio commercials broadcast before the referendum, Mr. Geronimo was particularly effective. Speaking in Apache, he said that like his grandfather, who fought the United States Army off and on from 1876 to 1886 with a few determined followers, he would do anything to protect his tribe.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 3, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the Mescalero Apaches' rejection of an agreement to store spent nuclear fuel on their New Mexico reservation rendered a statement by a nuclear industry spokesman about the tribal vote incorrectly. Phillip Bayne, president of the Nuclear Energy Institute, a trade association, said the result of the tribe's referendum "closes out this opportunity to build a private storage site." He did not say it closed out "the" opportunity to build a private storage site.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Ford's Profits Conclude Banner Year for Big Three

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 1

 BODY:
By announcing today that it had posted a record profit of $ 5.3 billion for last year, the Ford Motor Company made it official. The Big Three auto makers made more money in 1994 -- almost $ 14 billion -- than ever before.
And Ford's earnings report illustrated how they did it, even though the market for vehicles constituted about a million fewer sales than at its peak in 1986: emphasizing sales of more profitable mini-vans and sport utility vehicles like the Explorer, loading record amounts of overtime on their workers to increase productivity, and cutting other costs throughout the company. 
 For the quarter, Ford earned a record $ 1.56 billion, more than double last year's results of $ 719 million. The results came on sales of $ 33.6 billion, up nearly 21 percent from the comparable quarter a year ago.
Bolstered by a turnaround in Ford's overseas operations, the earnings were in line with analysts' estimates. But investors panicked, possibly because of confusion over a one-time gain of $ 110 million that Ford made in the quarter because of the devaluation of the Mexican peso.
Ford hit a 52-week low of $ 24.50 a share and rose as high as $ 26.125 before finally closing at $ 25.125, down 12.5 cents, in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Investors may have also concluded that the industry will set no more records during this economic expansion. Today's report, combined with January sales figures released by some auto makers and another Fed interest-rate rise, underscores that the auto makers have entered treacherous times.
"This is an interesting period," David N. McCammon, Ford's vice president for finance, said. "Sometimes I wish it wasn't quite as interesting."
Like his rivals at General Motors and the Chrysler Corporation and most industry analysts, though, Mr. McCammon said that demand for cars, and the economy in general, remained vigorous. The Federal Reserve would succeed in restraining growth to between 2.5 percent and 3 percent this year, he predicted, meaning that sales should rise and Ford should top its 1994 earnings.
Indeed, Ford projects the recovery could last into 1998, setting a new sales record along the way. "We believe there's still plenty of steam left," Mr. McCammon said.
For the year, the earnings worked out to $ 4.97 a share, compared with $ 2.27 in 1993. Sales rose more than 18 percent, to $ 128.4 billion.
But there were warning signs in the company's report as well.
Analysts said that Ford overproduced light trucks last year, piling them up on dealers' lots. That had the effect of raising 1994 earnings, since the company books a sale when it sells a vehicle to a dealer. But it also created excess inventories that Ford must siphon off by offering rebates and other incentives.
Rebate costs in the fourth quarter averaged $ 860 a vehicle, outpacing the year's average of $ 710 and only slightly less than the $ 865 Ford spent in the fourth quarter of 1993.
Mr. McCammon said Ford was using rebates to help its dealers reduce inventories, since higher interest rates had raised the cost of carrying large stocks. Once rebates are used to help sell vehicles, though, it is hard to remove them. "I don't know if it's temporary or not," he acknowledged.
Mr. McCammon projected incentives in the first quarter would average $ 715, up from $ 695 a year ago. The General Motors Corporation and Chrysler have also said that rebates could rise.
Unlike G.M., Ford continues to generate its greatest profits at home, though its overseas operations rebounded from a loss last year to a gain of $ 784 million. Ford's net profit margins in the United States were a robust 4.2 percent, compared with 2.4 percent overseas.
Over all, Ford's margin of 3.6 percent, narrowly ahead of G.M.'s 3.5 percent, is well short of both companies' goal of 5 percent.
Like its rivals, Ford is hoarding cash to prepare for the next industry downturn. At the end of the quarter, Ford had net cash of $ 4.8 billion compared with $ 1.8 billion a year ago. Ford said that its pension funds were overfinanced by $ 2.5 billion.
Mr. McCammon declined to say how much cash Ford thought would be sufficient to sustain its spending on new car and truck development during the next downturn.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 4, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about earnings of the Ford Motor Company for the fourth quarter of 1994 and for the year misstated the net profit margin for the year. It was 4.3 percent; 3.6 percent was the margin for the company's automotive operations.

HEADLINE: More Mexican Anguish Than Gratitude

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Two days after President Clinton announced a huge American-led effort to rescue the Mexican economy, there have still been no marches to the United States Embassy here by Mexicans wishing to show their gratitude.
"Really, we are not so convinced about all this money," said Victor Gonzalez, 31, a street vendor who was trying to sell plastic Flintstone dolls today near the Embassy. 
 "I am not one of those who thinks the United States is giving us this money just because they want Pemex," he said, referring to the state oil company. "But in the end, we are just going to owe more money, and it is money that the people on the street are never going to see."
Despite a widespread sense of relief in Mexico at the $50 billion deal, many Mexicans continue to harbor concerns, resentment and even anger about the American aid.
Their feelings, sampled in interviews today around the Mexican capital and in other parts of the country, underscored a rising anguish at the country's economic straits and growing frustration with its new President, Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon.
They also suggested some continuing mistrust about the 1993 trade accord with the United States and Canada. Rather than bringing higher standards of living, many Mexicans say, the North American Free Trade Agreement has coincided with lower real wages, tighter credit and now a probable return to recession and higher inflation.
"Nobody gives a loan without wanting something in return," said Fernando Avila, 34, who was selling cowboy boots at the vast Tepito market near the center of Mexico City.
As finally packaged, the loans and loan guarantees from the United States, the International Monetary Fund and the Bank of International Settlements were probably far less offensive to Mexican sensibilities than the original, all-American plan.
In return for support of the original plan, various members of Congress had demanded that Mexico cool its friendly ties to Cuba, block undocumented migrants from crossing its northern border and bring its minimum wage into line with that of the United States.
An opinion poll published on Monday in the Mexico City newspaper Reforma showed that more than twice as many residents of the capital thought that the original $40 billion loan-guarantee plan would hurt Mexico than thought it would help. In a national telephone survey published on Wednesday by the Mori de Mexico concern -- the kind of sample that generally excludes more nationalistic, lower-income Mexicans -- 80 percent of those asked thought that the deal would compromise the country's sovereignty.
Mr. Clinton has gotten most of the credit in Mexico for fashioning an alternative.
"There is a positive reaction toward Clinton," said a historian and magazine editor, Hector Aguilar Camin. But he added, "The question is still there of what non-explicit or private agreements were made."
In return for the new loans, Mexico put up revenues from its oil exports as collateral and promised austere economic policies in the months ahead. If the Government fails to make adequate progress toward what many economists consider the improbable goals of 1.5 percent economic growth and keeping inflation to 19 percent or lower this year, I.M.F. officials are expected to demand further cuts in government spending and stricter limits on the money supply.
Mexican and American officials said Mexico would also follow through on commitments for greater cooperation with the United States on issues like immigration and drug-enforcement that were tied to the original $40 billion plan.
The United States Ambassador to Mexico, James R. Jones, said in an interview today that he believed that President Zedillo had Mexicans' support to do so and that any conditions from the American Congress might "mess up the political base for that." He said he had also heard "great appreciation for what the President did" among businessmen and officials -- the Mexicans who had the most to lose if Mexico's economic troubles deepened.
Still, a sense that the United States was acting out of more than munificence has seemed to linger among more ordinary Mexicans.
"No one gives you money just because they like you," said Jesus Esparza, 22, a car stereo vendor at the Tepito market. "The United States has a history of trying to cheat us. There are always other interests involved."

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 954 words

HEADLINE: A Serb in Western Eyes

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Feb. 2

 BODY:
This week the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, snubbed the American Ambassador to Croatia. The snub would not have been that momentous in the great scheme of Balkan problems were it not that for the last several months, the United States and Western Europe have placed their faith in Mr. Milosevic to bring peace to the area.
The Serbian leader was always an unlikely man for the peacemaking job. His ruthless assertion, from 1987 onward, of Serbian nationalist aspirations in the Albanian-dominated Kosovo area unbalanced the Yugoslav federation, eventually plunging Yugoslavia into a series of devastating wars. 
 During these wars, in Croatia and Bosnia, the Serbs, encouraged by Mr. Milosevic, have sought to establish a homeland stretching from the birthplace of their nation in Kosovo through Serbia and Bosnia to the westernmost edge of their migrations over the centuries, the Croatian town of Knin. In general, outside Serbia, they have killed or thrown out non-Serbs from this proposed "Greater Serbian."
Nonetheless, the United States threw in its lot with Mr. Milosevic in August because the only other serious option -- using military power to oblige the Serbs to compromise or to defeat them -- had been discarded.
The aim was to get Mr. Milosevic to deliver two things: the ruin of the Bosnian Serbs through a crippling economic embargo, and Serbian recognition of the borders of Croatia.
It was in pursuit of the second of these aims that Peter W. Galbraith, the United States Ambassador to Croatia, arranged to go to Belgrade on Tuesday to deliver an American-backed peace plan offering substantial autonomy to the Serbs holding close to one-third of Croatia, in return for their recognition of Croatia's international borders.
But Mr. Milosevic snubbed him, abruptly canceling the planned visit and, in the Ambassador's view, persuading the leaders of the Croatian Serbs to refuse even to look at the plan the previous day.
Even by the abject standards of Western diplomatic efforts in the former Yugoslavia, this amounted to an utter debacle.
It came on the heels of another American failure that demonstrated that Mr. Milosevic has not delivered much in Bosnia either.
Last week, American officials went to the Bosnian Serb stronghold of Pale hoping to persuade the Bosnian Serbs to get serious about peace talks. Apparently unshaken by six months of Mr. Milosevic's less-than-watertight embargo -- prices in Pale are about the same as in Belgrade -- the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, rebuffed the Americans.
"We tried to use Milosevic to marginalize Karadzic," an American official said. "We tried to use Milosevic for progress on Croatia. We even tried to court Karadzic. Now all we are left with is prayer."
The time left for prayer is not great, however. Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, has lost patience with the Serbian occupation of close to a third of his country stemming from the 1991 war, and ordered the United Nations troops acting as a buffer to start leaving on March 31. In the absence of a Serbian-Croatian accord before then, a second Croatian war seems likely.
In Bosnia, a four-month cease-fire that is broadly holding expires on April 31. Without a settlement, the war will resume. The Balkans could thus be in flames by the spring.
"In retrospect, I suppose it was absurd to think that Milosevic, the man who started the wars, had undergone a conversion on the road to Damascus," another American official said.
In one sense, however, the attempt to work with Mr. Milosevic has its logic. He is the originator of the conflict, the strongest man in the former Yugoslavia, and the shrewdest politician. If anyone holds a key to ending the fighting, it is he.
But his conversations with several officials suggest that his rock-bottom aims include at least two crucial elements. The first is to hold on to what the United Nations calls Sector East. This is the Serbian-occupied area of Croatia that borders the Danube, is rich in oil and other industries controlled by Mr. Milosevic's allies, and includes Vukovar, the city on which the Serb-dominated Yugoslav Army spent so much devastating ordnance in 1991.
Because the plan Mr. Galbraith was carrying demanded that the Serbs hand this area back to Croatia, Mr. Milosevic snubbed him and persuaded the local Serbian leaders in Knin to do the same.
Mr. Milosevic is still hoping that the British mediator, Lord Owen, will deliver on ideas that territorial swaps with Croatia could leave "Sector East" in Serbian hands.
The second crucial element in Mr. Milosevic's thinking is the Yugoslav Army. Its espousal of a Greater Serbian, its intimate links with the Bosnian Serb military commander, Ratko Mladic, and its continued indirect support for the Serbian war effort in Bosnia set the limits of Mr. Milosevic's Bosnia policy. The Serbian leader will never put the Bosnian Serbs in so tight a corner that they have to cede.
Thus it seems clear that Mr. Milosevic cannot deliver what the West tried to believe he could. He cannot recognize Croatia's borders because he wants at least part of "Sector East," and he cannot undermine the Bosnian Serbs because his army is at one with them.
The lesson, however, has apparently not been learned. This week, Foreign Minister Alain Juppe of France, Lord Owen and Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany all called for a Milosevic-Tudjman meeting and as a last-ditch means to avoid a wider Balkan war.
Nobody seemed to have a clear idea what the two men would do, but a sense persists that Mr. Milosevic can deliver something. That is what Mr. Galbraith thought, too. The snub, and the record of the last six months, suggest the contrary.

HEADLINE: Desarmes Journal;
Rooting Up Fears, Haiti's Farmers Fill the Silos

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DESARMES, Haiti

 BODY:
The sorghum harvest is drawing to a close now, and the fields are filled with children and goats playing in the stubble. The crop may be smaller than anticipated, peasants here in this dirt-poor village in the Artibonite Valley say, but there is reason to celebrate, and the distant sound of music wafts through the hot and dusty afternoon air.
With the grain speculators who once controlled prices no longer able to call on armed bands of enforcers, it is finally safe to begin storing crops until the price rises. To the farmers, the silos they built with their own labor and money but which have stood empty for years are a symbol of their freedom. 
 "The better times have started, now that we have our silos back," said Adonyas Arelien, a 35-year-old farmer and father of five sons. "Soon I will have enough money to afford to send my children back to school and to put my wife in business, and my neighbors will be able to replace their straw roofs with tin."
In the speeches he has made since American troops restored him to power on Oct. 15, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide has talked much about liberty, justice and other abstract concepts. Yet to the peasants who account for nearly three quarters of Haiti's seven million people -- with per-capita incomes of less than $300 a year -- the most important aspect of Mr. Aristide's return is that it allows them to dream of escaping economic enslavement.
In this small, dusty village, 315 families banded together in 1986, shortly after the dictatorship of Jean-Claude Duvalier fell. They hoped to get a better deal for the corn, sorghum, peanuts, rice and beans they grow either as tenants or owners of tiny private plots. Their plan was simple: to pool their resources and build a silo to store their crops until market prices rose, and thus earn enough money to stay out of debt.
But to the local middlemen who dominated the grain trade here, the construction of a 50-ton silo represented a clear threat to their power and prosperity. Traditionally the middlemen would buy crops at harvest time, when prices were lowest, and then lend the farmers money, at interest of 20 percent a month or more, to pay for seed and to tide them over until the next harvest.
"This is a universal problem in Haiti, farmers wanting a greater return for their work but getting ripped off," said Robert E. Maguire, a visiting scholar at Johns Hopkins University and an expert on the Haitian peasantry.
With their own money and supplies and a $17,000 grant from the Inter-American Foundation, an agency of the United States Government, the farmers finished building a four-chamber cinderblock silo by the middle of 1987 that looked much like a conventional warehouse. But in November, more than a score of local gunmen attacked the silo and set it ablaze. The gunmen were members of a group called San Maman, or "The Motherless Ones" and their attack was led by the area's leading grain speculator.
"We had just finished storing the corn harvest and hadn't even made our first sale," Jean-Remy Azor, a peasant leader, recalled as he stood in front of the ruins of the silo, overgrown with weeds and pockmarked with bullet holes.
About 16.5 tons of corn and seed stock for the next planting were lost in the raid. In addition, Mr. Azor and other leaders of the peasant cooperative were arrested after they went on the radio and identified the attackers; they were released only after human rights groups protested.
The farmers were discouraged but determined to press ahead. They decided to build four smaller silos on separate sites, reasoning that it would be harder to destroy all of them. The units were finished in time for limited use toward the end of the harvest season in February 1991, just as Mr. Aristide took office.
The higher prices they got for the crops they stored gave the cooperative members a small taste of what the future might bring.
The Aristide Government was overthrown in a military coup on Sept. 30, 1991, just before the start of the corn harvest. "The motherless ones" returned and promptly raided the warehouses again. Finding them empty, they did damage to the smaller silos. Leaders of the cooperative, fearing an attack, had removed farm equipment from the buildings. But the renewal of military rule and the rise of terrorist squads forced many farmers into hiding and paralyzed the group.
With Mr. Aristide back in power, association members are already talking about building four more silos, rebuilding their credit fund so they can buy more crops, and learning more sophisticated growing techniques. They have been able to store some of the sorghum harvest because they had secretly hidden away money during the military dictatorship, and they expect to be operating at full throttle in time for the corn harvest in October.
As for the grain speculators and their hired guns, they are still around, Mr. Azor acknowledged. "But they are the ones who are afraid now, and walk around with their heads down," he said with a smile. "The people are ready to go."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With terror gone, Haitian farmers feel free to fill their silos again. A farm leader, Jean-Remy Azor, foreground in baseball cap, stood outside a silo built after another was wrecked by local gunmen in 1987. (Larry Rohter/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Homes Off in Sales In December

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell in December for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department said today, signaling that steadily rising interest rates have brought the housing market to the verge of a slowdown for 1995.
After a strong 1994, in which sales were at a six-year high, analysts say bulging inventories of unsold homes and costlier mortgages foreshadow a sales decline of around 5 percent this year. 
 "Until the fall, sales were good because of the strong economy, but eventually these higher rates just caught up," said David Berson, an economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae.
The Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates six times last year, sending mortgage rates up more than two full percentage points. On Wednesday, the Fed raised short-term rates again, aiming to slow the economic expansion to a rate it considers noninflationary.
Real estate analysts said the move would further slow the interest-rate-sensitive housing market.
The Commerce Department said December sales eased six-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 637,000, down a sharp 22 percent from the rate of 817,000 in December 1993. The drop followed a big revised plunge of 9.6 percent in November to 641,000. Previously, the department said November sales were down only 2.5 percent at a rate of 693,000.
Nonetheless, for all of 1994, sales of new homes totaled 670,000, little changed from 666,000 in 1993 but still the best sales year since 1988, when 676,000 new homes were sold, the department said.
The overall economy is forecast to slow this year from 1994's 4 percent expansion rate.
However, the Labor Department's latest report on the jobs market showed little hint of an impending slowdown. It said today that new claims for unemployment pay inched up by only 1,000 last week to 326,000.
"As of late January, we are seeing the same kinds of employment opportunity that we saw late last year," said Dan Seto, an economist with Nikko Securities.
The January employment report, to be released on Friday, is expected to show that 230,000 new jobs were created, following 256,000 in December.
Inventories of completed but unsold new homes have begun to grow. At December's sales rate, 6.7 months' worth of homes were available to prospective buyers, the department said, the biggest supply since September 1991's 7.4 months.
"With the prime rate rising with every Fed hike, this spells trouble" because it raises builders' costs, said David Seiders, economist for the National Association of Home Builders. Most banks raised their prime rates by half a percentage point, to 9 percent, immediately after the Fed's move on Wednesday.
Mr. Seiders said sales of new homes were likely to drop between 4 and 5 percent this year, while construction of houses would shrink about 8 percent.
Long-term mortgage rates have risen from 6.74 percent in October 1993 to 8.94 percent this week. However, that is down from 9.13 percent last week, according to a national survey released today. The decline was the first retreat below 9 percent in more than three months.
One-year adjustable-rate mortgages had an average initial rate of 6.75 percent, unchanged from last week, according to the figures from the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac.
Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 8.59 percent this week, down from 8.76 percent last week.
The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.
December sales of new homes weakened in every region except the South, where they gained 15.1 percent, to 312,000 a year. In the Northeast, they plunged 23.4 percent, to a rate of 49,000, and in the Midwest they fell 8.9 percent, to 123,000 a year. In the West, sales dropped 11.6 percent, to a rate of 152,000 a year.

HEADLINE: A Makeover for Electric Utilities;
Power Industry, Facing Competition, Struggles With Change

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The prospect of declining utility bills, along with the examples of successful deregulation in airlines and long-distance telephones, is powering a drive to introduce real competition to electricity production around the country.
With many power users capable of going around the system to cut costs, this revolution already brewing in several states seems inevitable and, to many economists, quite desirable. 
 But transforming "this staid, old industry into a nimble giant," as Irwin Stelzer, director of regulatory policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute, put it, will require wrenching changes and challenge a variety of interests, from environmental groups to utility stockholders to traditional power plant builders.
"We're cutting through 100 years of sedimentary layers in trying to make the market for power work better," said Gary J. Lavine, senior vice president at the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation in Syracuse.
The central quandary is that much of the existing investment in electrical power -- on everything from bread-and-butter coal and nuclear plants to exotic windmill farms and high-efficiency light bulbs -- is more expensive than the cost of starting over with a clean sheet of paper. As a result, utilities contend, the only way to provide big electricity savings quickly would be to deny investors a fair return on hundreds of billions of dollars of financial commitments that with hindsight should never have been made. That, they say, would be unconscionable.
"Regulators made promises to investors, and government has a moral obligation to honor them," said Alfred E. Kahn, an economist at Cornell University and a former chairman of the New York Public Service Commission.
Other problems flow from the same central challenge. The big industrial users of electricity would be in a position to "cherry pick" inexpensive sources of power, leaving small business and residential consumers with even higher monthly bills to support the existing grid.
Similarly, competition could undermine energy efficiency efforts that had been shielded from market forces. "Conservation doesn't sell unless it pays back the cost in a year or two," said Ralph Cavanagh, an economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Nearly all electric utilities are state-regulated monopolies, and have been so for most of this century. Electricity was a "natural monopoly," it was assumed, where a single enterprise could produce and distribute power more inexpensively than many different competitors for the same customers. That meant regulation would be needed to protect consumers from price gouging. In turn, investors needed laws guaranteeing a fair return on investments deemed necessary and prudent.
The idea of realistic alternatives is relatively new. The economists Paul Joskow and Richard Schmalenzee of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology made the case in the 1970's that power generation, in contrast to long-distance transmission and local distribution, would benefit from new entrants. Congress inched in this direction after the energy crisis hit, requiring utilities to buy power from independent producers at what was assumed was the relatively high "avoided cost" of producing it themselves from a new power plant. That led to some extravagant investments in futuristic but costly alternatives like windmills and solar energy.
But today new power plants can be much less expensive than many old ones. Most utilities get the bulk of their power from large coal and nuclear operations at costs that are two or three times as high as power from smaller, more efficient plants that can both make use of waste heat and take advantage of the current glut of natural gas. Thus neither the utilities nor their customers are currently getting the windfall from better technology and cheaper fuel.
The dam may be about to break, though. In upstate New York, the Alcan Aluminum Corporation won permission to buy electricity directly from a nearby independent supplier building a gas-fired plant. Long Island is pressing a more radical approach, hoping to create a government-owned power company that could buy electricity from independents at a third of the price charged by the Long Island Lighting Company.
Meanwhile, California state regulators, the source of much of the innovation in the field, are considering the most systematic assault on the retail electricity monopolies. Egged on by large industrial electricity buyers, the California Public Utilities Commission proposed last April to free power generation from regulation.
And the resulting controversy, which may force California to slow its timetable, is a preview of what is likely to happen in New England and the mid-Atlantic states, where there are also high electricity rates and many price-sensitive customers.
Some environmentalists fear that worthwhile goals will be lost when short-term bottom-line calculations rule. For instance, the failure of consumers to invest in cost-effective energy conservation ranging from commercial lighting to home insulation led regulators in several states to allow utilities to subsidize individual improvements and then pass on the cost as a surcharge on all consumers' bills.
That would not be possible in a world of free markets, said Mr. Cavanagh of the Natural Resources Defense Council, unless the commission added systemwide "green charges" to the cost of using the utility wires.
At the same time, stockholders in the regulated utilities have good reason to fear a full-scale deregulation of power production. Consider Southern California Edison, which serves much of the huge Los Angeles-Orange County-San Bernardino metropolitan region outside the city of Los Angeles itself from its home base in Rosemead. It is one of the three big California utilities caught between the rock of old commitments to high-priced electricity and the hard place of low competitive prices.
Southern California Edison is locked into long-term contracts from independent producers of everything from co-generation plants to geothermal operations to wind farms that oblige the utility to buy a third of its power at nearly 9 cents a kilowatt-hour. And it is allowed to charge roughly 5 cents a kilowatt-hour to earn a fair return on its own investment in power production, including part of its investment in nuclear operations. All told, the cost of power to Edison today is about 7 cents a kilowatt-hour.
Thus Edison estimated that it would take a one-time payment of $9.3 billion -- or the equivalent plus interest for many years -- to honor its long-term power contracts, provide acceptable dividends to its stockholders and still sell power at a competitive price that could be as low as 4 cents.
That $9.3 billion is double the stockholders' stake in the company. Unless regulators or the courts permit Southern California Edison to break its contracts with high-cost independent suppliers or pass on much of the $9.3 billion bill to captive customers, the utility would be technically bankrupt. While no one expects the state to push its utilities to the wall, the economic consequences are real.
And Southern California Edison is not alone. William Hogan of Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government estimates that the transition cost for electric utilities nationwide could exceed $200 billion, or more than double the total equity in the industry.
Regulators could -- and those in both California and New York have hinted that they would -- pay off the utilities by imposing hefty surcharges on the use of the utilities' distribution systems. Peter Bradford, the recently retired chairman of the New York Public Service Commission, envisions a "grand bargain," in which stockholders would be assured most of their money that way in return for cooperation in restructuring the industry.
A heated debate has already begun over whether a restructured power market should look more like today's long-distance telephone market, with big companies wooing individual retail customers, or like today's commodities exchanges, with anonymous buyers and sellers setting the competitive price paid by all.
But even the grand bargain is no panacea. For one thing, it would defeat what economists see as a primary objective of deregulation. "Prices should fall to reflect actual costs," said Mr. Stelzer of the American Enterprise Institute. Otherwise, he said, consumers will continue to have perverse incentives to use the wrong sources of energy.
More to the political point, shuffling the "stranded costs" to the distribution system would not satisfy customers who care how much they pay, not whom they pay. It would not stop big industrial customers from threatening to move to lower-cost states if they are denied inexpensive power. Nor would it inhibit the push for municipal electricity companies able to bypass the regulated monopolies.
Is there any way through the thicket of competing interests? To Mr. Bradford, all this points toward a compromise in which utilities are paid part of their stranded costs, but "not 100 cents on the dollar." Utilities may have a strong moral case for full compensation, he says, but the only realistic hope is to allow "a lot of room for judgment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wind turbines at Altamont Pass, Calif., are among the alternative means of generating electricity. Such futuristic but costly devices would be threatened if utilities are deregulated, as many are demanding. (Mickey Pfleger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mexican Report Details Brush With Insolvency

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Haunted by lingering investor uncertainty, Mexican financial markets lost ground today as a central bank report showed how close the nation had come to insolvency before a new international assistance package was announced in Washington earlier this week.
The peso, after gaining strength for the last two days, weakened slightly to 5.455 to the dollar, down from 5.375 on Wednesday. The Mexican stock market, unable to sustain a rally, slumped a further 2.7 percent today to close just under 1,944 -- 56 points below the 2,000 level many investors consider an important indicator of market health. 
 The Mexican central bank reported late Wednesday night that its foreign currency reserves had dwindled during January to $3.48 billion, a drop of more than 43 percent since the end of December, when reserves totaled nearly $6.15 billion.
The Government had previously denied a report in The International Herald Tribune on Monday that the reserves had fallen to $2 billion.
However, financial analysts here and in New York say that the $3.48 billion figure does not truly represent the central bank's current assets because some of the money may be tied up in accounts with restrictive terms. Furthermore, the bank reported that last month it had to draw down $2.1 billion from the lines of credit made available by the United States, Canada and other nations on Jan. 3.
The report made clear that Mexico had come close to going broke before President Clinton announced the new rescue package on Tuesday. Economists said the $3.48 billion in remaining reserves would have been enough to cover only two and a half to three weeks of imports. In addition, the Government knew that it was obligated to pay off more than $1 billion worth of short-term bonds this week. The bonds, called tesobonos, are indexed to the value of the dollar.
Alluding to Mexican economic officials, Jorge O. Mariscal, vice president of the Latin American equity group at Goldman, Sachs, said: "They were very close to having to really come up with something else. This week they may have solved half of the problem, which is the financing of tesobonos. But the other half is the lack of credibility of Mexican institutions."
By Monday, Mexico will have available the first installments of more than $50 billion in assistance brokered by President Clinton. This money is expected to come from the first part of a $17.8 billion line of credit approved by the International Monetary Fund late Wednesday.
[European financial officials were quoted in Frankfurt as saying Thursday that five leading European nations had abstained from the approval vote as a sign of displeasure at being given only an hour's notice of the new rescue plan by the United States.]
Investors will be watching next Tuesday's regularly scheduled auction of Government bonds to see whether the new assistance helps Mexico's credit standing. The Government canceled this week's auction after President Clinton declared that he was abandoning his efforts to get a Mexico rescue package through Congress, but before he announced his alternative.
Interest rates for the bonds had reportedly risen above 30 percent on Tuesday morning, persuading officials to cancel the sale.
The auction next Tuesday will be seen as a test of investors' confidence, both in terms of how many bonds are sold and the kind of inter est rates that investors demand. The current interest rate for the 91-day bond is 24.98 percent.
While the markets calmed down this week, financial analysts said they were unsure about the willingness of Mexico to tighten its budget and monetary policies, and uneasy that the Government had not yet announced a new policy for setting the peso's exchange rate.
American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, a bellwether for the Mexican equity market, closed today at $33.50 a share, down 75 cents, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The continuing uneasiness was apparent in a move Wednesday by Standard & Poor's to lower its ratings one notch on Mexico's long-term foreign-currency debt, to BB, Mexico's peso-denominated debt was similarly lowered, to single-A.
However, S.& P. also removed Mexican debt from the credit watch it had imposed on Dec. 23, three days after the Government set off the current crisis by devaluing the peso. "The removal of all ratings from credit and the stable foreign currency outlook are based on the stabilizing effect of the $51 billion multilateral financial support agreement," the rating agency said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Report Backs U.S. Program For Computer Development

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
A Federal program begun three years ago to support the development of advanced computers and computer networks is essential to the nation's half-trillion-dollar information technology industry, a report to be issued today by the National Academy of Sciences contends.
The Government is spending $1.1 billion annually on the program, known as the High Performance Computing and Communications Initiative, which has been cited by Congressional Republicans as a program that could be eliminated to offset proposed tax cuts. 
 But some of the nation's leading computer researchers at corporations and universities, who prepared the report, argue that Government support for research is crucial for the American economy to remain competitive.
"There is a great threat to the economic future of the country as corporations continue to retract their research horizons," said Larry Smarr, director of the National Center for Supercomputer Applications and a member of the committee that prepared the report.
The panel gives credit to the Federal program, which began in 1992 and is planned to continue for two more years, for having helped bring about wide acceptance by the industry of massively parallel computers and for having built the advanced computer networks that are the backbone of the Internet, a collection of computer networks used for research, education, commerce and entertainment.
Among the recommendations of the panel was that financing be focused on a new class of distributed information systems that would allow people around the country to manipulate large data bases that might be spread over various sites.
The panel also recommended that support be continued for a series of research goals known as Grand Challenges -- thorny scientific problems that are intended to push the limits of computer technology.
In light of the debate over national industrial policy, the panel called for the elimination of direct project financing for the development of commercial hardware by computer vendors.
That has been a bitterly contested issue: The critics of Government support for new technology development have said that it amounts to handing out "pork barrel" contracts to various Congressional districts.
One prominent critic of the program said he was pleased with the shift in direction.
"Part of what's wrong with this program is that we absolutely should not be funding any commercial development of any kind," said T. J. Rodgers, chief executive of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation in San Jose, Calif. "We're hurting American companies."
But Mr. Rodgers said he agreed with the idea of financing dozens or hundreds of small research programs at universities to support advanced education and research.
But Mr. Smarr, the committee member, said he was worried about the "slash and burn" approach to Federal support for scientific research and technology development. He said it could be decades before the country realized what had been lost.
"If we lose the information technology, and all we do in this country in the future is flip hamburgers, no one will remember the reason why it happened," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Withdraw Funds From Journalism Center in Budapest

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The United States Information Agency has moved to stop financing a journalism training program in Budapest that has been run by an American university for four years.
The decision has led to complaints by American journalists and the program's administrators that the agency is infringing on academic freedom and journalistic independence. 
The program, administered by the College of Journalism of the University of Maryland, is one of several in Eastern Europe aimed at developing an independent press.
They are administered by the American sponsors but financed largely with United States Government funds channeled through private agencies.
The college in Maryland said this week that it had notified its employees in Budapest that it would have to close the center because of the U.S.I.A. action.
Joseph D. Duffey, director of the agency, denied that he was interfering with academic freedom. He said he moved to cancel Government funds for the program last week after receiving complaints from the United States Embassy in Budapest.
"I don't think the issue is academic freedom," Mr. Duffey said. "There are questions about whether the quality of the program is up to the standards that were set in the early years. They are fair questions in terms of accountability to the Congress and the American public."
Because of the college's response, however, Mr. Duffey plans to review the facts and ask a respected journalist to evaluate the program, the American Journalism Center in Budapest.
Reese Cleghorn, the journalism dean at the University of Maryland, said the university had been forced to close its center because Mr. Duffey had withdrawn the funds.
On Wednesday Mr. Cleghorn sent government officials and journalists a statement protesting the U.S.I.A.'s decision, calling the move an attempted "takeover" of the center that "would be an infringement upon academic freedom and the independence of a journalism center."
Mr. Cleghorn included a copy of a letter protesting the action from Gregory Favre, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Mr. Favre said he was registering a "vigorous protest" on behalf of his organization, which represents more than 850 editors.
Kati Marton, the chairwoman of the Committee to Protect Journalists, also wrote to urge Mr. Duffey to reconsider because of the "danger that government intervention in any aspect of our profession represents."
Mr. Cleghorn's statement included a detailed response to assertions by officials at the Embassy in Budapest. Among other things, documents released by both sides showed that the Embassy had complained in January that the university had run the center with "long-distance management" and then installed new managers who "lack competency."
The statement denied those assertions and said U.S.I.A. and the Agency for International Development "made a clumsy effort in the fall of 1994 to take direct control of our center." The complaints began when that effort failed, the statement added.
Mr. Duffey said the Government was not assuming control over the center but was merely withdrawing government funds.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Benetton Touches a Nerve and Germans Protest

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KASSEL, Germany

 BODY:
The windows of Heinz Hartwich's four clothing stores here have blood-red tape blocking out the name of his former supplier, the Italian clothing manufacturer Benetton Group S.p.A.
At the center of the X's formed by the tape, a sign says in German: "No more Benetton, because we condemn the scandalous advertising using misery, war, sickness and death." 
 Benetton's advertisements, which have shown, for example, a man's arm tattooed with the words "H.I.V. positive," have also prompted protests in France, Italy, Britain and the United States in recent years. But they provoked the most conspicuous backlash in Germany recently, reflecting this country's intense sensitivities -- and guilt -- over war and death.
Because of the company's provocative print and billboard advertisements, Mr. Hartwich says that customers have boycotted his store and cost him almost $600,000 in lost sales in the last year. That is why, he said, he refused to pay for an equal amount of merchandise from Benetton and tried to sever relations with the company.
"If I continue selling Benetton clothes, I would go bankrupt," said Mr. Hartwich, who has been sued by the giant clothes maker for not paying his bills.
Mr. Hartwich was one of about 70 German Benetton licensees who met in the city of Mainz in January to discuss what to do about a drop of more than 30 percent in sales at almost 150 Benetton outlets licensed among them. They blamed public protests over Benetton's advertisements, which mix tragedy with mercantilism, for the fall-off.
The company's advertisements, which are produced in-house, have in recent years included photographs of a war cemetery, an oil-soaked sea-bird, a dying AIDS patient, children laboring in South America, and most recently the bloody uniform of a Croatian soldier. Some of the ads have appeared in Europe but not the United States.
Some other Benetton store owners from Italy, Spain, France and Sweden also attended the meeting of the "rebels," as members of the group called themselves.
"It is using human tragedy and suffering to sell clothes; I think that's totally cynical and without feeling," said Ulfert Engels, a Kassel lawyer who is defending Mr. Hartwich against the lawsuit by Benetton. "If you are against child labor, poverty, war, fine, take out all the ads you want. But don't put your company logo on it."
Mr. Engels now represents more than 50 rebellious Benetton retailers in Europe, most of them German, and said he added about two new clients daily. He said some of his clients had received death threats or had their store windows smashed with rocks.
"Mr. Engels is trying to generate a trial by media," said Maria Galante, a spokeswoman for Benetton. She said other loyal Benetton store owners in Germany were complaining that the bad publicity was hurting their sales.
"We're getting 10 phone calls a day by store owners who do not agree with this media circus," Ms. Galante said. "The silent majority is being ruined by the press."
Benetton officials at the company's home offices in Treviso, Italy, contend that the retail uprising in Germany was provoked by the store owners' own financial problems and business mismanagement, and not Benetton's advertisements. Sales have not fallen as far as the licensees report, the company said, but have actually risen when measured by the number of items bought.
Mr. Hartwich said his troubles began in March 1993, when he arrived at his store on Wilhelmsstrasse to find it spray-painted in red with the words "No business using sickness and refugees." In the following months, he said, he found the door locks to his stores filled with glue and protesters passing out leaflets with such slogans as "I buy at the United Colors of Benetton because I'm crazy about war."
It is not difficult to understand why many Germans object to Benetton ads. Fifty years after the end of World War II, Germany remains haunted by the two world wars it started and of the deaths of millions of Jews in Nazi concentration camps. Germans also complain that the nation's international image is tarnished by a tiny minority of neo-Nazis and skinheads.
A poll last year by the German weekly magazine Der Spiegel found that 84 percent of Germans surveyed considered Benetton's ads distasteful. Mr. Hartwich showed a typical letter he had received.
Albrecht A. Reinhold wrote that his family had spent up to $2,400 a year on Benetton clothing, but no longer. "Because of the aggressive, tasteless and largely damaging advertising," he wrote, "we have decided not to buy any more Benetton products."
One ad Mr. Hartwich cited for insensitivity showed the "H.I.V. Positive" tattoo.
"This reminded us of the number they tattooed onto Jews in the concentration camps," he said. "How can you combine such horrible tragedies with trying to sell clothes?"
Mr. Hartwich also accused Benetton of hypocrisy in its ad featuring a bird drenched with oil during the Persian Gulf war. "At the same time," he said, "it was spending millions of dollars funding Grand Prix racing that is polluting the atmosphere."
For Benetton, the protests and prospect of a long court battle come as the company's profits have been dampened by price-cutting and the larger recession on the Continent. Germany, which is its largest European market, had about 600 shops as recently as three years ago. There are now about 500, according to the dissident store owners, and with the drop in demand some say the German market will only be able to support 200 stores.
Four other lawsuits have now been filed in German courts against other Benetton store owners for nonpayment, Mr. Engels said. Benetton licensees say another four lawsuits have been filed in France and more are expected in Spain and Italy.
Mr. Hartwich and Mr. Engels contended that Benetton did not care that much about the protests because its corporate strategy was to reduce the number of outlets in Germany. In the United States and Britain, Benetton has switched from a vast network of small franchises to fewer, larger stores, many owned by the company itself.
"Small shop owners are being squeezed like you'd wring out a washcloth," Mr. Hartwich said. "We're trying to get together because we now see it as our only chance to survive."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Close Mixed On Slow Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Government securities traded mixed yesterday in thin volume as investors remained worried about inflation despite the Federal Reserve's increase of short-term interest rates by half a percentage point on Wednesday.
Traders fretted about whether the rate increase, the seventh in a year, would be enough to subdue future inflation. And there was caution ahead of the scheduled release today of the latest national employment data, along with a heavy supply of $40 billion in new Government debt coming up at next week's auction. 
 The 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to a price of 978/32 to yield 7.74 percent, unchanged from Wednesday. Shorter maturities were mixed, with the rate on a three-month security down seven basis points and a six-month unchanged at 6.16 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, described the market yesterday as "moving sideways, with very small price increases and decreases across the various maturities." He added: "We saw the market make major adjustments after the Fed move on Wednesday, and today there was a little bit of fine-tuning taking place after some early data. But really, the market is looking ahead to the employment report."
He also said heavy supply could be a concern when the Treasury's refunding got under way next week.
The forecast for today's employment numbers is in the moderate range, but the market will probably focus on any increase in wages, Mr. Alexy said, adding that "there is a seasonal bias for wages to go up at the beginning of every new quarter."
Traders said the market might have been a little overextended before the Fed rate increase was announced on Wednesday. Even though the move had been widely expected, bonds sold off.
While some investors sold to take profits, others suggested that there was also selling on the terse policy statement that accompanied the Fed's announcement, which signaled that more monetary tightenings were almost certain to come later this year.
The Fed said yesterday that it was adopting a policy of making formal announcements of decisions at meetings of its Federal Open Market Committee.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.54 percent, a slight improvement over the previous day, while a 10-year note was unchanged at 7.66 percent. The when-issued long bond also improved a bit, as the yield dropped a basis point, to 7.69 percent.
Yesterday, the Treasury sold $17.25 billion of new one-year bills at an average rate at auction of 6.59 percent, down from 6.86 percent last month, and the highest yield since Nov. 11, when it was 6.09 percent.
In the municipal bond market, where investors are beginning to find prices a little too rich as a result of a supply squeeze, prices dropped and yields, which move in the opposite direction, rose for the first time in days.
The Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues showed the average yield to maturity up a basis point, to 6.65 percent.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of a new one-year bill:

HEADLINE: Boeing Will Slow Output and Cut 7,000 Jobs

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Buffeted by continued weakness in the airline industry, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it would reduce production of two models of jetliners and eliminate 7,000 more jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force.
Both the production cuts and the job cuts had been widely anticipated. In the last two weeks, USAir Group, Continental Airlines, Air France and All Nippon Airways all said they would either cancel or delay orders. But the number of job cuts exceeded most estimates, even though analysts said the production cutbacks were smaller than expected and appeared to mark a bottom for Boeing. 
 The company's work force will be reduced over the course of the year, mainly through layoffs, while the production cuts will occur toward the end of the year.
Most of the cuts will be at Boeing's plants in the Seattle area, where the company will eliminate about 6,500 jobs, or 7.9 percent of the work force there. But local economists predicted that the cuts would slow but not stop economic growth in the Puget Sound area, which is no longer dominated by Boeing as it was in the 1970's and earlier decades.
Boeing's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, closing at $46.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. Aircraft industry analysts said the company's fortunes should improve as the airline industry picks up worldwide and as United States airlines are forced to replace aging jets because of increasingly strict noise regulations.
Aside from the latest round of jobs, Boeing had already eliminated 26,000 jobs in the last two years, reducing its work force to 117,331.
"These job reductions are higher than we anticipated just a few weeks ago," Frank A. Shrontz, the chairman and chief executive of Boeing,
said in a statement. "Since the beginning of the year, several customers came to us asking to postpone airplane deliveries because of the continued softness of the airline industry. Following a series of discussions with these customers, we decided to reduce production rates on the 737 and 767 airplanes."
Boeing said it would cut production of the 737, its smallest plane, to 7 aircraft a month, starting in November, from the current rate of 8.5 a month. Production of the midsized 767 will decline to 3.5 planes a month in December after rising as planned to a rate of 4 a month in April.
But Boeing also said it planned to increase production of its 747 jumbo jet to three a month in the second half of 1996 from its current rate of two a month.
Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities, said many analysts had been expecting Boeing to reduce production of its 747 and 757 planes along with that of the 737, so yesterday's report was better than expected.
Around the world, airlines report record passenger traffic and, at least outside the United States, solid profits, he said. "While the domestic airlines are not yet out of the woods, the overall picture is one of strong convalescence," he added.
Steve Lewins, an analyst with Gruntal & Company, said that the canceled orders reflected problems at individual airlines and that the industry's recovery, while slow, should continue.
William B. Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities, said that he had expected job cuts of 5,000 in the Puget Sound area rather than the 6,500 that were announced, but that he thought some of the cuts reflected improved productivity.
In addition to the Seattle area cuts, Boeing said total employment at its helicopters division in the Philadelphia area would be reduced by about 800 jobs, while employment in Wichita, Kan., was expected to decline by about 500.
The work force at other Boeing sites will increase by 800, the company said, much of it related to work on the space station, the recent acquisition of Litton Precision Gear by a Boeing subsidiary, and a contract to supply communications technology to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
 
 
Trouble on Test Flight
 By Bloomberg Business News
 SEATTLE, Feb. 2 -- A new Boeing 777 jetliner had to make an emergency landing after a rapid loss of cabin pressure during a test flight, the company said.
The failure of an air-conditioning duct clamp was blamed for the problem, which left seven crew members with decompression sickness. Boeing said the cause of the damage was under investigation.
The test plane had logged 450 hours of flight time. Boeing said the first 777 delivery remained set for May to United Airlines.

HEADLINE: Stocks Climb As Earnings Draw Focus

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
A day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, the stock market rose in earnest through most of the session, with little of the volatility of recent sessions.
Traders said yesterday's stock session was an extension of the rally in the last half-hour of trading on Wednesday, which followed the Fed's announcement that it was raising the Federal funds rate by half a percentage point, to 6 percent. Market speculation has already turned to what the Fed will do next. 
 High interest rates hurt share prices by raising corporate borrowing costs and making fixed-income instruments more attractive than stocks.
But if there is only one rate increase for the rest of the year, then "that could be bullish for stocks," said Edward Laux, senior managing director at the Chicago Corporation. "People are going to conclude that the Fed thinks the economy can grow reasonably well with rates that are relatively low compared to seven years ago or even 17 years ago."
Analysts also said that with President Clinton's Mexico rescue package appearing to stabilize the peso and uncertainty over the Fed's rate action dispelled, traders could again focus on fourth-quarter corporate profits, which are being reported at unexpectedly high levels.
Frank Teixeira, vice president for market analysis at Merrill Lynch, said that from a technical standpoint the market seemed poised for a rally that could last for several days. He said that the put-call ratio, the advance-decline ratio, and the price for Standard & Poor's 500 futures all indicated that "we're set up for a nice upward move."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.21 points, to 3,870.77, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.39 points, to 472.79. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 5.33 points, to 763.64.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was below normal, with 322.1 million shares changing hands, about 3.6 percent less than this year's daily average of 334 million shares.
Bank stocks rose because of the higher interest rates banks can now charge for loans. First Interstate Bancorp, for example, rose 2 1/8, to 75 7/8. Retailers reported strong sales but in a clearance month that is unlikely to post strong profits. Still, shares of the Dayton Hudson Corporation rose 1 7/8, to 72 1/8.
Semiconductor stocks continued their gains, with the Intel Corporation's shares rising 19/16 , to 723/16 , and Texas Instruments Inc. advancing 1 3/4, to 71 3/8.
Some companies reported strong earnings. The ITT Corporation rose 3 1/2, to 92 1/2, after reporting an increase in operating profits for the fourth quarter of 19 percent. The Scott Paper Company rose for a second day after it reported a fourth-quarter profit of $1.13 a share compared with a loss of $5.01 a share. Scott rose 3 1/8, to 73 3/4.
Class A shares of Pacificare Health Systems, a chain of health maintenance organizations, rose 4, to 69 1/2, after the company reported a first-quarter rise in profit of 33 percent, to 71 cents a share.
Shares of the Times Mirror Company fell 3 1/8, to 20 1/4, after the media group reported poor fourth-quarter profit and indicated that its first-quarter earnings will decline. Times Mirror also cut its dividend.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.18 points, to 257.18, with advancing stocks outnumbering decliners, 1,295 to 901. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.53 points, to 438.45.
Of the 30 component stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 22 rose, led by the International Paper Company, which rose 1, to 73 3/8. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 289 rose, led by the AT&T Corporation, whose shares rose 3/4, to 50 1/4.
The most active stock, at 7.8 million shares, was that of the EMC Corporation, a developer of computer-storage devices, which rose 3/16 , to 171/16 , after falling sharply on Wednesday when it said it may face steep price cuts in the coming year.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
President Pressuring Baseball's Negotiators

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton emphatically stated, "I want this thing settled," the mediator in the baseball labor dispute was summoned to the White House today for an update on negotiations, then returned to the bargaining table to try to shove the owners and players toward an agreement.
Although the two sides did not move closer together on the core economic issue on the second day of their resumed talks, interested Government observers said they hoped that Presidential pressure and fear of the unknown -- what Clinton or Congress might do in the absence of a settlement -- would hasten a deal by the Monday deadline the President has set. 
 With his appointed mediator, Bill Usery Jr., empowered to wield a 40-ounce bat, Clinton has made it even clearer to top aides in recent days that he wants to see an end to the dispute, and he reiterated that desire to one of them Wednesday with his emphatic remark.
"The President wants to get an agreement here," a senior Administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said today. "He's concerned about states that have spring training. He's concerned about the cities and he's obviously concerned about the fans. He wants to move this along as quickly as possible."
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said Administration officials expect this to be a long weekend as the talks creep toward the final hours of the pre-Presidential presence in the dispute. That presence would appear in the form of a proposal made by Usery at Clinton's direction.
Usery had been scheduled to convene a bargaining session at 1:30 P.M. at the Mayflower Hotel today, but he was called to the White House for a 2:15 P.M. meeting with Bruce Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel, and Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich.
The mediator gave Lindsey and Reich a status report on the talks in their 45-minute session. Usery then returned to the hotel to meet with negotiators for both sides in a discussion of the new proposal the owners made Wednesday.
Asked what he knew about the White House session, Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said, "The message was conveyed that the President expects and wants this to be settled."
John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, chairman of the owners' negotiating committee, was asked how serious he thought the Monday deadline was.
"My understanding," he said, "is the deadline is heavy, heavy."
The key element of the proposal, the two-tiered tax that would steeply assess payroll portions over thresholds of $35 million and $42 million, was not discussed in the three-and-a-half-hour bargaining session. Negotiators instead went over issues such as pension, international play, scheduling and changes in the uniform player's contract.
Fehr said they narrowed the differences on some of the noneconomic issues.
The union has not responded to the tax plan, but Fehr said at a news briefing this evening that the taxes -- 75 percent and 100 percent of the portions of the payrolls over the thresholds -- are "extraordinarily heavy; they would be very significant."
Individual members of the union's bargaining team have said privately that despite the different elements of the tax plan, it was no improvement over the implemented salary cap. It was premature, they indicated, to say if the union would formulate a counterproposal using the same framework. The owners hoped they would.
"Everything, I guess, is negotiable," Tom Glavine, the Atlanta Braves pitcher, said after leaving the meeting. "It's just a matter of how far you're willing to go."
Glavine said the issue of taxes always presents a problem to players, because money is taken away from their salaries. "The problem with thresholds," he added, "is what happens with them if revenues go through the roof. Every time we negotiate a basic agreement, revenues have gone up 50 percent. Who's to say that won't happen again?"
Usery will most likely take that question and others into consideration if he is called on to present his own proposal. He was said not to have anything of his own ready to present to the two sides if they pass the Monday deadline without an agreement or substantial progress toward one.
If they reach that stage of the strike, which will soon be half a year old, the owners and players would face the question of what Clinton would do if they rejected the mediator's plan. The uncertainty could impel them toward a settlement.
But if they don't settle, the President could send Usery's plan to Capitol Hill and ask Congress to enact legislation that would impose a settlement on the owners and players. Or Congress could pass a bill imposing binding arbitration on the two sides.
Representative Pat Williams, Democrat of Montana, has introduced a bill in the House calling for binding arbitration.
It would not be unusual for Congress to legislate a settlement in a labor dispute, but it would be a first for an industry like baseball that does not fall into the national-interest category of railroads and airlines.
As recently as 1992, Congress ended a labor dispute, between the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and a freight rail company, with legislation. The dispute had shut down virtually all freight traffic and threatened commuter service.
Would Congress view the baseball situation with such alarm? Its members would prefer a negotiated settlement, but if it becomes obvious that the owners and the players will not act on their own, large segments of the Senate and House could initiate action.
Harrington discovered today what steps some Congressmen might take. He had just finished giving a news briefing on a conference call of the expansion committee and walked out of the room right into the path of two Representatives from Florida, who were about to make their own appearance in the press room.
Peter Deutsch and Mark Foley expressed to Harrington their concern about the effect of the dispute on the Florida economy during spring training.
"You understand that's one of the main reasons why we're driving toward playing the season and opening spring training," Harrington told them. "We're making that commitment to you."
They proceeded to discuss for several minutes the lagging sale of tickets for exhibition games. Harrington said Red Sox sales were picking up in Fort Myers, but Deutsch and Foley said sales were "very dismal" on Florida's other coast, where their districts are.
Foley, whose district includes the Mets in Port St. Lucie, said later in the press room that no one is eager to see replacement players.
"The enthusiasm for watching minor league players is very negligible," he said.
At a later briefing, Harrington said the owners, in the pension part of their proposal, had offered to make the $8 million payment they refused to make last Aug. 1, an act that prompted the National Labor Relations Board to issue an unfair labor practice complaint against the clubs.
"We agreed we would make that payment on settlement," Harrington said. Asked if the offer was an admission the owners were wrong in having refused to make the payment, he said, "It's not an admission but a recognition that that $8 million payment would be made some day."
The N.L.R.B. has scheduled a March 14 hearing before an administrative law judge on its complaint.

HEADLINE: More Open Fed On Rate Moves

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is opening the window a little wider into its inner sanctum.
Breaking eight decades of resistance to greater public disclosure, the Fed made it official this evening that it would continue to announce changes in interest rates.
The central bank's resistance to announcing policy changes had already been crumbling, and the Fed began a provisional practice of announcing rate increases last year. But until today, Fed officials had maintained that each statement could be the last and that further rate increases might not be announced. 
 In the past, bond market traders and others interested in interest rates had to surmise what the Fed was doing by watching whether rates rose or fell during the period each morning when the Fed buys and sells bonds. That arrangement was long criticized by Congressional Democrats but defended by Fed officials who contended that financial markets might be too unstable if the Fed announced its moves.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the ranking Democrat on the House Banking and Financial Services Committee and a longtime Fed critic, welcomed the decision. "I consider the Federal Reserve's adoption of disclosure policies a victory," he said, "and commend the Fed for embracing some of the measures I have urged for years."
