HEADLINE: Retailers Sacrifice Profits To Enliven January Sales

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Christmas arrived in January for many retail chains, as sales exceeded merchants' expectations.
Shoppers turned out in force last month to snap up the bargains offered in the aftermath of the disappointing 1994 holiday sales season, when most retailers failed to post the sales gains they had anticipated. 
 Also, sales looked stronger in comparison with those in January 1994, when fierce winter storms in the East and Midwest and a powerful earthquake in California kept shoppers away from stores.
But most retailers paid for their sales with profits, which were sacrificed to price-cutting, and analysts said they had no plans to increase their estimates of fourth-quarter earnings because sales were stronger than expected. "We're calling it profitless prosperity," said Richard N. Baum, a retailing analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
J. C. Penney said yesterday that same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least one year, hopped 14.4 percent higher, and the May Department Stores Company reported a 9.2 percent jump in same-store sales at its department stores.
Federated Department Stores Inc., which operates Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh and Burdines, posted a 7.4 percent increase in same-store sales, and the Gap Inc., whose same-store sales have hovered in the low single digits for months on end, reported a 7 percent rise in same-store sales last month. Those companies and others slashed prices last month in an effort to clean up bloated inventories left over from weak holiday sales.
Retail industry analysts consider same-store, or comparable-store, sales figures the best measure of a retailer's performance because they factor out sales from new stores that are not necessarily comparable.
Two large retailing companies had disappointing sales in January. The Limited Inc. said its same-store sales fell 5 percent from January 1994 in spite of its efforts to clear out fall and winter merchandise, and the Woolworth Corporation reported a 3 percent decline in same-store sales.
Goldman's Composite Comparable-Store Sales Index, a weighted average of the same-store sales of 49 retail chains, climbed 4.7 percent last month compared with 3.5 percent in January 1994 and in the same range as gains retailers have posted every month since September. A similar index compiled by Salomon Brothers using sales data from 22 retailers showed a 6.1 percent increase.
Retail companies have usually used January to clear out the mistakes they made in merchandising for the holiday sales season, which is the peak sales season of their fiscal year. Only 5 percent of their annual sales come in January, and the month usually represents 15 to 20 percent of their fourth-quarter volume. Most retailers' fourth quarters run from November through January.
"January is what January is: a clearance month that really doesn't tell you much," said Robert F. Buchanan, a retailing analyst at NatWest Securities. "February is going to give us a better indication of what trends look like."
Mr. Buchanan and other analysts said that several retailers had reported strong sales of early spring merchandise that they began to put out toward the middle of the month.
Mervyn's, the Dayton Hudson Corporation's long-troubled discount department store chain, had an 11.6 percent increase in same-store sales last month, in part because of good sales of spring merchandise. Talbots Inc., a women's specialty store chain that had a 5.5 percent increase in same-store sales, reported similar gains.
But analysts cautioned against reading much optimism into those reports. The muddy picture of the overall economy, with some indicators portending solid consumer spending ahead and others pointing to a slowdown, has made many hesitate to forecast the year yet.
Many analysts expect 1995 to be a tough year for retail companies, as higher interest rates eat into discretionary income. Real wage growth is slowing, housing sales have been slowing and installment credit is reaching a level that many economists consider unsustainable.
"Year-over-year growth in consumer spending is going to slow in 1995," Mr. Baum said. "That said, the retail stocks may be finished with their period of underperformance."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Steady After Scare On Mexican Aid Package

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday after a brief selloff prompted by a a challenge to President Clinton's aid package for Mexico.
A small group of right-wing House Republicans proposed a bill to block the package of $20 billion in loan guarantees. 
 The dollar stumbled on the news, but recouped some of its losses when Republican and Democratic legislative leaders, including the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, stood by the President's plan.
"It gave us some knee-jerk selling," said Win Thin, senior international economist at IDEA, a research institute in New York. "If Mexico doesn't do something in the next couple of weeks we're going to see some more selling pressure. The Mexican Government has to reassure the financial markets that it's ready to do the painful policies necessary."
Anxiety in the currency markets over the Mexican aid package has underscored the perception that the United States is vulnerable to the Mexican financial crisis.
Aside from a flurry of selling after the Republican proposal, the dollar traded in a narrow range with little volume yesterday.
In New York late in the day, the dollar edged up to 1.5185 German marks from 1.5180 marks on Thursday. It fell to 1.2815 Swiss francs from 1.2840 francs. The dollar rose to 99.43 Japanese yen from 99.20 yen.
By the afternoon, most currency dealers seemed resigned to a quiet day and began to focus on today's employment report for January.
"The market is now waiting to see the payroll numbers to begin assembling its expectations whether yesterday's rate hike is all that the Fed will do," said David De Rosa of the Swiss Bank Corporation, referring to the Federal Reserve's action on Wednesday raising both the Federal funds rate and the discount rate.
In other currency trading, the British pound was little changed after the Bank of England raised interest rates in an effort to restrain inflation as a recovery picks up steam. The British central bank raised its base lending rate by half a percentage point, to 6.75 percent, the highest level since November 1992.
Higher interest rates typically bolster a currency by making deposits denominated in it more attractive to foreign investors. Britain's increase, the third since September, had been widely expected by the financial markets. In New York trading, the pound fell to $1.5815 yesterday from $1.5827 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: For Arts, State Budget Less Than Reassuring

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
The state budget released by Gov. George E. Pataki this week answered a question that had been worrying arts organizations around New York City: would it include the second slice of $5 million in matching funds to arts groups promised under the Cuomo Administration?
The answer, buried in the two volumes of budget figures and notes released on Wednesday, was yes, but the news did not bring much relief to those who work in the arts. That is because overall financial support for museums, theaters, dance companies and other arts groups had been cut to $25.8 million from $32.6 million, a 21 percent reduction. 
 And with the cut, the challenge-grant program has become a mixed blessing for arts organizations.
The challenge grants were initially welcomed last year as an innovative way to stretch government dollars. They allowed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani a politically palatable means of restoring cuts he had made to the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, by demanding state and private matches for $5 million in municipal grants and setting conditions for the use of the money.
Norma P. Munn, chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, a nonprofit organization representing arts groups, said, though, that last year's challenge-grant money came from a state budget that had grown about $6 million over the amount recommended by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. With this year's decrease in the state arts budget, the challenge grants would come from a shrinking pie.
Amid deep cuts in the state budget and an austere climate in Albany, the setting aside of $2.5 million for challenge grants to the city -- and the start of another $2.5 million matching program for the rest of the state -- means the state money would lessen the discretionary funds that would otherwise be used to help defray the basic costs of creating art. The city and state challenge grants would reduce the amount left for general subsidies to $20.8 million, a level not seen since 1973, according to state figures.
"What you have is the impact of squeezing less and less money out of individual discipline programs," Ms. Munn said. This process, she contends, would disproportionately hurt New York City, because that is where arts groups are concentrated and where the economy is most dependent on tourists drawn to the arts.
"As you put these special programs into effect, you're increasingly not supporting the central mission of arts organizations, which is to create art," she said, noting that financing for some groups had to go for reaching new audiences, a requirement that museums, for example, met by using the money to extend hours or re-open galleries.
"If that discipline internally no longer has $1 million to spend, but $500,000, it is cut from somewhere."
Schuyler G. Chapin, the City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, said he was saddened by state cuts but pleased to see the second half of the $5 million included in the budget package. "It means the full completion of the challenge grant," he said. He said he did not expect the state's cuts to influence Mr. Giuliani in putting together the city budget, because New York's economy depends so heavily on the arts.
The setting aside of $2.5 million to start a similar challenge grant program for New York State would, theoretically, depend upon the ability of local governments and private donors to match the funds. Yesterday, some state arts officials expressed concern that groups in rural areas especially might have a hard time finding the matching money.
"The challenge makes it difficult," said Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts. "In the past, we've given our money to institutions that we thought were worthy. It's like saying: 'You know, the thing worked very well in the city. Why not upstate?' But the situation is different there."
Mrs. Hart said the cuts to the council's budget were in line with reductions at other departments, but she noted they came on the heels of a severe cut to $27 million from $54 million in 1990, which led arts groups to drop some of their activities and staff. "They're already so close to the bone, with this extra cut, they're going to go out of business," Mrs. Hart said.
Reductions in administration would also mean the laying off of at least 9 of the council's 45 employees. The Pataki budget presumes $345,000 in support from the National Endowment for the Arts, which has been under attack in Congress, and whose fate appears uncertain.

International
 Europeans are uneasy over President Clinton's Mexican rescue plan. Britain, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Switzerland withheld their support from an American-backed loan package approved by the International Monetary Fund. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON'S BUDGET FALLS WELL SHORT OF G.O.P. DEMANDS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton will propose $1.6 trillion of spending in his 1996 budget, and he would more than offset the cost of a middle-class tax cut with savings in other areas of the budget. But he still falls far short of Republican demands for a balanced budget in the year 2002.
Mr. Clinton's budget request, to be submitted to Congress on Monday, shows a deficit of $196.7 billion for the 1996 fiscal year, up slightly from the $192.5 billion that he projects for this year. Although his Budget Message boasts that his economic policies have sharply reduced the deficit from record levels, he says the deficit will probably stay in the range of $190 billion through 2005. 
 The budget is always a political document, and a theme of Mr. Clinton's 1996 budget is that he wants to "work with Congress," now controlled by Republicans. Indeed, he appears to be in a race with them as he tries to eliminate or consolidate programs or transfer them to the states or to private industry.
Parts of the Clinton budget echo Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia. "The American people remain deeply dissatisfied with how their Government works," the budget says. "Many programs, perhaps even whole agencies, have outlived their usefulness."
In confidential page proofs of the budget, Mr. Clinton says he can "save $2 billion by ending more than 130 programs" and "provide better service to Americans by consolidating more than 270 other programs."
For example, he asks Congress to abolish the Interstate Commerce Commission and to eliminate the role of the Army Corps of Engineers in smaller projects like the control of beach erosion, "local flood protection" and the construction of recreational harbors.
He says private meteorologists should take over some functions of the National Weather Service. He would rely on private businesses to track and communicate with spacecraft like the space shuttle. And he asks Congress to terminate 37 "low-priority" education programs.
But budget documents show that Mr. Clinton will propose a major increase in his national service program, Americorps, which has been denounced by Mr. Gingrich as a form of "coerced volunteerism."
The number of participants, now 20,000, would rise to 33,000 at the end of this year and 47,000 next year under Mr. Clinton's proposal. For the corps' parent agency, which operates several volunteer programs, he requests $1 billion in 1996, an increase of $290 million over this year's appropriation.
Mr. Clinton says his economic policies have slashed the deficit from the record $290 billion in 1992. Still, his proposals would require additional Federal borrowing of nearly $1 trillion over five years, and the Federal Government would spend $194 billion more than it collects in revenue in the year 2000. The House Republicans' Contract With America calls for eliminating the deficit by 2002, but the Republicans have not specified the cuts needed to do so.
The President's $1.6 trillion budget for 1996 breaks down this way: $262 billion, or 16 percent of the total, for the military; $351 billion, or 22 percent, for Social Security; $271 billion, or 17 percent, for Medicare and Medicaid, and $257 billion, or 16 percent, for interest on the Federal debt, the accumulated total of Federal borrowing.
International activities, including foreign aid, would receive $21 billion, or 1.3 percent.
The President and the Republicans have agreed that Social Security is off limits in their quest for savings, and Mr. Clinton has said he would not tamper with Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly or disabled.
That means that a large share of the cuts must come from domestic programs subject to annual appropriations, including law enforcement, scientific research, highway construction and environmental protection. These account for $266 billion, or 17 percent of the budget.
The remainder -- $184 billion, or 11 percent of the total -- is for benefit programs like welfare, food stamps, Civil Service pensions and veterans' benefits, which are automatically available to people who meet certain eligibility criteria.
In his Budget Message, Mr. Clinton says: "Now that we have brought the deficit down, we have no intention of turning back. My budget keeps us on the course of fiscal discipline by proposing $81 billion in additional deficit reduction through the year 2000."
Mr. Clinton estimates that his tax cut, including a new tax credit for children and a new deduction for college expenses, will cost the Treasury $63 billion over five years. But he says, "I am proposing enough spending cuts to provide more than twice as much in budget savings -- $144 billion -- as the tax cuts will cost."
He says the net effect would be to save $81 billion over five years.
The savings fall into four categories: $26 billion from radically reorganizing three Cabinet departments and two agencies; $81 billion from extending a cap on military and other discretionary spending through the year 2000; $32 billion from benefit programs, and $5 billion from lower interest payments on the Federal debt.
Here are other highlights of the President's budget:
*The Federal deficit would rise to $213 billion in 1997, drop back to $196 billion in 1998 and then "fluctuate in a narrow range" around that level for several years. But the economy would continue to grow, so the ratio of the deficit to the gross domestic product would be lower than at any other time in two decades.
*Mr. Clinton proposes an across-the-board pay raise of 2.4 percent for Federal civilian employees and military personnel. The budget includes $3 billion for the raises, which would take effect in January 1996. There would be raises of 3.1 percent in 1997 and 2.1 percent in each of the next three years.
*The President proposes to increase fees charged for registration of securities and other activities at the Securities and Exchange Commission. New revenue is expected to total $1.7 billion over five years.
*Mr. Clinton would require the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Federal Reserve to charge fees for examination of state-chartered banks and bank holding companies. This proposal is expected to raise $500 million over five years.
*Medicare, for the elderly, and Medicaid, for poor people, are growing more slowly than predicted in previous budgets. But the growth is still phenomenal. Over the next five years, Medicare outlays are expected to rise 9.1 percent a year, while Medicaid grows 9.3 percent a year.
The President's budget says that health programs account for almost 40 percent of the total increase in Federal spending over the next five years. He says the deficit could be eliminated in less than a decade if per capita spending on Medicare and Medicaid increased no faster than consumer prices in general. But Mr. Clinton, battered by his experience with health care legislation last year, offers no major proposals to rein in the cost of Medicare.
The budget provides details of Mr. Clinton's previously announced plan to "reinvent" the Departments of Energy, Transportation and Housing and Urban Development, the Office of Personnel Management and the General Services Administration.
Mr. Clinton said the staff of the personnel agency, which now has 5,400 employees, would be cut by a third. And the staff of the General Services Administration, the central housekeeping and supply agency for the Government, with 16,800 employees, would be halved.
In keeping with the new spirit of federalism, Mr. Clinton proposes to consolidate scores of Federal grants and let local officials decide how to use the money. The Transportation Department now has 30 grants for construction and repair that would be merged into one of $10 billion a year.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development would merge 60 programs into eight worth $26 billion next year. He proposes to "demolish thousands of severely deteriorated, mostly vacant units," and he says that "by 1998 no housing authority will receive funds directly from HUD." Instead, tenants will get vouchers that they can use to pay rent in any public or private housing.
Like Ronald Reagan in 1986, President Clinton proposes to sell four Federal agencies that provide electric power at subsidized rates to millions of people in the West and South. He proposes to convert a fifth such agency, the Bonneville Power Administration, to a Government corporation, so it could "operate more efficiently."

HEADLINE: Western Allies Rebuff Clinton In Mexico Vote

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 2

 BODY:
In an extraordinary sign of the European uneasiness over President Clinton's plan to rescue Mexico's economy, financial officials disclosed today that six European countries withheld their support from an American-backed loan package approved by the International Monetary Fund.
Although the $17.8 billion package was accepted late Wednesday, the fact that six key Western nations -- Britain, Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium and Switzerland -- abstained from approving the Clinton plan was taken as a rare rebuff of American leadership in the handling of an emergency. 
 The six countries complained that they had not been consulted on the $10 billion increase in loans to Mexico, which was announced by President Clinton on Tuesday evening as part of an emergency package to bolster confidence in the falling peso.
"There is a feeling of unease among Europeans that the whole thing was not handled very well at all," said one European official whose country abstained.
European financial officials, none of whom wished to be named, said the plan was pushed through too quickly, without regard to whether it might dry up I.M.F. funds, including those for big developing countries with debt problems and the formerly Communist countries of East Europe.
"We think the package was put together with too much haste and that the member countries did not have enough time to evaluate it," said a German Government official.
Some European financial officials said France would also have abstained were it not that the managing director of the fund, Michel Camdessus, is French.
European officials said that not only were they caught by surprise on Tuesday when President Clinton announced the increase of I.M.F. aid, to $17.8 billion from the previously announced $7.8 billion, but that they received the documents detailing the agreement less than an hour before the meeting on Wednesday to vote on the package.
"For many countries, this package came out of nowhere," said one French official. "There was no prior consultation. This was done totally outside standard procedures. No one wanted the package to collapse, but countries wanted to make a point."
A German official added: "We normally have two to three weeks to approve such aid packages. When there is an emergency, we usually have two to three days. On this one, we had less than an hour."
An American official at the I.M.F. acknowledged that the United States had not consulted its European allies before announcing the decision to go ahead with the Mexico plan.
"There wasn't really time for consultation," said Karin Lissakers, the United States executive director at the I.M.F. "The Europeans aren't wrong about the lack of consultation and we understand fully their frustration."
She said the Administration made the decision in order to stop what was clearly a growing crisis of confidence in Mexico. She added that despite criticism that too much money was offered in the package to Mexico, "it was better to err on too much rather than too small."
European officials said the size of the I.M.F. loan for Mexico left them concerned about aid requests from other countries, particularly Russia, which is currently negotiating a $15 billion package.
They said such a huge injection of funds into the Mexican economy, while not jeopardizing the liquidity of the institution, would make it more difficult to provide loans to other countries. The officials also warned that as a result of the Mexican crisis, countries like Brazil may need additional assistance and will come to the fund expecting larger loans.
The $17.8 billion is part of a package of about $50 billion in assistance for Mexico announced by President Clinton after he failed to muster support in Congress for $40 billion in United States loan guarantees.
European central banks will put up $10 billion in loans from the Bank for International Settlements, based in Basel, Switzerland, and the United States has promised $20 billion from its Exchange Stabilization Fund.
Of concern to European financial officials was the fact that such large loans represent a change in the fund's lending policy. Usually, approval of I.M.F. assistance -- along with agreement by the receiving country to institute fiscal and monetary reforms -- is meant to cover a small portion of the monetary needs of a country in financial straits. Then the country can seek more help from commercial banks or other countries.
"This amount greatly exceeds what would traditionally be the amount of I.M.F. lending, and we think it is a bad precedent," said a Dutch official. "The fund is supposed to play a catalytic role."
European officials said the $17.8 billion was several times what Mexico would qualify for under normal circumstances.
Fund officials said no formal vote is normally taken on such loans, and none was recorded Wednesday night. But several European countries warned ahead of time that they would abstain and formally made that position clear today.
European officials said that despite their ire at what they regarded as being railroaded, the aid was needed and thus they did not vote against the program.
Assistance packages like the one for Mexico require only a majority vote for approval. Voting power in the I.M.F. is weighted according to the relative financial contributions of the member countries, with greater voting power in the hands of wealthy industrial countries.
If the fund's reserves drop and officials deem that a new injection of money is needed from member countries, a vote of at least 85 percent is required.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET;
Budget-Cut Target Has 9 Lives Plus

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget includes one item that is a hardy perennial on the list of programs to cut: "impact aid" to school districts having sizable numbers of military personnel or other Federal employees.
The program is intended to compensate school districts for revenue lost because of their inability to tax Federal property. President Ronald Reagan tried to reduce these payments in 1981, when they totaled $706 million, and he had some success. But they have since climbed back, reaching $728 million this year. 
 Under current law, some districts get aid even though large numbers of Federal workers there live on private property. Critics say there is no particular justification for such payments because those parents usually pay state and local income and property taxes and contribute to the local economy by buying goods and services.
The future of the program may suggest how serious Congress is about reducing the budget deficit.
Carroll Dexter, director of program operations at the impact aid office of the Education Department, said, "They've been trying to eliminate this program since Eisenhower in 1954."
The program, Mr. Dexter said, has enjoyed bipartisan support because every one of the 435 Congressional districts has had some children whose family connections to the Federal Government generated Federal aid for local schools.

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET;
Excerpts From President clinton's 1996 Budget Message to the Congress

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from page proofs of President Clinton's Budget Message, which he will send to Congress on Monday:
The 1996 budget, which I am transmitting to you with this message, builds on the Administration's strong record of economic progress during the past two years and seeks to create a brighter future for all Americans. 
 Our economic plan helped bring the deficit down from $290 billion in 1992, to $203 billion in 1994, to a projected $193 billion this year, providing three straight years of deficit reduction for the first time since Harry Truman was President.
Now that we have brought the deficit down, we have no intention of turning back. My budget keeps us on the course of fiscal discipline by proposing $81 billion in additional deficit reduction through the year 2000. I am proposing to save $23 billion by reinventing three Cabinet departments and two other major agencies, to save $2 billion by ending more than 130 programs altogether, and to provide better service to Americans by consolidating more than 270 other programs. Under my plan, the deficit will continue to fall as a percentage of G.D.P. to 2.1 percent, reaching its lowest level since 1979.
 
Standard of Living
 To build a more prosperous America, one with rising living standards for all Americans, we must turn our attention to those who have not benefited from the current recovery. My budget proposes to do that.
I am proposing a middle class bill of rights, which will provide tax relief to middle-income Americans. The middle class bill of rights includes a $500 per child tax credit for middle income families with children under 13; expands eligibility for Individual Retirement Accounts and allows families to make penalty-free withdrawals for a range of educational, housing and medical needs, and offers a tax deduction for the costs of college, university or vocational education. Also, I am proposing to revamp our confusing array of job training programs by consolidating some 70 of them. In my G. I. bill for America's workers, I propose to offer dislocated and low-income workers skill grants through which they can make their own choices about the training they need to find new and better jobs.
And I am proposing to pay for this middle class bill of rights with specific spending cuts. In fact, I am proposing enough spending cuts to provide more than twice as much in budget savings, $144 billion, as the tax cuts will cost, $63 billion, over five years.
 
Creating Opportunity
 By itself, the Federal Government cannot rebuild America's communities. My national service program provides incentives for Americans of all ages to volunteer their services in local communities across the country and earn money for their own education. The budget proposes to invest more in our urban centers as well as in rural areas. And I will work with Congress to enact comprehensive welfare reform that embodies the principles of work and responsibility for able-bodied recipients while protecting their children.
I am proposing new funds with which states and localities can hire more police, build more space in prisons and boot camps, invest in prevention programs and provide drug treatment.
While working to fulfill the Federal Government's responsibility to secure our borders against illegal immigration, the budget also proposes funds to assist states that are unduly burdened with the health, education and prison-related costs associated with illegal immigrants.
I am seeking significant new funding for the Advanced Technology Program at the Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology, NASA's New Technology Investments, the Defense Department's Technology Reinvestment Project, biomedical research at the National Institutes of Health, and research and development at the National Science Foundation.
 
American Leadership
 We have begun the post-cold war era and welcome one of its most significant fruits -- the continuing efforts of Russia and the newly independent states to move toward democracy and economic freedom.
We are redoubling our efforts to promote an open trading system in Asia, as well as in Latin American and the rest of the globe. I am proposing increased funding for our trade promotion agencies.
Our military strength works in synergy with our foreign policy. My defense funding initiative, a $25 billion increase in defense spending over the next six years, marks the third time that I have raised defense spending to support and maintain the most capable military force in the world.
 
Effective Government
 In the coming months, the Vice President will lead Phase II of our crusade to reinvent Government -- an effort to identify other agencies and programs to restructure or terminate, to sort out responsibilities among the Federal, State and local levels of government and to choose functions better performed by the private sector.
 
Conclusion
 Our agenda is working. By cutting the budget deficit, investing in our people and opening world markets, we have begun to lay the foundation for a strong economy for years to come. And by reinventing the Federal Government, cutting red tape and layers of management, we have begun to make Government more responsive to the American people.

HEADLINE: 3 City Employees Among 14 Arrested in Loan-Sharking Scheme

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
At 7:30 yesterday morning, three F.B.I. agents entered the Yonah Schimmel Knish Bakery on the Lower East Side just as Alex Wolf, the manager, was starting coffee. "I thought maybe taxes," he said. The agents ruffled through business papers and removed from the window a photograph of Sheldon Keitz, who Mr. Wolf said has operated the legendary 85-year-old establishment for the last five years or so.
The agents left the smiling photo of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. 
 Mr. Keitz was one of 15 people, including three employees of the city's Human Resources Administration, who law-enforcement officials said were part of a loan-sharking ring.
After a yearlong investigation sparked by a tip from an informer within Human Resources, the authorities arrested 14 of the suspects yesterday. Mr. Keitz was not arrested because he was out of the country. Mr. Wolf said his employer was on one of his frequent trips to Russia, where he says Mr. Keitz is in the casino business.
Federal and city investigators said the ring loaned money at exorbitant interest rates of 120 percent or more a year -- loans received and paid back at a variety of places across the city, including at least two Human Resources offices and the knish bakery, at 137 East Houston Street.
Part of the loan-sharking activity was said to have taken place at an H.R.A. office in downtown Brooklyn, at 80 DeKalb Avenue, and one at 115 Chrystie Street in lower Manhattan. Both housed operations of the agency's Office of Child Support Enforcement.
The ring had been operating for as long as 10 years, investigators said. They estimated that close to $500,000 in loans were outstanding during the investigation.
The inquiry began early last year, when an H.R.A. employee went to the city's Department of Investigation with stories about loan-sharking at the downtown Brooklyn office.
The informer was not without self-interest. Facing criminal charges of bilking H.R.A. clients by pretending to be a lawyer who could help them with their problems, he hoped to gain leniency by reporting the loan-sharking operation, the authorities said.
The employee reported that 30 workers at the Brooklyn office had taken loans at usurious interest rates from two men known as Harvey and Turk, and that an H.R.A. supervisor was the men's representative and would arrange the illicit transactions for a commission of $20 for every $500 borrowed.
The loans to H.R.A. employees were usually between $500 and a few thousand dollars, the authorities said. The victims, whose names were withheld, were described as modestly paid people with financial problems but without the credit rating that would permit them to borrow from legitimate lenders.
Investigators said they believe employees at other H.R.A. offices may have borrowed from the ring.
Zachary W. Carter, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, said that the investigation involved the use of an undercover New York City police detective who posed as a borrower and wiretaps on the telephones of some of those arrested.
Mr. Carter said the leader of the ring was Harvey Olchin, a 61-year-old retired butcher from Forest Hills, Queens, and that he was the "Harvey" the informant had referred to. Mr. Carter called him the "banker for the operation," the source for the loaned cash.
Mr. Olchin's wife, Ruth, was also arrested, and his brother-in-law, Jack Levy of Bayside, Queens, was described as the "Turk" of the operation. Mr. Levy, who was among those arrested, was one of the people "used as collectors and enforcers by Olchin, threatening violence and property damage if loans were not paid back with the extortionate rates of interest," Mr. Carter said.
Also arrested was Inez Bridges Richardson of Far Rockaway, Queens, an H.R.A. supervisor who the informer had reportedly identified as the person who represented the lenders at the Brooklyn office. Alfred DiStefano of Manhattan and Marvin Parker of the Bronx, both employees of the H.R.A.'s Chrystie Street office, were also arrested.
The three H.R.A. employees "were all involved in making loans to and collecting money from subordinates and coworkers in the H.R.A.," Mr. Carter said.
The suspects were arraigned yesterday on loan-sharking conspiracy charges in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Reached after being freed on bail, they declined to comment.
Specifics about the Schimmel knishery's purported role in the case were provided in affadavits filed in court by James Hylton, a city police detective supervising the inquiry.
He said that on Dec. 26, Mr. Keitz, in an apparently wiretapped phone call, "told Olchin that he would collect the envelopes and hold them for him, or meet him at the store."
The investigation, Detective Hylton wrote, "has revealed that 'envelope' refers to money from loan proceeds" and "store"' refers to the Schimmel.
Last June, the detective said, the informant and Mr. Olchin agreed to meet at the knishery so that the informant could pay Mr. Olchin some of the loan money he owed. But Mr. Olchin was not at the knishery when the informant arrived, according to the affidavit, so the informant "gave the $200 for Olchin to a woman at the bakery."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The owner of the Yonah Schimmel Knish Bakery at 137 East Houston Street was implicated in a loan-sharking scheme that involved employees of the Human Resources Administration. The bakery was said to be one place where loans were repaid. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Mayor Seeks Fiscal Help From the U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. outlined an ambitious plan today to save Washington from fiscal disaster, but he wants Congress to pay for a big part of it.
His proposal to eliminate the city's $ 631 million deficit would cut an unspecified number of jobs, require wage reductions and scale back city services like garbage collection and health care without raising taxes. But it also asks Congress to assume responsibility for the city's growing Medicaid costs -- an estimated $ 267 million this year, or 42.3 percent of the deficit. 
 James T. Walsh, the New York Republican who heads the House subcommittee for the District of Columbia, said he would not respond to Mr. Barry's plan until a Federal audit of city finances had been completed. And that is being held up, Mr. Walsh said, by unanswered requests for more documents.
Still, Mr. Walsh described the city's current state as "a serious fiscal crisis," and he said that if Mr. Barry could not correct the situation, Congress would, using whatever tools necessary, including a bailout. This would mean taking control of city finances from District leaders -- something Mayor Barry wants to avoid.
Jim Jeffords, a Vermont Republican who heads the Senate subcommittee on the District, sounded a cautionary note. "I cannot be optimistic that Congress will be willing to take extraordinary steps to help the District with problems that are all too ordinary across the country," he said in a statement
At a news conference today, Mr. Barry dismissed the suggestion that his request for money from a Republican-led Congress was fanciful. He said he was optimistic that Federal lawmakers would understand the city's predicament and be willing to help.
Mr. Walsh said nothing would happen anyway until the city meets the requirements Congress had set forth last year, to cut the budget by $ 140 million and eliminate 2,000 positions from the city government.
"I've got to see that happen; that's very important," Mr. Walsh said, a caution to any favorable consideration of the city's latest request. "They need to make those cuts."
Mr. Barry said that he had prepared a contingency plan in case Congress denied the city's request for help. But he declined to say what the plan is, adding that "it would be irresponsible to assume we won't get what we want."
The plan presented today, Mr. Barry said, would save $ 224 million in reduced city services, $ 70 million through layoffs, furloughs and wage cutbacks of up to 10 percent and another $ 70 million in restructuring of debt on loans, as well as the help from Congress to offset problems with Medicaid spending, the biggest drain on the budget.
Facing the largest of the proposed cuts, $ 68 million, the Department of Human Services would eliminate benefits for 19- and 20-year-olds and for pregnant women in the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program. Five local health clinics would be closed or consolidated.
The public school system, which has already canceled seven days of classes and 300 teaching positions, is being asked to cut spending by $ 45 million. The Department of Corrections is facing cuts of $ 25 million. And the Mayor's proposal also includes plans to lay off 90 doctors at the city's largest hospital, end tree trimming and reduce garbage pickups.
As part of the plan, the District would seek to transfer some services, like administering Medicaid and running a prison in Lorton, Va., to the Federal Government.
He said that a projected $ 91 million cash shortfall for the year, which was not addressed in his proposal, would be dealt with in some other way. But he did not elaborate.
Many of the workers who could be affected by the layoffs and furloughs were among the thousands Mr. Barry hired during the economic boom of his previous administrations from 1978 to 1990.
Advocacy groups for the poor and city unions condemned the planned cuts in services and jobs. The labor leaders argued that they were unfair because they did not appear to affect city employees at the management level. They also called for more taxes on business.
"The sacrifices cannot be one-sided," said Gizaw Gessesse, executive director of an American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees local. "Management cannot be spared at the expense of front-line workers. The wealthy cannot dump their responsibility on the city's poor."
Ron Richardson, the executive secretary-treasurer of the Hotel and Restaurant Employees Union, said the Barry plan did not make sense.
"It only apportions the pain," he said. "It affects everybody in the city. But the business community isn't being touched."
Mr. Barry, who has enjoyed strong support from city unions, said that he agreed with the labor leaders but that he had been powerless against the constant opposition to new taxes by the city's business leaders.
"Get them to stop opposing taxes," he said. "I can't."

HEADLINE: Pataki Plans A Sharp Cut In Rental Aid

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
As part of his plan to cut the budget and restructure the state's welfare system, Gov. George E. Pataki wants to cut assistance to the poor in myriad ways, including reducing rent allowances and cutting emergency money for utility bills.
On Monday, Mr. Pataki proposed the deepest cuts in the state's 60-year history of welfare programs. But it was not until late Wednesday, when he presented a package of bills to the Legislature that will enact his budget, that some of the specific cuts became clear. 
 They include sharp reductions in housing subsidies for 21,000 welfare recipients, as well as the elimination of monthly allowances for pregnant women on welfare and money for welfare recipients to buy basic items of furniture like mattresses or cribs. Emergency payments of bills for welfare recipients facing utility cutoffs would also be eliminated.
The cost of these programs is shared by the Federal, state and local governments. The state cuts could result in cuts in matching local funds. In fact, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has also proposed eliminating city payments for several of the programs.
As advocates for the poor said the Governor's plan could leave thousands of families homeless, Mr. Pataki worked yesterday to sell his budget in Manhattan.
The Governor defended his $343 million in welfare cuts, saying that the program had grown out of control and that his efforts to cut payments and require work would help break what he called a cycle of dependency "from year to year and generation to generation."
"You have heard and I'm sure will continue to hear," he told a business group during a luncheon at the New York Hilton, " 'Oh, isn't this attacking the poor, or isn't this an effort to balance the budget or cut taxes on the backs of the poor?' "
"The people now trapped in that welfare system," he said, "have the same desires for themselves and their children and their grandchildren: to see them get a decent education and build a better life and have the opportunity to become active and successful participants in the American dream. The system now traps them and penalizes them for doing that."
Mr. Pataki's emphasis on welfare yesterday underscored its importance in his overall budget and the importance of drumming up public support. Today, he is scheduled to fly to Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse to speak to other groups.
As the Governor was speaking at the Hilton, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, chief among his Democratic opponents, was meeting with Mr. Giuliani at City Hall.
Mr. Silver said that he told the Mayor he believed the budget proposals would hurt the city. "The City of New York appeared to be a target, whether it was education aid, or other areas," Mr. Silver said. Mr. Giuliani, on the other hand, has said that the budget appears to help New York City.
Several advocates for the poor said yesterday that the details of the Governor's cuts for welfare recipients showed that he had gone further than he had originally outlined. The plan would eliminate emergency assistance for recipients who are disabled or blind and end the payment of brokers' and finders' fees for government-subsidized apartments.
"It says that his welfare bill is far more conservative and budget-driven than we ever would have expected," said Russell Sykes, deputy director of the State Communities Aid Association and a welfare expert.
Mr. Pataki's plan on housing allowances would have the broadest effect in New York City, and is aimed at settling a question that has been tied up in court since 1987: Is the state allowance for housing welfare recipients adequate? For years, advocates have argued, and state data has confirmed, that the subsidies often do not come near the rents that landlords charge.
If Mr. Pataki's proposal is approved by the Legislature and survives a likely court challenge, 21,000 people would lose a court-ordered subsidy that bridges the difference between their basic housing allowances and their actual rents -- a move that could cause more people to become homeless, advocates say. The proposal would save the state $25 million this fiscal year, and $50 million in the next fiscal year. New York City would see a similar but smaller savings.
The legislation would set into law rates that the state considered adequate for shelter allowance. That measure is missing in current law, and has prompted complicated litigation on the issue.
But advocates complain that the rates in Mr. Pataki's proposal, which were initially set in 1988, are far too low. For example, the Governor's plan would set the average monthly housing allowance for a family of three on welfare in New York City at $270. Outside of New York City, the average assistance would be $260.
Shelly Nortz, director of state policy for the New York State Coalition for the Homeless, said the help for the poor would be "torn to pieces with these proposals." And in the long run, she argued, the government might have to pay more, because emergency shelter and services for the homeless are far more expensive than paying money to keep people in their own homes.
"I don't think the Governor understands that the consequence isn't just borne by the people who lose their income and lose their housing, but also by society as a whole," she said. "There is a reason that public welfare programs were created in the first place, and that is that the public conscience would not tolerate the existence of poor houses and soup lines."
Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the state budget division, said that the proposal was aimed at setting what the state considered adequate rents and stopping the growing number of people applying for the allowance over the basic rate.
Under a 1992 State Supreme Court order, welfare recipients whose rent is higher than their payments can apply for the extra supplement. Miss Hutton said the number of people who received the extra money had doubled since last year and was expected to double again next year.
"What has happened in the last few years is that we have encouraged a system to develop in which people on welfare could fall behind on their rent and know that the state would come in at the last minute, cover their arrears and pay future rent for them," Miss Hutton said.
Meantime, she said, "their more responsible neighbor next door could continue to pay rent on a monthly basis and not get this extra money."

HEADLINE: THE CLINTON BUDGET: THE POLITICS
Big Bargaining Chip;
President's Budget May Be Dead, But He Can Use It to Make a Deal

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Presidential budgets are seldom more than the opening ante in an annual poker game between Capitol Hill and the White House. But President Clinton's proposals for scattered spending cuts and modest tax breaks are even more preliminary than usual: He is sending them off to a hostile Congress not only ready to match his bet, but eager to raise him.
If the budget is always more a political statement of executive priorities than a reliable guide to legislative reality, this one is at once a dead-letter and an airmail special. The Republicans who control both houses for the first time in 40 years have vowed to use the Democratic President's plan as the basis for even greater spending cuts and tax reductions. 
 "I can't think of anything that Clinton could do, short of subscribing to the Contract With America, that would get the Republicans to say that he's done enough," said Allen Schick, a student of the budget process and a professor at George Mason University. "When you hear the phrase 'dead on arrival,' what that really means is not that it's dead, but that it's a document for bargaining. His real budget is still in his back pocket."
Accordingly, the President's advisers say he has tried to define himself as much by the programs he will seek to preserve -- nutrition grants for women and children, Head Start, national service, immunization, community development banks -- as by those he is willing to cut.
And in proposing to eliminate about 130 programs -- whether old chestnuts like the Interstate Commerce Commission and the strategic helium reserve, or new sacrifices like some smaller educational programs -- Mr. Clinton is both striving to signal that he, too, is serious about shrinking and reshaping the Government, and trying to keep his powder dry for the fights he cares most about.
"We have a lot of budget cuts that are very important and significant in this budget," Mr. Clinton told reporters today. "And I'm looking forward to working with Congress to see how we can do even better. And I think that -- I'm encouraged by what they said, that they want to pay for their tax cuts. And so I think when I submit the budget, I think it will be the beginning of a very positive thing. I don't have bad feelings about it."
James C. Miller 3d, who as Ronald Reagan's budget director often saw his work torn apart by a Democratic Congress's demands to increase domestic spending and Mr. Reagan's insistence on expanding the military, said Mr. Clinton's proposals would be far from irrelevant.
"Let me tell you something," Mr. Miller said. "If I'm old Newt Gingrich or Bob Dole, I'd be very anxious to see a list of the President's 50 biggest proposals, because there'll be things on there that look good to them."
One of the President's senior economic advisers, speaking on condition of anonymity, put it another way: "The budget's hardly D.O.A. They're looking to see what cuts we're going to do, because they'd like to take a lot of our cuts and say, 'Thank you very much.' So as we were doing cuts, there was not a sense of, 'This is false, it's not going to happen.' Just the opposite."
In fact, the White House's main goal so far has been to stay in the game. The broad details of the budget Mr. Clinton will submit on Monday have been known for weeks, since his address to the nation in December proposing new tax credits for families and deductions for college and technical education.
Unlike 1993, when Mr. Clinton's economic plan utterly dominated the debate in a Democratic Congress, or even last year when his budget message was eight bound pages chockablock with headings like "The Year Ahead" and bold, specific prescriptions for health care, crime and welfare, his letter to Congress this year is just over three pages, featuring headings like "Creating Opportunity and Encouraging Responsibility" and "Making Government Work."
The aim has been to position Mr. Clinton as the champion of working middle-class families, while painting Republican proposals for much deeper tax breaks or cuts in capital gains taxes as too soft on the rich, and warning that the Republican-backed balanced-budget amendment could place new burdens on the states or force cuts in programs like Social Security and Medicare.
"We have to put our cards on the table when we submit the budget proposal to the Congress," the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry said this week. "Congress can choose to do with that what it will."
What Congress is likely to do with it in the short term is wait just a bit. The Republicans are intent on passing the broad, 100-day promises provided in their Contract With America before delving too deeply into the messy and painful specifics of actual program cuts.
Mr. Clinton, too, is saving the specific proposals for how he would generate some of the most significant savings -- more than $50 billion over the next five years -- for springtime, when Vice President Al Gore is to present his second round of proposals for "reinventing" government by shedding and shrinking functions.
That is tricky for the President, since it will put him in the position of amending and revising his own proposals even as Congress is picking them apart. Mr. Clinton also faces the dual challenge of appeasing the Republicans in Congress, and moderates among the electorate, by showing his willingness to cut, without unduly alienating core Democratic constituencies likely to be hurt by such cuts.
In the end, Presidential advisers say, the challenge might not be vastly worse than dealing with a Democratic Congress that either passed some of Mr. Clinton's biggest initiatives by the barest majorities, or failed to approve them at all.
"There's no question this provides some opportunity for us," one senior aide said. "The President came here from Arkansas, and he wasn't someone who was wedded to a million different protected programs on the Hill. Now the Administration has a little more power with constituency groups to say, 'Hey, we want to protect some of these things, but they have to be reformed.' "

HEADLINE: Tackling the Fish Market Mess

 BODY:
Ending half a century of abdication by New York City -- and delivering on a promise he made a year ago -- Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has announced plans to impose municipal control on the mob-dominated Fulton Fish Market. This is welcome news for wholesalers who have suffered decades of bribery and extortion; for consumers forced to pay prices inflated by shakedowns and other transactional costs of crime, and for the city's economy as a whole. Over the years, the market's volume has shrunk dramatically as racketeers have driven suppliers and their refrigerated trucks to satellite markets elsewhere on the East Coast.
With $800 million in annual revenues, Fulton remains the country's largest fish and seafood market and the third-largest in the world. To visitors who take the early-morning tours, it still conveys the romance and energy captured in Joseph Mitchell's New Yorker essays years ago. To insiders, however, it is a place where fraud and payoffs are routine costs of daily business. And to the city and Federal prosecutors, it has been a source of constant frustration. 
 Fifty years ago, Thomas E. Dewey sent the infamous "Socks" Lanza to prison for using Seafood Workers Local 359 as an instrument of extortion and a personal piggy bank. In 1982 Federal authorities imprisoned Carmine Romano, a union official, for essentially the same reasons. Nevertheless, the market has remained the private turf of New York's leading Mafia families.
Mr. Giuliani, who is not a romantic when it comes to crime, now proposes to change all that. Under his plan, part of which will require City Council approval, the city for the first time would investigate, license and regulate all the market's businesses and its 800 or so workers. Any company with criminal ties would be denied a license and kicked out.
Mr. Giuliani also proposes to renegotiate the leases of wholesale dealers, who have been allowed to pay bargain-basement rents and to sublease space without city permission to "phantom dealers" who often disappear after running up big bills with out-of-town seafood suppliers. A 1992 study estimated the fair-market rental value of the leases at about $3 million -- fully $2.7 million more than the city now receives. Any increased income could be used to help pay for an overdue modernization of the market that will help entice business.
Mayor Giuliani has also targeted the strong arm tactics of the market's unlicensed unloaders who demand outrageous fees for prompt handling of perishable goods, as well as so-called "loaders" who purport to provide parking-lot security.
In a sense, Mr. Giuliani has come full circle. His investigation of Mafia influence eight years ago led to the appointment of a temporary Federal administrator. The administrator, Frank Wohl, made some progress but it has long been clear that only City Hall could finish the job.
Will Mr. Giuliani succeed where so many others have failed? Gerald McMahon, a lawyer for most of the unloading and loading companies, dismisses the plan as just another transitory scheme "to clean up the market when it does not need to be cleaned up."
But this is not a Mayor to be underestimated when he sets his mind to a problem. Council Speaker Peter Vallone has given his tentative approval to the fish market initiative. He can help fight corruption and generate badly needed revenue for the city by promptly rallying Council colleagues to approve whatever legislation is required.

HEADLINE: Cold-War Nostalgia

 BODY:
As part of their Contract With America, House Republicans are pressing ahead with a mischievous piece of legislation that would undo the Clinton Administration's modest efforts to adjust U.S. national security policy to post-cold-war realities. The bill, H.R. 7, has cleared three committees and seems headed toward House passage.
The legislation would increase pressure for higher defense spending, revive efforts to develop "star wars" missile defense systems, encourage reckless expansion of NATO defense guarantees to Eastern Europe and hobble U.S. participation in United Nations peacekeeping. It would also undermine Presidential authority by creating an unnecessary national security commission designed primarily to amplify the voice of the Republican Congressional leadership. 
 Despite the disintegration of the Soviet Union, the bill is built around the dubious assumption that a decade of modest defense cuts under Presidents Reagan, Bush and Clinton have seriously weakened American security.
At a time when no great power poses an immediate military threat to the United States and Republicans are poised to make deep cuts in domestic programs, there is no justification for increased defense spending. Certainly not on a missile defense system that is impractical, wildly expensive and designed to defeat a threat greatly diminished by the demise of the Soviet military.
Beyond these budgetary follies, the legislation takes a dangerously simplistic approach to expanding NATO by encouraging the early inclusion of East European countries. For now, these countries need help building democracy and market economies, not a military shield against a hollow Russian Army. The timing and pace of NATO expansion are delicate questions that cannot be micromanaged by Congress.
The drafters seem to view U.N. peacekeeping primarily as a danger to American lives and policies, rather than a cost-effective way to share the burdens of policing cease-fires and enforcing international resolutions. The bill would restrict American participation by limiting the kinds of missions Washington could join, reducing U.S. financial support and tightening the terms for American involvement when peacekeepers are under foreign command.
There is little need for that. When the U.S. contributes large numbers of troops to a U.N. operation, as in Haiti, an American military officer is generally in overall command. Participation in these missions, large or small, only takes place with the approval of Washington, and any enforcement operations ordered by the Security Council are subject to U.S. veto.
The bill does make a useful contribution by stipulating that American equipment contributed to U.N. operations be counted against the regular U.S. peacekeeping assessment. There is no reason for the U.S. to pay a hidden subsidy on top of an already excessive share of the costs.
President Clinton and Congressional democrats are understandably preoccupied with the Republican legislative march on domestic issues, but they cannot afford to ignore the advancement of this bill. House committee action eliminated some of its most egregious features, but much mischief remains. Without considerable further revision, it will undermine deficit-reduction efforts, twist defense strategy and project Congress into areas of foreign policy management best left to the President and his Cabinet.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Tilting the Scales

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Prevent victims of securities fraud from suing. Immunize company officials who manipulate the price of stock by false statements. Stop lawsuits against accountants and lawyers who were involved in savings-and-loan scams.
Good ideas? Not many Americans would think so. But those are some of the things that would result from passage of a bill, H.R. 10, that is expected to reach the House floor in about two weeks. It would carry out point 9 of Newt Gingrich's Contract With America. 
 "The Common Sense Legal Reform Act," it is called -- another of the wonderfully Orwellian names coined for provisions of the contract. A more accurate title would be the Protect the Wrongdoers Act.
Title I of H.R. 10, on tort reform, makes proposals to limit ordinary damage suits, especially those over faulty products. Title II, which has had less attention, would make drastic changes in securities law.
Under present law, for example, an investor who claims he was a victim of securities fraud must prove that the defendant he is suing had a reckless disregard for the truth. H.R. 10 would impose an even higher standard of proof: that the defendant knowingly engaged in securities fraud. That would be extremely hard for victims to prove, perhaps impossible in many cases.
The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., said last week that the standard of knowing fraud "could create a legal incentive [for company officials] to ignore indications of fraud. The phrase 'ignorance is bliss' could take on new meaning."
Another provision of Title II would make the loser in any private lawsuit over securities pay the lawyers' fees of the winner. This would be extremely intimidating to small, middle-class investors -- because company defendants could run up huge legal bills and an investor who sued would risk bankruptcy if he or she lost.
Utah's securities director, Mark Griffin, warned last week against the loser-pay rule. He is the spokesman for all 50 state securities regulators on the pending legislation.
"If we make the courts the playground for the very rich," Mr. Griffin said -- "that is, those who can afford to pay the expenses of the other party -- we have profoundly changed our judicial system."
Title I of H.R. 10, on tort suits, would also make losers pay the winners' legal fees. That rule, used in England, has been a rallying cry for conservative tort reformers in this country.
But now a powerful English voice has been raised against the English rule. The Economist, a conservative magazine skeptical of lawyers, urged in its Jan. 14 issue that Britain abandon the loser-pay rule.
"Enormous numbers of mostly middle-class people" simply cannot use the courts, The Economist said, because they must pay for the other side's lawyers if they lose. "For most people this means that they are risking financial ruin."
Today in Britain, The Economist said, "only the very wealthy can afford the costs and risks of most litigation. This offends one of the most basic principles of a free society: equality before the law."
Some proposals for reform of American tort law make good sense. One is to limit punitive damages. The Supreme Court has just agreed to review the award of $2 million to a man who bought a car without being told that its paint had been refinished to correct a defect. Such absurdities should not happen.
But H.R. 10 sweeps far more broadly than what could be called reform. As Mr. Griffin of Utah put it, in the name of stopping "frivolous lawsuits" it sees to it that "there are no lawsuits at all."
The bill might well kill the suits filed on behalf of pension funds and other entities that hold Orange County, California, bonds -- suits against Merrill Lynch, the firm that gave the county investment advice. Wall Street firms, not surprisingly, are among the enthusiastic supporters of H.R. 10.
Accounting firms, too. Some had to pay heavy damages for their failures in the S.&L. scandal. Their political action committees have given $4.4 million to Congressional candidates in the last four years, and they are pressing for "reform."
The effect of H.R. 10, and its real purpose, are to insulate the rich and powerful from being called to account at law.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: California Looks To Era of Growth

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Leaders in States Pledge to Reduce Taxes This Year" (front page, Jan. 30) contains a flagrant error, which strongly prejudices the argument for Gov. Pete Wilson's 15 percent cut in California's personal and corporate income tax rates. You state that "many are based on optimistic economic assumptions," and "Gov. Pete Wilson's proposed 15 percent cut in personal and income tax assumes 5.9 percent annual economic growth in the state and a victory in California's lawsuit against the Federal Government to recover costs related to illegal immigration." 
 Nothing could be further from the truth. As chairman of the Governor's task force on tax reform and reduction, I can assure you that the 5.9 percent figure is for nominal income growth, the sum of economic growth and inflation. This includes slightly under 3 percent real growth, and slightly over 3 percent inflation. The real growth assumption is below that of the Congressional Budget Office for the entire economy.
The growth of nominal income is more than 3 percentage points below that of the most widely quoted state economic forecast, that of U.C.L.A.'s business forecasting unit. Their real growth is more than twice that assumed for 1995 by our task force.
The economic assumptions were designed to be cautious. Virtually every economist would agree that a state or region coming out of a deeper recession than the national average would catch up over time. California's unemployment rate is still over 7 percent, compared with the national rate of 5.4 percent.
Hence, most private analysts, in academe or Wall Street, believe on balance California should grow more rapidly than the national average over the next few years.
While California and other states are suing the Federal Government for reimbursement for providing federally mandated services for illegal immigrants, and should prevail in court, the state's budget balance, or ability to reduce tax rates, does not depend on full reimbursement of these costs.
 
MICHAEL J. BOSKIN
Professor of Economics
Stanford University
Stanford, Calif., Jan. 30, 1995

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 
Job growth was surprisingly weak in January, with the unemployment rate rising to 5.7 percent, the Government said. The report provided the clearest sign yet that the economy is cooling off. For all practical purposes, the rise of three-tenths of a point in the jobless rate last month was the first real increase in unemployment in two and a half years. The latest figures indicated that the interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve may have done their job. [Page 1.] In New York State, unemployment rose to 6 percent. The jobless rate jumped to 7.7 percent in New York City and 7.2 percent in New Jersey. [44.]
President Clinton proposed an increase in the minimum wage, by 90 cents, to $5.15 an hour, over two years. [1.] 

Markets
 
Stocks surged after the weak employment report suggested that the Federal Reserve might curb its policy of raising interest rates. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 5.86 points. [33.]
The dollar gained against other leading currencies, bolstered by rallies in bond and stock markets in the United States. [43.]
Heating oil and natural gas prices climbed after forecasts showed a cold week ahead in the Midwest and Northeast. [43.]
Treasury bonds staged a strong rally, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling to its lowest level since September. [44.]
 
International
 
The Mounties are in hot pursuit of their royalties. To raise money, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police plans to license the image of the Mountie in his scarlet tunic and wide-brimmed hat. [33.]
 
Companies
 
The F.T.C. cleared a $1.42 billion takeover of QVC by Tele-Communications and Comcast, even though agency lawyers had recommended blocking the deal. The decision crowns Tele-Communications the undisputed king of TV home shopping. [33.]
Sea-Land Service plans to resume shipping out of Kobe, Japan, months earlier than had been anticipated. No containers or other goods have been flowing through the port -- Japan's largest -- since the devasting earthquake on Jan 18. [33.]
Ford Motor said sales rose 2.9 percent last month, led by light-truck sales. The increase suggested that demand in the auto market is stronger than previously believed. [33.]
Quaker Oats agreed to sell its European pet foods division to Dalgety P.L.C. of London for $700 million in cash. [35.]
An investment group is planning to buy the No. 2 supermarket chain in Chicago. The group, led by Yucaipa, will pay $750 million for Dominick's Finer Foods, a person close to the deal said. [35.]
Polaroid plans to dismiss up to 5 percent of its work force. It also plans to increase a stock buyback program by $100 million. [35.]
I.B.M. is moving away from its old corporate culture: the company will sell its 30-year-old headquarters building in Armonk, N.Y., and ditch a dress code that called for dark suits and starched white shirts for men, dresses or skirts for women. [24.]

A bit of studying is needed when parents invest in zero-coupon bonds to save up college tuition for their children. [31.]

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Weak Employment Report Helps Dollar Rise Broadly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose broadly yesterday, gaining on the strength of rallies in the bond and stock markets after a weaker-than-expected January employment report diminished fears of inflation by suggesting slower economic growth.
A sustained rally in American stocks and bonds would bolster the dollar, attracting money from overseas markets. Investors who cash out abroad and purchase stocks and bonds in the United States must first buy dollars. 
 "If the capital flows come back, you're going to see the dollar start to edge up," said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
But some analysts noted that the dollar made only moderate gains yesterday in less-than-robust trading. They said the currency remained under pressure from Mexico's troubles, an expected leveling-off of American interest rates and other factors.
"Over all, it was a very good day for the dollar," said Gary Sakamoto, vice president at National Westminster Bank P.L.C. in New York. "But it was a very civilized move; it didn't take off. We're far from a bullish trend."
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5267 German marks from 1.5185 marks on Thursday. It also rose to 1.2905 Swiss francs from 1.2815 francs and to 99.85 Japanese yen from 99.43 yen. The British pound fell to $1.5635 from $1.5815.
The dollar fell in early New York trading after the Labor Department reported that the economy created just 134,000 jobs last month, far fewer than analysts had expected.
The data suggested that the Federal Reserve had succeeded in slowing the economy and reducing the threat of higher inflation with seven increases in short-term interest rates over the last year.
"Many people think we're getting close to a peak in interest rates," Mr. Johnson of Harris Trust said. "We could get a stock and bond rally that would attract foreign money into U.S. markets and discourage U.S. investors from going abroad."
