HEADLINE: WEAKNESS IN JOBS SIGNALS A SLOWING OF THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
In the clearest sign yet that the economy is cooling off, the Government reported today that job growth was surprisingly weak in January and that unemployment rose to 5.7 percent.
For all practical purposes, the three-tenths of a point rise in the jobless rate last month was the first increase in unemployment in two and a half years. There was an artificial jump, which made comparisons invalid, when a new method of computing the jobless rate was introduced at the beginning of 1994. 
 The latest figures, while subject to quirks of weather and statistics that bar definitive conclusions, reduced the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates again soon, private analysts said. The Federal Reserve has been lifting rates in its effort to prevent inflation from accelerating as the economy advances closer to the low unemployment rate and tight labor market conditions that have historically led to higher wages and prices.
"The burden of proof is going to be on those who believe additional tightening is needed," said Richard B. Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Securities markets seemed to share the view that the Federal Reserve's yearlong ratcheting up of interest rates could well be finished for now. Bond prices soared enough to push long-term rates down to 7.62 percent, the lowest level since September, and stocks surged as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 57.87 points, to 3,928.64. [Page 33.]
The Federal Reserve had noted earlier signs of an emerging slowdown, but labeled them "tentative" when it raised rates this week for the seventh time in a year. The signs included soft spots in housing and vehicle sales and a buildup of inventories in warehouses and on store shelves.
Today's report showed that the weakness in the job market last month was widely scattered, with joblessness rising to 8.2 percent in California, from 7.7 percent, and from 4.7 percent to 5.3 in Illinois. Unemployment in New York rose to 6 percent and it jumped to 7.2 percent in New Jersey. [Page 44.]
A Federal Reserve spokesman said today that the central bank had not yet seen the Labor Department's report on the January job market when it took action on Wednesday. He said the customary procedure was followed in which the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, receives economic reports less than 24 hours before their official release, in this case on Thursday evening.
But not all of the evidence pointed in the same direction. Indeed, analysts said that even if Fed officials had known the contents of today's report it probably would have made little difference. Despite the rise in the unemployment rate and a payroll expansion of only 134,000 -- about half what had been anticipated -- the report showed the economy was still quite healthy.
The latest reading on consumer confidence also showed that the economy retains considerable momentum. The University of Michigan's final consumer sentiment index for January rose to 97.6 from 95.1 in December. The university also said its index of current economic conditions rose to 112, from 104.9 in December.
"Strength remains," John E. Silvia, an economist at Kemper Financial Services, told his clients. "The economy is not falling off a cliff and the unemployment rate is not rising rapidly."
Echoing that point, the Commerce Department, in a separate report, said factory orders rose 1.7 percent in December and jumped 10.2 percent for all of 1994. The yearly advance was the biggest since 1979 and was nearly double the increase of 1993.
"It confirms other information suggesting the manufacturing sector has good momentum," Carl Palash, an economist for MCM Moneywatch, a market research and analysis firm, told The Associated Press.
Indeed, in what Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, called the "brightest spot" of the jobs report, manufacturing employment climbed 39,000 in January. That is the fourth straight monthly gain, for a total increase of 161,000, in part reflecting the nation's powerful export drive of recent months as Europe and other areas of the world gathered economic strength.
An official said 15,000 of last month's 39,000 increase in jobs were in export-sensitive industries, defined as those in which at least 20 percent of their output is shipped abroad.
Another sign of vigor was an expansion by 18 minutes in the private-sector workweek and a six-minute expansion of factory overtime to a record 4.9 hours. Workers in the automotive industry averaged a high 46.6 hours a week last month, the report also showed.
Construction jobs grew 27,000, aided by unseasonably warm weather throughout the country, though this took a toll on jobs in other endeavors, like ski resorts. Employment in retailing was little changed.
Reflecting the lengthened workweek and buoyant factory sector, the index of aggregate weekly hours climbed 1 percent, to 132.3. Payroll jobs were revised down over all by 46,000 for December, but this was exactly offset by an upward revision for November.
The department's survey of households, on which the unemployment rate is calculated, showed people losing jobs but remaining in the work force, which swelled a substantial 411,000 last month.
The newly unemployed, those jobless for less than five weeks, jumped by 350,000 last month. But Government and private analysts caution that January figures are particularly hard to interpret because of the inflows and outflows of holiday workers.
On the other hand, it has become very clear that people of Hispanic origin are finding the nation's job market increasingly difficult; the Hispanic unemployment rate rose 1 point in January to 10.2 percent, the first time it has been as high as the rate for blacks since these statistics began in 1973. As recently as 12 months ago, the black rate was 2.5 points higher -- 13 percent compared with 10.5 percent.
In January 1985, the black rate was 4.7 points higher than the Hispanic rate.
By region, the worst performance last month was in the Northeast, where the jobless rate climbed three-tenths of a point, to 6.1 percent. The rate edged up a tenth of a point in the West, to 6.7 percent, and declined in the South (to 5.3 from 5.4) and in the Midwest (to 4.3 from 4.5).
Before rounding, the national jobless rate last month was 5.6741 percent, up from 5.4318, a change just above the threshold for statistical significance.
Ms. Abraham played down the rise in hourly earnings by noting that it reflected the fact that job gains were more concentrated than usual in industries with high earnings and long workweeks and that this series has historically shown substantial month-to-month variation.

One Dissent in Fed Vote
 WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (Bloomberg Business News) -- Federal Reserve policy makers were nearly unanimous in their decision to leave interest rates unchanged at their final meeting of 1994, according to minutes of the Dec. 20 session, which were released today.
The 11-to-1 vote of the Federal Open Market Committee more than a month ago left the Federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks at 5.5 percent. The lone dissenter, John P. LaWare, favored an immediate rate increase. "In his opinion, the expansion remained quite strong," the minutes said. "He saw a serious risk of rising inflation."
The Fed's decision to stay on the sidelines lasted until Wednesday when the committee raised the Federal funds rate by half a point, to 6 percent. The full Fed board also voted 7 to 0 to raise immediately the mostly symbolic discount rate on loans to its member banks by half a point, to 5.25 percent. The continued strength of the economy was cited by the policy makers as one reason they increased rates for the seventh time in less than a year.
The committee meets eight times a year, at intervals of five to eight weeks. Deliberations are held in secret and the minutes of the meetings are released on a delayed basis several weeks later.
The committee comprises the seven Fed governors and the presidents of the Fed's 12 district banks, five of whom can vote at any one time.

HEADLINE: Bonds Jump on Evidence Of Slowing Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond market rallied sharply yesterday on fresh evidence that the economy is slowing, leading some investors to speculate that the Federal Reserve will slow or halt its policy of raising interest rates.
 A weaker-than-expected employment report yesterday was the clearest sign yet that the Fed had done its job in keeping inflation subdued. The rally showed that investors are willing to lock into longer maturities if they are confident that the economy has cooled and that lower rates lie ahead.A flurry of buying sent the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond down to its lowest level since Sept. 8. Yields and prices move in opposite directions. Other maturities also rallied strongly.
 The price of the 30-year bond jumped 1 9/32 percentage points, to 9817/32 , for a yield of 7.62 percent, down from 7.74 percent on Thursday. For bondholders, it meant that for every $1,000 invested, they made $12.81.
 The Labor Department reported yesterday that the nation's unemployment rate rose to 5.7 percent last month from 5.4 percent in December as the economy created the fewest jobs in nearly a year. Only 136,000 jobs were added to the payrolls outside of the farm sector, the smallest number since the 101,000 gain in January 1994.
 The report, analysts said, provided compelling evidence that the economy was finally beginning to lose momentum, dragged down by the cumulative weight of the Fed's seven increases in short-term rates since a year ago.
 Analysts and traders said they saw less need for the Fed, which raised rates on Wednesday by 50 basis points, to move again. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 "We all recognize they're going to step back a little bit," Richard Schlanger, who helps manage $1.5 billion of bonds at Pioneering Management in Boston, told Bloomberg Business News.
 Indeed, the spread between the yield of the 2-year note and that of the 30-year bond was 48 basis points yesterday, up from 38 basis points Thursday. A widening spread indicates that the market does not expect another Fed rate increase for some time.
 The weakness of the employment report caught some investors by surprise, causing some large market participants to cover short positions.
 Short-covering occurs when traders buy back borrowed securities they had previously sold short in the hopes of profiting from lower prices. But if prices begin to rise, instead of fall, short-sellers needs to cover their positions by buying back securities to limit their losses.
 While the employment report cheered a battered bond market, economists noted that the data also disclosed some signs of inflation, which could halt the rally, or limit follow-through buying in the next session.
 Eugene J. Sherman, director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, noted that the report showed substantial increases in the workweek and in hourly earnings. "So, if you combined the hourly earnings with the lengthened workweek, and the additional number of people working," he said, "you'll find a big increase in personal income for the month." Such data suggest then, he said, that the economy is still very strong.
 Analysts also noted that the market faces a difficult task of absorbing a heavy supply of new securities next week. The Treasury is selling $40 billion of new 3-year, 10-year and 30-year debt securities as part of its quarterly borrowing needs, on top of the $27.6 billion in bills that it sells regularly each week.
 "Next week's refunding will be more difficult to sell," Mr. Sherman said, "because investors would be buying securities after a very substantial rally. And history shows that is not a good time to buy, especially if there are no changes in the fundamentals of the market. You still have several months before the last tightening by the Fed takes effect."
 In when-issued trading, the 3-year note to be sold on Tuesday was being offered at a price to yield 7.34 percent, while the 10-year note to be sold on Wednesday was offered at a price to yield 7.50 percent. The 30-year bond, the final leg of the refunding on Thursday, was offered at a price to yield 7.58 percent.
 Robin Mesch, chief analyst for Thomson Research in Boston, saw yesterday as a good opportunity for a bear market rally. "I think the market has been overdone all week long," she said.

HEADLINE: Big Rally For Stocks And Bonds

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Wall Street rejoiced yesterday as Main Street showed signs its economy was slowing and unemployment was rising.
In the sixth-busiest trading day on record, the Dow Jones industrial average staged its biggest one-day gain so far this year and its largest jump since last summer. The Dow rose 57.87 points, or 1.5 percent, to 3,928.64, finishing above 3,900 for the first time since Jan. 18. 
 Government data on employment in January brought new hopes that inflation would not rise so sharply in 1995, as traders once feared. Inflation would hurt stocks, bonds and the value of the dollar. Now, the Federal Reserve may curb its policy of raising interest rates, traders are starting to speculate.
"This is it," said Ray Hines, editor of Marketmetrics, a technical-analysis newsletter in Sarasota, Fla. "The Fed's through tightening money."
The employment report also set off a strong bond rally, sending the price of the 30-year Treasury bond up and its yield down to its lowest level since September. [Page 44.]
A few analysts are going so far as to say that the Fed, having succeeded in its inflation fight, may even cut rates later this year. Such a development would be sure to send the Dow soaring. Mr. Hines, who sees a chance that the Fed may cut rates as early as midyear, said the Dow could rise as high as 4,500 to 5,000 by the third quarter.
Traders often react in a seemingly paradoxical way -- buying stocks, bonds and dollars -- when bad news is reported about American businesses having trouble making sales and thus hiring fewer people.
Although the so-called headline economic indicators, like the Consumer Price Index, may so far indicate little inflation, analysts say, many fine-print indicators, like rising prices for raw materials, have implied for months that a rise in inflation is all but inevitable.
To try to hold down the overall price rise, the Federal Reserve had held to a stern policy of raising interest rates, which hurts job creation and growth of business profits.
Neal M. Soss, co-founder of Cotton & Soss L.P., an economic consulting firm, said that Wall Street was reacting so favorably to yesterday's job-creation report because it came on the heels of reports of sluggish housing sales and signs of a slowdown in automobile showrooms.
It was just such a report on Jan. 13 of an unexpected slump in December retail sales that prompted a 49.46-point rally in the Dow. Moreover, other reports, like the Producer Price Index next Friday and the Consumer Price Index on Feb. 15, may extend the rally.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that January job creation was 134,000, little more than half the 238,000 that Wall Street expected and the smallest gain since last January, when 101,000 jobs were created. Unemployment rose to 5.7 percent, the first increase in a year, and was far above the expected 5.4 percent.
"We're not talking about a recession here," Mr. Soss said. "The Fed is not aiming for a recession, and Wall Street is not looking for one, either. But they are looking for an economy with sustainable growth with low inflation."
Other measures of the market showed strong gains. The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 5.86 points, to 478.65, and the smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 8.42 points, to 772.06.
But technical factors may also lead to a rally. Mr. Hines of Marketmetrics said, "There is just one massive amount of shorts in this market, and they could drive this market on any given day."
Mr. Hines referred to professional short-sellers who sell borrowed shares in the expectation that the price will fall, enabling them to profit by repaying their loans with lower-priced shares. When prices do not fall as they expect, the market is squeezed into what is known as a short-covering rally, jargon for professional traders being forced to buy stocks to stem their losses.
Still, any number of negative factors could also slow any rally. Yesterday's job report showed a large jump in hourly earnings, the largest gain since October, and higher wages often lead to higher prices. Moreover, factory-use figures will also be reported on Feb. 15, and those figures are likely to show continued strength.
Yesterday, the Dow rose as much as 51.48 points shortly after noon, touching off circuit-breaker rules on the New York Stock Exchange, which are intended to slow high-speed computer-guided trading.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange passed the 200-million- share mark at noon, when volume of fewer than 150 million shares is more typical. By the end of the day, 441 million shares changed hands, just below the 449.3-million-share figure posted on Oct. 21, 1987, in the aftermath of the stock market crash.
Cyclical stocks and stocks sensitive to interest rates generally benefited. For example, the Aluminum Company of America rose 3 1/4, to 83 7/8, and Allied Signal rose 1 1/2, to 37 1/4. Boeing, despite recent announcements of layoffs, may be set for a recovery, analysts said, so its stock rose 3/8, to 46 5/8.
And banks and financial-services companies also rose. Travelers Inc. rose 2 1/4, to 39 1/2, and Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, better knonw as Freddie Mac, which packages mortgages as securities, rose 3 1/2, to 57 5/8. First Interstate Bancorp rose 2 3/8, to 78 1/4, and Nationsbank Corporation rose 2 1/2, to 49.
The most active stock, at 8.9 million shares, was Intel, which hit a 52-week high of 74 1/2, before closing at 73 1/2, up 15/16 .
Earlier yesterday, stocks ended lower in Tokyo. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 65.33 points, or 0.35 percent, at 18,538.97.

HEADLINE: After Delay, F.T.C. Allows QVC's Takeover

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
In a decision that will make Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver the undisputed ruler of television home shopping, the Federal Trade Commission voted unanimously today to allow it and the Comcast Corporation to take over QVC Inc. for $1.42 billion.
The 4-to-0 vote came after a four-month investigation, during which staff lawyers at the agency had recommended blocking the deal. Tele-Communications already owns a controlling stake in Home Shopping Network, the only other nationwide television shopping channel, and some agency lawyers argued that the Denver cable television giant would stifle competition. 
 Comcast and Tele-Communications already own 35 percent of QVC, and have been seeking to gain complete control. Under the deal, an all-cash sale that is scheduled to close by midnight Thursday, Comcast will increase its stake to 57 percent and Tele-Communications will end up with 43 percent.
Executives involved in the acquisition said they were pleased by the decision, though they sharply attacked the agency for delaying the deal.
"I don't want to appear to be ungrateful for a positive resolution, but this cost shareholders interest on their money for a full third of a year," said Barry Diller, the head of QVC. "This cost Comcast, T.C.I. and QVC millions and millions of dollars over a case that could have been resolved in a few hours of direct conversations. This is a case of staff gone mad."
The executives argued that the F.T.C. investigation effectively tied up the money of shareholders in QVC. The two cable television companies had agreed to pay $46 a share, a premium of several dollars over its trading value, so people who wanted to receive the selling price had to hold their stock for four months.
Agency officials refused to discuss their decision in public. In a letter to the companies, the F.T.C. merely said that "it now appears that no further action is warranted" and closed its investigation.
Staff lawyers at the commission's Bureau of Competition had recommended several weeks ago that the deal should be blocked because Tele-Communications would have a major stake in both of the companies that now dominate the $2 billion-a-year home shopping industry.
But the two cable companies persuaded senior officials that the staff recommendation was wrong, arguing that the F.T.C. should examine the deal against the backdrop of the entire retailing market and not just the television shopping market. They also pointed out that antitrust lawyers at the Justice Department had approved the purchase of the Home Shopping Network by Tele-Communications in 1993, even though Tele-Communications already owned part of QVC at that time.
As a result, the staff recommendations were opposed by the directors of both the Bureau of Competition and the Bureau of Economics. After meeting with company executives earlier this week, the commissioners decided to follow suit.
Today's decision removes the last obstacle to consummating the deal. The companies had originally set Monday as a deadline for closing the transaction, but said today they had extended the deadline until midnight Thursday in order to complete the final details.
Robert Thomson, senior vice president of Tele-Communications, said he was pleased but frustrated. "This has been one of the most unfortunate experiences we've ever had with the Federal Government -- and that's saying a lot," he remarked this evening.
The F.T.C.'s approval was announced after the stock market closed. Earlier, Tele-Communications ended Nasdaq trading up 25 cents at $21.875, while Comcast gained 50 cents, to $15.25, and QVC rose 37.5 cents, to $45.875.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Up to 600 Jobs May Be Cut At Polaroid

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
The Polaroid Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss up to 5 percent of its work force, sell $50 million in real estate and push consumer products harder in developing countries like India and China. ,
The company, which has been under pressure from institutional investors to improve its profitability, said the new program would result in annual cost savings of $25 million to $35 million. But the stock market reacted coolly to the announcement, sending the company's shares down 12.5 cents, to $30.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 Polaroid also said it would designate $100 million to repurchase about 7 percent of its own stock on the open market. That is in addition to the $20 million still remaining on a previous buyback plan.
"Polaroid's profitability is improving and time is validating the soundness of our strategic business plan," I. MacAllister Booth, the company's chairman, said. "Despite these encouraging developments, we need to manage our profitability over the short term more aggressively if we are to attract and retain investors."
Last month, the company, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., acknowledged that it would not meet its own goals for improving earnings and that it was reviewing a range of steps to improve earnings this year. The company agreed to form a committee of outside directors that would meet at least three times a year without Mr. Booth, who is also chief executive.
The purpose of these committees is to review management actions and act as advocates for shareholders' interests.
In yesterday's announcement, Polaroid said it would cut its worldwide work force by 400 to 600 employees and take a charge of $40 million to $60 million to cover the costs of severance. It said that some manufacturing plants would be consolidated and product-development plans would be altered.
Polaroid also said that it would scale back incentives and promotions aimed at dealers and direct them at customers to increase sales of instant photographic products. The likely result is that dealers will reduce inventories and factory orders, producing an operating loss of about $20 million in the first quarter of this year in addition to the restructuring charge, the company said.
As sales of its instant photography products slow in the United States, Polaroid is turning its focus overseas. In China, the company will establish three regional sales offices and expand its sales force and distribution to increase sales of cameras and instant film to the increasingly prosperous Chinese. The company hopes to increase sales quickly in areas where there are few processors of conventional film.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Jumps in New York Region

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
As bleak as winter, regional employment figures for January arrived yesterday from the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department.
 While the national unemployment rate was climbing last month to 5.7 percent, from 5.4 percent in December, New York City's unemployment rate surged a full percentage point, to 7.7 percent, as did New Jersey's, which reached 7.2 percent. In New York State, the rate rose to 6 percent, from 5.7 in the previous month. 
 "I think basically these first 1995 readings on the regional labor market show an economy that's slipping, with unemployment moving upward, erasing the December improvement that we had seen briefly," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "The recovery, which seemed to be moving ahead through midsummer of last year, has faltered in recent months, and the January figures provide evidence of a further weakening.
 "So January doesn't mark a change in direction," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "It tends more to confirm the problems we've seen in this region in recent months. It has been a slowing recovery that slowed further in January. In New York State, it stalled."
 Connecticut is not among the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases the national jobs data each month.
 Illustrating how the region has lagged behind the national recovery, Mr. Ehrenhalt said the United States had made up all of the 1.8 million jobs lost during the recession and added 5 million more.
 In New York State, where the downturn began in 1989 and reached bottom in November 1992 with a loss of 600,000 jobs, only about 125,000 have been recovered.
 In New Jersey, where the depth of the recession was reached in March 1992 with a loss of 260,000 jobs, about half of the lost jobs have been recovered.
 "New York City is at the heart of New York State's problem, although there are problems upstate, too," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
 The proportion of the population of working age -- from 16 up -- that is active in the city's labor market, either by being employed or seeking work, fell below 54 percent in January. Nationally, the comparable figure is 66.8 percent.
 "Here, employment has been on a fairly consistent downswing since last July," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "We have a shift from growth to decline in construction and in finance."
 In addition, he said, job growth in the service industries came to a halt; jobs in city government are in decline; erosion of factory jobs is continuing, and cuts are impending in health care, the city's No. 1 employer, with 300,000 jobs.
 Mr. Ehrenhalt, who, at 69, is to retire at the end of February after 39 years with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said he was reluctant to leave on a negative note.
 "The city has a lot of things going for it," he said, expressing confidence in its potential for recovery and economic growth.
 And, he added, "It's got this marvelous capacity for surprise."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Forecasts of a Cold Week Drive Up the Prices of Fuel

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Heating oil and natural gas prices rose sharply for a third day yesterday on forecasts for a cold week in the Midwest and Northeast.
Gasoline prices also surged, after the New York Mercantile Exchange announced measures that allayed traders' fears of falling demand for the current gasoline contract. 
 The trend on other markets was lower, with steep losses in copper, coffee and cotton prices. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities fell 1.02 point, to 232.29.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, wholesale home heating oil for March delivery jumped 0.89 cent, to 49.44 cents a gallon, while March natural gas leaped 4.7 cents, to $1.482 for 1,000 cubic feet, a four-week high.
Meanwhile, March crude oil rose 24 cents, to $18.78 a barrel, and March unleaded gasoline soared 1.4 cents, to 57.35 cents a gallon.
Heating fuels have been extremely weak, with natural gas trading near three-year lows, because of unseasonably mild weather this winter in the Midwest and Northeast.
A change is coming, though, with below-normal temperatures forecast for both regions for at least the next 10 days.
Gasoline prices recovered after the exchange said it was devising a second gasoline futures contract, representing fuel with a minimum 1.5 percent oxygen content. Such a formulation would match a grade that New Jersey wants to be allowed to sell.
Traders had feared the New Jersey plan would result in lower demand for the higher-oxygen fuel traded on the exchange.
Copper prices hit a new two-month low as traders continued their retreat from base metals.
"They're reading the higher interest rates as going to cool the manufacturing portions of the U.S. economy," said Richard Hirsch, a vice president of Deutsche Sharps Pixley Metals Inc. in New York.
The March copper contract fell 2.45 cents, to $1.3125 a pound on the Commodity Exchange of New York.
Coffee prices extended their recent decline on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York as speculators exited the market. Coffee for March delivery plunged 3.85 cents, to $1.5435 a pound, a six-week low.
March cotton ended 1.96 cents lower at 92.14 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange after hitting a new 14-year high of 95.25 cents. Analysts said the volatility could mean the market was peaking.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Do Tuition Bills Loom? Here's Your Homework

BYLINE: By Francis Flaherty 

 BODY:
AS the Federal Reserve raises rates yet again, parents may be drawn even more strongly to zero-coupon bonds, a favored way to turn today's money into tomorrow's tuition. But to earn high marks, buyers must crack the books.
Unlike regular bonds, which give investors periodic interest payments, zeros plow the payments back into the investment and pay the investor everything at maturity. Their charm is certainty. Used for retirement, cruises and down payments as well as school expenses, these bonds "give you a known amount at a known time," said James Lebenthal, a municipal bond dealer in New York. For a set sum now, he said, "parents know that come the year 2006 they'll have Princeton paid for," assuming college costs follow a predictable path. 
 Zero bonds are good for savers, too; no one can fritter away interest payments not received. And, especially for longer maturities, interest can be a big part of the pie. "A $10,000 municipal zero due in 11 years would now sell at around $5,000," Mr. Lebenthal said.
Zeros also have zippier yields than coupon-bearing bonds because of the deferred interest payments, said Mark Wright, an analyst with Morningstar, the fund research company. While a regular Treasury due in 2004 yields 7.57 percent, the zero-coupon version returns 7.71 percent.
But zeroes have limits.
Consider inflation, said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago. "You may get $10,000 in the future for $5,000 today, but that $10,000 is not adjusted for inflation." Investors can project inflation, though such estimates can err greatly, particularly for long time periods.
Such time spans reveal another limit of zeros. "If you have 18 years to get the tuition, use equities, not bonds," Mr. Markese said. Long horizons give stocks growing power and reduces their risk, he said.
Then come the zigzags in zeros' prices as interest rates move. "Zeros are very volatile," Mr. Wright warned. A Treasury due 2016 has a duration of 10.3, meaning its value will rise or fall 10.3 percent with each 1 percent fall or rise, respectively, in rates. But if that same bond is a zero, duration jumps to 20.5.
Zeros' odd traits can trip up even studious investors. One common misconception concerns taxes.
Many people believe that no taxes are owed on zeros until maturity, said James Flynn, a vice president at Chase Manhattan. But they are wrong. If the zero is neither tax-free nor in a tax-deferred account, "people must pay tax on the 'phantom income' during its life," he said.
Investors must also be wary of volatility. In theory, as "buy and hold" investors, most holders of zeros need not worry about price shifts; if the bonds are held to maturity their owners will receive the principal and interest, wherever prices have gone. But investors who plan to buy and hold may find that they need the money before maturity. The lesson: Given zeros' extreme volatility, be sure you can buy and hold unless you are a speculator.
Jeffrey Tyler, who oversees several zero-coupon funds run by the Benham fund family in Mountain View, Calif., has another lesson for the buy-and-hold set.
Called the Benham Target Maturities series, his funds invest in Treasuries of a designated maturity. Mr. Tyler is pleased at the funds' recent turnabout. After heavy 1994 losses, 1995 returns so far range from a healthy 1.71 percent to 3.93 percent. Yet, he shoos those who buy and hold away from his funds.
The funds' yearly fees of about 0.6 percent of assets make them costly for such investors, who will pay less by buying the bonds directly, he explained. His funds work best for active traders who are lured by the zeros' volatility. For them, the fund expenses are low compared with the broker bills that their frequent transactions would otherwise incur.
And Mr. Lebenthal waved investors away from tax-free bonds. "The supply of zeros is so thin in the municipals market that prices are out of whack," he said. Indeed, contrary to the normal situation, coupon-bearing municipal bonds are now yielding more -- and thus costing less -- than comparable zeros.
In buying zeros directly, investors confront more complexities. Banks often charge a flat fee, from $50 to $100, for these bonds. Brokers impose a markup, which is keyed to the bond's face amount and which rises as maturities lengthen. Merrill Lynch charges $1 for every $1,000 of bonds for maturities of three months or less and up to $7.50 per $1,000 for longer terms. Discount brokers? They often mix these approaches.
How can investors compare apples with oranges with a blend of both? They cannot. Instead, they must get a uniform measure of cost.
First, select an appropriate bond -- say, $10,000 of a Treasury that matures in 2005. "Then call three or four sellers and ask for the net yield," which factors in any fees, Mr. Flynn advised. The higher the yield, the better the deal. Many brokers always provide this net, or true, yield, but some may need to be asked.
Alternatively, ask the sellers what the cash outlay for the bond is. The seller with the highest yield should also require the smallest outlay.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "When They Are Good. . ." shows total returns for the Benham Target Maturities series of mutual funds. (Source: Morningstar Inc.)

HEADLINE: HOW THEY DO IT;
Surviving a Stolen Car Ordeal

 BODY:
On the Sunday after Thankgiving, LaRae Mardesic of Los Angelas discovered that her 1988 Nissan Sentra had been stolen from the carport at her apartment. She alerted police then her insurer, Farmers Insurance Group. "My greatest fear was that they would low-ball me, and I was very cautious when I started to negotiate," she said.
 
Rental -- As an account executive for the United Way who visits companies constantly, Ms. Mardesic needed a replacement qiuckly. Her insurance policy required her to pay for a rental car for the first two days -- $16.99 a day at a special insurance rate. After that, she paid $1.99 a day and the insurer paid the balance until the claim was settled.
 
REIMBURSEMENT -- Ms. Mardesic began working with her insurance claim adjuster. Using a car appraisal service, the adjuster placed the car's value at $4,488. After producing recent receipts for repairs and maintenance, she was credited for 20 to 25 percent of those bills. Farmers also covered the sales tax, the remaining time on the car registration and some contents. Ms. Mardesic received a check for $5,033 on Dec. 21.
 
CAR RECOVERED -- The day she received the check, the police found her car. Ms. Mardesic had the option of keeping the cash or taking her old car back. She did not owe any money on the old car, but she decided to keep the money and trade up to a more reliable car.
 
REPLACEMENT CAR -- She settled on a 1993 Sentra, paying $9,990 including tax and licence. Rather that using the insurance check as a down payment, Ms. Mardesic paid down credit card debt that carried a high annual interest rate, 15.15 percent. She borrowed the full cost of the car with a five year loan at 10.5 percent. Over five years, she will pay $13,083 for the car.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Some See a Better Year for Domestic Bonds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
The last shall be first.
That's the story behind a rally in municipal bond funds this year. Their bonds were pummeled in 1994 by a confluence of factors: limited supply, rising interest rates, some exposure to high-risk derivative investments and a thin market. Come 1995, the prices were so beaten down that municipal bonds looked good again. 
 Worldwide bond funds, still staggering from problems last year in Europe, are struggling with the recent devaluation of the Mexican peso. Short-term world income funds are in a similar boat, though the losses are less grievous because of their short-term holdings. Because worldwide interest rates generally follow those of the United States, there is apt to be a continuing ripple effect from higher rates here.
Domestically, it's fair to expect a better year in 1995 for bonds, said Jeff Kelley, associate editor, Morningstar Mutual Funds. Interest rate increases should be less drastic, and "I think fund management will be more conservative, because they've been reminded of what rate rises can do to share prices," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Scrap Salary Cap to Create a Ray of Hope

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
As baseball's striking players and owners moved in slow motion toward President Clinton's Monday deadline for a settlement, the National Labor Relations Board made its move today, inducing the owners to rescind the salary cap they implemented six weeks ago.
The board, through its general counsel, Fred Feinstein, achieved that feat by informing the owners that it would issue an unfair labor practice complaint against the owners on a charge the players filed Dec. 27, five days after the clubs declared an impasse in negotiations and imposed the cap. 
 "They prematurely imposed a salary cap and other measures," David Parker, the board's information director, said in a news briefing tonight. "There was no legal impasse."
It was unclear if the action would hasten an agreement. The two sides remained far apart in their positions on the game's economic system. The owners want a cap or a payroll tax that would control player salaries; the players are willing to have a tax, but such a slight one that it wouldn't have the owners' desired effect.
Such a tax would be one imposed on team payrolls that exceeded certain thresholds.
However, the Presidential deadline has lent an urgency to the negotiations, and it played a role in the N.L.R.B.'s decision to make its offer to the owners. "Mr. Feinstein was well aware of the President's desire to get an agreement," said Parker, adding that the deadline speeded up the board's process.
If the owners had not agreed to remove their implemented system, the board also was prepared to seek an injunction blocking it in United States District Court. "The owners were aware of that possibility," Parker said.
Although club representatives welcomed the opportunity to "clear the decks" as they try to meet the President's deadline, the union greeted the development as a victory for the players.
"We're back under the old system," Donald Fehr, the union leader, said late tonight. "As of Monday, players will start signing. If the clubs don't sign free agents, they'll be guilty of collusion." The union had imposed a freeze on signing contracts once the owners installed the salary cap system.
Because they became involved in the N.L.R.B.'s maneuver, the two sides did little negotiating today. A small group discussed noneconomic issues, but an evening session that had been scheduled with larger groups was not held. The union was expected to make a counterproposal when negotiators meet Saturday.
Today's action returns the owners and players to their status before the owners imposed the new system Dec. 23. Back then, though, they did not face the Clinton deadline.
The union, for its part, at least does not face the prospect of having the owners declare an impasse and implement the cap in the immediate future because the deadline and a possible third-party settlement could come first.
In a statement, Feinstein said that he would "continue to insist that no unilateral action be taken before the parties are at an impasse."
A lawyer familiar with the negotiations and the President's interest in pushing the two sides toward an agreement said the board was "playing into Clinton's game, putting pressure on the parties to resolve this dispute."
The lawyer acknowledged, though, that the development doesn't do anything to hasten an agreement. But, he said, "The players are in a better situation because the owners no longer have the threat of implementation."
Although union officials said they were not prepared to discuss whether or not they would recommend the end of the strike, that possibility at least existed if the union was confident the players did not have to fear impasse and implementation again.
However, if the players decided to go back to work without a new agreement, the owners most likely would lock them out because they are determined, one management official said, not to play the 1995 season under the old system.
The players struck Aug. 12 because they said they did not want to enter the off season facing the possibility of the implementation of a salary cap. If they went into the off-season without a new collective bargaining agreement, they said, they would lose their leverage.
Besides installing the salary cap, which would have placed a maximum on club payrolls, the owners eliminated salary arbitration and created a new category of restricted free agency. Under that system, players with four or five years of major league service would have been eligible to be free agents, but their clubs could have retained them under the right of first refusal.
Even though the union had placed a freeze on signings, about half a dozen of the 38 restricted free agents had negotiated tentative agreements with clubs that would have become official only if the freeze were lifted. Those players now remain property of their 1994 clubs.
The clubs' revocation of the imposed system officially won't take effect until Monday. John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the chairman of the owners' negotiating committee, said he believed today's development "will intensify the collective bargaining effort between the two parties."
Although the owners were told they illegally declared an impasse, in one way they welcomed the development. They felt the union has been delaying in the talks, waiting for a positive ruling from the board. That step now is behind both sides.
Each side filed unfair labor practice charges against the other Dec. 27, but the board did not find cause to issue a complaint against the players.
If the board had issued a complaint against the owners, then sought and got an injunction, the clubs could have appealed it to the circuit court of appeals. If an administrative law judge, after a hearing, had upheld the board's complaint against the owners, they could have appealed it first to the five-member board and then, if that appeal were unsuccessful, to the circuit court of appeals and on to the United States Supreme Court, if necessary.
Those procedures would have taken several years, with the ultimate outcome unknown perhaps until 1997 or 1998.
The union, in its charge, said that the clubs had "interfered with, restrained and coerced" players in violation of the National Labor Relations Act. Specifically, the union said the the clubs had refused to bargain in good faith and should not be permitted to make changes unilaterally in the working conditions.
The clubs charged that the union had violated the labor act by, among other things, refusing to negotiate wages on a collective basis and instead insisting on "the individual negotiation of wages and salary arbitration."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Government Magic: Cap Disappears

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Never mind.
That's how easy it is, apparently, for a government to remove a portion of the bad dream that is major league baseball. 
 Nobody removed the strike, mind you. But the National Labor Relations Board did remove, or "encourage," the removal of the owners' 1 1/2-month-old salary cap.
The cap went the way of daytime World Series games and the 154-game schedule after the clubs were informed that the Federal agency was likely on the verge of bringing an unfair labor practices complaint against them.
The owners, spinning well in this capital of spin controllers, praised the decision, as if baseball had stumbled onto its own V-E Day. The labor board has enabled the two sides to remove distractions by clearing the decks of N.L.R.B. charges, according to John Harrington of the Red Sox, the owners' chief negotiator, and the owners' lawyer, Chuck O'Connor.
Still, both those gentlemen admitted that Fred Feinstein, the labor board's general counsel, had indicated that based on the information he has in hand, he would have been inclined to find against the owners. It seems, Feinstein concluded, you can't impose a cap based on the supposition that there is an impasse at the negotiating table when there isn't, in fact, an impasse.
That's just what the striking players asserted Dec. 23, the day after the clubs declared the impasse and slapped a salary cap on the sport.
So it was that while the sport was warily awaiting a body blow from President Clinton, the top guy in the Administration, another top gun, the labor board, got the drop on at least one-half of baseball's recalcitrant negotiators.
Make no mistake. The board's action carried a wallop felt throughout the major leagues. It had to because of the message sent: that the owners were edging dangerously close to being slapped with a complaint by the labor board and that the board was intending to pursue an injunction against the cap if the owners had not removed it first.
The owners say they had removed it, anyway, when they put a new proposal on the table Wednesday. It did not contain a cap, but rather a luxury tax.
The labor board's action brought muted response from the players, the one group it all but cleared of any wrongdoing in the labor-practices area. These are sensitive days, after all, what with the 5 1/2-month-old strike still raging and spring training camp openings less than two weeks away.
In a sense, the board action represents a second chance, if not a victory for both sides. Yes, the owners were given an out, a very generous out. Withdraw the cap, they were told by Feinstein. The owners get to make like Bill Murray in "Groundhog Day" and just relive Dec. 22 all over again -- without the part that ended in a cap. Just pretend that the five weeks that followed the imposition didn't exist.
Yes, the charges -- and threat of penalties -- still exist. But they are being held in abeyance. Believe Harrington and O'Connor when they say they see those charges never re-emerging, because of the settlement both sides now openly pray for. Feinstein has given both sides that chance. The Federal Government, wielder of many swords, sheathed one mighty one last night.
But the Government did so, it seemed clear, with the understanding that baseball will now respond in a most positive way -- with a weekend of reasoned bargaining, a weekend devoid of the writing of briefs, a weekend devoid of lobbying, a weekend devoid of distraction.
President Clinton did not bring the parties back to the table in the shadow of his White House to watch posturing and case-building. The labor board got that message from the ultimate Washington bigwig loud and clear and did its part to clear the incredibly muddied waters that constantly swirl around baseball labor relations.
And Clinton wants those waters cleared. And the game played, with major leaguers and without strife. In Clinton's mind, replacement baseball may not represent a threat to national security. But it obviously represents a threat to the national pastime, not to mention the economies of 26 major league cities and the spring-training states of Florida and Arizona. Those threats alone are obviously enough to have caused Clinton to seize the issue and refuse to let go.
Will the action that walks like a pardon and talks like a pardon do more than allow the owners a sigh of relief? Will it, in fact, breathe even more life into a sport that all but put itself on a respirator? Everyone should know by Monday -- the day Clinton has said the game must settle or else.
One gets the feeling that baseball's owners and its players better start providing some positive answers to such questions on their own. Because the Government still has a lot of bite left in it. And agencies such as the labor board can obviously take themselves out of the game, but they can put themselves right back in, if need be, too.

HEADLINE: CLINTON ASKS RISE IN MINIMUM WAGE

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Challenging skeptical Republicans with a popular pocketbook measure that he knows is unlikely to pass, President Clinton today proposed a 90-cent increase in the minimum wage, to $5.15 an hour, over two years.
"The only way to grow the middle class and shrink the underclass is to make work pay," the President said in a Rose Garden ceremony at which he was joined by a number of Congressional Democrats, many of whom had urged him to fight for a higher rate than the $5 figure he originally favored. "And in terms of real buying power, the minimum wage will be at a 40-year low next year if we do not raise it above $4.25 an hour." 
 But, in a sign of the proposal's dim prospects on Capitol Hill, not a single Republican attended the ceremony despite the White House's efforts to attract some.
Speaker Newt Gingrich and the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, both promised to hold hearings and review the proposal, though Mr. Gingrich suggested the leadoff witness on the House side might well be Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader.
Mr. Armey, a former economics professor at the University of North Texas in Denton, has vowed to fight an increase in the minimum wage with "every fiber" of his being.
Mr. Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, expressed a similar view. "I personally am very skeptical of it, and I think it will kill jobs, and particularly will kill jobs for minority teen-agers," he said. "But I think we owe it to the President to have hearings."
Mr. Gingrich said he might prefer to create new "enterprise zones" in poor urban areas, Indian reservations and parts of Appalachia, in which employers who hired disadvantaged local workers would pay "zero capital gains" taxes.
In his State of the Union Message last week, Mr. Clinton said he favored raising the minimum wage but did not say by how much. His aides said later that he was leaning toward an increase of 75 cents an hour, but wanted to see if he could build Congressional support for a compromise. By today, the only compromise he could reach was with Democrats who had wanted an increase of $1.50 or more.
While the White House expects it will lose the fight to increase the wage, it is one that Presidential advisers say they are happy to make because they believe it puts Mr. Clinton on the winning side of public opinion on an issue that has had bipartisan support in Congress.
In 1989, President George Bush proposed the last increase, also 90 cents over two years, from $3.35, to a Democratic Congress, and it passed with the support of both Mr. Dole and Mr. Gingrich. Presidential advisers said Mr. Clinton had settled on the 90-cent figure in part to make the point that what was good policy for Mr. Bush then was good policy now.
But the Republicans control both houses of Congress now and have deep tax and spending cuts on their minds, so the White House cannot be assured that a wage increase will even be brought to the floor, where Republicans could face pressure from constituents to support it.
"It'd be nice to say, 'Let's just have a vote for the symbolism of it,' " said a Democratic aide in the House. "But we can't even schedule a vote. We might have to attach it as some wacky amendment."
Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the chairman of the House Republican conference, said he was concerned that an increase in the minimum wage could cost hundreds of thousands of jobs, the most common argument cited by opponents.
But several recent independent studies tend to show that such assumptions about job losses resulting from a wage increase may be overstated. Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that any losses would be minimal.
Mr. Reich, the biggest backer of an increase among the President's senior advisers, displayed a chart at the White House today showing that, adjusted for inflation, the minimum wage was worth far less now than it was in 1968, when it would have been $6.29 in 1994 dollars. "We have fallen behind in our national goal to make work pay," the Secretary said.
About 11 million Americans now earn between the existing $4.25 minimum and the proposed $5.15, and would probably benefit from the increase, along with about 3.5 million others who earn within 50 cents of the proposed new minimum and could see a ripple effect, Secretary Reich said.
Mr. Clinton promised in the 1992 Presidential campaign to increase the minimum wage, but deferred action after he was elected, in part because he wanted the support of business leaders for his health care plan, which would have required employers to bear new insurance costs for their workers and would have amounted to an increase in earnings for hourly workers.
Today, many of the same groups that played a central role in defeating the health care plan vowed to fight the wage increase. Jack Farris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business lobby, called the proposal a "regressive and job-killing scheme which will put a big dent in small-business hiring."
Mr. Clinton had been wary of proposing a wage increase lest he be seen as a captive of Democratic interest groups like organized labor. But in the end, aides said, he was comfortable proposing it as part of a package of spending cuts and middle-class tax breaks, and arguing that it was consistent with the bipartisan goal of overhauling welfare.
At the ceremony today, the President said that goal could not be met "unless the people we are asking to work can be rewarded for their labors."

HEADLINE: HOUSING PROJECTS TO GIVE PRIORITY TO THE EMPLOYED

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
For the first time in decades, the New York City Housing Authority will soon give preference to working people over welfare recipients in filling many vacancies at its apartments, a move officials hope will restore economic and social stability to the projects.
The rule change is part of an extensive campaign, including advertising and recruiting potential tenants at their workplaces, that the authority plans to attract more working families for the authority's 180,000 apartments. In the last decade, the agency has seen the number of working families drop from 46 percent to 32 percent. Now only 8 percent of the applicants for housing are working families. 
 "Projects that are economically integrated just work better," said Martin Pestreich, assistant general manager with the Housing Authority. "That has been demonstrated in city after city throughout the country."
The change breaks a long-standing Housing Authority policy of giving equal weight to applications of families on public assistance, the elderly and working people. In reality, though, over the past decade most vacancies have gone to welfare recipients as fewer and fewer working families applied for public housing.
Coming at a time when the city, state and Federal governments are pushing a wide array of cuts in public assistance to poor people, advocates for welfare families and minorities worry that the policy changes could cut off a critical housing option for them.
"I am going to watch this carefully," said Hazel Dukes, president of the New York State chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. "I do feel that it is important to give the working poor some help, and I know that residents of public housing want it. But it does raise a red flag. It has to be done fairly and in a way that will not discriminate against welfare families."
But housing officials and some tenants' advocates argue that housing projects around the country have become dumping grounds for the poorest families who are increasingly isolated from the mainstream and who often bring with them problems of crime and drugs.
In fact, the new policy follows other moves that the Housing Authority has made in recent years to screen new tenants, including criminal background checks, home visits and interviews.
In New York, the policy change will be felt most profoundly at Beach 41st Street Houses, a 712-unit development in Far Rockaway, Queens, where the authority will create a separate waiting list composed almost exclusively of working families and the elderly.
The 20-year-old complex recently received $48 million in Federal money for physical and social-service improvements over the next five years, including high-tech security systems for lobbies, full-time day care, the creation of an alternative high school for adults, a small-business loan program and the construction of a community center with performance arts space, a gymnasium and a library.
But the authority is not stopping with Beach 41st Street. Reuben Franco, chairman of the Housing Authority, said this week that the agency would soon give working families preference for up to 50 percent of vacancies as they come up in public housing developments.
"Beach 41st Street is a very important experiment," Mr. Franco said. "We expect it to be a showcase that we can repeat in other parts of the city. But we have all recognized the importance of a diverse population. We need to start on that now."
In recent years, the Housing Authority's efforts to maintain a balance among working families, elderly people and welfare recipients has been compromised. Because of fears of crime and the overall decline of some housing projects, officials say, fewer working people have sought public housing and more families on welfare were forced to turn to it.
In addition, during the late 1980's, the Housing Authority was called on to give apartments to homeless families as a way of reducing the population at city shelters. A spokeswoman for Joan Malin, Commissioner of the Department of Homeless Services, said she did not expect the new policy to reduce housing opportunities for the homeless. The authority's current obligation is to house about 1,400 homeless families, which is less than the 2,000 families the agency was taking in four years ago.
"A very small percentage of homeless clients go the Housing Authority," said Susan Wiviott, a spokesman for the agency. "We do not expect the change to impact our efforts."
The policy changes in New York, which have been endorsed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, are part of an overall shift in the way public housing is administered throughout the country. Officials of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development say they are hoping to encourage other housing authorities to adopt similar procedures.
"The goal is to do away with the concentration of poverty that public housing has become," said Joseph Shuldiner, assistant secretary for Public and Indian Housing at H.U.D. "We believe that fostering an economic mix is the most direct way of achieving that through a combination of modernization and changing the rent rules."
The money that H.U.D. has provided for the Queens complex is part of $350 million that the agency has provided to upgrade distressed housing developments in New York and seven other cities.
When the Housing Authority was set under Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in the 1934, it was free to set its own standards regarding tenants it would accept. Until the late 1960's, it gave preference to two-parent families where at least one parent had a job. In addition, the authority took into account what it called morality factors, such as arrest records and problems with alcoholism.
But the policies were challenged by civil rights groups, which argued that the rules discriminated against the population for which public housing was intended. The Housing Authority acknowledged that welfare families had little chance of getting apartments, and the policies were liberalized to give equal consideration to families on public assistance.
In addition, in the late 1970's, Congress began providing money to the nation's housing authorities and put in place Federal policies and income limits intended to guarantee that public housing was available to the poorest of the poor.
But last month, H.U.D. liberalized those rules, giving housing authorities in New York and in other cities the ability to set their own standards for up to half of the vacant apartments.
At Beach 41st Street nearly half of the tenants receive public assistance. About 40 percent are elderly people receiving Social Security, and working families make up about 11 percent. The average income, $10,380, is below the $12,500 average for all of public housing.
The planned renovations will require that some tenants be relocated. When new housing assignments are made, 60 percent of apartments will be filled by families earning 50 to 80 percent of median income for the New York area. Forty percent of the new apartments will go mainly to elderly applicants.

HEADLINE: Flow of Illegal Aliens Rises as the Peso Falls

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NOGALES, Ariz., Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Border Patrol senior agent surveyed the tattered border fence that separates Mexico and the United States and shook his head in consternation.
In broad daylight, as far as he could see to the east and west, people were slipping through holes and gaps in the barrier, fleeing the poverty of Latin America and making their way, illegally but unhindered, into the land of economic opportunity. 
 Some tossed the agent, Kevin Oaks, a smile and a wave as they ducked into alleys and side streets or disappeared into the tangled depths of rocky, trash-strewn desert canyons in the distance.
"Nogales is the hot spot these days for sneaking into the U.S.," Agent Oaks lamented. "We've been overwhelmed here over the past few months, ever since the special push was ordered to shut down hard on illegal crossings over at San Diego and back at El Paso. And things have only gotten worse since the peso tumbled. Now there's even less work to be had in Mexico and if the peso tumbles more -- Well, better pray."
Illegal border crossings at Nogales are already heavy. Last month the 80 overworked Border Patrol agents here arrested 10,476 illegal aliens, which was more than ever before and more than twice the 4,293 arrested in January 1994.
No one knows, of course, how many aliens slipped past without being caught. But if the scene playing out before Agent Oaks's frustrated eyes was any indication, thousands and thousands more got through than were stopped.
Those who evaded apprehension made their way to urban areas like Los Angeles, Chicago and New York with the help of friends or paid guides.
"The word is out down in Mexico that we're now the weak point in the defense," Agent Oaks said. "It used to be that two of every three illegal crossings were attempted at San Diego and El Paso. Now a lot of the people we're catching here tell us they specifically avoided going to those crossing points because of the increased patrolling. They know there are more holes in the border here than we have agents and equipment to plug them. We're something of a joke."
Unlike the Border Patrol stations at San Diego and El Paso, where the number of field agents and supply of surveillance equipment have been more than doubled recently, the station at Nogales has not been reinforced.
More people and equipment have been promised as part of an effort by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to slow what has become a costly and politically embarrassing assault on the southern border of the United States. But delivery is six months or more away.
"It's enough to drive you crazy," said R. S. Colburn, the chief patrol agent here. "The Patrol has proved at San Diego and El Paso that the flow really can be slowed and made almost manageable with the right mix of agents and equipment."
In particular, immigration officials are pleased with the results from San Diego, which was the most porous of all crossing points before the reinforcement effort.
Last fall, when the reinforcements, extra night-vision scopes, radios and all-terrain vehicles were deployed, monthly apprehensions more than tripled. Then, near the turn of the year as word began to spread among aliens that crossing at San Diego was no longer a breeze, illegal entry attempts began to fall off, followed by a decline in apprehensions.
A few days ago, Border Patrol officials proudly reported the most encouraging news to date. In January 1995, they said, there were 31,000 apprehensions at San Diego, compared with 38,000 apprehensions for the same month a year earlier, a decline of almost 20 percent.
At El Paso, monthly apprehensions are still running ahead of those for a year earlier. But as at San Diego, the gap is beginning to close.
Meanwhile, here in Nogales, outnumbered Border Patrol agents find that not only are they unable to apprehend thousands of illegal aliens but many of those they do turn back often try to cross again -- usually successfully -- within a matter of hours.
"Sometimes it seems that the biggest deterrent they face in crossing is not us but the bandits and drug dealers who sometimes ambush them in the gullies and alleys," Agent Oaks said. "We've noticed that as the number of crossings has increased recently, so has border crime, especially robbery, drug running and rape of women attempting to cross."
Late in the afternoon Agent Oaks helped apprehend a young man emerging from a cross-border drain culvert. The man reported that he had just been robbed in the dank tunnel by a group of teen-agers who had brandished knives and were high from sniffing paint fumes.
Asked why he had ventured into the tunnel, the man, an auto mechanic who identified himself only as "Osvaldo," replied that he could not find work in Mexico and was willing to risk robbery to hunt for a job in the United States.
He said he was from a farming area west of Mexico City, had spent two and a half days riding a bus to Nogales and was headed for Los Angeles.
Why, Agent Oaks asked, had he tried to cross at Nogales instead of San Diego?
"I heard that crossing at Nogales would be easier because there would be fewer border guards," he replied, a slight smile creasing his weary face.
What would he do after being returned to Mexico? Would he go home?
"There is nothing at home for me," he said. "It is worse now after the fall of the peso than it has ever been."
Would he try another crossing? Risk another robbery?
"Why not?" he replied. "I have nothing left to lose."
Another border agent moved in to lead him off. The slight smile returned.
"See you around," Agent Oaks said.

HEADLINE: On the Waterfront;
Investor Builds Reputation as He Develops a Recreation Complex on the Chelsea Piers

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Roland W. Betts was inspecting construction on his sprawling West Side sports and entertainment center at the Chelsea Piers when he decided to stop by the sound stage there where NBC's "Cosby Mysteries" is filmed. The show's star, Bill Cosby, was not in. But just outside Mr. Cosby's dressing room, a middle-aged woman was hunched over a mop, dutifully cleaning floors.
 Mr. Betts, the principal owner of the Texas Rangers, the major league baseball team, financier of major motion pictures and chairman of Chelsea Piers Management Inc., rushed over to hug and kiss her. After all, it was his wife's sister. 
 "She's been down on her luck," he said later, explaining why he helped her get the job.
 In a city where real estate developers often live chauffeured life styles, with reputations as large as the edifices they build, Mr. Betts has emerged as an anomaly. Although he has amassed millions of dollars financing hit films like "Beauty and the Beast," "Pretty Woman, and "The Little Mermaid," he has remained virtually anonymous, almost humble -- even as he undertakes one of the more ambitious recent developments in New York City, a $92 million recreation complex at the neglected Chelsea Piers.
 "He's a real person," said Tom Fox, president of the Hudson River Park Conservancy, a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
 Mr. Betts was not born to humility, however; he acquired it. The son of a wealthy investment banker, he grew up in Syosset, L.I., and received degrees from Yale University and Columbia Law School. But in between college and law school, moved by the idealism of the 1960's, Mr. Betts, who is white, spent seven years in Harlem that he believes changed him. There, he taught in public schools and met his wife, a teacher from a poor black family.
 It was Jessica, one of their two daughters, who eventually led Mr. Betts to develop the Chelsea Piers site, he said. Jessica was an ice skater, and Mr. Betts was searching for a site to replace the small, insufficient site where she practiced. When he saw the dilapidated piers, 840 feet long and column free, he had but one thought, he said: ideal for ice skating.
 That thought translated into an ambitious investment. Mr. Betts and his partner, Tom A. Bernstein, overcame what many saw as insurmountable environmental, zoning, and financing obstacles in their bid to develop a 1.7 million square-foot complex at the Chelsea Piers. The sports and entertainment complex, which sits on the riverfront between 17th and 23d Streets, is scheduled to open this summer.
 The four 85-year-old piers will hold two indoor, Olympic-sized skating rinks, a golf driving range, two roller skating rinks, a sports fitness center, an indoor running track, rock-climbing walls, basketball and beach volleyball courts and gymnastics equipment.
 Jutting into the water, two of the piers are covered, with two levels of indoor parking. The two others are open spaces. The headhouse leading to the piers is home to NBC's "Law and Order" as well as the "Cosby Mysteries," and more television and film production studios are under construction.
 Completed in 1910 for the grand luxury liners of that era, the Chelsea Piers were used to dock the ill-fated Lusitania, and one was the Titantic's destination when it sank in 1912. The New York State Department of Transportation owns the piers and has used them in recent years to park municipal vehicles and to impound cars.
 Under the terms of a 20-year lease, the developers will pay about $200,000 a month to rent the property, and that amount will increase each year based on inflation. The state is expected to use those revenues to design and construct the remainder of the park. Moreover, tenants are projected to generate 2,500 permanent jobs and $11.7 million annually in tax revenues.
 "The kinds of activities the Chelsea Piers provide are labor intensive but don't demand a high level of skill," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "Those kinds of developments are good for the city's economy."
 But some in the community say the development is heavy on the commercial side and short on park space. "We want bikeways, walkways, and to preserve the river," said Marcy Benstock, executive director of the Clean Air Campaign, which has successfully petitioned for studies to assess what impact development along the Hudson will have on the environment.
 Even some community leaders who originally were supporters of the Chelsea Piers complex are in a tiff over Mr. Betts's plan to lease a 42,000 square-foot space to Herman's Sporting Goods. Initial plans indicated there would only be 23,000 square feet of retail space. The critics charge that the larger store will create traffic and congestion.
 Councilman Thomas K. Duane, who represents the surrounding neighborhood, said that recent negotiations about Herman's have ended in a stalemate and he said he is considering a lawsuit to halt plans for the store. Despite his disagreement with the developers over the issue, Mr. Duane said that Mr. Betts and Mr. Bernstein are uncommonly receptive and accessible.
 "They are unusual because they come to meetings to negotiate with people who are opposed to their plans," Mr. Duane said. "Usually developers aren't at the table with the community. They just send their lawyers."
 Long before they were developers, Mr. Betts, 48, and Mr. Bernstein, 42, were lawyers themselves. The two met in 1978, when they both joined the entertainment department of the New York law firm Paul, Weiss, Rifkin, Wharton & Garrison.
 That was after Mr. Betts' seven years as a teacher and administrator in Harlem, which he wrote about in a book called "Acting Out" (Little, Brown, 1978). In the book, Mr. Betts wrote: "I have fallen in love with some children, and come close to strangling others. I have witnessed acts of rare beauty and grace, and lived through moments of violence and terror."
 While teaching, Mr. Betts also fell in love with Lois Phifer, a New York City school teacher, who grew up in a Roselle, N.J., family of 14 children. They have been married for 22 years and have two daughters in college.
 Calvin Hill, the former Dallas Cowboys football star who attended Yale with Mr. Betts, said: "On the surface, with his pedigree, he's not the type of guy you would think would have taught in Harlem, but he's driven by a lot of things other than money. More than anything, he's interested in the substance of people."
 In 1983, Mr. Betts and Mr. Bernstein formed Silver Screen Management, and, through a limited partnership, the pair raised $83 million to help Home Box Office produce feature films. Soon thereafter, Silver Screen entered a joint venture with the Walt Disney Company, and from 1985 through 1991, Silver Screen raised $1 billion for 70 Disney films.
 Three years ago, when the state awarded Mr. Betts and Mr. Bernstein the right to lease and develop the piers, many people doubted it could be done. Over the years, plans to rehabilitate the neglected shoreline had become mired in politics and opposition from the community and environmentalists.
 Obtaining the necessary permits would be a problem, they were told, but it took them only 24 months.
 And despite resistance, the developers convinced the community board and legislators that the time was right for a private investment that would focus on recreational activities rather than the high-rise office or residential buildings that have anchored other waterfront developments.
 "This is important because Betts has succeeded at going where no one else ever has," said Mitchell Moss, a professor at New York University's Taub Urban Research Center.
 Mr. Betts believes that he had an advantage as a neophyte in the real estate business. "Nobody knew us, so we didn't have any baggage," he said.
 Because they were unknown, people also doubted their ability to raise the necessary capital. However, the two men put up $17 million of their own money, and Morgan Stanley & Company issued $45 million in mortgage bonds. Also, the subtenants at the site are spending an additional $30 million improving their spaces.
 The initial reason that led Mr. Betts to the Chelsea Piers no longer exists. With Jessica now 18 and away at college, a place for her to skate is no longer an issue. However, Mr. Betts and Mr. Bernstein recently purchased Sky Rink, the rink where Jessica practiced, changed it from a nonprofit to a for-profit entity, and will relocate the facility to the Chelsea Piers later this year.

PUBLIC HOUSING TO FAVOR WORKING PEOPLE
The New York City Housing Authority will soon give preference to working people over welfare recipients in filling many vacancies at its apartments, a move officials hope will restore economic and social stability to the projects. The rule change is part of an extensive campaign the authority plans to attract more working families. Page 1.
 
A L.I. TRIAL, THROUGH THE LOOKING GLASS
Day after day, the curious and the bored line up for a chance to watch the man whose own lawyers say is mad defend himself against charges of murder. They have come to see Colin Ferguson, cast in the role of a lifetime: defense counsel in the Long Island Rail Road shootings. The trial offers an eerie contrast to O.J. Simpson's. On one coast, an army of high-priced legal talent defends a sane man accused of murder; on the other, a man whose sanity is in serious doubt argues for himself. Page 1.
 
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
TRUMP DEVELOPMENT CLEARS MAJOR HURDLE
Over the strenuous objections of environmentalists, Harlem residents and some elected officials, the city gave Donald J. Trump permission to connect the first phase of his Riverside South development to the troubled North River sewage treatment plant. With the certification, Mr. Trump clears a major hurdle in his long struggle to construct 16 buildings along the Hudson River. Page 23.
 
AMID THE DUST OF TIMES SQUARE, GHOSTS
"There's no doubt we have a presence," said Maria Alvorado, the manager of the tourist office of the Times Square Business Improvement District. The office moved a few months ago into the foyer of the old Harris Theater, on 42d between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. "Lots of people have seen it," she said as she walked to the area behind the movie screen. "I was unpacking brochures in this storage area when I felt someone watching me. I looked up and there he was. A man, tall and elegantly dressed. In a second he was gone." About New York, page 23.

CONTRADICTIONS IN DRUG POLICY?
Governor Pataki wants to change New York law so that nonviolent offenders can avoid prison. At the same time, the budget he proposed this week cuts treatment programs that may be needed as an alternative to prison. Some see a contradiction. Page 22.
