TAXPAYERS CAN SUE OVER ASSESSMENTS
What's good for General Motors may or may not be good for the country, but it could be very good for New Jersey taxpayers who believe their municipal assessor has it in for them. In a lawsuit involving G.M.'s plant in Linden, New Jersey's second-highest court ruled that taxpayers can sue their assessors under the Federal Civil Rights Act. And they can collect damages if they can prove the assessor acted out of malice or prejudice. Page 24.

HEADLINE: The Man Who Talked Too Much

BYLINE: By Bob Bauman; Bob Bauman, a Republican, was a Representative from Maryland from 1973 to 1981.

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

 BODY:
Until Representative Dick Armey referred to his colleague Barney Frank as "Barney Fag," I had a good impression of the new majority leader. Compared to the doctrinaire Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, Mr. Armey seemed a thoughtful if somewhat laconic sort, carefully choosing his words to convey his considered beliefs.
Mr. Armey protested that his comment was merely a slip of the tongue, a mispronunciation requiring no "psychoanalysis about my subliminal or about my Freudian predilections." Those are carefully chosen words, but I, as a gay man, shudder to think that anyone was convinced by them. Having seen the TV clips and read the transcript, I have to concur with Mr. Frank, who said, "I don't think it was on the tip of his tongue, but I do believe it was in the back of his mind." 
 A certain euphoria of self-importance can overcome a public person, surrounded by the media, thinking the world is listening. It is conducive to careless yet revealing utterances, instantly regretted because of the political consequences. With some remorse, I recall a House debate with Parren Mitchell, Democrat of Maryland, concerning economic sanctions against Rhodesia, to which I was opposed.
As our exchange became heated, I referred to him as "the gentleman from Africa." Mr. Mitchell, an African-American, instantly and rightfully objected. I withdrew my remarks with the lame excuse that in the passion of debate I regrettably had abbreviated my intended description of him as "the chairman of the African affairs subcommittee." Of course the Congressional Record was doctored to excise my racial slur.
There is much more to Mr. Armey's slur than simply the blatant disregard for the dignity of a colleague. It shows that gay people are apparently the last Americans at whom bigotry and prejudice can be aimed, even by elected officials, without fear of meaningful censure.
The episode is especially troubling because Mr. Armey comes from Texas, a state in which a recent epidemic of gay-bashing and anti-gay prejudice has led to several murders of homosexuals and at least one suicide.
Mr. Frank and I didn't choose our sexual orientation, the ignorant preaching of fundamentalists notwithstanding. I wish I could convey to my fellow Republicans the depth of despair and suffering that society inflicts on gays in a thousand subtle and, as Mr. Armey has demonstrated, not so subtle ways.
I do not mean just the denial of housing or employment or even the rejection of a gay child by his parents. Homosexuals experience a rejection of their God-given nature and being. Some are able to deal with this and live out their lives, though few ever reconcile fully to the cruelty. The less fortunate, especially the young, die by their own hands or seek escape in alcohol or drugs.
Barney Frank is a witty man and, from my political point of view, far too effective in Congress. As one who played the role, I know him to be well-suited to his current position as a scourge to the majority party. He has shown tremendous grace in this distasteful episode.
Too many Republicans are now embracing the tactics that Democrats used throughout their long domination of Congress: trying to impose their personal values through Government action. If the G.O.P. is to achieve a lasting allegiance among a majority of Americans, it must stop trying to piece together angry, frustrated constituencies with appeals to prejudice.

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Plans to Go Casual But Stay Put in Hometown

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ARMONK, N.Y., Feb. 3

 BODY:
When employees at I.B.M. headquarters here turned on their computers today, there was an E-mail message from their boss, LVG 20.
 Addressing each of his 700 co-workers as "Armonk colleague," Louis V. Gerstner Jr. announced that the company was planning to sell the 30-year-old concrete-and-glass honeycomb that is its headquarters building and build a new headquarters down the road where employees could do their jobs in a more intimate, collegial and state-of-the-art atmosphere. 
 At the same time, I.B.M. managers began telling employees that they could jettison the company uniform: dark suits, starched white shirts and ties for men, dresses or skirts for women.
 In essence, the message in both moves was, lighten up.
 "If you're comfortable, you can think better," Marge Robinson, an administrative assistant, said of the more informal dress code.
 The changes may seem cosmetic, but they go the heart of the company's efforts to transform itself. Mr. Gerstner, who took over almost two years ago, has been trying to reform a hidebound culture that he blames for the erosion in the company's dominance of the computer industry. He is trying to make the company more relaxed and up-to-date in the hopes that it will also become more profitable. On Jan. 23, the International Business Machines Corporation reported its first profitable year since 1990.
 His message about the new headquarters was heady news for the hamlet of Armonk and the surrounding suburban town of North Castle, which had feared that I.B.M. was thinking of leaving Armonk altogether. I.B.M. provides more than 12 percent of North Castle's tax revenues.
 "Isn't that wonderful," said Becky Kittredge, a councilwoman in North Castle, a town of 100,000 people. "Not only are we not losing I.B.M., which has been a wonderful neighbor, but we'll be receiving more taxes."
 A year ago, I.B.M. executives revealed that they were considering selling their hilltop headquarters on a 450-acre parcel. The move was seen as another wound to Westchester's economy, which then had a 27.1 percent vacancy rate in its office buildings.
 Today, Mr. Gerstner suggested that the location was not the problem, but the building itself, which, he said, "has too many offices and at the same time too little space for accommodating customer meetings."
 It is also obsolete. As leaders of the nation's computer giant, its executives often have to apologize for wiring that is too outdated to accommodate the modems needed by the building's personal computers, machines that were invented 15 years after the building was built.
 The building is also not wired for cable, video conferencing or satellite broadcasts. When Mr. Gerstner wanted to broadcast a worldwide New Year's message last month to employees, he had to go to I.B.M.'s Manhattan offices to do it.
 The new complex, which has not been designed yet, will be in a more wooded area on the same property as the existing building, near a cluster of management training buildings that will give the new headquarters a more open, campuslike setting.
 "He wants a more collegial work atmosphere," said Rob Wilson, a company spokesman.
 The new building or buildings will also be smaller and allow the company to continue to trim its staff, though Mr. Wilson said he did not know to what size. The cost of the new building, he said, would be between $ 60 million and $ 70 million, roughly the same as it would have cost to remodel the current building. I.B.M. said it hopes the complex will be completed in two years.
 I.B.M. has never had a formal dress code, but under the reign of its founders, dark suits, white shirts and neutral ties were de rigueur. Employees sensed that if they did not abide, they could run afoul of a paternalistic culture that protected their jobs for life, found them homes, secured work for their spouses and even provided them with country club privileges.
 Headquarters employees have been telling internal opinion surveys that they prefer to dress more casually, and they will now be able to wear slacks, sport shirts and loafers without fear that their jobs are in peril. Still, there is no insistence that employees dress more casually.
 "If you feel a suit is more appropriate you can wear it," Mr. Wilson said, adding: "I do have a closet full of white shirts that I'm not sure I know what I'm going to do with."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday on the decision by International Business Machines to build a new headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., misstated the population of the surrounding town of North Castle. It is 10,000, not 100,000.

 CORRECTION:
A News Summary entry on Saturday describing an article about Barbra Streisand's speech at Harvard University on the role of artists in politics misrepresented her use of the term "bubbleheads." She quoted others who had called Hollywood friends of President Clinton "bubbleheads." She did not use the term to describe Mr. Clinton's critics.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
ADMITTING THE HOLOCAUST: Collected Essays, by Lawrence L. Langer. (Oxford University, $23.) Mr. Langer, a retired professor of English, illuminates the literature of the Holocaust -- the chronicles of ghetto and camp, the fiction and poetry wrought out of the horror, the representations in film and on television. Mr. Langer is also the editor of ART FROM THE ASHES: A Holocaust Anthology (Oxford University, $30), a remarkable collection of personal accounts, both by well-known survivors and by victims otherwise obscure, and of fiction, poetry and art related to the cataclysm.
 
ALL THE DAYS AND NIGHTS: The Collected Stories of William Maxwell. (Knopf, $25.) Stories, balanced, gentle and humane, concerned above all with reconciliation, from six decades of work by a master writer and editor who is now 86.
 
ANGEL ANGEL, by April Stevens. (Viking, $19.95.) A strangely persuasive novel about a family petrified by a father's desertion, then restored to humanity by an ebullient young woman with enough excess mental health to go around.
 
ANTARCTIC NAVIGATION, by Elizabeth Arthur. (Knopf, $25.) A first-person novel, alive with feeling and animated energy, whose heroine's aim is to vindicate by imitation the vision and morals of Scott of the Antarctic.
 
DEMOCRACY ON TRIAL, by Jean Bethke Elshtain. (Basic Books, $20.) A thoughtful professor of ethics argues that the weakness of democratic institutions in America reflects the replacement of rights conceived as immunities from government interference by rights conceived as individual entitlements.
 
FELICIA'S JOURNEY, by William Trevor. (Viking, $21.95.) Mr. Trevor's latest novel concerns an unmarried, pregnant, vulnerable Irish girl, wandering England's industrial Midlands until she encounters a predatory Englishman whose monstrosity remains long concealed.
 
THE GENERALS' WAR: The Inside Story of the Conflict in the Gulf, by Michael R. Gordon and Bernard E. Trainor. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A lucid, meticulously researched report by the chief Pentagon correspondent of The New York Times and a retired general who is director of national security programs at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
 
NIGHT: Night Life, Night Language, Sleep, and Dreams, by A. Alvarez. (Norton, $23.) Personal and literary explorations of the less visible (and therefore more conjectural) half of life by a gifted critic and acutely intuitive memoirist.
 
THE PAPERBOY, by Pete Dexter. (Random House, $23.) An eerie and beautiful novel whose emotionally alienated title character, a reporter in quest of facts only, is outmaneuvered by violent half-wits who know what they want.
 
REFLECTIONS OF EDEN: My Years With the Orangutans of Borneo, by Birute M.F. Galdikas. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) An offbeat personal memoir that examines her own life and work, by a woman who studied the most autonomous ape.

HEADLINE: Reimagining Berlin

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger, chief cultural correspondent for The Times, won a Pulitzer Prize for his architectural criticism.

 BODY:
WHAT STRUCK ME FIRST IN BERLIN WAS not energy but emptiness. This city that is supposed to be the capital of the new Europe begins with a void, with the startling discovery that its center is 17 acres of weeds and debris. Where the streets lead you as you seek out its heart turns out to be . . . a sprawling vacant lot. Some of it is surrounded by fences, but most of it is open, and since Berlin has few tall buildings, there is almost no skyline to frame this lunar landscape. Berlin's two most famous landmarks, the Brandenburg Gate and the Reichstag, hover in the distance, while the foreground is all nothingness. It is as if Times Square had been replaced by a chunk of the New Jersey Meadowlands.
This was once Potsdamer Platz, Berlin's commercial heart, so busy in the 1920's that it received the world's first traffic light. For the last 50 years, it has been empty, damaged by Allied bombs and finished off by the East Germans, who rammed the Berlin wall right through its center and tore down what remained of the surrounding blocks. This is all about to change: ground has already been broken for a vast office and retail complex sponsored by Daimler-Benz, and Sony plans to build its European headquarters here. Today, though, five years after the wall fell, most of Potsdamer Platz is still a wind-swept, dreary wasteland, laughing in the face of Berlin's much-vaunted intentions to reclaim the glories of its past. 
 For all that has happened since 1989, Berlin is a profoundly wounded city, and its wounds still show. Yes, Potsdamer Platz is full of construction signs with pictures of sleek new buildings by Renzo Piano, Arata Isozaki, Helmut Jahn and other renowned architects, but these buildings will be a long time in coming and are only a small part of Berlin's broader, often rancorous, struggle to invent itself anew. "You can't isolate a discussion of architecture from a discussion of the rest of Berlin," says Josef Kleihues, the most prominent architect in the city, and he is right. The sheer volume of new construction -- some 35 major projects are under way -- has made Berlin the biggest magnet for the world's architects since Tokyo in the 1980's. Architecture has become a subject that often serves as a touchstone for the larger question of what Berlin should be. The future of the physical city is debated today with the passion that just a few years ago was reserved for politics.
For most of this century, Berlin has held a strange and powerful allure for the rest of the world. Enlivened to the point of decadence by the arts in the 1920's, battered and nearly destroyed by dictatorship and war in the 1930's and 1940's and thrust painfully into the role of cold war icon for most of the time since, the city looks from afar like some kind of forbidden fruit, a garden of dazzling creativity, utter evil and constant redemption.
The Berliner's view of the world is ironic, occasionally bitter, often funny and inevitably more sophisticated than that of the average German -- not unlike what can be said about New Yorkers and the way in which they relate to the rest of the United States. Indeed, most Germans view Berlin with the sort of resentment, occasionally combined with envy, that Americans seem perpetually to feel toward New York.
It is no surprise that a New Yorker feels instantly at home here. Both cities are filled with anxious energy and with people who grew up in the provinces and yearned for a more cosmopolitan life. While New York and Berlin could not look less alike, the "Berliner luft," that special air, gives a snap that is more than a little similar to whatever makes the mood along the Hudson.
In the ecstasy that followed the opening of the wall in 1989 and the reunification of Germany a year later, it looked like nothing could stop the juggernaut. Berlin seemed, for a brief moment, to be the most important city in the world and the one where things changed faster than any other. It seemed poised to become the focal point of a reshaped Europe, the city where the post-cold-war world would find itself. Here in Berlin, in the restored capital of the continent's strongest economic power, would the prosperity of the West meet the potential of the East. Here in Berlin, in the city destined to recapture from Paris the title of world cultural center, would music, art and architecture reign supreme.
After five years, it has not quite happened. Yes, you can buy a Mercedes-Benz on Friedrichstrasse in East Berlin, where only the tiny, soot-spitting East German-built Trabants once chugged. True, billboards all over East Berlin proclaim "Test the West," pushing a brand of cigarettes called West by neatly merging commercial exhortation and soft-sell politics. But the new Berlin, whatever form it takes, is still far from being realized. The city has lost, not gained, jobs since the wall came down. (The closing of antiquated factories in East Berlin cost 150,000 manufacturing jobs, while the curtailment of the Federal subsidies that for so long propped up the West Berlin economy has meant the loss of an additional 65,000 jobs since 1989.) With the sputtering economy, real-estate developers have few tenants for their fancy new buildings. The cultural picture is murkier than when the wall ignited a creative spark of radicalism. The return of the German Government to Berlin from Bonn has been delayed repeatedly and is now not likely to be complete until the year 2000.
It has all put Berlin in the grip of something -- not quite depression but more than ennui. The "Berliner luft" seems not to be as crisp as it once was. The former West Berlin, which looked for years like a sort of generic European city, energized by serving as a vitrine for Western prosperity within the Eastern bloc, is now just the richer, more bourgeois side of town. The former East Berlin, meanwhile, struggles with a pace of change that turns out to be considerably slower than anyone had expected.
"How to describe the present emotions in Berlin?" muses Ulrich Roloff-Momin, the city's Senator for Culture. "After the euphoria of 1989, we are now in the desert. We have to march through to the other end -- but the wall in the mind is higher than the real wall was."
Officially, of course, Humpty Dumpty has put himself back together just fine. Virtually all traces of the wall are gone, except for a few -- too few -- short segments that have been retained as unofficial monuments. The U-Bahn and the S-Bahn, the subway and elevated trains that for 40 years had to stop and reverse course in midcity, now travel their full routes. The city governments of East and West have merged (occupying the original City Hall in East Berlin), the phone system is all one again and taxis go everywhere.
Depending on whom you talk to, the rejoining of the city is either a miracle or a logistical nightmare. Upon reunification, it became clear that the two sides of the city were in dramatically different condition. In East Berlin, gas lines were so poorly maintained that constant leaks killed trees; phone trunk lines were so scattered that, even now, it can take a year to get new service. Since cellular phones are readily available, many people simply leapfrog over conventional service: in East Berlin, as in much of Eastern Europe, it is common to see long lines of the phone-deprived in front of public telephone booths, while a few feet away, shop windows display the newest cellular models.
Eventually the phone lines will come. The real question for Berlin is what happens above ground, not below it. This city, more battered by the 20th century than any others except perhaps Beirut and Sarajevo, will be rebuilding itself for the next decade.
Berlin sprawls. It is six times the size of Paris in area and with its 3.5 million inhabitants spread out over 339 square miles, it is one of the least dense great cities of the world. It has never been a city of tall buildings, and until 1969, when the East Germans completed a bizarre, 1,200-foot-high television and observation tower in the city center, there was little else on the skyline big enough to be noticed. Unlike every other great metropolis in the world, its future form is uncertain. London is London, Rome is Rome, Tokyo is Tokyo, but Berlin is a question mark.
"SO, YOU WANT TO SEE THE model now, yes?" says Hans Stimmann, the stocky, white-haired bureaucrat who serves as the city's building director and is, by common agreement, the most powerful figure shaping the physical future of Berlin. An engineer by training, Stimmann, 53, has taught and practiced urban planning for close to three decades. "The model" is an extraordinary object, bigger than most living rooms, showing every building in Berlin's center and every new one that has been proposed. It is a deft piece of high tech: push a button corresponding to a new project and a rendering appears on a hanging screen while a computer-driven spotlight whirs around to focus on its three-dimensional miniature. This is city planning with the spectacle of a theme park and it is dazzling.
For Stimmann, the model also serves an important polemical purpose, since he is the chief advocate of the view that Berlin should develop itself along traditional lines. He feels that every sensible notion about building cities is already known and he refers often to "the European way of making cities," by which he means the presence of low, boxy buildings set tightly together along streets and squares. If architects would only follow these simple rules, he believes, all would be well.
"Berlin was totally destroyed by the bombs and after the war it was totally destroyed by the planners," Stimmann says. "Berlin is the only city in the world where the inner city is empty. We must bring this city back so that when we look in the mirror, we will know that it is our face. If we look like Hong Kong or Tokyo, nobody will come. Berlin must look like Berlin."
But what does making Berlin look like Berlin actually mean? Filling in the gaps left by the bombs and the wall with buildings that look like those that were demolished? Berlin never had a very consistent cityscape to start with; there is even less consistency to Berlin than to New York and no generic "Berlin building" the way a brownstone or a 14-story limestone and brick apartment house might be called a generic New York building.
Most of Berlin is low, to be sure, but there are great differences between the haute bourgeois neighborhood of Charlottenburg, the faded working-class district of Prenzlauerberg and the grand classical boulevard of Unter den Linden in East Berlin's civic heart. The street life, too, is intensely varied. On the wide Kufurstendamm, the glittering main artery of West Berlin, cafes and shops brim with people; the streets, too, are teeming. There may be just as much vitality in the slowly gentrifying neighborhoods of East Berlin, but after decades of repression, it still plays out less visibly -- the cafes full; the sidewalks empty.
While Stimmann hesitates to admit it, much of Berlin was shaped by the very modernist architecture that he is now trying to fight. Back in the 1920's, long before the fifth-rate postwar modernism of the East Germans, visionary architects like Bruno and Max Taut were designing extraordinary housing complexes in Berlin that came as close to fulfilling modernism's utopian dreams as anything in Europe.
Yet modern architecture, for all its ability to create beautiful buildings, left an awful legacy in city planning -- in Berlin and elsewhere. The modern movement failed at creating cities, even while it succeeded at making buildings that were beautiful abstract objects poised in space. Like post-modern architects in the United States -- whose arguments in many ways parallel Stimmann's and whose debate with modernists is not so different from the architectural battle of Berlin -- Stimmann understands the virtues of the urban fabric. But he often exaggerates them to the point of denying the virtues, even the artistic power, of great works of architecture that do not follow the urban rules.
He is nothing if not a brilliant rhetorician, taunting architects with antimodernist sloganeering. And they have no choice but to listen. Although he reports to Wolfgang Nagel, the city's Senator for Construction and Housing, it is Stimmann who sets many of the rules. He also chooses the juries for the architectural competitions that are required for most major projects. To be an architect on Stimmann's good side is to get plenty of work in Berlin; otherwise, you might as well be in Helsinki.
One architect who has risen to his bait, and fought more bitterly and more publicly with Stimmann than any other, is Daniel Libeskind. He is the 48-year-old architect of the city's new Jewish Museum, set to open next year -- a bold, even monumental, example of the deconstructivist style of architecture. The museum, whose sharp angles make it look like a stone tower in the form of a zigzag, is now being built at the edge of the Kreuzberg neighborhood, a few hundred yards south of where Checkpoint Charlie once stood. Libeskind's museum may be the most important single piece of architecture now rising in Berlin and it is as un-Stimmann-like as a building can be. And yet, despite all the attention the architect has gotten for the museum and other projects in Berlin, he recently decamped for Los Angeles.
"I love Berlin and its culture, but I could no longer commit myself to living there," Libeskind says. In Stimmann's approach, he declares, "There is an unnerving nostalgia for the past." Libeskind refers to the city's current building rules as "the total erasure of 50 years of history of this city. It is going back to a time when things were not problematic, coupled with an authoritarian idea of how to develop the city."
Stimmann replies: "Libeskind is an intellectual, but the city is a social system, and every house has to work as part of a society. I have no problem with Libeskind. Libeskind has a problem with me."
It is not merely avant-garde architects who quarrel with Stimmann; many real-estate developers are no happier. Mark Palmer, the bow-tied, boosterish former United States Ambassador to Hungary who now lives in Berlin and runs the Central European Development Corporation, complains about the "small-town mentality of Stimmannism."
Palmer's company has planned five large commercial buildings -- to be called the American Business Center -- at the Checkpoint Charlie site, the most famous crossing point between East and West. "Berlin could be the most important city in the world," Palmer says, but after being beaten down by the events of the last 50 years, "Germans are so used to being self-effacing, not bold." Stimmann's rules reinforce this way of thinking, he says. They have turned the Checkpoint Charlie project -- which includes a curiously post-modern office building by Philip Johnson with round dormer windows and slanted walls of glass -- into a piecemeal effort rather than the big single splash Palmer would have preferred.
There is also something piecemeal about the part of the new Berlin that is closest to completion: the series of office buildings, some also containing apartments, along the Friedrichstrasse in Mitte, the central commercial and institutional neighborhood of East Berlin. Several buildings are by internationally known architects, including Josef Kleihues, Henry I. Cobb of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners in New York and Jean Nouvel of Paris. The buildings all follow Stimmann's regulations in that they are low and built out to the street, but there is tremendous esthetic variation from one to the other and the street has more visual interest than Stimmann's critics would suggest his rules permit. The Nouvel building, surely the most sensual piece of modern architecture now going up in Berlin, is sheathed in curving glass, while a building by O. M. Ungers, a Hamburg architect, is a somewhat stern, almost prim box of crisply detailed stone. Whatever else can be said about this street, it is surely no Weimar Disneyland, no Main Street of fake 1920's-style buildings.
And yet nothing in the Friedrichstrasse is a fully successful piece of architecture, either, since all the buildings suffer from a tension between the architects' esthetics and Stimmann's rules. These are not architects who came to the party wanting to sit quietly, and while they have all behaved themselves, it is hard not to see in each building a sculptural shape bursting to break free.
But the struggle over just what form Berlin should take is more than a fight over architecture. It is about history, too, and about authenticity, and about which parts of this city's extraordinary and tragic past should be expressed in the developing new city. The very existence of the Checkpoint Charlie project, whatever its architectural form, stakes a claim for a Berlin that would rather bury some of its history than protect it. The spot where Russian and American tanks faced off in October 1961 will now be the site of an intricate building of stone and glass by David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill.
Already, every piece of the Berlin wall is gone from this area. To get a real sense of Checkpoint Charlie, you must walk a block to a private museum, a rabbit warren full of artifacts, cars and letters and photographs of those who escaped East Germany and those who died trying. As the surrounding area becomes an expensive commercial district, even the museum may be squeezed out by higher rents, leaving nothing but sleek office buildings to mark the spot where the world nearly exploded.
BERLIN HAS ALWAYS BEEN A CITY hospitable to the avant-garde and never more so than in its great heydey of the 1920's, when in Weimar Berlin, far more than anywhere else in Europe, modernism in art, theater, music and architecture grew alongside traditional high culture. What is troubling about the city's present architectural picture is the sense that in post-wall Berlin, the very openness to new ideas and new forms that for so long defined the city's culture is threatened by a desire to make Berlin too comfortable, too smooth, too easy. It is as if the city had gone from oppression to smugness in one step.
"Utopian visions are a bad thing in this city right now," says Kristin Freireiss, an art dealer whose Aedes Gallery, which specializes in architectural drawings, has come to function as a forum for the international architectural avant-garde in Berlin. She is an outspoken supporter of Libeskind, the California architect Frank Gehry and virtually every other architect whom Stimmann dislikes.
"What Stimmann wants is to go back into the last century," she says. "He thinks that all those rules are still accurate. He is saying he wants stone, he wants brick, the windows should be this size and that, and it gives no chance for the architect. Young architects are excluded here and they don't dare speak up about it, his power is such."
Freireiss's complaints notwithstanding, architects are cultural heroes in Germany. Virtually all major commissions in Berlin are awarded through architectural competitions and international architects must make up the majority of the seats on the jury. Even private real-estate developers are not free to select their own architects: the city, in the person of Stimmann's office, organizes a competition and participates in the process. "The typical developer in the United States would go bonkers if he had to put up with architectural competitions the way they're done there," says Jerry Speyer, the president of Tishman Speyer Properties, a New York-based developer with a major presence in Berlin. Speyer, whose firm is developing the Sony complex at Potsdamer Platz, had to simultaneously submit three different schemes from three different architects to win approval for a major building in the Friedrichstrasse project.
Such a system is expensive and, there being only so many architects, incestuous. Today's jury member is inevitably tomorrow's competitor. Probably no one has profited more from this system than Josef Kleihues, who has become the Philip Johnson of Berlin -- an eminent architect with an unusual combination of political power and esthetic clout. Kleihues, 61, was the chairman of the jury that awarded Libeskind the Jewish Museum commission and he has directed other jobs to other younger architects. He also has 14 of his own projects going up in Berlin, including a new art museum in the old Hamburger train station and a Four Seasons Hotel in the former East Berlin. Kleihues is the consummate Berliner: he turned a building on the Spree River that was once used to load garbage onto barges into a stylish architectural office and he still tours the city by a boat he moors beneath his drafting room. His work is sharply detailed, generally modernist but rarely extreme enough to offend the traditionalists; it deftly walks the tightrope between the city's politics and its architectural salons.
It is too soon to tell how much of Berlin's new architecture will be of world importance. For now, only Libeskind's Jewish Museum seems certain to be, although the renovation of the Reichstag, by the British architect Norman Foster, may turn out to be brilliant (Foster is giving this heavy monument of 19th-century German classicism a huge glass dome). The buildings going up at Potsdamer Platz may also attract international attention.
And there, for once, the right thing is happening. The master plan correctly uses traditional streets (and even a recreation of the octagonal form of Leipziger Platz just beside Potsdamer), but there is a considerable amount of architectural invention within the framework of that plan. The hope, of course, is that Potsdamer Platz can resume its role as Berlin's Piccadilly Circus. Not until the first years of the new century, however, will it be evident if Sony's ultra-high-tech theaters, for instance, turn Berlin into a true urban center or merely a first-class theme park.
Another great opportunity for Berlin lies in the plan to renovate Museum Island, the group of five classical museums on an island in the Spree River, including the Pergamon Museum and Schinkel's Altes Museum, the greatest 19th-century classical museum structure in the world. The winner of last year's architectural competition was the Italian Giorgio Grassi, who proposed a fairly modest scheme that put many functions underground while leaving the buildings largely undisturbed. But Wolf-Dieter Dube, the director of state museums for Berlin, preferred a much more assertive proposal by Frank Gehry. His design called for a glass roof over the Pergamon's courtyard, several amorphously shaped structures in open space beside the building and a series of new bridges, including one right into the Altes Museum.
Dube says he preferred the Gehry plan not only for its ability to better integrate the cluster of museums but simply because it would have been a powerful piece of contemporary architecture (and it would have given the conservative forces in Berlin a nudge). "I say to people in Berlin: 'What would you do with the New National Gallery by Mies van der Rohe?' " Dube says. " 'Would you accept that today? Would it be possible to construct the Philharmonic Hall by Scharoun?' "
Even though the Gehry plan did not win the competition, it may be built after all; the politics are complicated and no final decision is likely for another year. It hardly matters right now anyway, since the Government has awarded only a fraction of the $200 million that either scheme is likely to cost. Meanwhile, the buildings continue to crumble, thanks to the East Germans' poor maintenance of most of the monumental architecture that came into their possession.
One of the strangest results of the years of separation between East and West is that the Berlin Government inherits a virtually complete set of duplicate cultural institutions. Since the city's traditional cultural center around the Unter den Linden fell on the East Berlin side of the wall, the West German government simply created new institutions across town. Thus the Deutsche Opera, the counterpart to the State Opera; Mies van der Rohe's extraordinary New National Gallery, which serves as the opposite number to the old national museum, and the State Library, a remarkable building by the modernist architect Hans Scharoun that is the counterpart to the old Berlin Library. (The Berlin Philharmonic, the most famous cultural group of all, moved entirely to West Berlin to play in Scharoun's Philharmonie Hall, built in 1963 and one of the most most stunning orchestra halls, esthetically and acoustically, of the 20th century.)
With a couple of exceptions (most notably the Schiller Theater, which closed in 1993), Berlin is keeping them all. With an arts budget of roughly $800 million a year -- more than four times the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts -- Berlin is one of the most lavishly subsidized cultural communities in the world, despite a tenuous economy. Yet discussions of culture, even more than those about architecture, are perpetually haunted by the Berlin of the 1920's, the golden era beside which the present seems tired, weak. It is a paradoxical thing, this yearning for the city of Kurt Weill and Bertolt Brecht and Christopher Isherwood, for it is at once an exercise in nostalgia and a battle cry for the city to resist falling into the banality of mainstream culture.
Weimar Berlin was a true burst of culture, a staggering moment of dancing on the edge that could not have lasted. Its beginnings were made possible by the sudden openness of what, until the Weimar Republic was declared in 1918, had been a closed and oppressive society. There was a sense not only that the world could be made anew but that it had to be -- that Germany, having lost the war, was given a blank slate on which to write its future.
Of course, the new Berlin has also been defined by a sense of release at the outset. But after the initial euphoria came a marked decrease of artistic energy. There was a profound urgency to life in Berlin before 1989, as East Berliners and West Berliners faced one another across a wall that was brutal in its silence and as looming in their consciousness as a mountain. It was the defining presence of the city and tension emanated from it like radiation. Now, Berlin copes more with the pains and pleasures of adjustment to bourgeois, democratic life. It is an adjustment that is full of complexities, though not necessarily the sort out of which great art is made.
Ulrich Roloff-Momin, the city's Senator for Culture, offers another reason why Berlin after the wall will not become another Weimar Berlin. "The Jewish people were the focus of the cultural energy in the 1920's and they are not here," he says.
Of course, there is Daniel Barenboim, who heads the State Opera, and the other Daniel much talked about in Berlin, the architect Libeskind. But Roloff-Momin is largely correct: whereas Jews once dominated the cultural scene in Berlin, there are now few Jews in high cultural positions and not many more working as artists, musicians or actors.
Discussions about Germany -- and Berlin -- seem invariably to come around to the question of Jews. In 1933, the year Hitler came to power, the Jewish community of Berlin numbered 170,000. By the end of World War II, emigration and the Nazi killings brought this count down to about 5,000. There are still only about 9,000 Jews in Berlin today, with most new immigrants coming from Eastern Europe.
Yet the Jewish community in Berlin is highly visible, in part because of an overt effort on behalf of the city government. In 1993, the city published an elaborate English-language brochure, "Jewish Places in Berlin," complete with colored maps. It lists historical spots of note, including the sites of synagogues destroyed by the Nazis or by Allied bombs as well as synagogues where religious services are now conducted. The same city whose police stood by in 1938 as Nazi storm troopers set fire to synagogues on Kristallnacht now pays for 24-hour police protection for all Jewish institutions. The city provided much of the money to restore the facade of the so-called New Synagogue on Orianenburgerstrasse in the former East Berlin. The synagogue's stunning gilded dome, all but obliterated during the war, once again holds pride of place on the city's skyline.
This huge Moorish structure, which seats 3,000, was built in 1866 and was intended to be a prominent presence in the cityscape. Here, as much as anywhere, was Reform Judaism born, and the fact that Chancellor Otto von Bismarck attended the building's dedication was a clear sign of the desire of Berlin's Jews to be seen also as Germans. By the end of the century, the position of Jews in Germany was less secure, however, and by the time of Kristallnacht, the synagogue had become the most conspicuous target in Berlin.
The much-vaunted restoration, elegant though it is, is only partial. The enormous sanctuary, razed in the 1950's after being badly damaged by British bombs in 1943, has not been rebuilt, and may never be. The synagogue that stands proudly today, its golden dome visible all across town, is really no more than a stage set. There is a new Jewish community center right beside it and a kosher restaurant and cafe next door, but the building itself is a glittering, hollow shell.
There is a better sense to be had of the reality of Jewish life in Berlin today a short distance to the northeast, in the old working-class community of Prenzlauerberg. There, set back within a courtyard, sits the Rykestrasse Synagogue, built in 1903, the only intact old synagogue in all of Berlin. Its site within the courtyard seems to have saved it during Kristallnacht; since the red-brick synagogue is tightly surrounded by tenements, a fire would have put non-Jews at risk. Used by the German Army to store munitions during the war, it was restored to religious use in 1953 and was the only functioning synagogue in all of East Berlin.
The Rykestrasse Synagogue is still in use, with a congregation of a few dozen worshipers, mostly regular, from around Berlin. At an evening service I attended recently, they ranged from their 20's to their 70's and the cultural differences were tremendous: one young man wore an earring and a punk haircut and a middle-aged man was dressed in the black suit of the Hasidim, while the older men wore sweaters and slacks. A couple of children scampered around the small chapel as the cantor chanted the service. It was conducted entirely in Hebrew and had none of the rote quality that sometimes afflicts religious rituals. It seemed as if every one of these people knew that reciting Jewish prayers a couple of miles from the headquarters of the Gestapo was a historical miracle and wanted their voices to proclaim it as such.
If there is a bridge between the world of the Rykestrasse Synagogue and the contemporary culture of Berlin, it is probably Daniel Libeskind. Born in Poland in 1946, he is best recognized in New York as one of eight architects annointed by the Museum of Modern Art in its 1988 exhibition "Deconstructivist Architecture." In Berlin, of course, Libeskind is known more as a public complainer than an esthete. He has hinted more than a few times that the city would rather forget the pain of its history with the Jews and that his architecture prods Germans to recall the anguish they would prefer to deny.
Libeskind's Jewish Museum makes no effort to blend in quietly. Surely the most conspicuous sign of Berlin's desire to reflect its contemporary attitude toward the Jewish community, it is literally annexed to the Berlin Museum, an ornate stucco villa full of five centuries of Germany history.
The Jewish Museum's most important space is not a gallery but a concrete-walled atrium at the heart of the building that can only be peered into, not entered. Libeskind refers to it as "the void," meant to symbolize the absence of so much of the Jewish community of Berlin. The uneven, trapezoidal shape of the gallery spaces represents the long and uneven history of the Jews of Berlin. Inside, there will be religious artifacts, a panoply of art, from paintings to fashion to furniture, and a section devoted to the achievements of Jews who spent time in German concentration camps.
Will the museum work? Utterly unsentimental, it uses abstract form to make a point about history and culture, one of the hardest things for architecture to accomplish. It will unquestionably be a difficult building, but few structures have had higher ambitions, both for their users and for the art of architecture itself.
You can't build a city of Jewish Museums. No one, though, not even Daniel Libeskind, seems to want to. Sadly, Hans Stimmann seems determined to act as if Berlin were in danger of becoming nothing but a laboratory for architectural art pieces. The true danger, in fact, is just the opposite: that in a city of growing commercial strength, architecture, driven by economic urgency, will be fast, cheap and banal. Stimmann's rules do make some sense, as long as they can be interpreted loosely enough not to squeeze out all the architectural fresh air. After all, cities do need order, streets are essential and most buildings don't have any business being prima donnas. But every so often, a city deserves a special moment, and Berlin, held down for so long, needs some architectural exclamation points as much as any city anywhere.
BERLIN IS DIFFICULT, IRASCIBLE, cynical. No one in Germany was surprised that the debate over whether to bring the capital back to Berlin was long and bitter. To many German bureaucrats, the placidity of Bonn, where the Government has been the only game in town, is vastly preferable to the miasma of Berlin.
Berlin is also a city of risk. It has always danced on the edge, and this alone gives it special kinship with New York. But for a long time, it has danced close to the abyss of history, and by this measure, New Yorkers live in Podunk. The day-to-day ambiance of Berlin may be calmer than New York, the subway trains cleaner, the streets safer, the whole system more in control even with all the logistical snags in rejoining East and West. But on the stress index, the stakes have always been higher here, for everyone. No one in Berlin could escape the presence of the city's checkered history and, during the years of the wall, the terrifying possibility that their city might be the spot where the cold war ignited.
With that danger gone, Berlin is left with a question: In a new Berlin, what could be as compelling as the wall? No architect in the world could make a new symbol to equal it, for the wall succeeded in doing what no monument in the history of architecture has been able to do -- it insinuated itself into every citizen's life, every moment of every day. Monuments aspire to that, but they all fail, for even the best of them turn out, in the end, to be peripheral to daily life. But the wall was everywhere. It stopped time as much as it blocked space. The blunt, harsh, dumb wall, a piece of anti-architecture really, turned Berlin upside down and captivated the attention of the world for nearly 30 years, like some grotesque mutation of a Christo artwork that refused to go away. Five years after the wall fell, the city still feels the vastness of its void.
Berlin must get on with its life, but it cannot pretend the wall was never there, any more than it can pretend that the Nazi years did not happen. As the city struggles to define itself as a cultural and political capital for the reunited Germany, it faces a troubling paradox: the more successful it becomes at creating an ordinary, satisfying good life for its citizens, the less it will show its wounds. If Berlin dwells too much in the past, if it allows its history to be too visible, it cannot become the new city it yearns to become. But if it becomes only a new city, it will not be Berlin.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1106 words

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
To Be Sure . . .

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
WANT TO ANticipate a rebuttal? Want to show how profoundly you understand your opponent's arguments before demolishing them? Then play the popular rhetorical game of to be sure . . . but.
This has nothing to do with the earliest meaning of the phrase, which is "to be certain." Nor is it synonymous with "of course," as in a 1657 discourse on the Book of Common Prayer: "Morning and Evening, to be sure, God expects from us . . . a publick worship." By 1795, a new sense emerged, of offering a concession before countering it: "The wind is contrary, to be sure, but it is far from a storm." The current, heavy use of the phrase in the prose of persuasion has that seemingly reasonable purpose, but it conceals the real goal: to pull the teeth of targets before they can bite back. 
 In op-ed-ese, admittedly is as outdated as true enough. Concededly is too likely to be confused with conceitedly. Stipulated is too legalistic, almost as billable to clients as arguendo. About the only other introduction to a grudging concession used these days is granted, but that, like admittedly, lacks the sonorous seriousness of the most voguish fang-extractor.
"To be sure, Mr. Gingrich has a right under House ethics rules to write a legitimately financed book and make money from it," goes a New York Times editorial. "But he cannot expect. . . ."
"To be sure, the next afternoon things were marginally better . . . ," Jonathan Yardley writes, coining his cliche in The Washington Post. "Still. . . ."
"To be sure, there will be no opportunity for cooperation in the middle," writes Norman J. Ornstein of the American Enterprise Institute, pulling back his rubber band further for counterargument with "Indeed, the G.O.P. has maintained a strikingly high level of party unity," before snapping back soon with "But moving to the majority makes a difference."
The straw-man modifier, to be sure, is sometimes intended to lull the opponent into thinking a valuable point has been conceded; more often, it treats as minor a portion of the opposing argument while setting up an assertion of what the to-be-surer wants to be considered more important. The telltale clue in detecting the construction of the straw-man modifier is the contrarian conjunction: but, still, nonetheless.
In the ranks of the practitioners of this there-are-those-who-will-point-out school of rhetoric, however, nobody comes close to our Deputy Secretary of State, Strobe Talbott. Perhaps because he used to be a pundit for Time magazine, he is extraordinarily sensitive to the need to anticipate and tolerantly acknowledge counterargument.
"To be sure, elections are neither a panacea for social ills nor a guarantee of enlightened government," he lectured his audience at Oxford, adding, "Nonetheless. . . ." Then, "To be sure, the United States still has disputes with Russia and with China . . . but there is, for the first time, no defining polarization."
For variety, the adept concessionarian slipped the phrase into the middle of a sentence: "The central issue . . . did, to be sure, involve land and power. . . . But the cold war was not just about land and power." Then back to the old-fashioned way: "To be sure, there are still a few countries that continue to decorate their flags with red stars . . . but these holdout communist states, too, offer reason for what might be called strategic optimism."
Sometimes it takes an explosion of uses in a single place to shock us into taking the anti-cliche pledge. Because Mr. Talbott is the only professional writer at the high levels of the Administration, it is fair to thank him for his pyrotechnic display of to-be-surety. Granted, he didn't know he was doing it. . . .
 
Day 1
One is where it's at.
"The House has been up to the usual kind of political fighting," said Bob Franken, reporting on CNN, "even on Day 1." This usage was given prominence by Newt Gingrich's promise to hit the ground running on his Contract With America; asked about welfare changes that could take two years, the Speaker said, "I'm closer to Day 1."
The locution gained a purchase on the American vocabulary in the 1970's. "The game shows," Forbes magazine wrote in April 1975, ". . . make money from Day 1 for everyone." That year, The Economist in London discussed wage and price controls, using the phrase in "values at day one of the freeze." Business Week at the same time wrote of assets that "belong to your child from day one," suggesting that the phrase had its roots in the business world.
Those were the earliest Nexis citations, but a 1973 use was found in the Westlaw data base, searched by Fred R. Shapiro, editor of the Oxford Dictionary of American Legal Quotations; he found a judge's opinion about "experience . . . from day one until the end of time." The Dialog data base tracks it back even earlier to a Miami Herald sportswriter, Scott Fowler, who wrote on Dec. 31, 1939, "From day one, we knew there would be a market of people out there that would want to sit in the first couple of rows." (Everybody styles the phrase differently; The New York Times prefers Day 1.)
The phrase was popularized by the ABC television program "Day 1," which began in 1993. But the Gingrich use seemed to trigger a proliferation of usages. "This Week With David Brinkley" on ABC titled a program "The 104th Congress -- Week One," and a New York Times editorial was headed "Governor Whitman at Year One." (Here we are on the verge of Millennium Three, and nobody has yet referred to Millennium One.)
Can anyone find an earlier use of this booming locution than The Miami Herald in 1939? If so, you may be the discoverer of Day 1's Day 1.
 
Construing the News
"News of my imminent departure or resignation," said Secretary of State Warren Christopher, "are neither new nor accurate."
Maybe the ordinarily careful lawyer meant reports, a plural subject; maybe he mentally substituted an and for the or and incorrectly made that the subject of his sentence; maybe he was so deeply "into denial," as the psychobabblers say, that he engendered subject-verb disagreement.
The only other possibility is that the Secretary construed news as plural, taking the plural verb are. (Media, for example, is construed as plural; one should never say, "The media is.")
Mr. Christopher would not be the first American public figure to treat news as plural. Legend has it that Horace Greeley, editor of The New York Tribune during the Civil War, sent this telegraph message to one of his correspondents near a battlefield: "Are there any news?" To which the reporter supposedly cabled back: "Not a new."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 12; Column 3; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 193 words

HEADLINE: Channel Tunnel

 BODY:
To the Editor: We enjoyed the article "At Last, a Train Under the Channel" (Dec. 4).
My wife and I traveled on the Chunnel train from London to Paris in November. As the article said, the convenience and economy of traveling from central city to central city is unbeatable. 
 We had nonrefundable second-class tickets, purchased in New York for $75 each. Since the trip takes only three hours and we arrived in Paris at 12:30 P.M., I cannot see why anyone would want to go first class and have a meal on the train, when upon arrival you have all the great restaurants in Paris to choose from.
Traveling on Eurostar is similar to Amtrak's Metroliner. The only time you realize its speed is when you note how quickly automobiles on the adjoining highway are overtaken. The actual tunnel segment doesn't feel any different from a New York subway, except it's smooth and quiet.
Our only complaint was that that snack, coffee and liquor service in the bar car was very slow, mainly because of the inexperience of the personnel. Also, it would be nice if there were some souvenir postcards or booklets available.
 
DANIEL G. SMITH
New York, N.Y.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
A Key State Rental-Housing Program Survives Test

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
WHEN the owner of a regulated apartment is allowed a rent increase to pay for major capital improvement work, should the increase become part of the permanent base rent? Or should it drop off, as though it were a surcharge, after the cost is recovered?
This was the most significant question that the New York State Court of Appeals laid to rest in reaching a decision in December on a case that has been perking in the court system for 12 years. The increase becomes part of the base rent, said the unanimous court, supporting the position of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which administers the Major Capital Improvement program, and of property owners themselves. 
 The court also ruled that such increases may not exceed 6 percent in any one year. In many cases the housing agency had been granting temporary retroactive increases on top of the 6 percent increase to compensate owners for the time it took -- almost three years on average in the mid-80's -- to process an application for a rent increase after the work was completed.
"The statute unequivocally places a ceiling on the total increased rental amount that may be collected in a given year -- spreading the excess forward, thereby protecting tenants from precipitous rent increases," the court said. This finding was a victory for the tenants who joined a class-action suit started by the Bryant Avenue Tenants Association in the Bronx in 1983. The case was pursued on behalf of the class by Legal Services for New York City. As in so many long-running lawsuits affecting housing, the decision comes at a time when housing circumstances are far different from what they were when the suit was initiated. The ambitious building improvement work undertaken by rental owners during a rising real-estate market is largely a thing of the past. Instances of rent-increase applications reaching 20 percent a year had fueled the lawsuit. The affected tenants normally would be paying lease-renewal increases as well.
Moreover, state policy decisions have long since eased the impact of rent increases attributable to capital improvements. Before state takeover of regulation of the rent-stabilized (mainly post-World War II) housing stock in 1984, there was no legal limit on the annual rent increase owners could seek. The state set one at 15 percent a year. Then it reduced the limit to 6 percent, allowing retroactivity to compensate for processing time.
The housing agency also raised the length of the payback period itself. It had been five years; the state lifted it to seven. But it never embraced the idea of eliminating the increase from the base rent after the payback period ended.
What remains, with the legal issue decided, is the challenge of administrative efficiency -- one among several challenges involving regulated housing that the new administration of Gov. George E. Pataki faces. In the latter years of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Office of Rent Administration brought down the average processing period to under a year, by adding processors to the Owner Multiple Application Bureau, state officials say. But why, it might be asked, should it take even a year to process applications for major capital improvement allowances?
Joseph E. Holland, a 38-year-old lawyer and businessman from Harlem who is the newly appointed commissioner of the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said he had "no doubt there are efficiencies that can be gained, but it's too early to speak about rent administration."
JUST last week Governor Pataki proposed in his over-all budget for fiscal 1996, starting April 1, a $1.3 million cut for the Office of Rent Administration, and a staff reduction of 38 people. How this will affect processing in general is not clear, but Mr. Holland said of the Major Capital Improvement program itself, "It's a good program because it encourages owners to invest in their property."
The likelihood is that the slowdown in the real-estate market itself is the main reason for the decline in major-capital-improvement work. In addition, many buildings have already done basic systems replacements, often in conjunction with plans to convert buildings to co-ops.
Now owners have to be more concerned about the ability of tenants in place to handle the rent increases required by improvements. "Many rents are already at market level today," said Jeff Chanchall, a partner in Realty Program Consultants of Fresh Meadows, Queens, who handles major-capital-improvement rent-increase applications on behalf of owners. "They do the work and they find they can't collect from 15, 20, 30 percent of the building."
Nevertheless, the slowness of the application process, coupled with the retarded payback period, are probably factors in the declining use of the major capital improvement program. Mark Engel, president of Langsam Property Services Corporation, which owns or operates 250 rental properties in the Bronx and Manhattan, said the affordability issue and the lengthy payback period have made the program "almost obsolete" for any improvement work that is not essential for building survival.
"The 6 percent limit over seven years is too little to induce owners to do capital improvement work unless it is absolutely essential for the building," Mr. Engel said.
That was in fact the goal of tenant organizations that fought the program years ago. They believed that many owners were making improvements the building didn't need, merely to lift rents closer to market level -- the rent that would be obtainable in a unit if it were unregulated. Tenants forced to move out could be replaced at higher rents.
The Office of Rent Administration reports that there were only 1,168 applications for major-capital-improvement rent increases in the state's 1994 fiscal year -- which ended last March 31 -- and there are only 1,004 so far in the current year. In fiscal 1991, no great year for real-estate investment, there were 2,385 applications, and the decline has been steady ever since.
The decline in the use of the program is attributable to the reduction in the incentive, the fact that higher rents are now less affordable, and the completion of much work in the 80's, said Jack Freund, executive vice president of the Rent Stabilization Association, an owner organization.
"The 6 percent limit would not be so crucial if the applications could be processed in three to six months," he said. He urged adoption of a fast-track system with rent increases approved on the basis of certification by contractors that work had been completed, dispensing with the current system requiring prior state inspections. The housing division would then do spot post-auditing, raising the specter of rent decreases and penalties for law violators.
The state division itself tried to introduce a self-certification system in 1987 but it was stopped in court on the ground that tenants were inadequately informed of the plan and no hearings were held on it. The agency dropped the plan.
PAUL J. Korngold, a lawyer who represents owners in filing applications, noted that current procedures make it simple for a disaffected tenant to delay an application's approval. All it takes is the filing of an objection, after the tenant is notified by the state of the owner's application, and the reasons for it. For example, the tenant may rightly say that a new window doesn't operate properly. And indeed it may not. But under current procedures, the minor repair needed may hold up a buildingwide increase for new windows for many months.
In fact, any buildingwide rent-reduction order resulting from a services complaint can undermine an owner's application for an M.C.I. increase. "A dirty hallway can stop a $1 million rent increase for a buildingwide rewiring," said Edwin K. Zarkin, president of Realty Program Consultants.
Another problem from the owners' standpoint is that processors themselves lack the professional experience that their predecessors had in the old Conciliation and Appeals Board, the quasi-governmental agency that did this work in New York City before state takeover of stabilization in 1984. The C.A.B. had accountants on staff as processors.
In the Bryant Avenue Tenants Association case, Iris J. Korman appeared before the Court of Appeals for the Division of Housing and Community Renewal. Andrew Scherer of Legal Services for New York City represented tenants and Joseph L. Forstad of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan represented the Rent Stabilization Association.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
The Odds Favor More Gaming Locales in the State

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
SHORELINE STAR, a $40 million greyhound track and clubhouse with a seating capacity of 2,600 is under construction in Bridgeport on the banks of the Pequonnock River. It will replace the Bridgeport Jai-Alai Fronton that has been operating since 1976 on 22 acres off exit 28 of Interstate 95.
When it opens in November it will feature remote betting computers at each seat, restaurants, bars, parimutuel wagering, simulcasting of nationwide sporting events and parking for 1,050 cars. 
 Bridgeport Jai-Alai, a familiar fixture just off Exit 28 of I-95 since 1976, has been under financial pressure since 1988, when a three-year players' strike was followed by abbreviated six-month seasons, with Milford Jai-Alai operating for the remaining six months. The Bridgeport building will be demolished -- probably by April 1996, says its owner -- and Milford will stay open year round.
The dog track is the only new gaming project in Connecticut since the Foxwoods Resort Casino opened on the 1,200-acre Mashantucket Pequot reservation in Ledyard in 1992. Its phenomenal succes has galvanized the state's comparatively sleepy gaming industry into competitive action, encouraged by the amenable attitude toward gaming that prevails in Gov. John G. Rowland's administration.
A. Robert Zeff, owner of the jai-alai property, and Mirage Resorts of Las Vegas have proposed a $400 million casino and entertainment complex on 50 riverfront acres that Mr. Zeff has optioned off exit 29 of I-95, currently owned by the Carpenter Technology Company. A competing casino proposal is being promoted by Donald Trump for the five-acre former Jenkins Valve Company parcel that he owns near downtown Bridgeport.
Both developers presented their plans to the Joint Public Safety Committee of the General Assembly last month in anticipation of a bill to be presented before the end of the legislative session in May that is expected to authorize just one casino in Bridgeprt. If approved, it would also authorize the expansion of electronic gaming devices in the state's three jai-alai frontons, two dog-track complexes, nine off-track betting parlors and four simulcast theaters.
Senator Angelina Lee Scarpetti, a Trumbull Republican who is a member of the committee, said that the prospect for passage "looks good for the first time." A similar bill on a Bridgeport casino failed last year, when then Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. promised to veto it.
If the legislature approves the measure, it will cost the state about $130 million a year from the Pequot operation. The Pequots are currently paying that amount under an agreement with Governor Weicker that will be automatically terminated if gambling facilities are established elsewhere in the state.
GOVERNOR Weicker negotiated the compact to get around the casino's Federal exemption from all taxes as property on an Indian reservation. The Pequots agreed to pay the state 25 percent of their gaming revenues provided the state prohibited any form of nonreservation casino gaming, slot machines or table games.
Mr. Trump and Mirage have stated that they would compensate the state fully for the loss. But Senate Majority Leader James T. Fleming, a Simsbury Republican who is a staunch opponent of gaming casinos, is not satisfied.
"That only levels the playing field," he said. "Are they willing to make that up and give us additional revenue? The state will lose hundreds of millions of dollars from the Pequots, and we will have to create an expensive state gaming regulatory commission."
Indian casinos are regulated at Federal government expense.
Meanwhile, activity within the industry is increasing. The Mohegans have obtained approval to build a casino on their reservation in the Town of Montville, situated about 12 miles west of Foxwoods. And the state's jai-alai frontons and dog tracks, complaining that they are losing substantial business to Foxwoods, want legislative approval to install a smorgasbord of electronic gaming devices to be competitive.
"They were going downhill for years before we opened," said G. Michael Brown, president of Foxwoods. "We are just incurring the blame. We're our own worst enemy that way. We have spawned an East Coast gaming boom."
Confident that it can handle any competition, Foxwoods is expanding its 194,000-square-foot gaming floor to 243,000 square feet. A steak house is under construction bringing the number of on-site restaurants to 13, and 165 rooms are to be added to the 280-room Two Trees Inn, one of two on-site hotels that have been 94 to 96 percent occupied.
Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport, flushed with a $1.7 million surplus and the elimination of an $18 million deficit that had the city on the brink of bankruptcy three years ago, is squarely behind a casino operation, no matter which developer the state eventually chooses. His director of economic development, Michael Freimuth, said that a casino would have "a stimulative effect, with a direct impact on jobs and property taxes."
While the 16-square-mile city has been unable to attract new business to replace the decades-long drain of industries gone south, it has retained the largest population in the state at 141,000, down by only 2,000 since the mid-1980's.
In an effort to improve the appearance of its grittier districts the city is setting up a development bank called the Lower East Side Development Corporation. Each year a portion of the gaming revenues paid by the dog track would be earmarked for paying down the debt on bonds floated to fix up surrounding housing, streets and open space.
BUT Mr. Freimuth is concerned about the distribution of the much larger revenues that the state could collect from a casino. Money that the state gets from Foxwoods is distributed under a formula that gives all of the state's 169 municipalities property tax relief. "A casino is not a be-all and end-all," he said. "It must spill over into the neighborhood. We need housing and infrastructure improvements here that local property taxes will not cover."
Throughout Bridgeport the prospect of a casino is viewed as a long-sought route to a brighter future. "we've had a hard time finding any local opposition," said David Grimshaw, head of the Black Rock Community Council, a citizens' group. "We've all seen what an incredible boon the Ledyard casino has been to local business, and to let something like that go to another city is something that people here don't want to happen. The loss of our commercial tax base is one of Bridgeport's biggest problems."
But Senator Fleming noted that church groups and the residents of suburban Bridgeport had strong objections, citing negative social aspects of compulsive gambling and prostitution, and additional degredation of downtown hotels and businesses when casino patrons who are offered every amenity on the premises never leave them.
"Massachusetts, New York and Rhode Island are also considering casinos," he said. "We will be over-saturated and the casinos will not generate the revenues they anticipate."
"The Federal Government," he added, "has warned us that if Fairfield County fails to clean up its air it will not allow any more business expansion. A casino in Bridgport will generate up to 30,000 polluting vehicles a day on already clogged highways. Do we want to put all our eggs in that one basket?"
Mr. Brown and the Pequots are sanguine. "I'm sure a casino would help Bridgeport, and we would save $130 million a year," he said.
