HEADLINE: Legally or Not, 1-Family House Is Often Home To 2 Families

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN 

DATELINE: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.

 BODY:
GEORGIANA and John Grant have raised eight children in their sprawling ranch-style house here while accumulating enough memories, friends and nearby grandchildren to want to stay in their home forever. Thanks to the rental income from their second floor, now a two-bedroom apartment, they can.
"I hope they never move," Mrs. Grant said of Kathleen and Hubertus Franke, the young professional couple who live upstairs. "When they do, we would have to if we didn't have someone else to move in." Mrs. Grant, a trustee of the village, is seeking re-election. "We love Croton," she said, "and we're not moving. That's why we have the accessory apartment." 
 The $800 monthly rent pays almost all of the Grants' $9,970 annual tax bill, easing pressure on the couple's pensions -- his from Metro-North, where he worked as a conductor, hers from 15 years as a personnel manager at I.B.M.
The arrangement benefits both couples, in sometimes unexpected ways. In summer, Ms. Franke often returns from her epidemiology studies at New York Medical College to find succulent tomatoes and zucchini from the Grants' garden waiting at her door.
Last winter, Mr. Franke came home from his job as a research scientist at I.B.M.'s nearby Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights and spent part of a bitter cold evening on the Grants' roof, chopping away ice threatening the roof. In season, everybody uses the family pool.
The Frankes say they like the arrangement. "In an apartment complex, you're always walking by people you don't know," Mr. Franke said. "You never make connections."
The Grants are among thousands of metropolitan area homeowners who have created separate housing units from the excess space in their single-family homes. They are one of the few families to do so legally. In this Westchester County village, authorities estimate that there are about 150 illegal units; only four units, the Grants' among them, are legal.
The pattern is the same throughout the region, and perhaps the nation. In a classic display of supply-and-demand economics, the Grants and their tenants are visible examples of the burgeoning accessory apartment market, most of it illegal, which has developed as suburban property owners profit from the demand for affordable rental housing.
No national study has documented the extent of this essentially invisible housing, but every mail carrier knows where there are double mail boxes, every public works department knows where to pick up separate piles of trash in front of one house, and every neighbor knows where there may be too many cars. In Nassau and Suffolk Counties alone, the Long Island Regional Planning Board has found at least 100,000 illegal accessory units in areas zoned for single-family houses.
Affordable rental housing for young professional couples, single parents and even small families who want a suburban lifestyle has become increasingly scarce. In Westchester County alone during the 1980's, 34,015 rental apartment were converted to cooperatives and condominiums, while few rental units have been built.
The accessory apartments' landlords are often "empty nesters," homeowners burdened by taxes they can no longer afford, bouncing around in space they no longer need. Some of them are young couples who need help paying the mortgage.
"People think there still is a single-family suburban town out there, but it's a fiction," said Frank DeRubeis, Director of Planning in Smithtown, L. I. "The typical Ozzie and Harriet family is just a minor component of the suburban population. The majority are older people, single parents or unmarried young adults, and single-family housing does not meet their housing demands."
The issue is a volatile one for single-family homeowners convinced their suburban lifestyle is under attack. Many fear that legalization of accessory apartments is tantamount to creating two-family homes, lowering property values, creating parking problems and adding children whose parents pay no school taxes to already burdened school systems.
Those fears are unfounded, planners say. "There is no reliable or substantial evidence that accessory apartments do anything to run down a neighborhood," said Patrick H. Hare, president of a Washington planning and design firm that specializes in accessory apartments. These units, he said, are "a runaway success in the hundreds of communities which have legalized them, providing invisible, affordable housing with no subsidies."
In some of the communities that have legalized accessory housing, however, residents and officials say the results have been mixed. Officials in Somers, in Westchester County, are currently reviewing their 13-year-old legalization law following complaints from residents. Although intended to increase the town's supply of affordable housing, the law has allowed landlords to charge premium rental rates, residents say, helping neighbors enhance their own property values while the values of the houses near them decline.
"The law was not meant to be an economic boon to property owners," said William Harding, the Town Supervisor. But "how do you make more affordable housing opportunities and not change people's neighborhoods? You can't. A community has got to accept that change will occur."
The controversy surrounding accessory apartments has led many communities to ignore them rather than regulate their existence. But in Hastings-on-Hudson, and in Rivervale, N.J., in northern Bergen County, officials are considering legalizing accessory units despite vigorous objections from single-family homeowners.
"Do we really want to increase the density of the neighborhood?," asked Dr. Mitchell Berman, a physician who lives in Hastings-on-Hudson. "That's what is being debated. People who are committed to a single-family neighborhood don't want that changed. It's not fair."
Legalizing the apartments, Dr. Berman said, would cause their numbers to increase. Although the proposed law may have the support of elderly residents, Dr. Berman said, "when the senior moves away, the apartment will stay. Who's going to tear it out?"
William Lee Kinnally, the Mayor of Hastings-on-Hudson, said that the village is simply trying to control what already exists and that most elderly residents would not be able to afford the $10,000 to $20,000 needed to transform part of a house into an accessory apartment. "Accessory apartments are here now," Mayor Kinnally said. "We have to be able to regulate what we have already got."
The proposed Hastings law would allow 50 accessory apartments. Officials are considering a 90-day amnesty period for owners of illegal apartments to come forward without having to comply with off-street parking and apartment-size requirements -- from 300 to 1,000 square feet, with a maximum size of 25 percent of the house -- stipulated in the proposed law. If more than 50 people come forward, the law would be reconsidered. New enforcement procedures would allow anonymous complaints and set stiff financial penalties for violations.
Owners of illegal apartments usually have little motivation to come forward, said Carol M. Walsh, principal research analyst in the Suffolk County Planning Department. "Most towns have an extra garbage tax and reassess for improvements," Ms. Walsh said, adding that most local laws attach onerous burdens for compliance. "The big kicker is that lovely income that has to be reported to the I.R.S.," Ms. Walsh observed. "Most people would rather have the cash."
Rivervale is considering a law especially designed to help its elderly residents. Councilman William Saydeh, who opposes the legislation, said: "This ordinance doesn't fulfill any purpose except to downgrade the area. It abrogates our responsibility to protect the rights of those who have purchased single-family homes here."
Mr. Saydeh said he is concerned about the growth of unregulated accessory apartments, but added that legalizing them was not the answer. After checking with several nearby towns that have adopted accessory apartment ordinances -- including Old Tappan and Mahwah -- Mr. Saydeh said he has found that the legalization has not encouraged homeowners to apply for permission.
Should Rivervale pass its ordinance, Dick Thompson, a retired music teacher and composer in Rivervale, will be one of the first to apply. "I need this desperately if I'm going to be able to stay here when my wife retires," said Mr. Thompson, who already has a separate unit in his house that he created for his parents. "All my doctors, my friends and my music groups are here. Why should I have to give up my home?"
Accessory apartment ordinances are becoming more common. In the last decade, 13 Westchester communities have adopted local laws allowing some form of accessory housing. Similar statutes are on the books in Westport, Weston and Greenwich, Conn., and in the Long Island communities of Babylon, Brookhaven, Babylon and Hempstead, among others.
In each of these communities, illegal accessory apartments continue to far outnumber legal ones. Most local officials say they are uneasy about enforcing local laws and evicting friends and neighbors. "Enforcement is always a problem in a small town -- you make a lot of enemies," said Mrs. Grant.
Mr. DeRubeis, the Smithtown Director of Planning, agreed. "You don't get kudos for kicking people out of their homes," he said. There are 1,800 or more illegal accessory apartments in Smithtown, which has not legalized them, he said; they represent 5 percent to 8 percent of the town's housing stock.
"Legalizing them doesn't solve the problem," Mr. DeRubeis said. "You still have lots of illegal apartments which can't meet the codes. They are a very large percentage."
Ms. Walsh, the Suffolk analyst, said: "It's a catch-22. If municipalities are going to enforce the law, they'd better think where these people are going to live. Accessory apartments are the closest we have to affordable housing on Long Island."
Local officials do enforce the law whenever they receive a complaint, Mr. DeRubeis said, adding that the process can be very expensive. One recent dispute took 11 months in court, and while Smithtown finally prevailed, the suit cost taxpayers $10,000 in legal fees, he said.
The American Planning Association reports that studies show that the presence of an ordinance legalizing accessory-apartments does not encourage single-family homeowners to create an accessory unit, and that the absence of such a law does not discourage them.
As municipalities wrestle with the issue, the growing number of illegal accessory apartments in single-family homes is also producing headaches for real estate appraisers, agents and banks.
Homeowners who want to sell a property with an illegal accessory apartment often remove the second stove before the appraiser arrives. "When you see a hole in a countertop, you must be suspicious," said Eugene Albert, chairman of Albert & Sterling, a real estate appraisal company in Tarrytown, N.Y.
While the owner usually describes the area as a "guest area" or "place for the kids," Mr. Albert said, if the appraiser sees a stove in what is typically a basement apartment, "we would discount the value of the lower level; The unit would have to be seen as a two-family house."
Real estate agents face similar problems. Frustrated brokers have to be warned repeatedly not to advertise illegal apartments using such terms as "mother-daughter unit," or "in-law apartment," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. A five-bedroom single-family home with an illegal two-bedroom apartment, Mr. Mercurio said, "can only be advertised as a single family home with five bedrooms."
Two years ago, Peter J. Russo, president of the Residential Mortgage Banking Company in Hauppauge, L. I., grew tired of what he called "the machinations" required to accommodate mortgage requests from young applicants relying on illegal rental income. "We knew they would use the rental income, but we had to require a parent to co-sign," Mr. Russo said. "It all seemed so silly."
Mr. Russo launched an effort to persuade towns on Long Island to simplify their procedures for allowing accessory apartments. Most refused. "They are resisting urbanization of the suburbs," Mr. Russo said, "but it already exists. Anyone who wants an accessory apartment has one; no one turns anyone in, and it's almost a joke."
The Grants have a legal accessory apartment because they live in a village that has tried to help the nearly one quarter of the population over 55 stay in their homes.
In 1982, Croton-on-Hudson passed a law permitting accessory housing provided either the tenant or the owner is aged 55. The owner must live in the home, the apartment is limited to a certain size, off-street parking is required for each car, only one front entrance is allowed and permits are limited to 2 years.
Although Croton-on-Hudson's law has not attracted many applicants, the trend is gaining strength elsewhere, supported by the American Association of Retired Persons, which is drafting a model ordinance to distribute to communities.
"Older people overwhelmingly want to stay where they have always lived -- in the suburbs," said George Gaberlavage, senior analyst in the organization's Public Policy Institute. But "they need income." Half of all older adult homes have three or more bedrooms, he said, "surplus space which can provide low-cost housing and revitalize neighborhoods." The key, he said, is designing legislation that meets community concerns.
The Croton law is not properly enforced, said Arcadia Kocybala, who tried unsuccessfully to sell her Croton home after a neighbor got permission for an accessory apartment and then moved out after renting additional space in the home to a tenant who ran a psychic reading business.
"Zoning is a contract which the homebuyer enters into with the municipality," Ms. Kocybala said. "Accessory apartments create de-facto two-family zoning. which lowers your property value. Single-family zoning should entitle you to peaceful enjoyment of your property."
The growing older adult population in the suburbs is putting increasing pressure on communities to allow accessory apartments. Passage of such a law has proved particularly successful in Greenwich, which now has 175 legal accessory apartments.
The law, similar to Croton's, limits units to 800 square feet, making them too small for families, said Diane W. Fox, assistant town planner, but the apartments are attractive rentals for young professional couples who cannot afford to buy in Greenwich.
Municipal officials and area planners agree that the accessory apartment market, legal or not, is likely to grow as family size continues to shrink, home ownership costs increase and the demand for affordable, rental housing grows amid the continuing loss of free-standing rental units to co-ops and condominiums.
Single-family homeowners are just as likely to continue their opposition. "Our homeowners resent two-family homes," said Mr. Harding, the Somers Town Supervisor. "They want Ozzie and Harriet back."

HEADLINE: Big Change In Teaching Of Foreign Languages

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL 

 BODY:
NEW technologies and curriculums are transforming the teaching of foreign languages in the state's high schools, supplanting techniques that have produced generations of foreign-tongue-tied Americans.
Minitel, a French version of America Online, and the Internet are being used to keep students tuned in and turned on to language study, and the emphasis has shifted from textbooks and grammar to conversation. The changes, experts say, help explain the increase in enrollment in foreign language courses in recent years. 
 But there is also considerable confusion as some teachers resist the new pedagogy while others struggle to keep pace with it, and students find that, for all their newfound fluency, their progress is not always rewarded on standardized tests like the S.A.T. II.
"The materials are there," said Ada Ortuzar-Young, immediate past president of the Foreign Language Educators of New Jersey. "The problem is the teachers don't know how to use them yet."
Dr. Ortuzar-Young, chairman of the Spanish department at Drew University and director of its Latin American studies program, said there are many multimedia programs to choose from that individualize instruction and make it possible to learn a second language faster and more thoroughly.
In one CD-ROM, for example, while information is presented on screen, a small window on the computer screen shows the closeup of the speaker's face. "If you see the movement of the lips and the tension of the muscles in the mouth and face, you can get a better feeling of how that sound is produced," she said.
But few New Jersey high schools are making full use of the computers they possess, Dr. Ortuzar-Young said, and the Foreign Language Educators are trying to organize workshops at Drew to train more public school teachers in how to integrate the new material into the classroom.
Rosanne Zeppieri, a teacher of French and Spanish at the High Technology High School, a magnet school for math, science and technology in Monmouth County, is surrounded by computers in her classroom, but she still relies on textbooks for basic instruction. She uses technology to supplement those studies.
A laser disk, for example, allows her French students to view duplicates of paintings found at the Louvre on their computer monitors, listen to explanations of them in French or English and reproduce the images for use in written reports. In another program, words in a text can be highlighted, and a translation, grammatical information and other words of the same family appear on screen.
"It's like having a teacher right there with you," she said, "and it's all individualized so students can do it at their own pace."
Ms. Zeppieri's students use Minitel and the Internet to communicate with French students around the world. The topics are as diverse as the interests of the students themselves. In one recent class, her students debated students from the Netherlands on the wisdom of legalizing drugs, all in French.
Meanwhile, a number of new curriculums have been introduced. Two popular ones are "French in Action" and "Destinos" for Spanish students, both on videos. Students view sagas replete with attractive young characters, romance and intrigue and then discuss the show. A typical episode of "Destinos" concludes with the heroine's veering her car sharply into a ditch to avoid an oncoming truck.
Grammar is secondary to listening and understanding the story. "It's as close to immersion as you can get," said Judy Wenner, chairman of the foreign language department at the Blair Academy in Blairs town, which has just switched over to the curriculums. "The idea is to get students interested, and then a lot of the technical language will be acquired just from hearing it."
But some teachers are finding it hard to leave books and workbooks behind. "I still see young teachers coming out of school being taught in a very traditional way and having difficulty with their own proficiency, especially speaking," Mrs. Wenner said.
Curriculums like "French in Action" and "Destinos" have their roots in a movement begun in the 1970's but only recently gaining widespread popularity, called the "communicative" approach. Here, the emphasis is not on grammar and translation but on the ability to communicate effectively, which proponents argue will be achieved by immersion in the language -- much as a child learns a first language.
Facial expressions and gestures are as important as the spoken word. For example, "French in Action" students are urged in the foreword to the material to note the "typical" French handshake practiced by two of the story's characters: "One takes the hand of the other, shakes it up and down strongly once, and then on the up-movement the two hands are released. (This shake is shorter and much more vigorous than an equivalent American handshake)."
Mary Coleman, coordinator of special projects for the Yale University Press, which publishes "French in Action," said students learning French through the program will eventually master grammar. But Erwin Petri, supervisor of the foreign language department at Millburn High School, warned that students who intend to take advanced placement exams are better off with more traditional methods.
"For example, in the passe compose, there are agreements on the end of the participles that are never heard when you speak," he said, "and on the Advanced Placement exam you have to know all the minute rules of things."
Nevertheless, Mr. Petri is an enthusiastic supporter of "French in Action" and "Destinos" for other students, including those with learning disabilities who may have difficulty with written words.
In keeping with the communicative approach to language acquisition, Millburn has replaced its one-and-a-half-hour written examinations with a 15-minute oral exam for all foreign language students except those taking Advanced Placement exams or Latin. There is also a small written component done in class, like writing a short letter or postcard to a friend.
Other school districts have investigated Millburn's testing plan, and the biggest stumbling block for those who decide against it, Mr. Petri said, is the logistical problem of scheduling the exams.
Educators say students seem more interested in learning one or more foreign languages with the new curriculums, and the number of public school students signing up for foreign language courses has been growing. The New Jersey Department of Education says that the number of foreign language teachers in the state's public schools rose more than 15 percent between the 1989-90 and 1993-94 school years.
Charles Zecher, head of the foreign language department at New Providence High School and coordinator of a survey last year of selected foreign language programs in the state, said there was also an increasing demand for foreign language instruction at the elementary level.
One of the most innovative language programs in the state can be found at the Peddie School in Hights town. For the last two years, students have been learning foreign languages through the study of subjects like economics, psychology and ecology. This "communicative" approach, called "Content Area Teaching," is based on the theory that students will be more motivated to learn if the subject matter is meaningful and has a clear focus.
While content area teaching is becoming increasingly common at the collegiate level and can be found in some elementary schools, it is still a rarity in secondary schools. The course offerings at Peddie are determined by the interests and expertise of the teachers, and students are graded on mastery of both the language and the subject being taught.
Originally, Peddie gave students about 220 hours of introductory language instruction before they began the study of specific subjects, but now it begins almost immediately.
There is a heavy emphasis on alternative forms of assessment, like exhibitions and presentations. Last year three third-year Spanish students traveled to the World Bank in Washington to defend a paper they had written on the Latin American economy. They presented their views to a panel of economists for an hour and then were grilled with questions, all in Spanish.
"It was nerve-racking," said Andrew Usmiani, one of the students. "They had no facial expressions, and the questions were very hard."
Nevertheless, Andrew found the experience rewarding. "At this point my friends from other schools might be able to name more grocery items in the supermarket, but I can talk about more relevant ideas in life," he said.
Donald Duffy, chairman of second language learning at Peddie, said he had decided upon content area teaching after experimenting unsuccessfully with several other teaching methods. "Conversation would break down immediately because there was no reason for them to communicate," he said.
One difficulty with content area teaching in general is finding teachers who feel competent enough to teach both the foreign language and a separate subject. Mr. Duffy, who holds a degree in economics and taught the economics course, said a workshop he presented at the Newark Academy in Livingston to introduce the concept of content area teaching to representatives of New Jersey's independent schools was greeted with mixed reactions.
"A lot of the teachers were impressed, but they seemed a little scared and said they wouldn't dare try to do it themselves," he said.
Another drawback is the lack of materials. Teachers often have to devise their own curriculums and import books from other countries. Some students complain they can be at a disadvantage compared with those in traditional classes when it comes to tests like the S.A.T. II and its heavy emphasis on grammar.
In an editorial in the Peddie newspaper, Tara Shingle wrote that the study of grammar had been "blatantly missing" and that a better balance between conversation and grammar had to be struck.
Despite all the change occuring in the classroom, a number of educators think that the state and Federal governments should be doing more. Mr. Petri of Millburn points to a North Carolina mandate that foreign language instruction begin in kindergarten and, in Fairfax County, Virginia, to a partial immersion program in French, Spanish, German and Japanese at the elementary school level.
Rene Lavergneau, coordinator of foreign languages for the Hackensack School System, wistfully recalls the 1960's, when the National Defense Education Act provided scholarships for language majors to improve their skills abroad.
Nevertheless, there is a sense that the country is moving out of its isolationism as far as foreign languages are concerned.
As to whether the communicative approach is just another fad and will soon go the way of new math, or grammar-based language instruction for that matter, Deborah Short, an associate division director at the Washington-based Center for Applied Linguistics, said: "This is not just a flash in the pan, like new math. There, researchers said to do this, and teachers implemented it. But here it's very much come from the teachers, and it's growing. Despite America's best efforts, I think we're going to value bilingualism, and this is a great way to achieve it."

HEADLINE: The Education of Robert Rubin

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ROBERT E. RUBIN first heard about Mexico's currency crisis when he was on Christmas vacation in the British Virgin Islands, just weeks before his move from the National Economic Council in the White House to the office of Secretary of the Treasury. His initial instinct, he tells visitors with the self-deprecating half-smile that has become his trademark in Washington, was to let the Mexicans and the market sort it out, and to return to the important business of casting for bonefish in the azure waters of the Caribbean.
"My first reaction was that financial distress in Mexico was a very serious problem," he said the other day. "But other countries have had financial problems and the appropriate adjustments get made." The phone kept ringing, though, with a series of increasingly dire warnings from the undersecretary of the treasury, Lawrence H. Summers, and the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, about what could happen next if a currency crisis turned into something far worse. 
 The more the 56-year-old former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company thought about it, the more he became convinced that in Mexico the Administration was faced with the most modern of foreign policy crises: No troops, no nukes, just the potential for global financial apocalypse if Mexico's imminent default on billions of dollars in bonds prompted a pullout from scores of emerging markets for which Mexico was a beacon.
Even the enemy was different: Beyond a recalcitrant new Congress, Mr. Rubin was wrestling several million investors -- participants in pension and mutual funds that have rushed into international markets -- who finally put forth a set of non-negotiable demands and were threatening to suck every peso back home from Mexico and leave it in economic rubble.
"This isn't the old days where there are three rich market manipulators in a back room threatening to pull the pin," Mr. Rubin said. "Now, it's everyone."
Ultimately, it was those threats that forced Mr. Rubin and the White House Chief of Staff, Leon Panetta -- who were sharing a pizza at 11:30 Monday night when they were joined by President Clinton -- to decide that Congress was not about to act on $40 billion in loan guarantees and that markets were not about to forgive.
A few slices later, the three men opted for Plan B: An extraordinary order to use $20 billion in Treasury funds under the President's control to keep Mexico from defaulting on its short-term bonds and to restore investor confidence. However, $20 billion was not enough, so Mr. Summers was dispatched to squeeze another $17.8 billion out of the International Monetary Fund. The tactic so angered many European allies that when they were asked to formally approve the loan on Wednesday six abstained, opening a rare rift within the organization.
Irritating the allies, whose finance ministers he met yesterday in Toronto for the first time as Treasury Secretary, was the least of Mr. Rubin's problems over the last four weeks. Aiding Mexico was a political loser for Mr. Clinton. It was left to Mr. Rubin to tell the President that the markets would no longer wait for Democrats and Republicans to make up their minds, and that the political risk of failing to act could be enormous.
In boom times -- that is, until December -- Mexico was the kind of country that President Clinton regularly hailed as an engine of growth for the new American economy. Exports are the source of millions of new, high-wage jobs, the Administration has told anyone who will listen, and demand from the Big Emerging Markets -- from Brazil to China to Indonesia -- are where America's export-led economic future lies.
It was a positive message, brimming with hope. In the last few weeks, however, before he even had a chance to move into Lloyd Bentsen's old office on the third floor of the Treasury, Mr. Rubin suddenly found himself explaining to Congress about the two-edged realities of a financial world that at times may be a bit too global for its own good.
The first part of the explanation was straightforward: Geography still counts in foreign affairs, and political and social chaos in Mexico would mean trouble on the border: A half million more illegal immigrants, a threat to 700,000 American jobs dependent on exports to Mexico. More difficult was what the soft-spoken Mr. Rubin, choosing his words carefully so as not to trigger the panic he was trying to avoid, called the potential "catalytic impact" of a collapse in the Mexican market.
"THERE is an unique role that Mexico has played in the past five or six years as a prototype of a developing country coming into the modern world," said Mr. Rubin, who unlike his dressed-to-the-nines predecessor often cruises the hallways of the the Treasury in shirtsleeves, the knot of his tie dangling a few inches below his neck. "It is the linchpin, the model. And I don't think any other country plays such a pivotal role."
A massive outflow of investor confidence in Mexico City, he argued, could trigger the same in other economies highly dependent on foreign investment for growth. And that would threaten the reforms, the democratization and the growth to which the United States has linked its own future.
Not all of Mr. Rubin's friends on Wall Street fully subscribe to what he calls this "theory of interconnectedness" -- "if that's a word," he adds. One close ally in the investment banking world, who declined to be named, wondered why Mr. Rubin had gone so far. "This notion that if we don't do this, a global meltdown occurs -- I've never seen a Treasury Secretary take that position. And if it's really true, then we shouldn't have been trying to do this alone. Where were the Germans, where were the Japanese?"
But Mr. Rubin may have been partially vindicated last Monday, when "interconnectedness" surfaced with a vengeance. As investors realized that the initial rescue plan pending in Congress was dead as an armadillo on the Mexican highway, sell orders spread to economies that shared none of Mexico's immediate problems. Poland, of all places, dropped. And when Mr. Clinton took matters into his own hands on Tuesday, markets around the world recovered. By the end of the week Mr. Rubin was being hailed as the market-savvy hero of a White House otherwise incapable of shooting straight. Even the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, defended the president's action as "courageous," and told carping Republicans to shut up and give thanks they did not have to vote on an aid plan that 80 percent of Americans oppose.
In his first month as Treasury Secretary, Mr. Rubin has worked 20-hour days, grappling with difficult questions: Can the United States afford to be seen as the saviour of any major country whose leaders borrow too much and fail to discipline their own booming economies? Where does the offer stop? In Mexico? In the former Soviet Republics?
"Clearly, there's a line we cannot cross," Mr. Rubin said the other day. "Just don't ask me where it is."
If the ghosts of past Presidents truly haunt the White House, one old Democrat must have been lurking over that Domino's pizza the other night: Grover Cleveland. Even Newt Gingrich has been telling Congressional colleagues the cautionary tale of what happened to poor Grover 102 years ago.
At the time, America was the ultimate emerging market. Mr. Cleveland had barely begun his second term before a panic set in around the world that the United States was about to devalue the dollar. With the Treasury's reserves of gold shrinking, President Cleveland wanted Congress to repeal the law requiring the United States to back its bonds with gold, breaking the artificial linkage between the value of an ounce of gold and the value of the silver coin in which most private transactions were settled.
THE result was Mexico-scale chaos. The silver mines of the West closed. Riots broke out, unemployment soon soared to 20 percent and the newly jobless marched on Washington. Credit collapsed, industry slowed, imports screeched to a halt and once-enthusiastic European investors pulled out of the country. Mr. Cleveland, like the leaders of Mexico over the past month, argued that the country's fundamentals were sound. But it made no difference. Democrats in his own party rebelled, Republicans who controlled Congress after 1894 refused to cooperate. He had to turn to Wall Street -- to J.P. Morgan and August Belmont -- for the credit he needed to keep the country afloat.
A future president, Woodrow Wilson, writing the history of that era, argued that a great revolution had come, but that no one understood it. "All the world," he wrote, "had in fact become at last a single commercial community."
A century later, working from somewhat different and certainly more complex facts, Robert Rubin is making the same case. The combination of his 26-year career at the investment banking house of Goldman Sachs and his low-key style -- he has skillfully turned humility into a powerful weapon -- has given him extraordinary credibility as a mentor on the workings of the new economy. "The problem is that it is a complicated transformation, and very difficult to explain in the public domain," Mr. Rubin said recently. "I've been in on this from the beginning, and I'm still coming to grips with the implications."
THE transformation: Developing nations no longer have to depend on bank lending for their capital -- in part because their needs are now far greater than public or private banks could supply. David D. Hale, the chief economist of Kemper Securities, notes that private capital flows to stock and bond markets in Latin America, Asia and Africa were running at $10 billion a year in 1989, and $60 to $80 billion in the last few years -- with Latin America by far the largest recipient of foreign funds. The capitalization of the stock markets in these emerging economies -- the value of all the listed shares -- was $100 billion a decade ago; it is $2.1 trillion now.
No place was as much a beneficiary of investor enthusiasm as Mexico. Building on -- and overselling -- the country's deregulatory reforms, its democratization and the benefits of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexico sold tens of billions of dollars in stock and debt securities to the United States throughout the 1990's. It was gobbled up by emerging market funds and pension funds that had rarely invested abroad before, and were desperate for alternatives to the paltry 3 percent returns available at home. But along the way, Mexico developed an addiction to the capital, financing its long-term debt with the sale of short-term bonds, called tesobonos. They were essentially Government-issued junk bonds, yielding anywhere from 15 to 50 percent.
The Clinton Administration and others quietly warned the country's leaders last year that they were headed for trouble. Mexican officials said they understood the problem, but they did nothing. There was an election on, the leading candidate had just been assassinated, the Chiapas region was still in revolt -- and it was certainly no time to admit economic weakness by devaluing the currency. The outgoing president, Carlos Salinas, was already angling -- with American support -- to become the first head of the new World Trade Organization in Geneva, and he wanted nothing to soil his record of economic reform.
How much of Mexico's financial bungling was known to Mr. Rubin as head of the National Economic Council -- the group Mr. Clinton created to coordinate economic policy among competing agencies, much as the National Security Council does in foreign policy -- is a matter of considerable debate in Washington these days. Republicans, led by Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, threatened an investigation.
For his part, Mr. Rubin told reporters recently that the warning signals, while evident, did not suggest the size of the problem on the horizon. "No one I'm aware of saw what was really coming," he said.
Watching how Mr. Rubin handled a hostile Congress over the past month quickly became one of Washington's chief spectator sports, largely because he was constantly being compared to Mr. Bentsen, the master of the art form. The 74-year-old Texan, many believed, would never have permitted the $40 billion loan guarantee program to languish in Congress, where opposition grew daily. Still, it's unclear that Mr. Bentsen's presence would have made a difference.
Until a few weeks ago there was a sense in Washington that Mr. Rubin excelled at being Mr. Inside, and that the glare of scrutiny -- and the sparring with Congress that will intensify when the Administration's budget is submitted this week -- would make him regret seeking the Treasury job.
"He doesn't naturally seek the spotlight, and you get the sense that he dislikes a lot of the public role," said one senior official who has worked with him closely. "At the White House, it never failed: Whenever he was about to leave on a major trip with the President, he would always come by and say 'Do I really have to go?' " Sometimes he didn't, skipping the Asian economic summit in Indonesia in 1994..
Mr. Rubin points out that he was not as reclusive as his Washington reputation suggests. "When I was running the N.E.C., I was on television probably once a week. Maybe it was just shows no one watches." But since the start of the Mexico crisis, he has also become a daily fixture on Capitol Hill, testifying, talking in private to the party caucuses, never showing anger when member after member of the House Banking Committee denounced the $40 billion bailout as a reward to Mr. Rubin's rich friends on Wall Street, who made bad bets on Mexico.
MR. Rubin, who is believed to be worth about $100 million himself, was ready with his response. "I don't give one whit for the investors, and if that's what this was about, we wouldn't be here talking about it" he shot back at one point.
But it was impossible to save Mexico, he said time and again, without also helping those who had sunk their money there. Mr. Rubin could also be enormously patient, as evidenced at one hearing when it became clear that a member of the House Banking Committee, attacking the plan to rescue Mexico, did not understand the difference between a loan guarantee -- essentially co-signing a loan -- and actually lending money to Mexico. Back in his office, he smiled and asked some visitors "Isn't democracy a wonderful thing?"
"This is the part of the job that's going to give him ulcers," one Treasury official said.
But even after the Administration's effort had collapsed, Mr. Rubin was still winning praise. "The problems were not with Rubin, but in the White House and with the Democratic party up here, where there was no discipline on this," said Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the House Banking Committee and spent two weeks drafting compromise legislation for the ill-fated $40 billion loan-guarantee program. "I think Bob Rubin brought to a very political town a fine sense of the outside world, with a manner that is competent and quiet, without being arrogant. And almost overnight, he has become the pre-eminent cabinet member."
Whether Mr. Rubin continues to impress may depend on whether the Mexico decisions made this week come back to haunt the White House. If the Mexicans fail to reform their now discredited techniques for handling their economy, if the peso's devaluation hurts American imports and workers, or if illegal aliens surge into Texas and California, the president's team, having acted alone, will be blamed alone.
But Mr. Rubin says inaction would be a withdrawal of American participation in emerging markets, backtracking from the world's move toward more open economies and toward reform. "Fixing this now is cheap," he said early in the crisis. "Fixing it later may be very expensive."

HEADLINE: One Employee Buyout That Actually Worked

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: KAPUSKASING, Ontario

 BODY:
DAVE SIMARD, a 35-year-old worker at the sprawling paper mill here, is feeling flush these days. He has just plowed $6,000 into a new roof on his trim, white-frame, three-bedroom house with forest-green shutters.
"Things are looking up, for sure," says Mr. Simard, a 15-year veteran of the mill. "Otherwise, I certainly wouldn't have undertaken all of this." 
 Mr. Simard is one of 1,200 workers who received up to 5,000 free shares each under an employee buyout four years ago of the mill, which produces giant rolls of newsprint used by the newspaper industry. Those shares are now worth nearly $5 each, and some financial analysts think the price could easily double over the next year or two.
In 1991, few homes were being fixed up in this one-industry town 500 miles north of Toronto.
Back then, recalls Mayor Rene Piche, "For Sale" signs were a fixture in front of many houses. "The town faced a bleak future, if any at all," he says.
Mr. Piche, who himself bought 50,000 shares at $1 each, as part of the community efforts to support the buyout, adds jubilantly: "We never dreamed it would turn out this way."
So far, the company, Spruce Falls Inc., is the story of a successful worker buyout. And with newsprint prices rising -- from $411 a ton to $550 a ton since November 1993, and expected to increase another $125 a ton by summer -- Spruce Falls should continue to prosper.
INDUSTRY analysts see a bright future for Spruce Falls during the next couple of years. Norm Levine, a broker for Merit Investment Corporation in Toronto, expects the company's earnings growth to justify a share price "at least twice present levels in the next 12 to 24 months."
The Spruce Falls case is a "pretty unusual turnaround," says Corey Rosen, director of the National Center for Employee Ownership in Oakland, Calif., who has monitored worker buyouts of troubled companies in the United States and Canada.
For the last two decades, the experience of employee ownership of companies has been decidedly mixed. Sometimes, the companies have benefitted as the new worker-owners try more cooperative management practices, work teams and a sharing of financial information. But a different ownership structure can do little to insulate companies from competition, technological change or shifting markets.
Still, Canada can point to some thriving worker buyouts besides Spruce Falls. Also in Ontario, there has been the rebirth of the big Algoma steel enterprise in the shadow of the International Bridge linking Sault Ste. Marie with northern Michigan, whose worker-owners have seen their shares soar with a surge in automotive steel buying. But Morley Gunderson, director of the Center for Industrial Relations at the University of Toronto, cautions that the acid test will be the next recession -- which, for Spruce Falls, means the next cyclical downturn in newsprint prices.
Mayor Piche's office looks across a bend in the Kapuskasing River, named for the Cree word for "branch of a river," toward the giant smokestacks of the paper mill that employs one out of every 10 of its 10,000 inhabitants.
The worker buyout was a response to the 1990 decision by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation of Dallas, which owned 51 percent of the plant, to get out of newsprint. The maker of Kleenex tissues and Huggies disposable diapers wanted to concentrate on its consumer products.
The New York Times Company, which had a 49-percent stake in the plant, went along with Kimberly-Clark, deciding that the mill's remote location, old technology and high-cost labor practices made it attractive only to new ownership. The capital costs that would have been required to make the mill viable would have run into the hundreds of millions of dollars.
In the mid-1920's, New York Times had joined Kimberly-Clark as minority partner in the enterprise, christened Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, to guarantee a steady supply of newsprint.
FOR decades, at least half of the Spruce Falls daily output went to The New York Times. The New York Times is still a customer of the newly reorganized mill, along with such other newspapers as The Boston Globe, The Buffalo Evening News and The Indianapolis Star and The Detroit Free Press. Power for the mill came from a generating station the two companies built at a falls 50 miles north, harnessing hydroelectricity from the Mattagami River.
For 65 years, the newsprint operation brought steady employment here. But after the owners decided to sell in 1990, no buyer could be found. For about a year, the town feared the mill would either shut or drop as many as 1,000 workers.
"I think we would have become the most modern ghost town in northern Ontario," said Wayne Green, the publisher and general manager of the local weekly newspaper, The Northern Times. "You can't take one industry out of a one-industry town and survive."
An employee purchase group was organized, assisted by another employee-owned company, Tembec, Inc., which makes specialty paper and wood products in Temiscaming, Quebec, about 200 miles to the east.
Under a complex arrangement, the Spruce Falls mill was sold for $1 to the Tembec-led employee group, and the two American owners sold the Mattagami River power station, which had increased tremendously in value over the years, to Ontario Hydro, a provincially-owned utility, for $140 million. The gain from selling the power station more than offset the charges the companies took for walking away from the mill and surrounding timberlands, most of which were leased. In addition, the utility agreed to give the mill's new owners 10 years of free power and some $34 million.
"It's turned out to be a win-win situation for investors, workers, community, sellers and the Ontario government," said F. A. Dottori, president of both Tembec and Spruce Falls.
AS part of the deal, Kimberly-Clark and New York Times made a $60-million loan on preferential terms -- money the new management, under Mr. Dottori, put into mill modernization. Tembec itself put up $25 million, half in equity, to give it 40 percent of the 32 million outstanding shares, and half in loans. Its shares today are worth more than $50 million.
For their part, the workers gave up 20 percent in pension, health and vacation benefits. They also accepted a three-year wage freeze in return for a 52 percent stake in the company and a special profit-sharing program. For 1994, the profit-sharing, at 6 percent of earnings before interest, depreciation and taxes, will work out to between $400and $500 per person, according to Maurice R. Hicks, vice president of corporate development.
"We're at the beginning of a few good years in the newsprint business," said Mr. Hicks, who owns 60,000 shares of Spruce Falls.
Employment at the plant today is 1,050, or only 150 below the level in 1990. Norm Leybourne, president of Communications, Energy and Paper Workers Union Local 256, a director of the company and holder himself of 18,400 shares, says he is amazed by the turn of events over the last four years. "It's like night and day," Mr. Leybourne said.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Women Seeking a Working Agenda

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble 

 BODY:
IT takes a certain je ne sais quoi to plan a political agenda these days without once muttering the imprecation "middle class tax cut." Yet seldom were heard those monotonous code words late last month when some three dozen representatives of business, government and scholarship gathered for a weekend meeting of the Women's Voices for the Economy Commission.
The task of the privately sponsored commission: to develop what its members are calling a new "women's economic agenda" and use it as an organizing tool, in the process lowering some of the partisan barriers among women's groups. To cut costs, the group met not in Washington, but just outside, in Arlington, Va., an edge-city Oz that resembles late 20th century suburban America, where most voters live, more than does the company town across the river. 
 As most of the meeting's participants would be the first to point out, the term "women's economic agenda" is a slight misnomer. To be sure, though women in professional and managerial jobs are gradually catching up with men, generally women -- and other historically disadvantaged groups -- are still disparately affected by low and inequitable wages and a lack of access to capital.
Consider these factoids from the weekend:
A single mother in a minimum-wage job -- 62 percent of all minimum-wage workers are women -- must pay from half to three-quarters of her salary for licensed day care.
And women are starting new businesses in record numbers, but more than half of them use high-interest credit to get going.
Moreover, the experience of women in the work force has adapted them to merge nicely with the trend toward what is euphemistically called the "mobile worker" -- temporary, contingent and part-time, without benefits and security. "Unfortunately, women are the leading edge of the degradation of the work force," said Heidi Hartmann, an economist who moderated one of the meeting's panels.
Yet, to call women a special interest group, as some would do, is to miss the point that when pollsters ask that all-important question -- Just what is it you people want? -- women express as much concern about the economy as men do. But, unlike men, they tend to nail their concerns to concrete time and money issues like the decline in family income and their difficulties in juggling family and work responsibilities. Like almost all Americans, women are worried about public schools and rising crime, but they often link these quality-of-life issues to a poor economy because financial pressure means they can no longer be at home if they choose to be, tending to their communities.
The women's commission proposes support for the following, from the draft of the agenda available before the meeting:
* Capital to start and expand businesses.
* Job training, continuing education and skill development.
* Equitable pay and benefits for contingent workers.
* Flexible schedules.
* Adequate care for children and the elderly.
"This agenda is central to the lives of the middle class: how to educate kids; how to keep them safe," said Linda Tarr-Whelan, head of the Center for Policy Alternatives, the Washington-based group that sponsored the meeting and established the commission. "When you talk to people, that's what they talk about."
The agenda would encourage, among other things, public-private partnerships in developing child-care centers; support training programs for women who want to work in nontraditional jobs; use government as a broker between contractors and service providers and offer incentives for business to invest in their communities. These are reality-based objectives: in each category, meeting participants could point to successful programs in place in one of their communities.
The agenda is also sensitive to the current realpolitik that no matter how worthy a program, no one who plans to stay in the conversation for long dare speak of appropriating public money for it. The commission's plans emphasize partnerships, incentives, individual contributions and the creative leveraging of available resources.
There is some confidence that this initiative will not simply languish in typical commission fashion. First, the agenda is building on networks already in place nationally. The group included a core of Northeast Corridor stars, like Betty Friedan, who in the latest installment of a long life of activism is conducting an influential salon on economics at the Smithsonian Institution, and Ms. Hartmann, the head of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, who momentarily replaced Barbra Streisand as an object of liberal fascination last year when she won a MacArthur award. And there was representation from the business community, including Barbara Blum of the Adams National Bank in Washington, and Raydean Acevedo, who heads her own consulting firm in McLean, Va.
But most of the women at the commission meeting represented state and local groups from across the country. And the Center for Policy Alternatives invited people beyond the "usual suspects" list from nonprofit and grassroots groups.
Nevertheless, there was a little testiness when two participants expressed exasperation with a drift the discussion took briefly toward some concerns that might have been categorized as traditionally liberal. The group is determined to remain bipartisan. In a world lacking in appetite for either Republicans or Democrats, that is surely the path to influence.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Betty Friedan was among the Northeast Corridor stars at the Women's Voices for the Economy meeting. (Kenneth Lambert for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Software Fix May Revitalize the Supercomputer

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
FOR seven years, Burton Smith has been leading a lonely crusade to reinvent the supercomputer. Now, Mr. Smith's moment of truth is nearly at hand -- a moment that promises not only to help determine the future of the Lamborghinis and Ferraris of the computer world but also to affect the Government's role in developing new technology.
To many people in the computer industry, Mr. Smith and his tiny Seattle-based Tera Computer Company have been on a quixotic mission. Custom-made supercomputers have been flirting with a dinosaur's fate. By definition the fastest machines around, increasingly they have not been efficient enough to earn their keep in the face of ever-speedier, far less expensive off-the-shelf computers. At the same time, basic research has suffered as budgets at the country's weapons laboratories have shrunk with the end of the cold war. 
 Indeed, a steady stream of the nation's brightest engineers and computer scientists have broken their swords defending the supercomputer's turf. Companies like Supercomputer Systems, Thinking Machines and Kendall Square Research have all fallen by the wayside trying to give new life to the high-performance end of the business. Supercomputer sales, about $765 million worldwide last year, are expected to shrink to $542 million in 1998, according to Smaby Group Inc., a Minneapolis-based research and consulting company.
But now, the 54-year-old Mr. Smith says he is ready to build his masterpiece. If he is right, by this summer he will have a working prototype of a machine to match the speed of the powerful Cray Research supercomputer, but at one quarter the price. More important, he will have found the Holy Grail that has eluded the best computer designers for more than two decades: building a supercomputer that can be programmed easily, opening up its uses to more types of customers even as it becomes more affordable.
"The industry has been short-sighted," Mr. Smith said. "The market for a general purpose supercomputer will be growing more quickly than anyone believes."
There is just one problem: Tera Computer, which has spent $20 million so far on the project, mostly from Government financing, still lacks the $5 million to $10 million to build the prototype. And that places Mr. Smith and his company in the middle of the resurgent debate over what stake the Government should have in incubating high-tech companies.
Looking for ways to offset proposed tax cuts, Republicans in Congress are preparing for an assault on the National Institute of Standards and Technology's Advanced Technology Program and possibly the Pentagon's Advanced Research and Projects Agency. Both agencies have underwritten research in the private sector; the latter has provided most of Tera's financing over the years.
Just last week, the National Academy of Sciences issued a report calling for the elimination of direct Federal financing of commercial hardware development by computer vendors. Critics of such projects say it amounts to "pork barrel" spending.
But defenders of programs that support small and innovative projects like Tera's argue that for a relatively tiny investment the Government can generate a vast economic payoff that translates into new jobs and technologies that will keep the country ahead of foreign competitors. They point to successful computer companies like Sun Microsystems, Silicon Graphics and Cisco Systems, which all spawned new industries thanks to small Government grants.
Mr. Smith's supporters argue that just such an investment in Tera could revitalize the supercomputer business. (Mr. Smith says he is trying to get financing in the private sector, but others in the industry say that will be difficult since venture capitalists have been scared off by the declining fortunes of supercomputers.)
THE first generation of supercomputers, known as vector processors, and the current generation, so-called massively parallel processing machines, bring lightning speed and brute force to solving big-picture problems -- like predicting the weather -- that require billions of repetitive calculations. But it is harder to program them for general tasks, including most standard business computer problems, that call for many different kinds of calculations.
That is not the case with off-the-shelf machines. Though the cheaper machines are not as fast as supercomputers, they are not that much slower, either. And given the huge price gap, they have increasingly become the machines of choice. The smaller machines, called minisupercomputers, cost between $500,000 and $5 million. Supercomputers, by contrast, run $10 million to $30 million each.
Recognizing the programming problem, Mr. Smith has made software the priority, with the goal of adding enough versatility and efficiency to outstrip the cost advantage of the smaller machines.
Tera has come along just when many in the industry have begun to believe that innovation in computer hardware design is a thing of the past, or will be carried on only by consumer electronics companies for videodisks and gadgets designed to go under the Christmas tree.
"We have Burton Smith to thank for the fact that there is still a debate over the future of high-speed computing," said Kenneth Kennedy, a Rice University computer scientist who is a leading expert on parallel software and a member of Tera's board.
Still, skeptics believe that the era of the lone supercomputer designer -- men like Seymour Cray (first at Cray Research, then Cray Computer), Steve Chen (Supercomputer Systems) and Danny Hillis (Thinking Machines) -- is ending. While there will always be a market for hand-built cars like Ferraris and Lamborghinis, the skeptics say, small supercomputer companies can no longer keep up with the pace of consumer-oriented computer makers, which invest billions of dollars in each design generation.
"BURTON is building big iron and these dinosaurs are stone cold dead," said David Patterson, a computer scientist at the University of California at Berkeley. "Today, if your custom project slows down, the rest of the world doesn't wait for you."
Mr. Patterson was referring to Moore's Law, named for Gordon Moore, a co-founder of the Intel Corporation, who first determined that the number of transistors that can be squeezed onto a computer chip doubles every 18 months, effectively doubling the speed.
But Moore's Law also poses a tremendous problem for computer designers -- one which Mr. Smith believes he's solved. The problem is that memory chips have not been keeping up with processor speed.
As a result -- much like an engine that can't get fuel quickly enough -- the fastest processors are increasingly starved for data, forced to wait on the slower memory chips and unable to get to the next task. The problem, known as memory latency, is exacerbated in massively parallel processing supercomputers, which string together large numbers of chips to do computations in parallel formation.
MR. SMITH's solution is the Multi-Threaded Architecture, or M.T.A., supercomputer. When it is completed, it will use a relatively small number of fast processors -- between 16 and 256. Each processor is able to juggle more than one task by making new requests for data while waiting for an earlier one to be answered.
"What Burton has done is finally proven that the latency problem can be solved," said David Probst, a computer scientist at Concordia University in Montreal. "I suspect that there are a lot of customers waiting impatiently to buy one of his machines."
One of those potential customers is Sid Karin, director of the San Diego Supercomputer Center, one of five national computing laboratories financed by the Government.
"We've been talking to them very seriously and we are hoping to be their first customer," Mr. Karin said. "One of the things that is impressive is Tera's emphasis on software. There are lots of examples of companies littering the shoulders of the information highway who paid attention to hardware and not software."
At the same time, there is no way to prove Mr. Smith's ideas until a prototype is available, said Jack Dongarra, a computer scientist at the Oakridge National Laboratory and one of the nation's leading experts on supercomputing. Companies like Kendall Square also made bold claims about programmability, but failed to live up to their promises of greater speed. "It sounds like a big win, but the verdict is still out," said Mr. Dongarra.
Mr. Smith is no stranger to the risks inherent in the high end of the computer business. A graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Smith taught computer science at the University at Colorado in Denver before working at Denelcor, a Colorado maker of supercomputers in the late 1970's and early 80's. The Denelcor HEP computer -- which had some of the design ideas now found in the Tera machine -- failed in the marketplace competing against machines from Cray Research.
After leaving Denelcor, Mr. Smith spent several years at the Supercomputing Research Center, a Government laboratory in Lanham, Md., with close ties to the secretive National Security Agency.
Now he is trying again from his small laboratory in Seattle. Compared with the high-profile efforts of Mr. Cray and Mr. Chen, who have each been backed by hundreds of millions of dollars, Mr. Smith's Tera, with its complement of 54 employees, is truly computer-design-on-a-shoestring.
Despite that, by concentrating on software rather than hardware, Mr. Smith may succeed where others have failed. And if he does, he will upset the applecart of the cheaper-is-faster crowd who believe that the industry will increasingly be dominated by personal computer and consumer electronics companies.
"You wouldn't think that a startup in the supercomputer game would be given much chance today," said Gary Smaby, a computer industry consultant at the Smaby Group. But, he added, Tera's scaled-down approach, which Mr. Smith thinks will guarantee financial success with even only a few customers, "might just permit them to make it through the turmoil."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Burton Smith, Tera Computer's founder, says general purpose supercomputers still have a role to play. (Dan Lamont for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Markets;
A Headlong Crawl Toward Capitalism

BYLINE: By Paul Lewis 

 BODY:
"I HOPE we can avoid a Mexico-type collapse," Hungary's reformist-minded former Finance Minister, Laszlo Bekesi, said last week after being dismissed in a battle over plans to accelerate the privatization of state-owned companies and complete the country's transition to a market economy by 1998.
His warning, as well as his fall from grace, are the latest signs that five years after the countries of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union began their march toward capitalism, several of the most important are stumbling just as their economic prospects start to improve. 
 After suffering several years of sharp contraction, Poland clocked the highest economic growth rate in all of Europe last year at 4.5 percent, while Hungary and the Czech Republic finally made it into positive figures. Although Russia saw its economy shrink by another 12 percent in 1994, industrial output stopped falling last summer and consumption is rising.
Yet the undoubted triumph of Russia's transition bid so far -- the privatization of some 14,000 state enterprises -- is being challenged by hardliners at the same time the bill for the Chechnya war imperils the Government's economic stabilization drive.
Meanwhile, Hungary and Poland are wavering on privatization, and while the Czech Republic has sold off 90 percent of its economy, this may not be enough to make efficient the companies that were sold.
"The more favorable economic outlook for 1995 creates the illusion that they have done all they need to do," said Lado Gurgenidze of the Institute for East-West Studies in New York. Andrezej Rapaczynski who directs a study project on central European privatization at Columbia University, noted, except for the Czech Republic, privatization is stymied."
In Moscow, President Boris N. Yeltsin has replaced Vladimir Polevanov as privatization minister after he had called for the " renationalisation" of strategic industries falling under foreign control.
But signs of a nationalistic backlash within the Russian Government against foreign investors are still clearly visible.
Last month, the conservative daily newspaper Rabochaya Tribuna published documents, reportedly leaked by the security services, warning that Western investors want to "guarantee the technological backwardness of Russia." And the Central Bank has since announced tighter licensing requirements for foreign investments.
Meanwhile, Russia is trying to convince a skeptical International Monetary Fund that it deserves a $13 billion loan to help stabilize the ruble, despite recurring inflation and an incalculable budget deficit swollen by the cost of an unpopular civil war.
Like Russia, the Czech Republic is privatizing its economy by doling out vouchers to its citizens that entitle them to bid for shares. After two major selling rounds, some 90 percent of the economy is reckoned to be in private hands.
Most citizens entrusted their shares to mutual funds run by banks. But these conservative banks are more likely to run companies they buy with an eye to avoiding "costly bankruptcies and politically damaging increases in unemployment rather than achieving efficient outcomes,"John C. Coffee of Columbia University argued in a recent study of Czech privatization.
Although Hungary appeared the most market-oriented Eastern European country under Communism, the World Bank reckons no more than 40 percent of its state enterprises have been privatized so far, and the process has slowed markedly since the former Communists came back to power in last year's elections.
Before Mr. Bekesi was forced out as Finance Minister, the country's respected privatization chief, Ferenc Bartha, had been dismissed along with the Central Bank governor. The Government has also rattled foreign investors further by recently canceling the high profile sale of the HungarHotels chain to American General Hospitality for $57.5 million.
In Poland, where the ex-Communists are also back in power, the Government plans to sell 480 big enterprises to privatization funds that will distribute shares to the public, but appears in no hurry to do so. And although retail trade is now mainly private, the state retains ownership of most stores, which are only leased to entrepreneurs.
Not surprisingly, these countries' fledgling stock markets have reacted adversely to such public second thoughts about the virtues of capitalism after an initial euphoria when fortunes were easy to make.
The Russian market index, compiled by Credit Suisse First Boston, which opened at 100 on Dec. 1 1993, had climbed to 1,706 by Sept. 15, 1994, but was down to 654 last week.
According to Salomon Brothers, the Polish index rose from 1,000 in late 1992 to 12,439 a year later but stood at 6,153 last week. In Hungary the market index had risen from 826 at the end of 1993 to 1,430 a year later but is now back at 1,159, while the Czech index peaked at 1,224 last March before declining to 485 last week.
Caveat emptor.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: No Cheers for Greenspan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alan Greenspan does not deserve the accolades Floyd Norris heaped on him for having created the speculative bubble the Fed is now trying to deflate without causing an economic crash landing ("Man of the Year: High-Wire Artist Alan Greenspan," Market Watch, Jan. 1). 
 Mr. Norris implies that the steep yield curve Mr. Greenspan engineered in the early 1990's saved the American banking system. Banks, however, can make money regardless of the slope of the yield curve. The decline in long-term rates, for which the Fed does not deserve much credit, helped to revive the economy and restore value to troubled loans burdening some, but not all, banks.
When the Fed signaled early last year that it was time for short-term rates to rise, it did not understand how many time bombs, like the one in Orange County, Calif., the steep yield curve had planted in private- and public-sector balance sheets.
Contrary to Mr. Norris's suggestion, it was not asking too much that the Fed move sooner than it did. In fact, its inaction in 1993 was a major blunder. Summaries of Federal Open Market Committee meetings for the second half of 1993 clearly indicate that the Fed board had failed to appreciate the extent to which low short-term rates and the steep yield curve were beginning to overstimulate the economy.
Worse, Mr. Greenspan's Fed ignored strong signals from the money markets in the fall of 1993 that short-term rates should begin rising. The yield in the secondary markets on the three-month Treasury bill rose almost 25 basis points from late September to late November.
More dramatically, rates on one-month borrowings jumped more than 30 basis points in the first week of December. The Fed immediately signaled its displeasure by driving the easily manipulated Federal funds rate noticeably below its then target rate of 3 percent until short-term rates began drifting back down.
The costly Greenspan bubble reflects the Federal Reserve chairman's misreading of the economic forces at work in the early 1990's. The time has come to encourage the financial markets to set interest rates, without any Fed guidance.
BERT ELY Alexandria, Va., Jan. 5
The writer is principal of Ely & Company, consultants on public policy issues affecting financial institutions.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Gay Dollars on the Road

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
FRED KOHN remembers a time not so long ago when he could not say "gay" at Eastern Airlines to describe the tours he discreetly booked for groups of homosexual travelers.
"We would push those packages through the airlines quietly," said Mr. Kohn, a former sales representative. "We would call the annual trip of gay lawyers going to Puerto Rico the 'San Juan' group, and only those who needed to know, knew." 
 Up to the mid-1980's, gay and lesbian travelers had recourse only to a small network of gay travel agents, or gay airline employees like Mr. Kohn, who would unofficially help them find welcoming hotels and vacation spots. Airlines, booking agents and cruise ships didn't want to court such customers openly, for fear of being ostracized by advertisers and mainstream travelers.
But increasingly, the big companies are seeing dollar signs instead of stigma. And gay travel agencies like Islanders Kennedy, owned by Mr. Kohn and Shelley Shusteroff, are being forced to find ways to compete.
Surveys by gay publications and the U.S. Census Bureau show that gay people have a collective $514 billion in yearly expendable income and take vacations more than any other single demographic group, mainstream travel executives are aggressively going after their travel dollars. (As have some companies that get bookings from big travel agencies. Recently Avis Inc. changed its "domestic partnership" rule to allow same-sex couples to rent cars without paying an additional driver's fee.)
"It's a great marketing niche," said Rick Cirillo, who works in a newly created position at American Airlines: national sales manager for the gay and lesbian community. "We've already booked $15 million worth of potential revenue for '95-'96."
The Cunard Line is also appealing to gay travelers. And these days anyone can go into a Liberty Travel agency and ask for a gay package -- like an RSVP Travel Productions Gay Vacation (cruises) or Atlantis at Club Med (a gays-only week at a club resort) or Olivia (women-only cruises).
The competition, say some industry insiders, ends up benefiting the gay customers enormously. "Gay and lesbian individuals have many more choices in a rapidly expanding industry," said David Alport, vice president of the International Gay Travel Association.
But it's also driving the city's handful of gay travel businesses, like Islanders Kennedy, to try out different strategies.
"We're going to revive the gay travel club concept," Mr. Kohn said. "We're going to have newsletters, theater parties, Fourth of July cruises, and then we're going to out-advertise everyone else." The agency advertises in three gay publications -- POZ, 10 Percent, and Out.
 IN a way, Mr. Kohn's business partnership with Ms. Shusteroff was a response to the competition.
In 1984, after 20 years with Eastern, Mr. Kohn borrowed money to buy out Kennedy Travel, in Floral Park, Queens. "I immediately turned it into a gay travel business," he said. With just word-of-mouth advertising, business boomed. (He declines to discuss revenues; the office still operates as a branch of Islanders Kennedy with a clientele that is about 40 percent gay.)
At about the same time, Ms. Shusteroff was running Islanders Travel, a bus service to Fire Island. As her Greenwich Village business became more popular, Ms. Shusteroff offered trips around the country, cruises and theater parties. Her mailing list of gay men in New York City became one of the most comprehensive in the industry. In November, Mr. Kohn and Ms. Shusteroff, business acquaintances for years, opened Islanders Kennedy Travel, at 183 West 10th Street on the corner of Seventh Avenue South -- the heart of Greenwich Village.
Ms. Shusteroff found what she calls this "perfect location" last summer. "I saw that 'Ladies Boutique,' this store run by a drag queen, was having an inventory sale," she recalled. A sign, she says, read Everything Must Go, and "I grabbed the space."
"It made complete economic sense," said Mr. Kohn. "We now have more buying power and less advertising cost."
A rainbow flag, a symbol of gay pride, hangs over the wood-paneled storefront to announce that the business is gay friendly, although Mr. Kohn says that about 5 percent of his customers are not gay.
What Islanders Kennedy offers, Ms. Shusteroff says, is something that still eludes mainstream agencies: an anxiety-free atmosphere. Many gay customers, she says, "aren't comfortable walking into the local small-town travel agency." Plenty of her own customers still seek privacy, she says, pointing to a list of clients from across the country who want the agency's brochures sent to post office boxes.
Longtime customers like Robert Legere, a Manhattan bridal designer who has tried the big companies, praise Islanders Kennedy's approach. With gay agencies, "you don't get any attitude," he said. And, he added, "I know I'll get a vacation where I'll be in my element; if I hold hands with my lover on the beach, it will be a place that people won't stare."
Ultimately, that kind of confidence may help the gay travel boutiques regain their marketing edge. "There's a big difference between data and knowledge," said David Love, a spokesman for American Society of Travel Agents, a trade group with 25,000 members in 130 countries. "Many mainstreams may have the packages, but they don't know the products firsthand."
Islanders Kennedy remains ahead of mainstream companies in booking tours for RSVP, a Minneapolis-based gay travel company that works with 8,000 major agencies nationwide.
RSVP's Sheridan Square billboard, showing male couples vacationing at the beach, has become a Village landmark. Ms. Shusteroff says she wants the company to paint an arrow on the billboard pointing around the corner "right towards us."
"Shelley only calls me every three days about it," said Charlie Rounds, RSVP's sales director. "We may just give them that arrow."

GRAPHIC: Photo: RSVP's gay-gateway ad on Sheridan Square. Gay travel shops like Islanders Kennedy, nearby, book many of the tours. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)
