HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
Nursing Home Loses a Round On Extension

BYLINE: By JENNIFER KINGSON BLOOM 

 BODY:
For two years now, neighbors of the Amsterdam Nursing Home on 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue have been fighting a losing battle to stop the home from building a 13-story extension.
Residents say the construction would destroy the neighborhood's historic feel, deprive them of open space and spoil the view from the Cathedral of St. John the Divine across the street. 
 The neighbors have lost repeatedly in the courts, been turned away by the City Council and brushed aside by Government agencies.
Now they say they have won a round.
In December, after prodding by the Morningside Heights Residents' Association, the state Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation ruled that the addition would have an "adverse effect" on the area. This means that the Federal Advisory Council on Historic Preservation will review the project's impact, with local input.
"So far, we've thrown one punch," said Robert E. Roistacher, the residents' association's president.
Mr. Roistacher has waged much of this battle singlehandedly, filing suits in state court and sending reams of documents to agencies. Others in the neighborhood, chiefly those living farther from the site, support the expansion as a boon to elderly residents.
The expansion would add 106 beds to the 303-bed home and an additional 68,000 square feet -- almost doubling the size of the building.
The nursing home's operators minimize the impact of the "adverse effect" ruling and predict that construction will begin this summer, even though two other approvals are pending: one from the Federal Housing and Urban Development agency that must insure the $32 million project, and one from the New York State Dormitory Authority, which would issue the bonds to finance it.
James Davis, the nursing home's executive director, says he has tried to placate opponents by revising plans: The 120-year-old Croton Aqueduct Gatehouse, for instance, is now to be saved and renovated into an adult day center. But plans still involve destroying a 150-year-old garden on Amsterdam Avenue.
Mr. Davis says that Amsterdam Nursing may not survive if the project is thwarted, because the home depleted its reserve fund in spending $2 million to develop plans, including $300,000 for legal fees.
Mr. Roistacher's group has appealed to Community Board 9, which passed a committee resolution asking for a role in the Federal review. On Feb. 16, the board will vote on the resolution. J.K.B.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
Progress and Setbacks for a Downtown in Search of a Vision

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
As the focus of a sweeping vision of economic revival, Downtown Brooklyn has never quite reached the goals set for it in the 1980's when planners and developers saw a hotel, two office towers, a $1 billion high-technology office and academic complex and a 24-acre office, retail and housing center in its future.
To be sure, progress has been made. Metrotech, the 10-block office and academic center -- a downtown unto itself -- is nearing completion and full occupancy. The Pierrepont Plaza and Livingston Plaza office towers are built and fully occupied, and construction has begun on the first phases of Atlantic Center, the retail and housing complex. 
 Atlantic Center's developer, Bruce Ratner, said on Friday that he and Caldor's have reached a deal for a branch of the discount department store to become the anchor tenant. Caldor's is to replace Bradlees, which withdrew in November.
But a series of setbacks has cast attention on the strength of the comeback, the most serious blow coming with the announcement last month of the loss of 900 A.& S. headquarters jobs. Atlantic Center has been significantly scaled back by the city's decision to shelve the renovation of the decrepit Long Island Rail Road Terminal.
Adding to the anxiety among some is Mayor Giuliani's proposal for tax breaks to help the ailing Financial District across the Brooklyn Bridge.
"We have run into a bit of a slowdown in the 90's," said Robert B. Catell, president of Brooklyn Union Gas Company, which moved to Metrotech from nearby.
Still, not all is gloomy. In a few months, Metrotech will get its next major tenant, the nerve center for the city's new, enhanced 911 emergency system. Other tenants include Bear Stearns, the Internal Revenue Service and Nynex. Construction has started on Atlantic Center's 378 attached homes, for families earning up to $53,000 a year, and 800,000 square feet of retail space. And concern over Fulton Mall's future has eased with the announcement that the A.& S. store will stay as anchor tenant, refurbished as a Macy's.
The City Planning Commission chairman, Joseph Rose, says Brooklyn will be helped by the Giuliani administration's tax breaks for the Financial District in Manhattan because smaller companies and back-office operations of larger firms will be attracted to Brooklyn's cheaper space.
The 1980's boom on Wall Street spawned Brooklyn's current revival, Mr. Rose said, a renaissance that has added 25,000 jobs, and several million square feet of new, leased office space. Real-estate experts are pleased since this was accomplished during the recession.
Where does Downtown Brooklyn go from here? The biggest question mark continues to be the Renaissance Plaza hotel and office complex, a major component of the original picture that has never been filled in. It has suffered years of delay, mostly because of the failure of the developer, Joshua Muss, to win financing. Under growing pressure from city officials, Mr. Muss again says he is near a deal.
The expansion of local, state and Federal courts are in various stages of planning.
The development that has reshaped the Downtown Brooklyn skyline has raised other problems: how to connect the area's fragmented components and cope with its increasingly clogged streets. Can the benefits of the revival extend to nearby neighborhoods, creating more jobs for residents?
The Regional Plan Association, whose 1983 report served as the blueprint for the current development, is assessing the change and helping to map the area's future.
"You've got the makings of an extraordinary downtown," said Jeffrey L. Raven, who is managing the study, "but right now it's a place in search of a cohesive vision."
Some hopeful strategies are emerging. New signs will point the way to local places of interest and banners are being installed to enhance Downtown's identity. After offices and stores close for the day, much of the district is deserted so another goal is to promote night life and increase street safety.
Officials are also considering a shuttle bus to cut down on cars and move workers and shoppers more efficiently. "If you have a transit loop for commuters to stay and shop and play here," said City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, "you would see a thousand flowers bloom." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BAYCHESTER/CO-OP CITY;
After Years of Rising Vacancies, Malls at Co-op City Bounce Back

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Last spring, Giulio Divito looked around the Dreiser Loop mall in Co-op City and saw five vacant stores. Undeterred, Mr. Divito, who owns a pizzeria and deli inside the mall, decided to get into a third business in the mall, a chicken rotisserie outlet. After spending $310,000 to renovate a store once occupied by a kosher deli, he recently opened N.Y. BBQ.
Mr. Divito did not foresee that Co-op City would rebound rapidly from years of rising vacancies and that its three shopping malls would be fully occupied. "When that happened," he said, "I felt, boy, I was a smart guy. But I was just a lucky guy." 
 Lucky or smart, Mr. Divito is benefiting from what many consider the rebirth of Co-op City, the largest cooperative housing complex in the United States. Two years ago, roughly 10 percent of Co-op City's 15,372 apartments were vacant. Today, only 560 apartments are vacant, said Alan Brenner, the general manager of Riverbay Corporation, which owns and runs the complex.
Not surprisingly, the rising number of residents and consumers has drawn businesses back to Co-op City's three shopping malls, on Dreiser Loop, Bartow Avenue and Einstein Loop. As of Feb. 1, all commercial space at the three malls was rented or scheduled to be occupied, Mr. Brenner said.
Residential vacancies have fallen mainly because Riverbay dropped the price per room in each apartment to $1,750 from $2,832. But rents on commercial space did not change.
"The whole economy here is doing better," Mr. Brenner said, explaining that Co-op City's malls are thriving despite the continuing growth of Bay Plaza, a giant shopping mall adjacent to Co-op City.
Built in the late 1960's and early 1970's, Co-op City is a middle-income housing project with its own stores, supermarkets, banks and schools. Most original residents were Jewish, Italian and Irish. Over the years, many retired to warmer climates or died, replaced by a growing Hispanic and black population. More recently, many Russian Jewish families have settled here. The shifting population is reflected in the diversity of restaurants in the malls.
Iris Baez, president of the resident board of directors, said that the stores that opened most recently -- including a florist, a discount store, a nutritionist, an H & R Block tax service -- have also diversified the malls' businesses.
In Dreiser Mall, for example, two of the first tenants were an office of H.I.P., the health-maintenance organization, and a rehabilitation center.
"I thought we were becoming an extension of a hospital," Ms. Baez said. "Now, it's a lot livelier here. You don't have to be sick to come here." N.O.

HEADLINE: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:

HARLEM
Changing the Image Even Among the Locals
"So many New Yorkers have the same feelings that out-of-towners have about Harlem -- they're afraid to go," said Lynn Brooks, executive director of the Big Apple Greeter. "They think it's a terrifying den of iniquity." The nonprofit agency, which uses more than 600 volunteers to show visitors New York and its neighborhoods, is working to change this image. 
 The problem is that many of the volunteers have never been to Harlem either.
On Saturday the volunteers and anyone else who would like to join in are invited to spend an afternoon exploring the area; one highlight will be a tour of the Apollo Theater.
Afterward, Sam Mattingly-Wilford of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation will speak about Harlem's economics the importance of tourism and Phil Dante, a photographer, will show slides at the Window's Cafe in the State Office Building on 163 West 125th Street.
Meet at the Apollo, 253 West 125th Street, between Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and Frederick Douglass Boulevards; Saturday, Feb. 11, 2 P.M.; free. Reservations must be made in advance; (212) 669-2364.
 
PROSPECT HEIGHTS
The English Father Of the Hudson River School
A traveling exhibition of 60 Thomas Cole paintings, organized by the National Museum of American Art in Washington, D. C., is making its final stop at The Brooklyn Museum.
The artist, who was born in 1801 in Lancashire, England, lived on Greenwich Street in the Village and spent weekends in Catskill, N.Y. Much of his subject matter was drawn from the Hudson Highlands and the Adirondack mountains. "He is considered the father of the Hudson River School," said Linda S. Ferber, chief curator at The Brooklyn Museum.
The Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue; museum hours: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesday through Sunday; $4, $2 students, free for children under 12; (718) 638-5000.
 
LITTLE ITALY
State of Siege: A Sarajevo Exhibit
Five architects from Sarajevo spent a year taking photographs of the buildings in their war-torn community. The results are on display at the Storefront of Art and Architecture, a not-for-profit group that promotes innovative architectural ideas about social, political and environmental problems
The exhibit is meant to be "a constructive response to the state of emergency in Sarajevo," said Shirin Neshat, the co-director of the Storefront. "It is through these photos that ideas and strategies for rebuilding can be generated."
There will also be a symposium on Saturday, with panel discussions and film footage of the siege of Sarajevo.
Storefront of Art and Architecture, 97 Kenmare Street, at Lafayette, free; symposium, Saturday, Feb. 11, 11:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Dia Center for the Arts, 155 Mercer Street at the corner of Prince Street; $15, $10 for students; (212) 431-5795.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
How the Federal Reserve Drops Hints

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
IN voting Wednesday to raise interest rates for the seventh time in a year, the Federal Reserve couched the justification in its usual language -- fear of rising wages and rising inflation. But there was another dynamic also in play that in a way preordained the rate increase days before it happened.
 A dialogue developed in January between the Fed's policymakers and the bond market, the latter being a collection of people who trade or manage or own trillions of dollars in Government bonds and other securities. These securities depend for their value on interest rates. So naturally, the bond market has strong views about which way rates should be moving -- lately up, thank you. 
 But January was unusual. The bond market people were unsure, for once, what they wanted rates to do. For more than a year, they had been beating the drums for higher rates to slow the economy and hold down inflation, which chips away at the value of their bonds. Then in January, tentative signs of a slowing economy finally appeared. And suddenly the bond people wondered whether they should switch horses and bet for a while on lower or unchanged rates. They favored a slowdown, but they did not want to be blamed for a recession.
 So a strange, indirect dialogue got started. Many of the members of the Fed's policymaking committee -- 19 people who can change rates at their periodic meetings -- made speeches or gave interviews in which they dropped loud, encoded hints that a rate increase was coming. And the bond people answered in the language that they speak, betting their bonds not on the likelihood of falling or unchanged rates but on the near certainty of another increase.
 "We had been running in circles," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston, a bond house. "They were trying to figure out what the bond market was thinking and the bond market was trying to figure out what the Fed was thinking."

 
 
Different Goals
 In this ritualistic dialogue, which everyone pretends is not happening, the reason for the Fed's existence is sometimes overlooked. Aside from fighting inflation, the Fed's mission, specified by Congress, is to keep the economy growing and Americans employed. That goal can get lost in any dialogue with the bond market, which puts slowing the economy to fight inflation ahead of putting the unemployed to work.
 "The market is congratulating the Fed for its anti-inflation stance," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company on Friday, referring to trading late last week in which bond values rose. "Today, the unemployment rate shot up to 5.7 percent -- from 5.4 percent in December -- and that added further credibility to the view that the economy is moderating."
 Whether by design or by accident, the Fed went to great pains to advertise the coming increase in the various rates that it either controls. These in turn influenceother rates, among them interest charged on mortgages and car loans. One policymaker after another made the same basic point: The robust economic expansion is producing labor shortages, evident in the low unemployment rate. That inevitably means higher wages as employers bid for scarce workers. And since wages figure prominently in the cost of most products, rising wages inevitably force companies to cover the cost by raising prices.
"The current unemployment rate is comparable to the average of the late 1980's, when wages and prices accelerated appreciably," Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, told a Congressional committee.
 Never mind that neither rising wages nor rising prices have shown up yet in Government data. They will, Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues suggested in their public declarations. They did rise in 1988 and 1989, when the unemployment rate was similarly low. And the economy has not changed that much.
 Even Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman, and Janet L. Yellen, a governor, offered this view in mid-January. "Whatever the danger was two months ago, it looks bigger now," Mr. Blinder said about inflation. That statement, in an interview, really got the point across to the bond market. Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen, being President Clinton's only appointees at the Federal Reserve, were the two people most likely to speak out against a rate increase, and they did not.

 
 
Clues in the Dialogue
 So the Fed raised rates on Wednesday -- specifically to 6 percent from 5.5 percent for loans that banks make to one another and that the Fed makes directly to banks -- and the bond market gave its blessing. That raises a question: Should the dialogue be restricted to the Fed and the bond market, because they have the power? (Most of last year, for example, the bond market kept pushing up rates more than the Fed, which it considered too timid.)
 Or should this dialogue include others? Any number of executives have tried to sway the two principals by declaring that the economy has changed. They can't make price increases stick as they could in the late 1980's, they say. So they cut costs, often through layoffs, and when the Fed or the bond market, or both, slow the economy, that only adds to the cost cutting and layoffs.
 Neither the Fed nor the bond market seem to take notice of this clamoring. Already their dialogue has moved into the next phase: what to do next about rates. "Despite tentative signs of some moderation in growth, economic activity has continued to advance at a substantial pace," the Fed said in a statement on Wednesday.
 That sounds like the beginnings of another rate increase, which pleases the bond market. "The markets always have the final say," Mr. Roach said. "And this time the Fed has done a good job in reaching a sound conclusion with us."

HEADLINE: Word for Word / Advice for Republicans;
Attention! All Sales Reps For the Contract With America!

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE civics books would tell you that the election is over and Congress and the White House are now about the business of governing. But the apparatus of the campaign has not withered away. Witness the memorandum that came into the hands of a Democratic strategist (who insisted on anonymity) and was made available to The New York Times last week.
 The "research executive summary" was written by Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster who worked on his party's Contract With America and was now advising Congressional Republicans on the coming struggle over the budget. Mr. Luntz, on the basis of polling and focus groups, talks about how to talk about the issue. Poll-driven strategy memos like this are not unusual these days in the increasingly campaign-like struggles over major legislation. But they rarely come into public view. 
 Here are excerpts, with original typographical emphases. ROBIN TONER
 
To: The Republican Conference
From: Frank Luntz
Re: Communication Strategy for the Upcoming Budget Battle
Date: Jan. 9, 1995
 
INTRODUCTION
 "The most important reason to eliminate the Federal deficit and balance the budget? For the future of American generations, for the children."
 -- budget survey respondent
 "The Government in incredibly inefficient. It's like a bad charity that gives more to administration than to the people it's supposed to benefit."
 -- focus group participant
 "You give me a sign that you can spend money responsibly, and I'll give you every penny of my taxes without even flinching."
 -- focus group participant
 Debt. Welfare. Bureaucracy. Taxes. Spending. In your hands over the next six months is nothing less than the chance to transform America's perceptions of the G.O.P. and Congress and, more importantly, to rebuild the nation's expectations for the 21st century. Carpe Diem.
 Since the election, we've conducted two national surveys and two focus groups to discuss budget and spending issues with real Americans. If a single conclusion can be drawn, it is this: if we communicate our VISION AND POLICIES effectively, we will survive and prosper as a party and as a political movement. But if we forget the future and surrender our language to the Democrats (as we did in 1982 and 1986), our reign will be short indeed.
 . . .
 Your challenge is to create "The New America," the post-welfare state vision as powerful to Americans as the New Deal was 60 years ago. This is a lofty goal, of course. And it will take tremendous precision and repetition to achieve. But only then -- when you've described an irresistible future to the American public -- will the nation support you and your agenda unconditionally.
 . . .
 
THE PERCEPTUAL ENVIRONMENT
 Before moving into recommendations, it is important for you to understand the perceptual environment you face:
 . . .
 By an overwhelming 20-point margin, voters believe Republicans are more likely to balance the budget than the Democrats -- but you need to understand the whole picture.
 You are already seen as "conservative" and "anti-government" -- two important strengths in the budget arena. The Democrats are tagged as "big government liberals," a fatal weakness. But a number of Americans (even those who voted G.O.P. for the first time this year) believe Republicans are "mean" and "uncaring." As one woman not-so-delicately put it, "The Republicans don't give a damn about the average person." She was not alone. A male colleague added, "The Republicans might care about our money, but they definitely don't care about us." Thus, to an important segment of the population, you are more likely to achieve the right objective (a balanced budget) but for the wrong reasons.
 . . .
 Remember that many Americans perceive the key challenges ahead in moral terms rather than economic terms -- a reality the Democrats still don't fully understand.
 . . . Talk about the challenges of irresponsible debt, runaway spending, destructive welfare and an anti-saving tax code in moral -- as well as economic -- terms. American believes Washington isn't just irresponsible but that it is also fostering all the wrong values in our society.
 
 
STRATEGY
 "If we all ran our personal finances like the Government, we'd all be bankrupt."
 -- focus group participant
 The following are some of the more important lessons learned from the two focus group discussions and the budget-related polling. . . .
 The moral force for balancing the budget must be stronger than the pseudo-moralists who will decry the specific budget cuts. Our enemies are already gathering their stones. The New York Times has taken the lead, running two full pages of pictures of homeless people sifting through dumpsters for food.
 . . .
 Individual programs have friends. Bureaucracies and bureaucrats don't. Therefore, focus the general rhetorical attack on the "Washington bureaucracy."
 . . .
 Both focus groups (even though they included six individuals employed in education) accepted the elimination of the Department of Education, but student loans were a completely different matter. "It's just a question of whether you want money going to programs, or money going to people," said one teacher. The N.E.A., N.E.H. and C.P.B. will be even less difficult, as long as museums aren't forced to close. The communications lesson: be ready with assurances that any "truly important" program will be maintained even while entire departments are being eliminated.
 . . .
 Nothing tells America more about your priorities than the sequence of your actions. The media are watching closely to see what comes first. . . . It would be a serious communications mistake to implement a capital gains tax cut ("for the rich") now while only phasing the "middle class tax cuts" over multiple years. Regardless of the economics, this will look like you're putting the "wrong people" first.
 
 
COMMUNICATION
 The objective of the two national polls and focus groups was to learn how to communicate Republican budget and tax policies to the American people. In one sense, this memorandum is about taking back our language and turning the issue of "fairness" against the Democrats. For example, why don't we begin to ask:
 * Is it "fair" for Medicare recipients to have even greater choice of doctors and facilities than the average taxpayers who are funding the system?
 * Is is "fair" to give student loans for truck driving schools?
 * Is it "fair" to penalize middle-class families for saving for the future?
 * Is it "fair" to leave battered children in abusive homes?
 . . .
 Put the budget debate in terms of "the American dream" and "our children's future." When asked to comment on the relationship between a balanced budget and the future of America's children, both groups unanimously agreed that they would feel extremely optimistic about their children's future if the budget deficit were erased. The public does not want to pay higher taxes or see their services cut, but the vast majority are prepared to make sacrifices "so that their children can achieve the American Dream." If we talk about pain, we lose. If our words invoke a better future, we win.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank Luntz, the Republican pollster framing the issues.

HEADLINE: The World: Models for China;
Either Filthy and Free Or Clean and Mean

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
AT first glance, they couldn't be more different. The tiny city-state of Singapore is scrubbed clean. The authoritarian Government has made it a crime to chew gum or fail to flush a toilet, and litterers are humiliated by having their faces splashed across the pages of the Government-owned newspapers. Taipei, the capital of Taiwan, is filthy, arguably the least inviting city in Southeast Asia. The chaos of the streets there is matched only by the mayhem of the democratically elected legislature. Fistfights are a regular event on the floor of the Parliament.
 But different as they are, these two island-nations have one important thing in common. Both offer a vision of the future for 1.2 billion Chinese on the mainland. It is a future in which a Chinese-run government provides prosperity and security without sacrificing a distinctly Chinese way of life, with its reverence for the family and its reliance on hard work. 
 While Singapore and Taiwan embrace western concepts of free markets, the social structure remains Chinese. During last week's celebrations of the Chinese New Year, both countries effectively shut down for several days so that families could mark the holiday together. The social problems that plague the United States and other developed Western countries -- drug abuse, divorce, teen-age pregnancy, school dropouts, among them -- exist in Singapore and Taiwan, but they are far from common.
 Measured on almost every scale of economic and social achievement, Singapore (with 3 million people) and Taiwan (with 21 million) are the most successful Chinese-run nations in nearly 7,000 years of Chinese civilization. Their size belies their huge stature as role models for China. And their competition for the mainland's soul makes for the most interesting rivalry in Southeast Asia. (While Hong Kong is just as prosperous as Singapore and Taiwan, it fails as a political role model, since its Chinese citizens have had little say until recently in the running of a British colonial government.)
 So what is the battle? Simply put, many prominent Singaporeans see the Taiwanese as undisciplined roughnecks whose free-wheeling style of democracy, if adopted in China, could tear it apart. The Taiwanese, or at least many of them, see Singapore's leaders as iron-fisted bullies who treat the citizens like dimwitted children, and whose style, if transplanted to China, would mean another generation of oppression.
 The rivalry is no secret. In a scathing article in a Taipei newspaper last fall, Lung Ying-tai, a prominent Taiwanese social critic and author, attacked Singapore's Draconian legal system and ridiculed the Government's attempts to appoint itself the upholder of Asian values. "Thank goodness I am not a Singaporean," she wrote.
 Singaporeans are not all that polite about Taiwan either. The Straits Times, the Government's major English-language newspaper (private newspapers are banned in Singapore) ran an editorial last summer under the provocative headline "Singapore and Taiwan: Which Is better?" and left its readers with no doubt about the correct answer. The paper said there had been "a loss of national purpose and discipline after 10 years of democratization" in Taiwan. One of the newspaper's columnists wrote that "what the Taiwanese have done with their greater political freedom has not been encouraging" and that many Taiwanese "long for the earlier days of stability and honesty" under authoritarian rule.
 There's a saying here that Singapore's legislators love a good fist fight, just so long as it's on the floor of the Taiwanese Parliament. The press in Singapore have made much fun of the ugly side-effects of Taiwan's rush toward democracy. With glee they have covered Taiwan's brawls, vote-buying, its rising crime and divorce rates.
 Still, Taiwan is a continual annoyance for authoritarian governments in Asia, for it tends to put the lie to the idea that Asians are different from all other people; that, even after they have achieved prosperity and security, they prefer a government that restricts the rights of the individual whenever they conflict with the rights of the larger society.
 After a generation of repressive rule under President Chiang Kai-shek, Taiwan began to move toward democracy in 1987, when martial law was lifted. In 1991, President Lee Teng-hui restored constitutional rule and cleared the way for free elections for the legislature. Next year, the President will be directly and democratically elected for the first time. Taiwan now has two strong opposition parties and a free press. Tsu-Lin Mei, a professor of Chinese studies at Cornell University, said Taiwan proves that "you can have genuine democracy" in a Chinese society -- that "you can lift the iron fist and things will not dissolve."

 
 
One Vote for Singapore
 China's leaders are clearly alarmed about what is happening in Taiwan, and that has made them all the more enthusiastic about Singapore. "You do hear people on the mainland saying, 'Hey, we should do it Singapore's way,' " said Richard H. Solomon, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs in the Bush Administration. "For those who want to say that you can have an authoritarian system and really raise people's living standards, Singapore is a great model to point to."
 Nominally, Singapore is a democracy. The ruling People's Action Party has held power since 1959, mostly under Lee Kuan Yew, the former Prime Minister, who is still believed by many to be calling the shots. Human rights groups have long complained that opposition parties are harassed and citizens seem genuinely frightened to speak their minds.
 The Singapore Government has also tried to bring its foreign critics to heel. This month, The International Herald Tribune, which is owned by The New York Times and The Washington Post, was found in contempt of court for publishing an opinion article accusing unnamed Asian governments of using "a compliant judiciary to bankrupt opposition politicians." The newspaper was ordered to pay fines and court costs that will total tens of thousands of dollars.

 
 
The Trains Run On Time
 When it comes to physical environment, Singapore wins. For those Singaporeans willing to swallow their criticisms of the Government, life could not be much better. Compared to other Asian cities, Singapore is a paradise, with sprawling gardens, marble shopping malls and efficient transportation system.
 Taipei, by contrast, is a smoggy nightmare. Indeed, some Taiwanese wonder whether the country has sacrificed too much for democracy. Last year, a Taiwanese magazine, CommonWealth, compared Singapore and Taiwan and found that what most Taiwanese want is "rule of law, not greater freedom."
 That view is by no means shared by all Taiwanese. "Yes, the Taiwanese politicians are breaking the heads of one another like clowns in Parliament," Lung Ying-tai, the Taiwanese writer, has said. "But I would much rather see this sort of boisterous, tasteless farce than quiet and dignified ceremonies where oppositionists are locked up." And if the Taiwanese want change, they need only wait until next year, when for the first time in their lives, they will freely a elect a president.

HEADLINE: Poland's Leaders: Old Communists, but With a Difference

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Feb. 3

 BODY:
After nearly 18 months in power, Poland's coalition Government, with roots in the Communist past, has stalled on economic reforms, raised doubts about its commitment to joining the West and tried to clamp down on the press.
In a country where the President has threatened to dissolve Parliament on the grounds that the Government's budget was not reform minded enough, the question is: how "ex-" are Poland's ex-Communists, the first of a series of former Communists elected to lead Eastern European countries? 
 The answer appears to be: not as "ex-" as they would like to appear, but not as Communist as President Lech Walesa suggests.
Most political analysts, including the opposition, see the unpopular President, who has failed to come up with a specific alternate economic program, as posturing for re-election. The invincible Mr. Walesa of five years ago is trailing with 15 percent approval ratings.
In contrast, surveys show Poles are pleased with the slowdown on the path to a market economy. Gazeta Wyborcza, the largest circulation newspaper, published a poll today that showed 60 percent of the people opposed Mr. Walesa's current maneuverings.
In many respects, analysts say, the former Communists are merely responding to the public mood.
"These are clever guys; they know they eventually have to go to capitalism," said Henryk Domanski, a professor of sociology at the Polish Academy of Sciences who has studied Poland's Communist elite. "But they revert to symbols of the proletarian tradition and there are attempts to defend the symbolic remnants of the past."
Slawomir Nowodny, director of Demoskop, a leading public opinion survey company, said most strata of Polish society are increasingly satisfied with their economic well-being. "In recent months we're seeing more and more satisfaction among those groups who should be this government's electorate: the elderly, the unemployed, the less educated, people in small towns and villages."
So far, the partnership of the Democratic Left Alliance and the Peasants Party, whose leader, Waldemar Pawlak, is Prime Minister, has enjoyed the benefits of dramatic reforms made in the early 1990's.
Poland's economic indicators looked relatively sturdy with a 4.5 percent growth rate in 1994 compared to 2.5 percent in the Czech Republic, a leveling off in the growth of unemployment and a recent increase in foreign reserves. Consumer confidence rose as more Poles discussed whether to buy a two- or four-door car, foreign or domestic.
But these positive trends disguised deeper problems bred by the Government's stalling on privatization, analysts suggested.
The United States Ambassador to Poland, Nicholas A. Rey, a former managing director of Bear, Stearns & Co, told the newspaper Rzeczpospolita that the slowing of economic reform risked squandering the gains of the last five years.
Mr. Rey noted that the number of state enterprises privatized by the sale of equity in 1994 was 25 percent lower than in 1993. He acknowledged the argument of the Minister of Privatization, Wieslaw Kaczmarek, that the treasury had gained more revenue from privatization deals in 1994 than the year before. But Mr. Rey stressed that the goal of privatization should be to serve the long-term growth of the economy rather than to produce short-term gains.
The economy is not the only place where the former Communists have made their mark. There is less enthusiasm for joining NATO, even though, formally, it is the Government's policy. And Prime Minister Pawlak's first foreign visit was to Moscow.
Western governments were taken aback when Mr. Pawlak announced his choice for Defense Minister: Longin Pastusiak, an ideologue of the Communist Party who harped against NATO during the cold war.
The Foreign Minister, Andrzej Olechowski, who resigned over differences between his pro-NATO stance and what he termed Government lack of interest, accused the coalition leaders of cozying up to Moscow behind his back, a charge that made some Western officials wonder how serious Poland is about NATO.
"An autonomous dialogue with the Russian leadership was opened," Mr. Olechowski said. "As a result, Russia's top officials were openly talking about 'nice prime minister' and 'ugly foreign minister.' "

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Salary Cap Vanishes; Problems Don't

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Negotiators in baseball's increasingly complex labor dispute fought over the critical payroll tax issue again this evening, keeping one eye on the nearby White House and one on the ramifications of the owners' agreement with the National Labor Relations Board to withdraw their implemented salary-cap system.
The players, saying that "salaries would crash," rejected the tax plan the owners proposed last Wednesday and presented a new plan of their own. The owners quickly provided a preliminary view, saying the proposal offered "little or no movement." Under the owners' plan, the Yankees would have paid $14 million in taxes on their 1994 payroll; they would pay $1.5 million under the players' plan. 
 The labor board's action in inducing the owners to withdraw the salary cap was intended to simplify the effort to get an agreement ahead of President Clinton's deadline. But it seemed, initially at least, to create the potential for additional conflicts between the owners and their striking players.
All of these developments could collide Monday, the day of the Presidential deadline and the effective date of the clubs' withdrawal of the system they implemented Dec. 23. The two sides don't know what Clinton might do if they don't settle their dispute, and the players don't know what the owners might do if the union lifts its signing freeze once the old, pre-salary cap system is restored.
A lawyer with ties to the Administration said he believed "there is a growing groundswell behind the notion of binding arbitration," an idea Congress would have to enact through legislation. While White House officials have acknowledged that the President might intervene by asking Congress to force an end to the strike, they said today that he would prefer not to take that direct a step.
The owners, meanwhile, wrestled with their response to dealing once again under the economic system they thought they had jettisoned, only to learn that the N.L.R.B. believed the owners did not have a legal impasse when they acted.
The union is expected to end its signing freeze Monday. The clubs, however, don't want to operate under the old system, one management official made clear today.
They could avoid it by applying a signing freeze of their own, incurring the risk of triple-damage collusion against free agents; they could impose a partial freeze, signing free agents but not players eligible for arbitration, or they could suspend operations altogether by locking out the players even while they strike.
In all three instances, they could run the risk of incurring the labor board's wrath for acting unilaterally after they agreed to bargain in good faith. The owners offered no immediate indication of what they would do, positively or negatively.
A union official indicated the union may ask the labor board on Sunday to direct that beginning Monday, players be permitted to sign under the old system.
In explaining why they rejected the owners' proposed new tax system, Lauren Rich, a union lawyer, said, "They want Fort Lauderdale plus $1 billion dollars." She referred to the revenue-sharing plan the owners adopted in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a year ago.
The $1 billion represented what the union computed would be the amount of taxes generated by the owners' plan over a seven-year term if payrolls and revenues remained static.
"I don't think anyone seriously believes the clubs would do anything but respond to the heavy disincentive and salaries would crash," Donald Fehr, the union leader, said of the owners' tax plan.
The owners want to place a 75 percent tax on the portion of payrolls over $35 million and 100 percent over $42 million. The money from those taxes would fund the players' pension and benefit plan. The players' plan calls for the tax money to fund one-third of the $58 million the clubs want to distribute to low-revenue clubs under the revenue-sharing plan. The other two-thirds would come from high-revenue clubs.
The players, altering their Dec. 22 proposal, proposed a 5 percent tax on the portion of payrolls from 50 percent of the average of $40.6 million to 130 percent, 15 percent on the portion from 130 percent to 160 percent and 25 percent beyond 160 percent.
"It was a little disappointing," John Harrington, head of the owners' negotiating team, said. "There was hardly any movement."
In their new proposal, the players also offered to eliminate salary arbitration completely or partially and provide earlier, unrestricted free agency for players who otherwise would have been eligible for arbitration. The owners want to eliminate arbitration but in return for restricted free agency.
A minor flap arose late in the evening. The two sides had been scheduled to reconvene at 9:30 P.M., but 25 minutes after that time, Harrington appeared in the press room, commented on the proposal and said no meeting was scheduled.
When Fehr learned of that comment 20 minutes later, he said to reporters, "We did not get notice that they were recessing negotiations for the evening and had to find out from all of you." A few minutes later, Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, joined the players and told them he had just learned from the owners that they did not plan to meet.
Earlier in the evening, the President was at the same hotel, one floor up, attending a Wellesley College reunion with his wife, Hillary. He did not duck out to meet with negotiators.
Aides to Clinton made plain that he and his aides were monitoring the negotiating developments closely. But with opinion polls showing most Americans would prefer that the owners and players resolve their dispute themselves, the White House was also being careful not to be seen as having assumed the central role.
"It is not constructive when the two parties are at the table to comment on negotiations as sensitive as these," said the White House spokeswoman Dawn Alexander. "If the parties reach an agreement over the weekend, then obviously the President will be thrilled. If not, the possible course of action will come in the form of a recommendation from Mr. Usery. Mr. Usery is in charge."
The President has said he will ask Usery to propose his own solution if the two sides can't get there by Monday.
Other Administration officials acknowledged today that the White House had made clear to the owners in recent weeks that it would not look favorably upon their use of replacement players.
Administration officials said that even if the weekend talks fall short of a settlement, Clinton does not intend -- at least publicly -- to embrace any specific solution himself. They said they hoped a proposal from Usery would carry sufficient weight to put pressure on both sides.
If that strategy fails, too, the idea of binding arbitration could leap to the forefront.
"I think there's a growing sense that that may be the only answer," said the lawyer with Administration ties. "You can't really specifically offend anyone if you recommend binding arbitration because you're not favoring one side or the other. You're saying the sides are desperately far apart. Maybe an arbitrator beyond reproach, perhaps a former Supreme Court justice, could decide the dispute."
Even if that becomes the White House's weapon, it would have to get through Congress, and that could become a dubious effort. Whether Senators and Representatives believed it was a good idea or not, some people raised the question of whether a Republican Congress would want to make a Democratic President look good by helping him get Major League Baseball restored.
Meanwhile, Usery, who would prefer the two sides settle the dispute without a proposal from him, did make one request. He asked Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, to come to Washington to join the talks.
"I haven't talked to Bill for a little over a day," Selig said today by telephone from Milwaukee before heading for a previous engagement in Atlanta. "I'm waiting to hear from him. Whenever he wants me to come, I'll be there."

HEADLINE: A Trade Tie That Binds

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Nearly a year and a half ago, the United States decided that it had to end the deterioration in relations with China by embracing rather than isolating the Beijing Government.
Since then, there has been a steady stream of high-level diplomatic, economic and military contacts. There have also been setbacks to American goals concerning human rights, weapons proliferation, Taiwan and trade, culminating in today's decision to impose the toughest retaliatory trade sanctions in American history. 
 But despite today's harsh words and actions, senior Administration officials insist that the policy they informally call "intensive engagement" has not failed, and that they will continue to pursue it.
No matter that the bilateral dialogue is so irregular that the Chinese did not even bother to reply to an invitation to come to Washington this week to talk about the problems.
No matter that Republican critics of the policy, including House Speaker Newt Gingrich and Frank H. Murkowski, who heads the Senate subcommittee on Asia policy, say the Administration is fooling itself in thinking Beijing can be wooed. Arguing that Communists respond only to a harder line, they have mentioned normalizing relations with Taiwan.
American officials point to cooperation they say the policy has yielded, like nudging North Korea into a nuclear cooperation agreement. And they say China's behavior may have been even worse had there been more threats and less talking.
But the main reason for the Administration's determination to press ahead is this: American policy makers say there is no other choice.
China is still a one-party Communist state, but it is the third-largest economy in the world, and economic concerns have taken center stage in the Administration's foreign policy. The decision last spring to renew China's trade benefits despite its poor human rights record was a decision to help American business; so was today's decision to punish China for its rampant pirating of American goods and services.
In imposing the sanctions, the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, made clear that business had won out over diplomacy, that he had paid no attention to China's internal decision-making process or the declining health of Deng Xiaoping.
"I have one job: to protect American workers and create markets for U.S. products and exports," he said in an interview on Friday. "I cannot control what China's leadership does. That is none of my business."
In addition, the Administration argues, a new wave of nationalistic statements and repression attributable to Mr. Deng's worsening health make it even more important to stay the course.
"I'm not trying to pretend that the relationship is in great shape," Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said in an interview on Friday. "There are some difficult patches, as well as some areas where we are making progress. But the purpose here is to make progress on whatever fronts we can, and to maintain the overall momentum even if things are stalled on certain fronts."
That view is reflected in a formal paper assessing the policy and United States interests over the next several months that will be discussed at the White House next week. Still, senior Administration officials make no secret of their disappointment with China's failure to respond positively to Washington's overtures and conciliatory gestures.
"There has been a stiffening across the board in our relationship with Beijing," said one senior Administration official who has been a strong proponent of the policy. "We continue to implement our engagement strategy at all levels, because managing the relationship is so important. But now the problems are building so much it's going to be extraordinarily difficult to do it."
For example, senior officials said, the Administration's campaign to persuade China to cooperate on curbing the spread of weapons has been stalled since last October, when Foreign Minister Qian Qichen pledged in writing that China would not sell or transfer surface-to-surface missiles covered by an international accord controlling the transfer of sensitive missile technology.
Since then, the Chinese have rebuffed an American proposal to forgive Chinese violations of the accord, known as the Missile Technology Control regime, and to waive possible sanctions if China admits the violations.
They have also ignored American protests about their nuclear cooperation with Iran and have refused repeated requests to establish a regular high-level dialogue to discuss weapons-related sales and arms control issues.
Chinese officials have complained loudly, in private diplomatic protests and in public statements, that Washington's decision to upgrade its contacts with Taiwan violates its "one China" policy, which recognizes only the Government in Beijing.
Senior Administration officials, including Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary of State for Policy, and Mr. Lord have repeatedly tried to convince the Chinese otherwise, arguing that the contacts are economic, not political, and that the United States is doing less with Taiwan than many of its European allies.
As for human rights, the State Department's recent annual report on human rights concluded that China failed to make progress in all major human rights areas last year, underscoring the Administration's failure to nudge China into improving its performance despite the extension of trade privileges to Beijing eight months ago.
Both liberal and conservative critics of the Administration's policy have used human rights as an issue on which to make points. Many rights advocates predicted when the Administration dropped the link that the result was unlikely to be improved treatment of dissidents. And Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House International Relations Committee, said after the report's release that torture and other abuses seemed to be more prevalent in China since "comprehensive engagement" began.
"The Administration's policy seems to be accept what they say in the area of human rights and ignore what they do," he said.
These and other problems in Washington-Beijing relations are to be discussed at the White House next week in an effort to fine-tune the policy toward China.

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IMPOSES TRADE SANCTIONS ON CHINESE GOODS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration imposed punitive tariffs today on more than $1 billion of Chinese goods, the largest trade sanctions in American history, and warned of further action if the Communist Government continued to refuse to crack down on rampant piracy of American software, movies and music.
The decision to impose 100 percent punitive tariffs on goods ranging from silk blouses to cellular telephones was met almost immediately by an angry Chinese announcement of tariffs against American goods. 
 The confrontation comes at a particularly delicate moment in Chinese-American relations, with disagreements brewing on human rights and arms control, and with China's 90-year-old paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, reported to be seriously ill.
But after several meetings at the White House in recent days on the deteriorating relations, Administration officials decided that despite the delicate transition of power presumed to be under way, they could not justify delaying the sanctions any longer. Through the first 11 months of 1994, the United States imported $36 billion of products from China while exporting $8.5 billion of goods there.
Each country said its penalties would take effect on Feb. 26. The delay, a common practice in cases of trade sanctions, is intended to assure that goods shipped before the retaliatory tariffs were announced would not be affected.
The delay also provides a chance for further talks; last February, the Chinese struck a deal in a textile dispute on the day when previously announced sanctions were to take effect. But some trade officials speculate that the unsettled state of the Chinese leadership makes such last-minute bargaining less likely.
American consumers will be among the first victims of the trade dispute, as they are any time the Government decides to set a tariff to harm the sales of another country's goods. Under the rules published today, for example, the United States Customs Service would be required to put a $100 tax on every $100 Chinese-made bicycle imported to the United States.
Over the last five weeks, however, American officials have been pruning the list of products selected for retaliation, homing in on goods produced in several other nations as well, so that American consumers could choose, for example, a Japanese or British-made bicycle that is not subject to the tariffs.
They have also avoided products on which tariffs would be likely to hurt American business, including two of China's biggest exports to the United States, toys and electronic goods.
Today's action was the culmination of a dispute between the United States and China that has bubbled along for nearly two years, a period in which the Administration said it would no longer link human rights issues to preferential trade status.
The current dispute has begun to eclipse Washington's long-running trade arguments with Japan. Last year the American trade deficit with China climbed to $30 billion -- roughly half the size of the deficit with Japan -- and United States businesses say that piracy of American "intellectual property," particularly copyrighted material like movies and music, has contributed to the trade imbalance.
The United States has repeatedly demanded, for example, that China close 29 factories -- many of them state-owned -- that are producing 70 million compact disks and videodisks every year, from illegal copies of Whitney Houston's hit soundtrack from "The Bodyguard" to movies like "True Lies" and "Clear and Present Danger." Those goods can be found all over Asia, from the streets of Hong Kong to many stores in Tokyo.
At a news conference here today, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, held up bootleg products purchased around Asia, including knockoffs of the latest version of the Microsoft Corporation's personal computer operating system and canned foods bearing the label "Del Monte." Mr. Kantor said that after 21 negotiating sessions in the last two years, China still refused to crack down on the production and distribution of such products.
"The Chinese know what they have to do," he said. "They are the third-largest economy in the world, and they can stop this if they want."
Mr. Kantor said the sanctions were approved by President Clinton.
China also said today that it would suspend negotiations with American auto makers over the establishment of joint ventures in China to build mini-vans and passenger cars. Getting American car makers into China, as both German and Japanese manufacturers are expanding their presence there, has been an important economic priority of the Clinton Administration.
Even so, business support for a tough stand has spread in the last month, in contrast to trade sanctions in the past, which have often divided business leaders. The chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Alexander J. Trotman, said last week at an economic conference in Davos, Switzerland, that if the company was caught in the middle of a Washington-Beijing trade war, "so be it."
He added, "I think it's a very important question that needs to be addressed."
Mr. Kantor made it clear, however, that the list of affected goods had been shaped with the aim of minimizing the impact on American businesses.
"We have also tried to pick products that are produced by China's state-owned enterprises," Mr. Kantor said. While he declined to go into the reasoning behind singling out those businesses, many of those enterprises are owned by the People's Liberation Army and other Government agencies, and their profits have frequently enriched China's leaders and their families.
The decision not to include toys and electronics came after hearings in recent weeks convinced Mr. Kantor's aides that so many toys are now produced exclusively in China that doubling the tariff would harm American retailers and anger consumers. "It didn't take a political genius to see that we would be blamed for taking toys out of the hands of little kids," one Administration official said Friday as the final list was being prepared.
In fact, because of a quirk in trade laws, the United States actually ended all tariffs on toys as of Jan. 1, under the new General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade approved by Congress in November. While China is not a signer of the agreement, President Clinton's decision last year to extend preferential trade status to China mandated that it, too, would benefit from the elimination of toy tariffs.
American officials said today that they did not know how much those tariffs would total, but outside experts said they could compensate for the penalties imposed today and perhaps exceed them.
Administration officials said they excluded most electronic components from the sanctions after American computer makers were told that China was the main supplier of a large variety of cables and circuit boards used in personal computers.
Imposing sanctions on those goods, Mr. Kantor concluded, would only work to the advantage of foreign computer makers. But his aides said other items could be added to the list if China refused to reach a satisfactory agreement.
Mr. Kantor acted today under the "special 301" provisions of the 1974 Trade Act, which covers intellectual property. The law requires that after an investigation, the trade representative can declare a country's trade practices unreasonable. He made that declaration in December, two years after a previous dispute with China on the same subject resulted in an agreement with Beijing to write laws protecting copyrights and patents.
"They passed the laws, and they are well written," Mr. Kantor said in an interview in his office on Friday. "They have just refused to enforce them."
Lengthy negotiations were held in Beijing in January that yielded some progress, including an agreement by the Chinese to place a distinctive identifier code on compact disks produced in its factories, so that they can be traced to their point of manufacture. But the talks stalled when it came to taking tougher action, and China declined an invitation to continue talking in Washington last week, during the celebration of the lunar New Year.
Administration officials have a variety of theories as to why this dispute is proving so intractable.
The most popular centers on the transition in power in Beijing. Several State Department officials say they think the intense focus on Mr. Deng's health has distracted the Chinese leadership. They also speculate that some top leaders, mindful of the price they paid during the Cultural Revolution, do not want to be identified as internationalists -- seeking accommodation with the United States -- until it is clear who will dominate China's leadership.
The current dispute is linked to a broader argument between China and the West: whether Beijing is ready for admission to the new World Trade Organization, the successor to the GATT organization in Geneva that has presided over world trade since the end of World War II.
Entry to the World Trade Organization, with the trade benefits that implies, has been a central objective of China's leadership. But the United States has stood in the way, saying that until China respects intellectual property and opens its markets, it is not suited for membership.
"We must stand firm," said Representative Philip M. Crane, an Illinois Republican and chairman of the trade subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee. "If China wishes to become a member of the World Trade Organization, it must show that it is complying with the rules of the multilateral trade regime."
China's restrictions on American imports are legion, and many go beyond Japan's most protectionist policies. Only 10 American films, for example, are permitted to be shown in China each year, a quota that has both political and commercial roots. But that restriction has created an enormous demand for bootleg copies of American video cassettes and videodisks, the large, CD-like platters that can store an entire movie.
While the focus of the dispute has been on movies and music, the bigger money may lie in computer software. Copies of the most popular American software are available in shops from Beijing through the new economic zones in Southern China at a fraction of their retail prices in the United States.
"One of our negotiators paid $100 for a CD-ROM that had $10,000 worth of American software on it," Mr. Kantor said Friday. "And the Chinese told us this was out of their control."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, announced sanctions on Chinese goods yesterday. At issue is the pirating of American software, movies and music, including compact disks; United States businesses say piracy of American "intellectual property" has contributed to a $30 billion trade deficit with China. A customer checked the quality of a bootleg compact disk yesterday in Beijing. (Photographs by Associated Press) (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: More Prisons Are Banning Cigarettes

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VALHALLA, N.Y., Feb. 1

 BODY:
Charles Sanders gets a lot more than a nicotine fix from cigarettes. He wagers them in blackjack games, and he can even swap them for shampoo, shaving cream, candy bars, hamburgers, sandwiches and other goods.
He is an inmate at the Westchester County Jail here, and cigarettes serve as the currency of daily life for him and other inmates. "Cigarettes are like money to us," said Mr. Sanders, 39, who has served 13 months. "A lot of guys buy cigarettes and don't even smoke. They just buy them to trade." 
 But this staple of prison culture was eliminated this week when Westchester corrections officials imposed a smoking ban inside the jail and placed cigarettes on a list of contraband that includes liquor, knives and drugs. The officials say they enacted the prohibition for much the same reason that restaurants, museums, malls, offices, theaters and other public places have: to provide a smoke-free environment for nonsmokers.
Westchester's is not the only jail to be seized by the nation's anti-smoking fervor. Corrections officials from here to Texas to California have imposed similar restrictions in recent years despite heavy opposition from inmates and even guards, who maintain that cigarettes have long played a vital role in soothing nerves in the combustible atmosphere behind bars.
"It's a stressful environment," explained Mr. Sanders, who smokes about half a pack of Newports a day. "You want to know how stressful it is? There are people who don't smoke, but end up smoking once they come in here."
In New York State alone, at least 13 out of the 62 counties, including large ones like Nassau, Suffolk and Albany, have enacted or announced plans to enact smoking bans in their jails. In Connecticut, 14 of the state's 27 prisons prohibit smoking; the rest have opened at least one nonsmoking housing unit. And in New Jersey's 12 adult prisons, inmates are no longer permitted to smoke in their cells if their cellmates are nonsmokers.
The anti-smoking regulations also apply to death-row inmates in California and Texas -- even those seeking a final smoke as a last request before execution. "We wouldn't give them a shot of whisky or cocaine," said Larry Todd, a spokesman for the Department of Criminal Justice in Texas, where the smoking ban begins in March in the state's 80 jails and prisons, "so I doubt we'd give them a cigarette."
But smoking bans have run into problems in some places. In Vermont, corrections officials loosened restrictions on smoking after some inmates became so desperate that they began smoking powdered Tang, the instant juice drink. In addition, the black-market price of cigarettes skyrocketed, with individual cigarettes selling for as much as $ 3 and a single puff for $ 1. As a compromise, officials now allow inmates to smoke outdoors.
"More and more prisons and jails are looking at going smokeless," said Rod V. Bottoms, a senior corrections specialist with the Information Center of the National Institute of Corrections, a branch of the Department of Justice. "But it's difficult, because of the culture in prisons."
In Rensselaer County, which is across the Hudson River from Albany, a smoking ban was enacted about two years ago in the local jail. Corrections officials are so concerned about the possible consequences that they have adopted a program of handing out carrot and celery sticks, potato chips and popcorn twice a day to calm jittery inmates.
"It takes more than just putting up no-smoking signs," said Robert Loveridge, a colonel with the Rensselaer Sheriff's Department, who supervises the county jail. "You have to be empathetic to the needs of the prisoners."
In Albany County, corrections officials announced a smoking ban last month but decided not to implement it until March to give prisoners time to break the habit. "We decided it would be better if we gradually wean the inmates off cigarettes," said Thomas J. Wigger, the assistant superintendent of the Albany County Jail. "Cold turkey was not the best solution for all involved."
In some cases, local and state corrections departments have adopted the no-smoking policy because of a growing number of complaints and even lawsuits from nonsmoking prisoners and guards who worry about the health risks of secondhand smoke. Others have done so to comply with local anti-smoking ordinances. Many corrections officials have refused to allow prisoners to smoke outdoors or in designated smoking areas because regulating when and where smoking takes places would entail extra work.
The Dutchess County (N.Y.) Sherriff's Department started prohibiting smoking in its jail in 1992 after Kenneth Altieri, a corrections officer, filed a lawsuit demanding a smoke-free environment for himself and other nonsmokers.
Mr. Altieri, who is 45, says he became very unpopular because of his stand. But he said he could no longer tolerate coming home reeking of smoke. "You couldn't go anywhere in the building without running into smoke," he said. "Your clothes would stink of it. Your hair would stink of it. You couldn't escape it."
"Besides," he added, "it kills you."
Here in Westchester, corrections officials adopted the policy in order to comply with a county order banning smoking in all county buildings. As of the beginning of this month, inmates face a loss of privileges -- for example, they can be confined to their cells -- if they are caught with cigarettes, cigars and other tobacco products. By contrast, possession of drugs or weapons carries more serious penalties like criminal charges.
Luke J. Smith, the Deputy Commissioner for the county's Department of Corrections, said officials had not set up any special program to help prisoners cope with nicotine withdrawal because many are jailed for only a few days, usually until they can post bail. "We have a constant turnover," he said.
But what about withdrawal symptoms for inmates who are locked up for longer periods? "If inmates have problems," Mr. Smith said, "they can call to see a nurse and handle it as a medical problem." It would be treated like any other addiction, he added.
To prisoners, the ban adds yet one more layer of punishment to the deprivation of life behind bars.
Ambrose Rooney has managed to get by in jail for the last 10 months by smoking after every meal. "Being locked up alone is stressful," he said. "Cigarettes relieve that stress, frustration and anxiety."
He added: "A lot of times you see guys get off the phone after arguing with their girlfriends or wives and the first thing they do is grab a cigarette."
But cigarettes have served as more than just a tranquilizer for Mr. Rooney. Occasionally, he has traded them for hamburgers, rice, scallops or other leftovers from the kitchen.
But those days are behind him, and he wonders if there isn't a better solution. "They should have come up with a more flexible guideline, like smoking and nonsmoking blocks," he said. "They should have done it that way."
Mr. Rooney added, "This is a jail, not a restaurant, museum or country club."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles Sanders, a prisoner at Westchester County Jail, where tobacco is now banned, said cigarettes were often bartered as well as smoked. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times) (pg. 44)

HEADLINE: Clinton Decides to Control, but Not Cut, the Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In drafting the budget proposal he plans to send to Congress on Monday, President Clinton seriously considered more aggressive efforts to make deep reductions in the budget deficit. Instead, a variety of political reasons led him to settle for keeping the deficit near its current level, Administration officials said today.
The President's budget calls for spending $1.6 trillion in the 1996 fiscal year, which begins in October. It shows a deficit of $196.7 billion in 1996, up slightly from the $192.5 billion projected for this year. 
 One of Mr. Clinton's proudest boasts is that in 1993 he persuaded Congress to adopt a budget plan that saves at least $505 billion over five years. He describes it as "the largest deficit reduction package in history." As a result of that plan, he says, the deficit dropped sharply, and "the economy has improved far more than even the most optimistic forecasters predicted."
By contrast, Mr. Clinton says his new budget would save $81 billion over five years, and the decline in the deficit would stop. His strategy is to control the deficit, but not to reduce it further.
For friends and foes, who say that Mr. Clinton had the political courage to propose tough cuts in the deficit two years ago, the apparent decline in his interest at a time when deficit-cutting is more in vogue on Capitol Hill could seem puzzling.
The President decided on that strategy in December. Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, was virtually alone in advocating more aggressive efforts to reduce the deficit, Administration officials said. She received occasional support from Leon E. Panetta, the former budget director who is now White House chief of staff, they said.
"There were discussions about whether we should do more to reduce the deficit," said a White House official who participated in those discussions. "Except for Alice and occasionally Leon, no one thought we should do more."
The President's conclusion was based, in part, on a political judgment. "People don't care about deficit reduction," said a White House official. "We did that in the first two years. Look where it got us. We lost the House and the Senate."
Mr. Clinton's decision was also based on tactical considerations. He and his advisers feared that if they proposed a major new effort to drive down the deficit, they would inadvertently help the new Republican majority in Congress.
"If the Republicans want to do more deficit reduction, let them come forward with their own ideas," a White House official said. "Why make it easy for them? In the current political environment, we don't have control. The Republicans could take our proposed savings and use them for the tax cuts in the Contract With America."
The political risk, of course, is that the President's old deficit fighting notwithstanding, his new, more cautious approach could allow Republicans to cast him as a defender of the status quo on the deficit. And both Republicans and conservative Democrats have reacted to news of his budget plans by criticizing him for cutting too little.
The Administration has other strategies in mind as well. The President has denounced the Republican tax proposals on the ground that they would cost too much, nearly $200 billion over five years, and would shower the greatest benefits on the richest people. (Mr. Clinton says his own tax proposals would mainly help the middle class and cost $63 billion over five years.)
The Administration also makes an economic argument to justify its approach: the dollar amount of the deficit is said to be less important than the size of the deficit in relation to the economy as a whole. Under the President's budget, the deficit would be stable, but the economy would continue to grow. So according to his projections, the deficit, now equivalent to 2.7 percent of the gross domestic product, would decline to 2.1 percent in the year 2000, "its lowest level since 1979."
Democrats in Congress say that argument may have merit as economic analysis but is useless as a political response to voters and lawmakers demanding a balanced budget.
"Clinton's argument that the deficit-to-G.D.P. ratio is declining, that's just a bunch of words that most Americans don't relate to very well," said a longtime Democratic aide on Capitol Hill. "He may be right, but he will not score any political points unless he can explain his position in a way that people understand."
Gene Sperling, an aide to the President, said Mr. Clinton's budget showed that he was willing to make the "hard specific choices" needed to keep the deficit under control.
But members of Congress, who are debating a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget, want more.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said the spending cuts proposed by Mr. Clinton were insufficient. Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, said it was now obvious that "the Administration does not believe in balancing the budget." Representative Martin O. Sabo of Minnesota, the ranking Democrat on the panel, said he would have preferred more deficit reduction and has told colleagues that he will not be a cheerleader for the President's budget.
Martha H. Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan organization that lobbies for a balanced budget, said Mr. Clinton was sending a signal that "$200 billion is about the right level for the deficit."
And Representative Gene Taylor, a conservative Democrat from Mississippi, said the Clinton package was "an insult to all those people who walked the plank and lost their jobs supporting his budget two years ago."
But Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said Mr. Clinton's political judgment might ultimately prove to be correct.
"If the deficit goes down in the next couple of years and it's done as a result of actions by the Republican Congress, the President will still get some credit," said Mr. Reischauer. "He signs the appropriations bills. If he's running for re-election, he can go to the American people as a co-author of deficit reduction."
Budget documents show that the President carefully balanced fiscal and political concerns on other issues as well:
*A business tax credit for research and experimentation would be allowed to expire on June 30. In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton supported the credit as a way to stimulate research investments by high technology companies. In his budget, he does not formally propose extending the tax credit. But he says he may support it if Congress can find a way to pay the cost, estimated at $10 billion over five years.
*In keeping with his campaign pledge, Mr. Clinton would increase Federal spending on AIDS programs. The total would rise 7 percent, to $2.9 billion. That includes $1.4 billion for research financed by the National Institutes of Health and $724 million for community health care services.
*Mr. Clinton's budget avoids large cuts in farm programs, protects spending for rural electric cooperatives and seeks an increase in rural development programs run by the Agriculture Department.
For Head Start, which provides a wide range of services to preschool children, Mr. Clinton will seek $3.9 billion, an increase of $400 million over this year's level.
