HEADLINE: Union Point Journal;
Pilloried On a List That's Guilt By Name

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNION POINT, Ga., Feb. 3

 BODY:
Wanting to squelch a rash of shoplifting, burglary and vandalism, the authorities in this small eastern Georgia city came up with a list of those assumed to be responsible. Then they published it, an exercise that has turned into a variation of the colonial practice of using pillories to display residents for the scorn of fellow citizens.
But there was a troubling racial twist. All those on the list were black. 
 It contained the names of 19 men and 2 women from the ages of 15 to 31 who were suspected but never convicted of committing such crimes. With the help of merchants, the 21 were banned from more than two dozen stores and other businesses ranging from banks to video arcades to coin-operated laundries along the half-mile-long commercial strip.
"You are not to enter said premises," said the tersely worded notice that the police personally delivered on Dec. 7 to the 21 people. "If you do so, you will be charged with criminal trespass and/or disorderly conduct."
Some residents said the list reflected a long history of racial bias and police harassment of blacks in the town of 1,750 people, which is 43 percent black. And this week the ban led eight on the list to file suit in Federal District Court in Macon, alleging that the ban violated their civil rights and was racially discriminatory.
About a mile from downtown Union Point, in the black community known as "the Old Field," three of those named on the list, at first angrily and then plaintively, told of what it had meant for them.
As a practical matter, said Reginald Howard, an unemployed 31-year-old construction worker, it meant that he now had to go 10 miles to nearby Greensboro to a dry cleaner or laundry. For Reginald and Rodney Barnett, 19-year-old twins, the biggest problem was the "guilt by association" and the unfairness of singling out blacks "for something that white kids are doing, too."
"Everybody on that list may not be innocent, but I know I am," Reginald Barnett said of the humiliation he felt. "I'm upset. Every time people see us they think we're thieves because we are on the list."
While the city Police Chief, Richard Reese, insisted that Union Point officials who had the idea of the ban were on firm legal footing, based on talks with the city and district attorneys, others were not so sure.
"It is quite extraordinary and appears to be an unconstitutional racial classification on its face," said Laughlin McDonald, regional director in Atlanta of the American Civil Liberties Union, which is not involved in the suit. "But it offends a number of other constitutional rights as well, including the requirement for due process. It is a legislative body and the executive branch, and not a judge and jury, making outcasts of a group of people."
What is clear from interviews throughout the town is that the idea of the list originated with Mayor Ben Stewart, the owner of a local finance company and three other downtown businesses. The five whites and one black on the City Council went along with the idea.
In an interview, Mayor Stewart denied that the makeup of the list amounted to racial discrimination. It reflected "a behavioral problem and not a racial problem," he said, adding that he and others were still trying to devise a class that those on the list could attend to have their names purged from it.
In the meantime, though, he said he had been contacted by the Federal Justice Department's Community Relations Service, which he said might want to mediate the dispute and avoid a court fight.
Some merchants said they were having second thoughts about the ban. Samuel E. Kilgore, the white owner of Rhodes and Kilgore Pharmacy, one of about a half dozen businesses in a strip of renovated 19th century storefronts facing the railroad tracks that run through downtown Union Point, said he was surprised that the list had only blacks on it. He said he was pretty sure that some whites were guilty of shoplifting in his store. But he said he reasoned that those on the list were the most troublesome.
"We were all having problems with shoplifting that seem to have ended," Mr. Kilgore said. "I really trusted that the police and city officials knew what they were doing to the point that I was willing to assist them. But when people start filing lawsuits it puts some doubt in your mind."
While Mr. Kilgore has not completely backed away from the list and the ban, another merchant, Dexter Jackson, 25, has. Mr. Jackson, who runs his family's arcade and clothing store downtown and was the only black store-owner to originally endorse the idea, has withdrawn his support and participation. He said when he saw that all those on the list were black and some were his most frequent customers, he talked with many of their parents and decided that it was not the right thing to do.
"The police came up with this list on their own, and the kids saw it as a way for the cops to pick on them and harass them," he said. "That's one of the reasons why I had a problem with it. Plus, no white kids are on the list and I know that in any town you will have good whites and good blacks, bad whites and bad blacks."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reginald Howard, left, Reginald Barnett, center, and Rodney Barnett, are among 21 people whose names appeared on a list of suspected, not convicted, shoplifters in Union Point, Ga. Those on the list have been banned from some retail stores in the area, prompting the filing of a civil-rights lawsuit. (David Murray Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Allies Mute Discord Over Mexico

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Financial leaders of seven leading industrial countries expressed "full satisfaction" today with American-led efforts to rescue the Mexican economy but said they wanted international organizations to improve their ability to forestall similar crises.
Finance ministers of the Group of Seven countries met in Toronto as the crisis of recent weeks over the fragile state of Mexico's finances appeared to ease. 
 European ministers made a determined effort to tone down disagreements earlier in the week with the United States over Mexican aid.
The International Monetary Fund, which is supposed to provide early warning of financial crises, has been criticized for failing to anticipate the difficulties in Mexico. The ministers said they had discussed the need for the monetary fund and the World Bank to improve their ability to detect problems early.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who spent 25 years with the New York investment house of Goldman Sachs, said today that the problem was the "almost instantaneous flows of capital that take place in today's financial markets."
He said the I.M.F. and World Bank, sister organizations that have piloted the world's economic system for half a century, "need to be as modern as the world we live in."
The discord between the United States and European allies related to President Clinton's failure to consult them as he changed gears in the face of overwhelming Congressional opposition to an earlier proposal that would have required the approval of the Congress. He then announced a new $50 billion Mexican aid plan that did not require Congressional approval and which was greeted enthusiastically in financial markets.
Mr. Rubin said President Clinton had to make his decision in a few hours last Monday night and Tuesday morning, without "the consultations that we as much as anybody would have liked."
Finance Minister Edmond Alphandery of France said, "The rapidity with which the plan of mobilization of $50 billion was put together did not permit all the consultation that one would have liked, but the plan is solid and has the confidence of markets, as has been shown."
But his British counterpart, Kenneth Clarke, said, "The pace of events in Mexico underlined the need for maximum communications and advance warning."
Mexico has been battered by waves of flight by investors since its devaluation of the peso in December. Many financial analysts said the country was close to defaulting on its debt when the American aid was announced.
"We were very close to very serious financial distress in Mexico," which could have had damaging effects on world markets and the global economy, Mr. Rubin said.
The President's package includes $20 billion in medium- and long-term loans or loan guarantees from the Treasury's Exchange Stabilization Fund, which the President was able to order without Congressional approval. Another $17.8 billion is to come from the I.M.F., $10 billion from the central banks of leading nations through the Bank for International Settlements and $3 billion from commercial banks.
The monetary fund, a Washington-based international agency that helps countries in financial trouble, had already agreed to a $7.8 billion loan to Mexico. Mexico will be able to draw on it on Monday.
But several European countries said they were caught by surprise with Washington's demand for an additional $10 billion from the fund, which is supported by contributions from the world's richest nations, and they registered their displeasure at a meeting of the fund's executive board on Wednesday in Washington.
At that meeting Britain, Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium and Switzerland abstained from approving the Clinton plan, saying they had not been adequately consulted. But the plan was approved with nearly 85 percent of the weighted membership vote.
The thrust of European objections, echoed this weekend in Toronto, was that by doing so much for Mexico, a major trading partner of the United States, the international community was in danger of shortchanging Russia and perhaps other countries that are major trading partners of the Europeans.
The meeting of the seven countries -- the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan -- began on Friday night and ended today.
The ministers spent a good deal of time discussing conditions in Russia. They said they welcomed "the state of commitment of the Russian Government to economic reform," but noted "with concern the recent rebound in inflation and substantial risks for the budget, which have been heightened by the situation in Chechnya."

HEADLINE: Subway Bombing Suspect Moved to Bellevue

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The man accused in the Dec. 21 subway firebombing in lower Manhattan has left the hospital where he had been handcuffed to his bed and guarded around the clock.
The suspect, Edward J. Leary, who suffered third-degree burns on 40 percent of his body when the bomb went off in his lap, was moved from New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center to the prison ward at Bellevue Hospital on Friday. 
 Skin grafts have improved Mr. Leary's condition from critical to stable, said a New York Hospital spokeswoman, Kathy Robinson.
Mr. Leary, an unemployed computer expert, was one of 48 riders injured when the homemade gasoline bomb exploded on a subway train in the Fulton Street station in lower Manhattan.
The police said that the bomb went off prematurely in Mr. Leary's lap.
Mr. Leary's doctors concluded that his treatment could continue at Bellevue, where he joined nine other prisoners in the locked ward, said a Correction Department spokesman, Tom Kelly.
Mr. Leary, 49, of Scotch Plains, N.J., was arraigned at New York Hospital on Jan. 10, pleading innocent to attempted murder and other charges. The authorities have said the bombing was part of a scheme to extort money from New York City.
Six other people severely injured in the bombing remained in the burn unit, Ms. Robinson said. Reufield Edey, 60, burned over two-thirds of his body, remained in critical condition. The others were in serious or stable condition.

HEADLINE: Don't Forget About American Coat Makers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It's somewhat unfair to view the layoff of 300 Ukrainian workers -- a result of curbs on Ukrainian coat exports -- as a way "to shield a relative handful" of coat makers in Maine and elsewhere ("In Ukraine, a Free-Market Lesson Learned Too Well," Jan. 1). American coat makers employ workers, too, and laid-off American workers can buy fewer products and may have to be supported by unemployment insurance or welfare. The country loses their contribution to our gross domestic product and has to support them. Sending American jobs abroad is one reason that real wages in America have fallen.
 
MARVIN H. SCILKEN
Manhattan, Jan. 2
 
The writer is a retired public librarian.

HEADLINE: The Wrong Road to the Greening of America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Big Environment Hits a Recession" (Jan. 1) describes the recent falloff in memberships and finances of major environmental organizations that boomed in the 1980's. The writer quotes a report from the Center for the Study of American Business that cites a need to "trim down and stick to core competencies" as the best way to regain influence and check the decline -- a most unfortunate analysis that fails to recognize the primary reform that is required. 
 The critical challenge for these groups in the 1990's is to identify in the popular consciousness the concept of greening with jobs and profits. It is to articulate a vision that links the regeneration of the world's ecosystems with the long-term reanimation of the United States economy. It is to seriously and systematically pursue the direction that organized environmentalism briefly adopted before the 1992 Presidential campaign, and then dropped when the coming of a new Administration in Washington created the illusion that an old ethics-based, choose-nature-over-prosperity paradigm could be dusted off, repackaged and resold to the American public.
The backlash against environmentalism embodied in the Republicans' Contract With America is but the latest symptom of what happens when green groups continue to treat "the environment" as a means to launder the existing wealth of big contributors, rather than as a mechanism to generate new wealth for America as a whole. A curious aspect of present-day politics is that while most Americans recognize that strong environmental policies and good economics are not merely compatible but synonymous, representatives of major environmental organizations either ignore this concept or fail to promote it aggressively. Trimming and sticking to core competencies may make organized environmentalism trimmer and more competent, but not a whit more relevant.
 
MICHAEL SILVERSTEIN
Philadelphia, Jan. 1
 
The writer is the author of "The Environmental Economic Revolution," (St. Martin's Press, 1993).

HEADLINE: Outside Pressures on the U.S. Inflation Rate

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One hopes Michael Marn's analysis of the factors reshaping economic realities in America ("Inflation: It's Not What It Used to Be," Viewpoints, Jan. 8) will catch the attention of the Federal Reserve and others who provide the micro impacts on our economy. 
 There is no question that the game has changed with respect to the forces affecting inflation. It's time to end the upward interest-rate spiral which, I believe, is doing more harm than good to the average citizen -- those who have to live in this economy.
While Mr. Marn provides a complete analysis of the domestic economic elements that have changed from the 70's and 80's, I don't believe he goes far enough. We must also come to grips with the fact that the American economy no longer exists in isolation, as Nafta and GATT attest.
Production capabilities have become more sophisticated worldwide, offering another extremely powerful control to inflationary pressures. There is no question that the ability of countries outside the Group of Seven to compete in an increasing number of consumer and industrial markets maintains a significant downward pressure on prices. The reality is that the world has become smaller -- and the sooner we understand it and learn to live within it, the better off we will all be.
 
H. DAVID ROSNER
Manhattan, Jan. 16
 
The writer is director of market research for Clark Boardman Callaghan, a legal publishing company.

HEADLINE: Washington's Other Crisis

 BODY:
The nation's capital -- Washington D.C. -- has a budget deficit equal to almost one-quarter of its whole budget. The rapidly worsening fiscal mess is a scandal, largely the result of years of lax management by mayors and City Councils. But it also reflects underlying political and economic forces that keep the city in the poorhouse.
 The first responsibility for a solution lies with Mayor Marion Barry and the Council. In that respect, the Mayor's emergency plan, announced Thursday, was disappointing. It put too much emphasis on the need for a Federal bailout while proposing too little in the way of new cutbacks. 
 Even so, the District's financial bind is so desperate that Congress must probably act, too -- with constructive help, not punishment. But the crisis should not be an excuse, as some critics threaten, to end the District's two-decade experiment with limited home rule.
 The District's plight is clear enough: a large and growing welfare and Medicaid population, a declining base of working taxpayers and constraints on its ability to raise its own revenues. But its political leaders made things worse by building one of urban America's most bloated and least efficient bureaucracies.
 When the current fiscal year began last Oct. 1 it appeared the budget would be $140 million in the red, and Congress told the District to start trimming. A month later the projected deficit had grown to $250 million, by late January it was $600 million, and last week Mayor Barry said it will reach $722 million -- in an overall budget of $3.2 billion.
 The escalation reflects recently discovered bills the District incurred but has not paid, especially for Medicaid. Mayor Barry and his predecessor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, blame each other. Either way, fiscal management has been sloppy in the extreme.
But the District operates on difficult terms. Unlike other troubled cities, it has no state government to help it absorb costly services like health care, welfare and education. It cannot even control its own revenues and expenditures. Congress approved a limited form of home rule for the District in the 1970's but kept budget control -- even though most spending is covered by local taxes that Washingtonians pay directly to the District. The District's taxing power is further hobbled by the vast presence of the Federal Government, foreign embassies and nonprofit institutions, all tax-exempt.
 Mayor Barry has now proposed spending cuts of some $200 million, and has asked Congress to cut the wages of city workers if their unions continue to balk at negotiating. He also wants Congress to pick up $267 million in immediate Medicaid costs. For the longer term, he proposes that the Federal Government take over Medicaid, mental health services, the local prison and courts, and the largest welfare program. He will have a hard time convincing Congress.
 Given the District's awkward status, as a vassal of Congress with no state government as a buffer, it will need Federal assistance of some kind now, maybe even Federal assumption of local poverty and Medicaid burdens. But there is a risk that Congress will demand still greater control of District affairs. It might be justified in creating a financial control board to keep watch on the District budget. But this crisis is not sufficient reason to strip the District of the limited home-rule powers it fought so hard to get.

HEADLINE: Investors Drop Mexico and Woo Peru

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Now that Mexico is no longer the darling of Latin America among investment bankers, it is good to know that Peru is. Your Jan. 31 Business Day juxtaposition of "Peru: On the Very Fast Track" with "Plunge by Mexican Peso Jars U.S. Stocks" is ironic. The Wall Street analysts who were so bullish on Mexico right up until the peso plunged in December now reassure investors that "Peru keeps getting better and better." 
 True, economic growth of 12 percent last year was the world's highest, but off what base?
The answer is buried in the article: "From 1988 to 1992, the economy shrank by 25 percent -- more than the 21 percent growth it has recorded during the last two years." Between 1981 and 1988, the economy grew just 2.4 percent. Glowing forecasts are just forecasts.
You fail to mention Peru's current account deficit, the source of Mexico's problems. Receipts from privatization help offset this, but these are one-shot inflows that Peru will be unable to count on once the selloff of state companies runs its course. As in Mexico, foreign investment is helping sustain the balance of payments. So is portfolio investment.
But perhaps it is not such a good thing that "last year's surge of foreign investment -- largely American -- pushed the exchange index up 50 percent in dollar terms." If Mexico has illustrated anything, it is that an excessive reliance on foreign portfolio investment makes a country vulnerable to a quick crash.
Peru deserves enormous credit for aggressive privatization, deregulation of the economy, the taming of hyperinflation, huge improvement in domestic security and introduction of a private pension fund system. But investors should be wary. The problems of a country like Peru do not disappear in one presidential term.
 
HELEN M. CUNNINGHAM
New York, Jan. 31, 1995
 
The writer was an editor of Business Latin America, a newsletter, 1984-88.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1404 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 29 - February 3

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Is This What the Federal Reserve Was Waiting For?
That was quick. On Wednesday, in the most unsurprising event of the week, the Federal Reserve raised interest rates half a point, putting the Federal funds rate at exactly twice its level of a year ago (in the days of mortgage-refinancing bliss). And on Friday came news that January's unemployment rate had turned higher for the first time in over two years, to 5.7 percent from 5.4, with job growth at a weak 134,000. That's bad news for the jobless, of course, but it's just what the Fed wanted -- a too-strong economy means inflation. But even as the Fed clamped down over the past year, the unemployment rate headed stubbornly lower -- until that mirror image cracked last week. Needless to say, the stock market was giddy, with the Dow industrials rushing ahead by 57 points, its largest jump since summer, on the Big Board's sixth-busiest day ever. 

Balanced? Not Even Close
While the House was indulging in soft-focus visions of balanced budgets, the Administration had to come up with numbers. In a budget the President submits to Congress tomorrow -- if he has any sense, he'll drop it on the Capitol's doorstep and run -- Mr. Clinton proposes $ 81 billion in deficit cuts through 2000, but deficits still in the $ 190 billion range for a decade or so. It's hard to see how he could do otherwise -- much of the budget is, even on Republican terms, untouchable. The Contract With America calls for balance by 2002, but gives no recipe for that miracle.
 
Yes! Really! It's Opening!
What price progress? Let's see. In Denver, that snazzy new airport -- the one whose Space Age baggage system is said to treat suitcases with great disrespect -- will finally open this month after numerous delays, having cost $ 4.2 billion. For Denver, it can't come too soon -- it's paying $ 1 million a day in bond interest. But put it on a human scale: the new airport will put travelers fully 23 miles from downtown, and last week several airlines said a round trip to or from Denver would cost $ 40 more when the airport opens. And the infamous baggage system? For now a traditional system will move the bags. The automated system might, uh, be ready in a year or so.
 
Pataki's Tax-Cut Math
George Pataki faced a $ 5 billion budget gap, and was set on tax cuts; drastic measures were clearly called for. He did come up with something drastic last week: he became the first New York Governor in half a century to call for less spending than the year before -- $ 1.1 billion less. A billion is going right out in tax cuts -- a down payment in a four-year tax-slashing crusade -- and it soon became apparent that the spending cuts would hit the poor hard. There'll be reductions in everything from rent allowances to emergency cash for utility bills. In New Jersey, meanwhile, ripples of discontent surfaced about a flip side to tax cuts: cuts in school aid. You can't, it seems, have it both ways.
 
Sign of Good Banking Times
Sometimes things sneak up on you, the way you suddenly realize a headache has disappeared. That was the sense last week when the Government proposed slashing bank fees for deposit insurance -- by perhaps $ 5 billion a year. The message, of course: bank failures, once a regular ritual, barely happen now. If there's justice, that means bank customers will get a slightly better deal -- higher interest to earn, lower interest to pay. But what of savings and loan fees? Not yet, the F.D.I.C. said. Which means, of course, that the S.& L. industry will be at a distinct competitive disadvantage in attracting depositors.
 
If It Ain't Broke ...
It's an old theory: If it works, fix it. In that spirit, Detroit came up with a new way of giving report cards on itself. The result, chaos. Auto makers used to take two days to tally things up, then report sales on the month's third business day. Neat and consistent. But some of them decided to go to the first day, with the result, last week, that no one really knew what to make of these crucial figures -- too many asterisks, too many holes. Not till Friday -- the 3d -- did all become clear: growth continues, but it's slower.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Helping Mexico, Somehow
It was messy, but it looks as if Mexico will get help. First, President Clinton gave up on a wary Congress and just said he'd do it on his own, with emergency authority. The loans he promised came to just half the $ 40 billion he'd tried to get with Congress's seal of approval, but with more from other nations, that could hit $ 50 billion. It wasn't exactly neat getting the European allies to go along, though, for six nations -- Britain, Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium and Switzerland -- balked at supporting the I.M.F.'s slice. The package was approved, but those nations wanted to vent their irritation that they'd had so little time to think it over. They clearly weren't sympathetic to Mr. Clinton's need for a decisive move.
 
A Benetton Backlash
Benetton has always had an odd way of selling clothes -- running ads with, say, a war cemetery or an oil-soaked bird. Yes, such ads fulfill a prime goal: they get attention. And in that time-honored equation, attention equals familiarity equals sales. Up to a point. That point may have been reached in Europe, especially in Germany, where protests against what critics call tasteless ads are creating a backlash that store owners say are cutting into sales. About 70 Benetton licensees met recently to discuss this, and a lawyer for one store owner called it "totally cynical" to use "human tragedy and suffering to sell clothes." Benetton says the stores are just blaming other problems on the ads.
 
Totally Private! (Usually)
Don't worry, the future-tech folks keep telling us -- all this fancy stuff we're throwing at you won't invade your privacy one iota. Take caller ID -- that miracle technology that broadcasts your number to friend and marketer alike. Totally safe, Nynex insisted. You can be protected if you wish. Right. Last week it turned out that up to 30,000 customers hadn't gotten the privacy they'd been promised. Nynex "botched it," said one privacy advocate. And who knows what other privacy lapses lurk out there, waiting to rear their all-too-public heads. (Are you safe from caller ID? Call Nynex at 800 634-2006.)
 
A Comeback That Wasn't
For William Agee, his career's blazing start was a tough act to follow. In 1977, not yet 40, he became one of the nation's youngest chief executives, guiding Bendix on a growth spree. But then came a failed takeover battle, and a controversy over his promotion of Mary Cunningham, later his wife. After the dust settled, and Bendix was swallowed by Allied, the couple lowered their profile, running a venture firm from Cape Cod. But in 1988, Mr. Agee seemed back on track, taking over at Morrison Knudsen, in his home state of Idaho. The smell of turnaround was in the air, but it never came. Last week Morrison said Mr. Agee, now 57, would retire.
 
Ben & Jerry & ... Not You
Hmmm. President of Ben & Jerry's. The warm glow of running a "socially responsible" company. (Plus, no doubt, all the designer ice cream you could eat.) Sounded tempting to 20,000 or so hopeful souls, who responded to an invitation to demonstrate, in 100 yummy words, why they had the right stuff. Bad news, folks. The job's been filled. Last week Ben & Jerry's, whose ice cream provides 107.2 percent of your daily recommended allowance of guilt, named the winner: Robert Holland Jr., once a McKinsey turnaround consultant. Yes, one finalist did come in the mail. Close, but no Cherry Garcia -- which happens to be one of Mr. Holland's favorites. (What would you expect him to say -- Haagen-Dazs's rum raisin?)
 
Passing 'Go' in Style
Alan Greenspan has to love Monopoly. Yes, yes, the game's an ode to capitalism, but here's its real glory: No inflation! After 60 years, Boardwalk is still $ 400. (Even in the New York edition, in which Boardwalk has mutated into Trump Tower, the bargain price stands.) Surely such a game -- 160 million copies sold -- deserves a party. So to mark its 60th anniversary, Rich Uncle Pennybags, the game's top-hatted mascot, will ring the opening bell at the American Stock Exchange on Tuesday, surrounded by traders in top hats. Think that's silly? You can go directly to jail. (Do not, of course, pass Go.)

CORRECTION-DATE: February 12, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An entry in the Business Diary column last Sunday about the new Denver airport misstated the status of the automated baggage system. When the airport opens on Feb. 28, the system will be used for all outbound United Airlines flights, roughly 60 percent of all outbound flights. The other outbound flights, and all the inbound flights, will use a traditional system.

HEADLINE: Profile;
A Silk Blouse on the Assembly Line? (Yes, the Boss's)

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

DATELINE: AVON LAKE, Ohio

 BODY:
Deborah S. Kent remembers well her first day on the job.
There she was, standing at the entrance of the Ford assembly plant here, awed by the cavernous 3.3 million-square-foot building sitting on 419 neatly manicured acres. 
 She'd conquered an attack of first-day jitters -- "You know, that I'd get lost on the way or leave the keys to the office at home" -- and actually arrived several minutes early, only to find herself momentarily paralyzed at the front door.
She was still standing there when a man in orange coveralls walked up from behind. "You must be the new plant manager," he said. She was indeed -- though she recalls wondering how he'd figured that out, since no photographs of her had been published in the newspapers or company bulletins.
"Here, I'll open the door and you just come on in," he told her. "Everything is going to be fine."
Ms. Kent saw it as a good omen. She hasn't seen him since, but when she does she wants to thank him for the friendly encouragement.
A petite woman, she seems out of place walking the assembly line in her horn-rimmed glasses, tiny pearl earrings, white silk blouse, mint-green wool slacks and flat suede and leather shoes. A white-collar woman in a brawny blue-collar man's world.
In September, at age 41, Ms. Kent became the first woman to head a vehicle assembly plant at the Ford Motor Company, and the only African-American woman ever to rise to that post. Her duties include managing two shifts with a total of 3,746 workers, as well as 420 robots, and overseeing the annual production of 216,035 Ford Econoline vans and 115,184 Mercury Villager and Nissan Quest mini-vans at a pace of up to 56 vehicles an hour on an assembly line that stretches 19.5 miles. The plant, the third largest of the company's 38 United States facilities, is the only one to manufacture those models.
Armed with a master's degree in industrial psychology from Washington University in St. Louis, Ms. Kent is part of a new auto industry generation. The industry had lost its competitive edge and its reputation for quality to foreign auto makers, and this new generation is determined not to repeat the mistakes that allowed that to happen. An avid reader, she enjoys talking to the press, and speaks an energetic mixture of Ford phrasing and maternal wisdom. Her conversations are peppered with words like "quality" and "competitive edge."
"The best thing that ever happened to this industry was competition," said Ms. Kent. "We can't ever again become complacent about any indicators, not quality, not costs, not our customers."
ARTICULATING her visions of the job, she said: "It does no good to have a diverse work force if you don't listen to their opinions and thoughts. I treat people the way I want to be treated. You give me your overall guidelines, give me a minute or two to get the systems in place, to meet the guidelines, and I'll meet my objectives. I don't have to be constantly reminded or quizzed about them."
Although she is still furnishing her new apartment, a few minutes' drive from the plant, she has managed to fit comfortably into this noisy, physical, sweat-stained universe. Already, she has become an energizing influence among peers and subordinates as well, employing an administrative style that embraces W. Edwards Deming's corporate philosophy for improving product quality: "Do it right the first time" and "Don't treat employees as adversaries."
"When I talk to my area managers, I say, 'Give me some feedback and some eye contact,'" Ms. Kent said. "Don't look away from me and say, 'O.K. we have to do this because she says so.' Let's talk about it. If I had all the answers, surely I'd be someplace on high, so when I call you into my office, I'm looking for feedback."
Daniel J. Jowiski, body and assembly operations manager for the Econoline vans, quickly came to appreciate Ms. Kent's style. "She's open to our opinions, and she's accessible," said Mr. Jowiski, who has worked at Ford since 1984 and came to Avon Lake in 1988. "Nobody looks at it as if, 'She's a woman, can she do the job?' It's: 'She's the manager, so she can do the job.'"
Dave Gorman, Ford's vehicle operations manager and Ms. Kent's boss, said that when she was hired seven years ago, "three things stood out about her: she was a female, she had great people skills and she worked in production." He added: "We were extremely impressed with her floor savvy, and she had come from a plant that had a reputation as being difficult to run and she had been good at it."
Mr. Gorman said he only wished there were more Deborah Kents working their way up the assembly line.
"Unfortunately it is difficult to get women to go into manufacturing and to stay in it long enough to succeed," he said. "I wish we knew why that was. But Deborah has had the tenacity. She's a tough lady."
Her straightforwardness seems genuinely appreciated by the United Auto Workers, whose members have always stood out for their toughness and tenacity. After all, this delicate-looking executive with her college degrees and nonunion, salaried position hasn't exactly reached her spacious, carpeted office with the window view by toeing the line in assembly, a windowless bay where one's skills require precision of hand, reliability and old-fashioned teamwork.
"The first thing she did on the first day was to have us walk her through the line," recalled Jesus Schnierle, an 11-year Ford veteran who had arrived at the Ohio plant only a few months before his new boss. "She told us that the only way to know the operation was to watch the process from beginning to end. To learn from the workers down here who do the job."
Lest anyone be mistaken, in no way is Ms. Kent some innocent when it comes to looking under the hood. She has spent more than 17 years in the automobile industry, first with General Motors, then Ford, learning every phase of the job, from manufacturing and quality control to customer satisfaction -- and working her way up without mentor or affirmative-action preferences, thank you.
"One of the first things I did when I arrived here was to hold a meeting with the area managers," she recalled. "I said, 'Let's assume you guys know I got this job because of my competency and proven successes with this company and you're just as happy to have me here as I am to be here, and I won't ever think anything other than that."
The third of nine children, Ms. Kent was raised in St. Louis, but still speaks in slow cadences that reflect her parents' Mississippi roots. She says she got a toughness from her father, Leodas Stewart, a laborer, while her mother, Earline, a housewife, gave her a sense of quiet confidence. Both raised her to believe in her God-given instincts, which serve her well in a job that often calls for spur-of-the-moment decisions with millions of dollars weighing in the balance.
On a recent day, which began at 7:30 a.m. with a review of the night shift's production report and was followed by a walk through the assembly plant, Ms. Kent managed to carry on two to three conversations at once -- one on the telephone, another with a visitor, a third with her secretary -- without losing her train of thought.
But one beep on her pager stopped her in her tracks. A crisis in assembly! How will the new plant manager handle this one?
Workers in Area A were out of alternator belts for the Villagers. Should they stop production and wait for the part or continue production and install the part later? If they waited, production would have to shut down until the part arrived, and that could be a while.
"I've got all these people standing around looking at me like, 'O.K. you're the plant manager. Make a decision,'" Ms. Kent recalled with a smile.
That decision was to send everybody to lunch early and bring the part in by helicopter. Lunch ended at 10:30. The part arrived at 10:23.
The decision was as much a crap shoot as one driven by chance, she later acknowledged. "I can't tell the staff one day that quality is our No. 1 priority," she said, "then say, 'Don't worry about that part, just keep building those cars and we'll put the part on later,' because there was a potential customer concern that would result from that decision.
"When you have to make a pivotal decision," she went on, "that's when the organization looks to see what kind of a leader they got. Does she walk like she talks?"
Ms. Kent does not think that race or her being a woman were necessarily factors in her selection. And she will not allow her status as a "pioneer" to place an additional burden on her round shoulders.
"That would mean I would be second-guessing myself on every decision based on risks," she explained. "I focus on my role as plant manager. I can't help the fact that I'm a black, woman plant manager. I have to make the kinds of decisions based on what my job requires and people can interpret it how they will in terms of race and gender."
HER promotion hasn't come without its sacrifices, however.
A mother of two daughters, Jessica, 14, and Joy, 12, Ms. Kent, who declined to discuss her marital status, decided not to uproot her children from the Detroit community they have called home for close to seven years -- a decision shared by her daughters. She sees them only on weekends and holidays. During the week they are cared for by a nanny, a longtime family friend, and Ms. Kent speaks with them on the phone daily, after homework.
Do they understand the significance of their mother's achievement?
"You know, I really don't know," said Ms. Kent. "They've never said anything about it. That's an interesting question."
It seems odd that she hadn't noticed, for Ms. Kent is as meticulous about details as she is about appearances. On her way through the assembly plant, she will stop to pick up a scrap of paper on an otherwise spotless floor, and gives a once-over to trays of neatly stacked engines.
"It's important not only from an appearance but safety standpoint that parts are stacked orderly and in appropriate places," she explained.
Like a sergeant inspecting the barracks, she walks down the long rows of newly assembled cars, scrutinizing every inch -- inside and out -- to see if they pass muster.
"I'm looking at the metal finish, paint, looking for any streaking, interior trim, and the fit, meaning the margin of gap between points on the vehicle," she said as she moved down the line to the next vehicle. "We measure 42 different points on the car. If we find anything out of spec, we contact the area manager to have it corrected."
And her dedication, apparently, doesn't stop at the plant door. She has been known to approach strangers driving Villagers or Quests and ask their opinion of the car. Once, when she saw a Villager stopped alongside the road, she pulled over to see what the problem was, taking heart that it was merely out of fuel.
"I feel this sense of ownership, responsibility and pride about every Econoline, Villager and Quest on the road," she said. "Particularly since I know we're the only manufacturing plant producing those vehicles. And if something's wrong, I want to know about it.
"Our challenge is to give the customer what they like -- up to the millimeter of the vehicle -- and improve on the things they don't like," she added. "That's the fascinating part about this job."
 
Deborah S. Kent
 
Born: March 10, 1953; St. Louis.
 
 Drives: What else? Mercury Villager and Ford Explorer.
 
 Recent reading: "Zap! The Lightning of Empowerment," by William C. Byham with Jeff Cox. And "Brothers and Sisters" by Bebe Moore Campbell.
 
 A childhood lesson: "If you wanted to have a true falling out with my parents, all you had to say was, 'I did it because so-and-so told me to.'"
 
 Quiet time: "I get up and organize my day between 2 and 4 a.m. I take a nap around 4 a.m. and awaken at 6. By the time I get to the office, I'm ready to go." Without coffee, too.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
An Expanding Base For Hartford Action

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IF Hartford does not strike anyone as a city meant for theater, perhaps it's time for reconsideration.
And we aren't just talking Hartford Stage, which is in the middle of a banner season, or The Bushnell, where megashows and big-time musicals pass through. Next week, for example, Carol Channing will appear in the latest "Hello, Dolly!" tour. 
 TheaterWorks, too, a modest professional company is in boom time. "We own the building," reads the announcement being distributed to audiences. Though major fund-raising from individuals, corporations, foundations and state grants is ongoing, the purchase by TheaterWorks, now in its ninth year, is effectively an offering of rehearsal and office space to small arts organizations.
Company One has found administrative asylum upstairs in TheaterWorks' art deco home at 233 Pearl Street and a performing sanctuary at the Cathedral Theater a few blocks away at 45 Church Street, across from Hartford Stage. The surcease from the nomadic life came "after looking all over town for space," as the company's managing director, Wendee Greene, put it.
Company One's new lease on life is reflective of what appears to be a newly vital theater consciousness in Hartford.
The enterprising company, which has boldly produced plays about porpoises and film noir, not to mention an opera by Gertrude Stein, is recovering from economic constriction and a budget cut from $250,000 in 1992-93 to $97,000 for the current curtailed season. It is now putting on its sole full 1994-95 production, "Women in the Kitchen."
The trimmed budget also allows for 20 rehearsed script-in-hand readings of contemporary plays at lunchtime in a series known as Play With Your Food, which is just how Company One began 11 years ago.
"Bringing us back to our developmental beginnings can make us fiscally sound and assure that we serve our mission of producing new works," Ms. Greene said. Readings are held on the second and fourth Fridays of each month at 12:30. The number for more information is 233-4588.
With frugality, minimalism and expanded exposure in mind, "Women in the Kitchen" is conceived and packaged to tour. "We can pack our kitchen installation into a truck and fit it into most spaces," said Maxine Kern, the artistic director of Company One.
Next week the show will play at the performing space in the now-closed G. Fox department store. It is a five-part program by black writers consisting of two one-act plays, "Casualties" by Allison West and "Poof" by Lynn Nottage, as well as a solo performance piece, "Black Bitches Brew," in three sections, by Jake-ann Jones.
In "Casualties," two grandmothers are sitting in the kitchen, talking about the lives they sacrificed for children who now perceive them as ignorant, yet asserting that they are not victims.
"Poof" is a surreal comedy about a physically abused woman who musters the courage for verbal revenge on her unseen husband. He goes poof -- a case of spontaneous combustion, leaving a huge pile of smoking ashes in the middle of the kitchen. "It is a magical dispelling of abuse," in the words of Ms. Kern. What to do with the man's ashes is the concern of the wife and her neighbor upstairs.
The interweaving performance piece by Ms. Jones is a narrative poem wherein the kitchen, a sacred place, a power place, is perceived as metaphor for woman's contemporary search and ancestral connections. "My mother's kitchen is not my own" is the piece's recurring refrain.
Sarah Edkins's set design is of a real kitchen equipped with a refrigerator and a stove on which a stew is cooking. It is set against a collage of photographs by Phillip Fortune depicting children in a nearby housing project as well as painted images of classical and contemporary black women.
"We're committed not to social consciousness alone but to new plays and new forms that address the contemporary life concerns of underserved voices of artists and audiences. So it's not a mistake that we're featuring women African-American playwrights," Ms. Kern said.
Ms. Greene added, "I've been in Hartford five years now, and I see people on the downtown streets in the evening. For the past few years, there were none. It's a resurgence, a revitalization."

GRAPHIC: Photo: From left, Jake-ann Jones, Carla Dean and Frances McAlpiine Sharp at Company One in Hartford. (Thomas Giroir Photography)

HEADLINE: City vs. County Over Protection Of Watershed

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
PROPOSED rules intended to protect the quality of New York City's drinking water in the Catskill, Delaware and Croton watersheds -- and help the city avoid an expense estimated at $2 billion to $8 billion to build a chemical filtration system mandated by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency -- have drawn criticism from a coalition of municipal supervisors in the northern part of the county and some county leaders.
The coalition includes the leaders of North Salem, Bedford, Pound Ridge, Lewisboro, Somers, Yorktown, New Castle, North Castle, Mount Kisco, Harrison, Mount Pleasant and Cortlandt. 
 "A number of folks have gotten the impression that Westchester and some municipalities are opposed to the regulations," said Patricia Lynn Oliva, who is the county's Planning Commissioner. "That is untrue," she added. "We are in favor of 98 percent of the regulations. But there are certain areas, like septics and diversion to sewage treatment plants, where we would like to see some flexibility. Because the Croton watershed is going to be filtered, we think there can be some exceptions to the regulations.
"Filtration avoidance has nothing to do with Westchester County. The issue boils down to a nonresponse from New York City. The city's position has been, 'Let's have regulations promulgated, and then we will talk about flexibility.' "
The city's water supply system covers about 2,000 square miles on both sides of the Hudson. About 900,000 county residents receive their water from the city's supply, with most of that water coming from the Catskill and Delaware systems. About 230,000 Westchester residents live within the Croton watershed.
Of particular concern to the coalition of municipal supervisors who will be most directly affected by the proposed regulations is the specter of the city's long bureaucratic arm hovering over local decisions.
"It's a classic home-rule issue," said William C. Harding, Town Supervisor of Somers. "Anytime there is a regulatory overlay, it reduces the power of local government's ability to govern, and it reduces our ability to make our own decisions. The most obvious is the economic impact of the regulations. We need to have the ability to grow and develop sanely. We need to provide for land use that in turn provides for a well-planned growth rate."
As an example of how the proposed regulations would affect homeowners, Mr. Harding said, the city has reserved the right to have its inspectors supervise and sign off on individual sewage and septic installations and repairs, a regulatory function that is already handled by town inspectors.
"We don't need another layer of government," Ms. Oliva said. "The closest government is the one that should do it."
But not everyone has reservations about the city's regulations. "In December I called for the county to support New York City's regulations without reservation," said Thomas J. Abinanti, a Democratic County Legislator who represents Greenburgh. "About 85 percent of Westchester's population is served by New York City water. If New York City is not successful in preserving water quality, then we in the county will have to build a filtration plant.
"Why should we take what is some of the cleanest drinking water in the world, let it get polluted and then spend billions of dollars to make it drinkable? Why did we allow such great drinking water to go down the drain? We ought to be siding with the people of this county, not the developers who will make a profit."
What is particularly frustrating for these north county supervisors is the city's apparent inability to distinguish between their concerns and those of the watershed municipalities on the west side of the Hudson.
"No one is a growth freak," Mr. Harding said. "We are pro open space, pro quality of life issues. Somers is very environmentally oriented. We have local wetlands regulations now. I find myself in a very difficult position. I agree with all of the city's conceptual thrusts. Environmental protection is very important to us, and this will go a long way to protect our drinking water supply. But with the functional particulars of enforcing these regulations, it may be impossible or such a burden that I don't know where to come down."
Ms. Oliva said: "Westchester has sophisticated planning and engineering techniques. There is strong environmental awareness on town planning boards. It's very different here."
The city's sluggish response to the county's concerns has also created problems. Ms. Oliva said, "The county and north county municipalities voluntarily came together more than a year ago not to pursue litigation" against the city.
"We have always felt we have had more to gain by collaborating rather than opposing," she continued. "Last February we submitted to the city our proposals for watershed-protection planning and requested that the city enter into the planning process with us. Until recently, the city has totally ignored it. We kept pushing, and two weeks ago, we got a response that eviscerated what we had proposed."
By the end of January, however, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had met and agreed to set up a subsequent meeting to discuss the issue.
Still, the drawn-out process has frustrated those who originally pursued a strategy of cooperation with the city. Mr. Harding said: "We are trying to achieve some closure on this. Because of the lack of movement, the specter of litigation looms larger and larger as the weeks pass."

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York City's water supply system covers about 2,000 square miles on both sides of the Hudson River. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: County Initiatives Gain Social Service Spotlight

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH much of the state and national spotlight has focused on Westchester's success with its workfare program as a means of achieving welfare reform, there are other elements of the county's social services initiatives that are being studied as potential models.
A program known as Front-End Detection, which has been in operation for the last five years, was intended to screen more effectively applications for public assistance. Under this program, social service field investigators assess applicants' actual need for assistance, as part of an overall effort to reduce possible fraud. Existing Home Relief cases are also investigated regularly to determine continuing need. 
 In a related effort, the county's Social Services Department also runs computer matches of its recipient files with other databases, like Internal Revenue Service and unemployment, to determine other sources of income. "This computer system acts in an efficient way so that all incomes are fully accounted for," said Joseph Hogan, deputy commissioner of the county's Social Services Department.
To help women move away from public assistance, the county has also been running a program known as MOMS (Mothers on the Move) for the last few years. Women who are receiving Aid to Dependent Children are eligible to enroll in this two-year college program. Courses are offered at Westchester Community College in Valhalla and the Pace University campus in White Plains. Program participants take classes in specifically targeted marketable areas, like computer and medical technician skills, and are given follow-up placement counseling to find jobs. "Significant numbers of these women are now working and are off welfare," Mr. Hogan said.
Through the use of more specialized residences for homeless families, which provide those families with counseling, training and other services, the county has been able to reduce its spending in this area, to $46.3 million last year from $60.3 million in 1990.
And as an example of the county's continuing effort to make the delivery of social services more efficient and economical, the county recently opened a one-stop district office in Yonkers, where the city's 14,000 clients can receive all services. MERRI ROSENBERG

HEADLINE: How The County's Workfare Set a Trend

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
TWO years ago, William Howard, 35, was out of work and as he describes it, "down on my luck," barely getting by from one month to the next on a welfare check. He has since obtained a driver's license, landed a full-time job and become the father of a son who is now 3 months old.
Similarly, Agnes DiRenzo, 55, was unemployed with few prospects until recently, unable to pay her bills and afraid she would lose her small apartment, the only home she has known for more than 30 years. 
 Mrs. DiRenzo and Mr. Howard, both Yonkers residents, were on Westchester's welfare rolls in the Home Relief program for single adults. Able-bodied and under 60, they are among 7,600 or so people in the last seven years who have been required to work 20 hours a week in exchange for welfare benefits under the county's Pride in Work Program -- an innovative workfare plan initiated in 1988, which is now serving as a model for Albany and Washington.
The debate has been growing in recent months at the local and national levels about whether welfare should remain an entitlement program. Currently, any person who meets Federal eligibility guidelines can qualify for cash assistance in most states.
There has been a shift away from strict entitlement programs, although wide differences of opinion remain on how best to serve the poor. Some government leaders favor workfare solutions, which, like the Westchester model, require able-bodied participants to earn their keep. Others advocate finding solutions to some of the causes of poverty -- teen-age pregnancy and fathers who fail to pay child support, for example.
Despite their differences, there is a consensus among conservatives and many liberals that the current welfare system is no longer working and needs to be redesigned because it is too expensive, unwieldy and often abused by those for whom it was intended.
"Generally across the country there is a very big dissatisfaction with welfare as we know it," said Westchester's Commissioner of Social Services, Mary E. Glass, the architect of the county's Pride in Work Program. "It is a major item now on the national agenda."
Ms. Glass has been hired by Gov. George E. Pataki, on a 90-day assignment, to help revamp the state's welfare system. The Governor on Monday proposed dramatic changes to that system, calling for, among other things, broad requirements for work. Under Mr. Pataki's proposal -- which also tightens eligibility requirements and reduces many cash benefits -- about half of those receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children would be required to work.
In Westchester, single mothers receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children are not required to work, and Ms. Glass said the state would limit its workfare requirement to families with school-age children. She said that it would be too costly to provide child-care assistance for welfare mothers with young children.
The state spent $1.29 billion on Home Relief to aid 311,000 single and childless adults in 1993, and $2.78 billion for 1.2 million people receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Home Relief recipients receive an average of $350 a month plus Medicaid; the average monthly benefit to families on welfare is $577.
Mr. Pataki said his proposals could save the state $343 million in the fiscal year, which starts April 1, and $589 the next fiscal year.
Nationally, it is estimated that $22.8 billion is spent by the Federal Government and the states for cash benefits to 14 million poor people.
In Westchester, where there are 12,884 people receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children and 6,221 receiving Home Relief, the county budgeted $169.6 million for welfare costs this year. Under the Westchester Pride in Work Program -- which was designed by Ms. Glass along with County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke -- employable applicants for Home Relief Aid are required to work 20 hours a week in a government office or nonprofit establishment in exchange for their benefits. They are assigned to a variety of tasks, including removing graffiti, painting park benches, picking up trash and filing documents.
Mr. O'Rourke said he was inspired by his own experiences to develop a workfare plan. His mother, a widow, was blind and received welfare although she worked whenever possible and taught her five children to do the same.
The Westchester program waives the work requirement only if it can be medically verified that a Home Relief applicant is ill or disabled. But prompt medical treatment, paid for through Medicaid if necessary, is required to help remedy the problem. Likewise, drug and alcohol abusers who are temporarily unable to hold a job are required to receive treatment.
Those who are found to be permanently disabled are often eligible for Supplemental Security Income benefits, which in turn represents a savings for the county.
Joseph Hogan, Deputy Commissioner of Social Services, said the county saved $50 million from 1989 to 1994 on Home Relief benefits, because those welfare rolls grew by only 0.8 percent over that period. The county does not have cumulative numbers for those receiving Home Relief.
Mr. Hogan, in describing the strict standards of the Pride in Work program, said: "This is a two-way street. A person has a responsibility that they must fulfill, and we will fulfill our end."
Since the program's inception, 15,982 home relief cases have been closed because recipients failed to meet attendance or performance requirements, and 60 percent never reapplied. The department said some clients probably found employment, but others may have been deterred by the work requirements.
"In any case, there were those that we never heard from again," Mr. Hogan said.
Last year about 13 percent of the 6,700 people on Home Relief were eligible for the Pride in Work program. Others were considered too old, sick, addicted or incapacitated to manage a job, and the homeless were not included because it would be difficult to monitor them.
While some critics of the program cite its limited scope, the Department of Social Services says its success stories speak for themselves.
Consider the case of Mr. Howard. When he applied for Home Relief, he was assigned to the Yonkers Animal Shelter, where he cleaned cages and assisted with the animals' care. Once he received his driver's license and was able to go out to pick up strays, he was offered a full-time job at $19,000 a year.
Now off the welfare rolls, he says he sleeps more soundly and looks forward "to giving my son a life." Mr. Howard is the custodial parent for his infant son.
Mrs. DiRenzo also found full-time employment through the Pride in Work program. The Department of Social Services first assigned her to the Yonkers Community Health Center to perform clerical duties. She has since become a supervisor of records there and earns $16,000 a year, which is "not that much," she said, "but I keep my head above water."
The county has also introduced a fraud-detection program, which sends investigators on unscheduled field visits to check out all Home Relief clients, unlike other counties that only conduct spot checks. The county spent $1.7 million from December 1993 to November 1994 to pay for 38 investigators and closed 1,925 cases out of 8,377 at a saving of $9.4 million, Mr. Hogan said.
Investigators found that some recipients did not live where they said they did, had income they had not revealed or were receiving other benefits, like Supplemental Security Income.
In all programs over five years, the county says that it has closed 18,911 cases and saved $63 million by reforming the welfare system.
But despite Westchester's apparent successes, Rachel Leon, a spokeswoman for the Hunger Action Network of New York State, a nonprofit advocacy group for welfare recipients, said the county had "one of the worst track records."
A report by the organization cites the Westchester Department of Social Services for problems in a variety of areas, including, among other things, not providing adequate transitional child care and failing to treat clients with dignity and respect.
And Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from Harrison, said that in general she was skeptical about "all the rhetoric and simplistic answers" lately on welfare reform.
"I want to know how these programs affect people's lives," said Mrs. Lowey, who is chairwoman of the Congressional Caucus on Women's Issues. "To talk glibly about cutting back when those programs will severely punish children will not work."

HEADLINE: Baymen Rejoice As Sweet Bay Scallops Return

BYLINE: By MARY CUMMINGS 

 BODY:
AFTER lean times that lasted almost 10 years,East End baymen are celebrating a bountiful harvest of bay scallops.
"Incredible" is a word that comes up when baymen and others in the seafood business speak about the season that opened in October and runs through the end of next month. 
 Before 1985, when the algae blooms known as the brown tide infested East End waters, the small sweet bay scallop -- a delicacy prized not just locally but also in fancy restaurants in Manhattan and beyond -- was a mainstay for baymen, the fishermen who make their living off the fertile breeding grounds of Long Island waters.
Harvests fluctuated from year to year, but demand always seemed to outpace supply, and baymen traditionally dropped everything to go scalloping, at least in the early weeks of the season.
At the height of the brown tide in 1986 scientists found concentrations of the microscopic plant that makes up brown tide as high as 2.5 million cells a milliliter, or 10 times the level at which scientists believe other marine life begins to suffer. The condition turned waters a coffee brown and crowded out or suffocated other marine organisms. Thousands of acres of eelgrass, an important habitat for juvenile fin fish and shellfish, died when the blooms blocked out sunlight.
When the brown tide did not appear in 1988 members of Green Seal, an umbrella organization of baymen's associations, started to plant a million quarter-size seed scallops from Fishers Island in waters off Orient Point, Hallock's Bay and Northwest Harbor.
But a series of disasters stymied the efforts to restock the waters. In the first year, the scallops starved to death, the brown tide wiping out the algae and plankton they eat as well as the eelgrass in which they nest. Next predatory starfish and spider crabs ate the winter seedlings. Then some juvenile, or immature, scallops disappeared. Weeks later they were found about a mile away.
Bay scallops were once as synonymous with Long Island as ducks and potatoes, constituting an industry of $1.5 million to $2 million a year to the baymen. To counter the tide, organizations and government agencies undertook a variety of reseeding efforts.
Seedings began in 1986, with the shipment of Long Island scallops to Maine for spawning. The "bugs" were then sent to Fishers Island, where they grew until mature enough to be reseeded in the Flanders Bay-Peconic Bay system. The State Urban Development Corporation and Environmental Conservation Department, with Suffolk County, financed the project, providing more than $200,000 over a four-year period.
A marine specialist with the Cornell Cooperative Extension Suffolk County office in Riverhead, Christopher Smith, said another reseeding program, which concentrated on the western Peconic area, received Federal financing through the Peconic Estuary Program after the Peconics' acceptance into the National Estuary program in 1992. Initially financed with $50,000, that program has been given an additional $76,000 for more seeding and research.
When the brown tide spread through the bays, the baymen stopped scalloping.
"The scallops disappeared in one year," said Ed Warner Jr. one of the few baymen who continue to work full time.
"In 1986 there was probably not a live scallop anywhere in the bay," added Mr. Warner, who learned his trade on Shinnecock Bay from his grandfather and father.
Mr. Warner, who has a degree in marine technology from Suffolk Community College, said he was on the water year-round, "from sunrise to sunset most days." He continued to harvest scallops in Shinnecock Bay at the end of last month, although the supply was nowhere near what it had been in October.
He estimated that in the course of the season 1,000 of the 30-inch-wide scallop dredges that baymen drag from their boats had been back and forth over the bottom. Of all the bays, Shinnecock was perhaps the most bountiful when the season opened.
"The first couple of days you just shoved them into the basket," Mr. Warner said. "That is when it was good. Now you pick through the mud."
Nearly four months into the season, on a winter morning that dawned with snow flurries, Mr. Warner was on the water again, sorting through the eelgrass, mud, rocks and shells that each of his 10 dredges brought up from the bottom.
Moving quickly, he picked out four or five mature scallops from each load, pitched the debris overboard and heaved the dredge back into the water. Any immature scallops in the mix were returned to the bay, which was otherwise perfectly still. Mr. Warner appeared to have the waters all to himself.
"Any time in the first weeks there would have been 50 other boats," he said. Back then, he said, the daily limit of 10 bushels a bayman. or 20 bushels a boat, could be harvested in a few hours.
His goal that day was to fill his bushel basket three times, he said, a harvest that he was counting on to net him $150. He estimated that his 22-foot craft, the Privateer, would consume 30 gallons of fuel plus two quarts of oil, narrowing his profit margin.
Jon Semlear, a bayman and Southampton Town trustee, said fishermen were receiving $7 a pound for scallops at the end of January. Earlier, when the harvest was at its peak, the price had dropped, to $4.50.
The owner of Cor-J Seafood in Hampton Bays, Jim Coronesi, said a bushel of scallops might yield as few as three or four pounds of meat or as much as 10 pounds. He said that his wholesale price in late January stood at $8.50 a pound and that scallops were retailing for about $10. The wholesale price had dropped as low as $5.50 when they were at their most plentiful.
Back then, consumers who had seen prices soar to almost $20 a pound in previous years were feasting after the famine. They were paying $6.50 a pound.
This season was "the best we have seen in probably 15 years, especially in Shinnecock," said Mr. Coronesi.
Southampton, in general, did especially well, according to Mr. Semlear. Supervisor Hudson B. (Hoot) Sherman of Shelter Island also reported an exceptional season, noting that scallops were not only plentiful in local waters, but were also bigger than usual.
In Southold, Bay Constable Donald Dzenkowski called it a banner year for scallops.
A trustee of East Hampton, James McCaffrey, sounded a lone slightly negative note. Mr. McCaffrey said that "state waters were very good," but suggested that the yield from town waters had been disappointing.
State waters generally open a few weeks before the creek areas and interior harbors, which the towns have controlled since the colonial era.
Mr. Dzenkowski said the improvement in his area had been gradual, though this year's yield was "a lot more than expected."
The towns' seeding programs are often cited as contributing to the recovery. This year, a trustee of Southampton, Scott Strough, the trustees are planning to place one million seed scallops in town waters at a cost of $25,000.
East Hampton operates a a hatchery to provide seed clams and oysters, as well as scallops.
Seeding, by all accounts, improves the odds considerably. But Mr. Warner said luck also played a major role in producing the bumper crop. Not only were there no signs of the brown tide, but the infestation that drastically reduced the scallop population after 1985 apparently killed its predators, as well.
"The scallops are back, but not the predators," he said. "And there is eelgrass. Mother Nature treated us well."
Scallops nest in eelgrass, which helps keep them off the bottom and hidden from predators.
Because the causes of the brown tide remain largely unknown, no one can say if and when it might return. Moreover, seeding scallops "is not like a farmer's planting potatoes," Mr. Warner said. The larvae, which float in the water for 14 days before developing, "can end up anywhere on the Island," he said. The weather at the time of spawning can also significantly affect the scallops.
Despite the seeding, Mr. Warner said, he is concerned about the next season. He said he had not spotted enough babies this year to indicate a good crop of mature scallops in October.
Mr. Semlear agreed, saying: "Next year we're not going to have that many." Seeding "enhances spawning stock," but in the end "it's the luck of the draw."
Scallops that escape predators and the risk of burial by shifting sediments typically live 18 months, spawning once, sometimes twice. Among the variables that affect them, Mr. Semlear speculated, two dry summers, with little runoff to carry pollution into the waters had probably helped pave the way for the crop this year.
Conditions appear to have been less favorable for the scallop population that will reach maturity in time for next season, he said.
Should next year yield a poor harvest, the only acceptable substitute for aficionados of the Long Island bay scallop is the one from Cape Cod. "Last year we bought a lot from Martha's Vineyard," Mr. Coronesi said. "You could not tell the difference."
This year there was no need to supplement the local harvest, which also outstripped the competition in size. "Our scallop seems to be a lot bigger," Mr. Coronesi said, referring to the firm adductor muscle, known as the eye, which is the edible section.
China is also producing scallops of the same genus and species, according to Mr. Coronesi. They are inexpensive and very good, he acknowledged, but are less desirable, because they are only available frozen. As for the Southern, or calico scallop, it is inexpensive and plentiful, he added, but its size and shape make it uneconomical to open by hand, and it loses much of its flavor when it is steamed open.
The market has shown that people will pay more for the real thing. There were even times, Mr. Warner acknowledged, when the bay scallop scarcity worked to a bayman's economic advantage.
"That first year, when they were paying $16 a pound, if you got eight or 10 pounds a day, you could actually make more money," than when they were plentiful, he said.
Yet it was tough. "When you're only getting a bushel a day," he said, "mentally it's hard to go out there."
This year, especially with the mild weather, the mood is entirely different. "I'm 35 years old," said Mr. Warner, adding that he has been on the water since he was 8. "I learned to do anything that can be done on the water, trap in spring, gill net in summer, catch clams, oysters and eels.
"I could do anything. But the good scallop season is a boost in the arm for me. For a full-time bayman it's a real help. It means I can go to work and I don't have to worry about it. It's a little bit of job security."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SHEEPSHEAD BAY;
Fishing-Boat Owners Are Caught Between City Hall and the Deep Blue Sea

BYLINE: By JOHN DESANTIS 

 BODY:
"Fresh fish! Fresh fish here!" Frank Russo's voice is clear as the winter sky, hawking piles of brilliant silver mullets on the foredeck of the Pastime Princess on Pier 3 in Sheepshead Bay. A Russian woman tries to bargain and he shoos her away. "She wants fresh fish for cheap," Mr. Russo explains.
Alan Dresner says, "The whole economy here is built on fish." Mr. Dresner, 44, is the owner of the 90-foot Apache V, another of the bay's 18-boat fleet. "I don't have to put up with the rest of the planet most of the time because I'm not there." 
 From April to December, the boats carry fishing parties to the Atlantic coastal waters, where humpback whales and sportive dolphins frolic and blow within sight of the World Trade Center. In winter, some deckhands, like Mr. Russo, make what they can selling fish they catch. But the fishermen fear their way of life could be a way of the past because of a soft economy and a city government they say treats them like second-class citizens.
"The boat owners have had a very tense relationship with the city dating back to La Guardia," said Councilman Anthony D. Weiner, referring to the city's condemnation of old, rickety wooden docks decades ago. Back then, the fleet paid the bill for new docks, and they were certain the cost would drive them out of business. It didn't.
Two years ago, the city spent $13 million to rebuild the piers, lay new concrete and, for the first time, run electricity. Last year, the Department of Parks and Recreation took over responsibility for the piers from the Department of Ports and Terminals, and promptly proposed a 40 percent increase in docking fees over three years. The fees currently average $10 a foot per month. Under the proposal, a 90-foot boat, average for a fishing vessel, would have to pay the city $15,120 annually, up from $10,800.
"This is a brand new facility," said Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner. "There had not been an increase in many years."
But the boat owners cried foul. With Mr. Weiner as intermediary, they stated their case to Mr. Stern, and the city responded by offering a 10 percent increase for one year. The owners accepted and have been paying the new rate since Jan. 1.
"We'd like to encourage the return of the tour fishing industry to that area," Mr. Stern said. "I think it's wonderful that New York City has a fishing village. After all, we're a port, we ought to have a fishing village."
Many boat owners are reluctant to reveal how much they earn. The boats take out anywhere from 20 to 150 people, charging between $10 and $50, depending on the length of the trip (half day or full day) and the season. That's an affordable day trip, said one boat owner, 78-year-old Mike Scarpati, "for the guy who makes the least amount of money." Some, he said, make a few dollars by selling their catch.
Among obstacles to the business, owners cite a decline of interest in fishing among young people and the proliferation of auto thefts in the area, which drives away clientele. And, they say, there is another, costly type of theft at pierside: in this case, the culprits are turkey-sized herring gulls.
"I'd rather fight with the gulls than fight with the city," said another fisherman, Mike Parascandola. "At least with the gulls, sometimes you win." JOHN DESANTIS

International
 A day after the United States imposed trade sanctions against China, some American companies said that they were preparing to switch production from China to sites in other Asian nations, while others waited and said that they expected a resolution of the dispute. [Page A1.] 
 For the better part of a year, China's leaders, notably President Jiang Zemin, have assumed that President Clinton was willing to overlook a great deal in trade, human rights and other issues. But that strategy has repeatedly proved wrong. [A1.]
 As India emerges from 40 years of socialist economics, American companies have become leading investors in many areas, from power plants and telephone systems to ventures that will provide new choices in breakfast cereal, computers and soft drinks. [D1.]
 
The Economy
 After 15 months of robust growth, the American economy is beginning to slow. But no one yet knows whether the slowdown will turn out to be only a lull or the beginning of a slide toward much slower growth, if not recession. [D1.]
 As President Clinton lays out a five-year budget plan today, including a bid to shave $144 billion more from Federal spending, the Republican-led Congress is preparing to raise him several hundred billion dollars. [A1.]
 Farm subsidies are center stage in a political battle in Congress like few before. [A1.]

And health care executives said many hospitals would be under even greater pressure in 1995 if Congress enacted proposals that would slash spending for medical care for the elderly and poor. [D1.]
