HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newsprint Costs Trouble Newspapers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The price of newsprint, a commodity that is usually uninteresting even to newspaper publishers, has climbed faster in recent weeks than ever before -- and faster than newspaper executives had predicted.
A metric ton of newsprint that cost $469 in 1994 was up to $552 in January. If announced price rises hold up, the price will jump to $600 in March and $675 in May, for a total increase of 37 percent this year. Newsprint often accounts for 20 percent or more of a newspaper's costs. 
 The sharp jump in newsprint prices, the second-largest expense for American newspapers after salaries, has suddenly made newsprint interesting: to save money, newspapers from coast to coast are cutting the size of their staffs, the amount of news in their publications and even the width of their pages.
As the pace of price increases has accelerated in recent weeks, strong newspapers have revised budgets to try to protect profits. Weak ones have begun to worry about whether they can survive several years of high newsprint prices. And throughout the $45 billion newspaper industry, executives have begun asking why the cost of their primary raw material is rising so rapidly.
"There is no way for newspapers to recover these costs this quickly from advertisers or consumers," said Fred Drasner, co-publisher of The Daily News in New York.
Newsprint is sold in metric tons. Large newspapers use hundreds of thousands of metric tons of newsprint annually. For example, it takes more than 300,000 metric tons of newsprint to produce the daily and Sunday New York Times every year.
Financial analysts and experts on the newsprint and newspaper industries say the explanation for the speed of the price climb is the law of supply and demand, which has been enacted with a vengeance because an unusual combination of factors has exaggerated the price swing typical of commodity markets.
After sustaining huge losses in recent years, when newsprint prices were at recent lows, the newsprint industry is trying to catch up, and at the same time, the costs of raw materials used to make newsprint have climbed sharply.
Demand for newsprint is up worldwide. As newspapers recover from the recession, they are selling more advertising and printing more pages. But supply is not growing because mills have been running near capacity for years.
Virtually no new mills are planned in North America and because of recent financial troubles among paper producers, it is not clear that they would be able to raise the capital needed to build new plants, which can cost $300 million or more.
In addition, there is increased worldwide demand for paper of all kinds, which is keeping foreign producers busy filling their own newspapers' needs. This demand has driven up the price for old newspapers, which are increasingly recycled to produce more newsprint.
In one measure of what has happened to the market for recycled paper, the New York City Department of Sanitation recently announced a crackdown on thieves who, before the garbage trucks arrive, steal curbside bundles of old newspapers to resell them.
The profit-starved state of the newsprint industry is the biggest reason that newsprint prices have been climbing so quickly. Depressed prices in the early 1990's led to multimillion-dollar losses at virtually all the 30-odd newsprint manufacturers in the United States and Canada.
"If you consider that this industry lost its shirt for three to four years, they are very greedy to recapture the massive losses," said Bruce Kirk, a paper industry analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company.
Chip Dillon, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said part of the reason for the large losses was a huge miscalculation by paper company executives: When newspapers were thriving before the stock market collapse in 1987, many mills decided to make large investments in new equipment.
It can take two or more years to add newsprint production. By the time many of the new machines were ready to churn out newsprint in 1989 and 1990, newspapers had begun to be hit by the recession that brought the largest decline in advertising since the Depression.
When newsprint consumption dropped, profits disappeared for most mills, which were still paying for their modernization. Several companies shut down older machines or switched them to production of other grades of paper. The effect, analysts say, was that North American newsprint capacity remained about the same despite huge costs for new construction.
Now that demand for newsprint has returned, paper executives and their lenders are wary of repeating the pattern. Some also say that changes during the last several years have also made expansion more risky for them.
Some executives say they are concerned that the demand for newsprint may weaken because of fundamental changes in the newspaper business, like growing challenges from electronic media. Others say environmental regulations, particularly in Canada, have made construction of new plants more costly.
Perhaps the most significant change that is slowing expansion of newsprint capacity, some analysts say, is the growing reliance on recycled paper as a raw material. The American Forest and Paper Association, the principal trade group for United States mills, says recycled materials constitute 46 percent of the nation's newsprint.
In the days when trees were the only source of the pulp used to make newsprint, expansion was easy to plan: mill executives would select a site in the forest and build. But now that what paper makers call the "urban forest" has become a prime source of raw materials, paper company executives must deal with the complexity and expense of construction, transportation and waste disposal in populated areas.
In recent weeks there has been no hotter topic inside publishers' offices than the cost of newsprint. The newspaper industry is awash in rumors about deals. One company is said to have made a special deal for a boatload of newsprint, while another is said to have wrung a special promise of supply from a mill. Publishers say privately that they are trying to lock in supplies without appearing so desperate that they embolden suppliers to send prices up again.
A strike at three mills on the West Coast has added to the atmosphere of general anxiety by shrinking North American newsprint production an additional 4 percent, by some estimates. That has stirred rumors that some newspapers are in danger of running out of newsprint.
Some publishers have quietly spoken to each other and consulted their antitrust lawyers about whether they can somehow challenge the unwritten pricing rules of the newsprint market.
Newsprint producers have generally matched price increases announced by rival companies, like Abitibi-Price Inc., a Canadian company that has been aggressive with its pricing policy. The New York Times Company recently transferred a minority interest in a newsprint mill to Abitibi-Price, the majority owner, but continues to own a minority interest in another newsprint mill.
Spokesmen for the paper industry have not been particularly sympathetic to the complaints of their newspaper customers. Virgil K. Horton, the vice president of the paper group at the American Forest and Paper Association, said newspapers should have planned for the inevitable price increases. "Let me ask you if they complained when prices went down," Mr. Horton said.
Some newspaper executives acknowledge that the psychology of scarcity has taken hold. That mindset is helping push prices up as publishers try to edge each other out to get newsprint supplies at the lowest possible cost.
"Everybody is trying to get as much paper as they can to beat the March price increase," said William J. Hee Jr., director of purchasing for Gannett Supply Corporation, which buys newsprint for the newspapers owned by the Gannett Company. "And then they are going to try to get as much paper as they can to beat the May price increase."

HEADLINE: Slowdown Is Raising Questions

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
After 15 months of robust growth, the American economy is beginning to slow. But no one can know yet from the scant emerging evidence whether the slowdown will turn out to be only a lull -- followed by another stretch of strong growth -- or the beginning of a slide toward much slower economic growth, if not recession.
Auto sales and home construction, the two pillars of growth, remain mostly intact. But once built, the new homes now sell less quickly. Many retailers find they must offer bigger discounts to keep people buying. Manufacturers say that while they are still very busy, new orders are not as numerous. And last month, for the first time since 1992, the unemployment rate rose. 
 "I am hearing in the past two months comments that I had not heard before, comments that new orders are flat or slowing," said Ralph Kaufman of the National Association of Purchasing Managers, which conducts a monthly survey of its members, who are all in manufacturing. "Some of the managers feel that the higher interest rates are starting to take hold."
Yet the hard data is far from conclusive. "It is mostly straws in the wind, a sense things are not going as well as they had been," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office.
No straw seems more noticeable than the stockpiles of merchandise and materials piling up at stores and warehouses. Virtually every forecaster expects stockpiling to be less robust this year than last, helping to slow the economy. The slowdown could turn into a recession in the unlikely event merchants decided, more or less simultaneously, that they had stockpiled much more than they could sell. After all, their inventories in the last quarter reached three times standard levels -- and a reluctance to order more goods would have a ripple effect.
Factories would be forced to cut back, layoffs would rise, consumer confidence would falter and the economy would slow sharply. That sequence has been a major cause of recessions in the past.
"The most important ingredient for a slowdown is in place," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist.
But right now, the nation's merchants are not talking cutback. "Our inventories are right where we expect them to be," said Harold Ruttenberg, chairman of Just for Feet, a chain of 15 sporting goods stores based in Birmingham, Ala.
Still, some store owners are clearly concerned. "We had a very strong Christmas season, but my inventory is higher than I want," said Craig Cooper, owner of Bikes to You, a bicycle shop in Grinnell, Iowa. "My suppliers are eager to extend credit to me to get their goods into the store. Ultimately, as the retailer, I have the final say, but they are offering discounts and deals on credit that I just cannot refuse."
Economic recoveries in the United States typically alternate between strong growth and lulls. That was the pattern during the recovery that lasted through most of the 1980's. A lull now would be the second in the current recovery, which began in March 1991, with the end of the last recession. The first came in the winter and spring of 1993.
The Federal Reserve, of course, has been encouraging the onset of a lull by raising interest rates steadily since last February, and most recently last week, when it raised the lending rates it controls by half of a percentage point -- hoping to slow the economy by damping demand for housing, cars and other goods and services purchased on credit. Less growth, in turn, would keep inflation from rising.
So far 15 months of strong economic growth have produced neither rising inflation nor rising wage levels, the principal source of inflation. But Fed officials and many economists say that absent a lull, in which economic growth would decline to an annual rate of 2.5 percent from the current 4 percent, both phenomena are just around the corner.
In their view, the economy is too much like it was in 1988 and 1989. In those years, labor costs and the inflation rate rose after a period of low unemployment and weak inflation very much like today. Although the unemployment rate rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in January, to 5.7 percent, many economists consider that rate still low enough to produce labor shortages and wage pressures.
"Economists are no better than the readers of history," Professor Gordon said, "and the big historical caution is that in 1988 and 1989, inflation did accelerate."
The antidote, rising interest rates, is beginning to have an effect and, if precedent holds, the effect will be even greater in 1995. Home sales, for example, have fallen since October, partly in response to a 30-year mortgage rate that averages 9.1 percent today, more than two percentage points higher than late 1993. And rising rates might help to account for a phenomenon that manufacturers are just beginning to report.
Manufacturing has played an important role in the robust growth. Factories have operated at full capacity, and while wage levels have not risen, overtime pay and bonuses have put spending money in the pockets of tens of thousands of people. But now orders for production several months ahead are no longer growing at their old rate, according to the National Association of Purchasing Managers.
The Mexican crisis might also be a factor. Exports have been an important source of new orders and sales, but that market might shrink this year, partly as a result of the Mexican crisis, with its ripple effect. Latin America accounts for more than 20 percent of this nation's overseas sales.
Still, American consumers have been at the heart of the strong economic growth, and the rising interest rates have cut only slightly into their buying habits, says Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center.
Mr. Curtin cites several reasons. What with overtime and more people holding jobs today than a year ago, the total income available for spending has risen, even though individual wages have not. Then, too, Mr. Curtin's surveys show that most consumers do not expect a recession, despite the rising interest rates, and for this reason, their fear of layoffs has diminished.
"There is some point when consumers will judge that current Fed policies have crossed some threshold and the rising rates will cause a recession," Mr. Curtin said. "That threshold has not been crossed yet."
Most important, consumers have adjusted. While in the past, they would have cut spending abruptly if their wages failed to rise faster than the inflation rate, today they keep spending as long as their wages manage to keep up with inflation.
"There was a sense in the 1970's that if you were not gaining ground on inflation, you must be losing ground; you could not stand still," Mr. Curtin said. "That attitude is no longer true. There is greater acceptance now of slowly improving living standards."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Well, Mr. President, Baseball Hasn't Caved

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Bill Clinton, the well-meaning, part-time baseball fan and full-time President, should know this: Be careful what you wish for. You may get it.
The President last week wished himself into the position of being the last line of defense between a sane resolution to the six-month-old baseball strike and the repugnancy known as replacement baseball. Clinton felt that the force of his public pressure would drive baseball's Hatfields and McCoys out of their well-fortified bunkers and into a new, desperately needed relationship. So he told them to make a deal. Or else. 
 Fortunately, or unfortunately, for Clinton, or else time is here. So nonexistent were the chances of a negotiated settlement yesterday afternoon that Bill Usery Jr., the super mediator brought in by the President, pulled the plug on all pretense. Unless the two sides reach agreement by 5 P.M. today, Usery will come up with his own recommendation, as requested by Clinton.
No use wasting time they no longer had, Usery said when he announced yesterday afternoon that he would kick-start his part of the process. Not when the parties were moving in inches when they needed to move in yards, he said.
So the White House moves to war footing. More than 30 years ago, Bobby Kennedy joyously ran through his brother's White House yelling, "Steel has caved! Steel has caved!" after President John F. Kennedy forced the steel barons to back away from inflation-causing price increases.
Usery, for all his months of trying, couldn't get baseball owners or players to compromise, let alone cave. And now, no matter how adamant the President is in this matter, who knows whether Usery will ever get to take his own victory lap?
Remember, the biggest bat that Clinton could yield in this situation is binding arbitration. He cannot do that without the cooperation of Congress -- a Republican Congress.
"Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich, they're the big players here," a lawyer familiar with the Administration said yesterday, referring to the Republican leaders in Congress who the Democratic President would have to appeal to. "Without Republican support, there's not much that can be done."
Still, Clinton isn't about to give up. That much was clear when he welcomed Usery and Labor Secretary Robert Reich into the Oval Office for 45 minutes last night to again underscore his desire to see the strike settled by this evening.
As Usery subsequently suggested at a news conference, it's a big order. It may well end in defeat, assuring that the ultimate decision will fall into the hands of the President.
Then the question becomes this: How long can baseball command the Commander in Chief's attention as he seeks bipartisan support and the elusive solution to this mess?
Remember, Clinton is to get Usery's best recommendation today, the same day that debate begins on his national budget proposals to Congress.
"Baseball is still the toy department," said the lawyer who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The President of the United States has an awful lot more serious things on his plate."
Serious things with, perhaps, simpler solutions. Baseball's gridlock, after all, puts Washington's to shame. The game has become a quagmire where economic solutions seem permanently out of reach because of all the moral indignation, anger and angst that the union and the owners have carried on their backs for almost a quarter of a century.
"I mean, just imagine," the lawyer said, "the President of the United States all but ordered them to settle and they ignored him. That's pretty remarkable."
It's also baseball. At its intractable worst.
A perfect example occurred in the last few days when the National Labor Relations Board convinced the owners to kill the divisive salary cap. Yet in the wake of that action, the players and owners simply dug in deeper around their big-tax, little-tax positions, remaining a billion dollars and a trillion light years apart.
A host of government mediators didn't move them in August. Usery, the ace in that sport, obviously didn't make them budge, either. And to date, neither has a President who has had some success calming the menacing nuclear-charged rhetoric of North Korea, ousting Haitian dictators and banning assault weapons in spite of fierce gun-lobby opposition.
Nonetheless, Bill Clinton remains the nation's last best advocate for baseball. For baseball's sake, let's hope he isn't devoured by the ugliest battle for supremacy over the national pastime to date.

HEADLINE: Israel Eases Palestinian Entry Ban, but Refuses to Scrap It

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Although slightly loosening its restrictions, Israel reaffirmed an entry ban today that has kept tens of thousands of Palestinians from work since Islamic suicide bombers killed 21 Israelis two weeks ago.
At its weekly meeting, the Government agreed to a list of exceptions to a territorial closing that has prevented Palestinians from crossing from the West Bank and Gaza Strip into Israel, even to reach Arab neighborhoods in Jerusalem that they regard as their cultural and business centers. 
 Among those who will now be allowed into Israel are doctors, nurses, teachers and some merchants -- at most, a few thousand people, Israeli officials said. The change does nothing for the more than 50,000 Palestinian laborers who depend on jobs in Israel and whose sudden unemployment deprives the hard-pressed territories of their main source of cash.
No one in the Israeli Government denies that the territorial closing -- the latest of many imposed, lifted, then reimposed during the last two years -- inflicts hardship on ordinary Palestinians.
That theme was echoed by the United States Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, who led a trade mission to Israel today on a swing through the Middle East.
Asked about the ban at a news conference, Mr. Brown said, "It is evident that it is devastating economically to the West Bank and Gaza not to have entry." But he said Washington was "very pleased" by the easing of restrictions, calling it "an important first step."
The unemployment rate is estimated at 60 percent in Gaza, and officials in the self-rule government there protest that Israel's entry ban imposes collective punishment on many for the deeds of a few extremists. It also weakens the political standing of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization and head of the self-rule authority, they argue, and fuels support for militant Islamic groups like Hamas.
Israeli officials acknowledge those points. Agriculture Minister Yaacov Tsur, citing the "severe conditions" in Gaza, said today that the Palestinians there "do not have an alternative yet to jobs in Israel."
But he and other officials say their priority is to make Israelis feel safe after a series of bombings during the last 10 months that have claimed 56 lives inside Israel. The way to do that is to keep the populations separated as much as possible, they say.
"Separation" has become a dominant slogan lately for Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who says that his long-range goal is to end Israel's dependence on cheap Arab labor, notably in construction work and farming. But it will not be an easy task, he said several nights ago as he talked about the "tragic complexity" of the entry ban.
As an example, he cited a phone call that he received on Jan. 22 from the parents of a young soldier killed in the suicide attack earlier that day, at a bus stop in central Israel. The new restrictions on Palestinian laborers had just been imposed, and the parents were asking Mr. Rabin to make an exception for a Gazan in their employ so that they could keep their business going while they went to their son's funeral.
"I got goose bumps," the Prime Minister said, pulling at the flesh on his left arm. He gave his permission in this case, he said, but added that he wanted such reliance on the territories to end.
A demand that the entry ban be lifted is expected to be high on Mr. Arafat's list at meeting he and Mr. Rabin are supposed to have on Thursday at the northern edge of the Gaza Strip. On Tuesday, Israeli and Palestinian negotiators are supposed to resume talks on future elections in Gaza and the West Bank, which is supposed to be preceded by a redeployment of Israeli forces.
But for now the focus seems less on achieving a breakthrough than on keeping the talks from collapsing in the prevailing atmosphere of uncertainty and mutual mistrust.
Israeli officials accuse Mr. Arafat of not doing nearly enough to keep Islamic violence in check. Since he is their negotiating partner, though, they are also trying to keep from giving an impression that he has done nothing.
An unidentified senior Israeli official, presumed to be Mr. Rabin, was quoted in Israeli newspapers today as saying that Mr. Arafat's security forces had prevented three or four anti-Israel attacks in the last two weeks, including a suicide bombing.
Still, fundamental differences on security are evident. This was reflected in conversations between Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat last week when they took part in a four-way summit meeting in Cairo with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Hussein of Jordan.
In those talks, reconstructed in the Israeli press today based on accounts from the unidentified senior official, Mr. Rabin complained that the Palestinian authorities had arrested only 7 Gazans from the Islamic Holy War group after the latest bombing while Israel rounded up more than 200 people in the West Bank.
Mr. Arafat, in turn, accused Israelis of selling guns to Hamas and Islamic Holy War militants. "Arms sales are taking place in the West Bank -- I can provide you with addresses," he was quoted as saying.
Mr. Rabin reportedly replied: "If Hamas has more guns than you, are you the right partner for the agreement? How can you exert control if they are stronger?"

HEADLINE: With Sanctions Set, Companies Rethink Their China Plans

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A day after the United States and China imposed trade sanctions on each other, some American companies said yesterday that they were preparing to switch production from China to other Asian nations, while others waited and said they expected a last-minute resolution of the dispute.
Many American executives expressed support for Washington's decision to impose 100 percent punitive tariffs, to take effect in three weeks, on more than $1 billion of Chinese goods ranging from silk blouses to cellular telephones. But they also said they were fearful that their investments in China would prove disastrous if a trade war broke out and their competitors in Europe and Asia were to receive favorable treatment from the Chinese. 
 And Beijing took measured steps yesterday to heighten those fears.
"There are countless markets abroad for Chinese products," Foreign Trade Minister Wu Yi said at a news conference in Beijing, when asked if Chinese exporters would suffer from $1.08 billion in American import tariffs. "Other countries are happier about this."
While the punitive tariffs imposed on China for its purported piracy of American software, movies and music are larger than any used in Washington's numerous trade disputes with Japan and Europe, they nonetheless affect only about 5 percent of the total trade between the United States and China, which reached $46 billion last year.
And the American tariffs seem to have been imposed with an almost surgical precision so as to minimize the effect on American businesses and consumers, penalizing Chinese goods that are available from other nations.
Determined to emphasize that the dispute is but one small piece of America's relations with China, Washington yesterday sent to Beijing, as scheduled, an advance team from the Energy Department. The Americans are preparing for talks this month in which Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary hopes to persuade China to spend as much as $8 billion in the United States to satisfy its growing need for energy.
The Chinese also seemed to retaliate with moderation. Imposing 100 percent tariffs on American-made video games, compact disks cigarettes and alcohol, Beijing left untouched grain and the major American industrial sectors, though the Chinese did suspend negotiations over major automotive projects with Detroit's Big Three auto makers.
"I was surprised by the Chinese reaction; I thought it would be much worse than it is," Robert Dernberger, professor of economics at the University of Michigan's Center for Chinese Studies, told The Associated Press. "The restrained nature of the Chinese reaction indicates they want this resolved."
Because the sanctions announced on Saturday do not take effect until Feb. 26, to insure that goods already shipped are not affected, nearly three weeks are available to negotiate a settlement. No talks are scheduled, but after Washington announced similar sanctions against China last year in a dispute over textiles, a deal was reached in five days.
"We've seen this before and the Chinese have caved in at the 24th hour; I think Mickey Kantor thinks they will again," said Gib Ford, chairman and chief executive of Converse, which is based in North Reading, Mass., and makes athletic shoes. "This is very typical of the Chinese."
At some of the largest American companies, the watchwords were wait and see.
"Nothing we're doing now is threatened," said Herb Linnen, an AT&T spokesman in Washington. AT&T has sold about $500 million in telecommunications equipment in China during the last two years and has invested $200 million in joint ventures with the Chinese.
China is the largest and fastest-growing market for telecommunications equipment in Asia and is expected to invest $40 billion for new equipment between now and 2000. "We're competing with the Japanese, French and Germans," Mr. Linnen said.
And at the Boeing Company in Seattle -- the company is America's largest exporter -- Lawrence W. Clarkson, senior vice president of planning and international development, said: "We're not directly affected, but it's highly unlikely that we are going to get any new orders as long as the trade situation exist. We're obviously disappointed it came to this but naturally support Ambassador Kantor's decision. You can only hope that the parties can quickly get back to the table and reach an agreement before the sanctions are officially in place."
In the last two years, one out of every seven airplanes delivered by Boeing has gone to an airline in China, and the company is scheduled to deliver 18 aircraft to China this year.
"While airplanes and components are not on the list," Mr. Clarkson said, "our concern is what could happen if the trade war expands."
But other companies are more vulnerable, like athletic shoe makers, which have numerous factories in China.
Some American executives said the disruption would not be severe, because the shoes selected for the American tariffs are mostly children's and women's footwear that make up small parts of their business.
"China has been a key country of origin for some of our production," Mr. Ford said, noting that Converse planned to produce three million pairs of shoes in China this year and "our preference is to leave production in China." He said Converse, "in anticipation of problems," had made plans to move some production from China to Indonesia, Taiwan and Thailand. But shoes made in Taiwan may cost American consumers more because of higher labor costs, he said.
New Balance, which makes 30 percent of its shoes in China and the rest in the United States, said it was prepared to switch to Taiwanese production. "It'll be a disruption, and prices may go up," said Jim Davis, chairman of the Boston-based company. "It's not a huge logistical problem to shift production, but just a gearing up of personnel."
Donna Gibbs, a spokeswoman for Nike, the industry leader, said production would be shifted from 10 Chinese factories, which produce 28 to 30 percent of Nike's footwear, to Indonesia, where 12 plants make Nike shoes. She described the impact of the tariffs as "very minimal."
Among companies that suffer most directly from Chinese piracy, support for the American position was strong.
The Microsoft Corporation in Redmond, Wash., has complained bitterly that much of its software is pirated, and a spokeswoman, Beverly Bird, said the company would like to see China close the 29 factories that manufacture pirated compact disks, and enforce copyright laws vigorously.
The 29 factories produce 75 million pirated compact disks annually. To rein them in the central Government would need the compliance of the powerful local governments that approved the factories in the first place. Since they pay no royalties, the factories are extremely profitable.
Robert Holleyman, president of the Business Software Alliance, a trade group in Washington, said the rate of software piracy in China was about 98 percent, with losses to American software publishers estimated at $351 million a year.
"While a copyright law does exist in the People's Republic of China," Mr. Holleyman said, "it is not effectively enforced."
He said the alliance supported the tariffs announced Saturday but hoped the outcome would be a resumption of negotiations and eventual protection for American software companies.
At the Chrysler Corporation, which has been negotiating for two and a half years to start a $1 billion joint venture to build mini-vans in southern China, executives were fatalistic. The talks on the project have run into many obstacles, said Tony Cervone, a Chrysler spokesman, adding, "We have not had recent talks anyway."

HEADLINE: Farmers Brace for Stormy Debate Over Subsidies

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Kan., Feb. 1

 BODY:
This wind-bullied land, the center of America's wheat empire since the late 19th century, is bracing for a political fight over farm subsidies like none before.
Of the 73 new Republicans in the House, 33 are from rural agricultural districts and have been at the vanguard of the movement to cut the Federal budget, curb regulations, and limit the Government's authority to interfere in business. 
 This more conservative Congress is writing a new farm policy law this year, the first since 1990. In every previous law since the first one was written during the Great Depression, the paramount provision has been a contract in which the Government helps to decide how much a farmer can grow in exchange for guaranteeing to pay farmers a set price for their crops.
Now, the central question is: What arguments will farmers and their conservative champions in the House and the Senate use to win support for one of the most costly and intrusive Government programs of all?
Here in Reno County and in more than 2,000 other rural counties across the country, perhaps the only thing as enduring as the great vaulted sky is the money that blows out of Washington to support farm incomes. In the last 10 years, $149 billion has been spent on crop subsidies nationwide, nearly $8 billion of that in Kansas alone. Farm economists say Kansas farmers typically gain $20,000 to $40,000 annually, far more than is received by families on welfare.
Those indisputable facts of economic life in Kansas and other farm states are now fueling a battle in Congress that is being sharpened by deepening concern about costs.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Representative Pat Roberts, a fellow Kansan who heads the House Agriculture Committee, have both been advocates for cutting the Government, returning more power to the states and balancing the Federal budget. But both lawmakers have protected farm subsidies for years, particularly for growers of wheat, the state's most important crop.
In a speech last month in St. Louis to the American Farm Bureau Federation, Mr. Dole, who has helped shape farm policy since he entered Congress in 1961, was guarded as he discussed the coming debate, saying only that "some cuts will be made" in farm programs.
Mr. Roberts has been more voluble. In an interview, Mr. Roberts defended the subsidies, saying that nationwide they had decreased to $10.2 billion last year from $25.8 billion in 1986. Still, Mr. Roberts's 66-county Congressional district, which includes Reno County, received $5.45 billion in farm subsidies over the last decade, more than any other, according to the Environmental Working Group, a policy analysis organization in Washington.
Mr. Roberts vowed to defend those payments and his constituents from being a target for budget cutters. "Farmers have already given at the office," he said. "I will make sure that if there are additional cuts, they are not disproportionate on farmers."
Opposing the Kansas lawmakers is Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican who heads the Senate Agriculture Committee. He said in an interview that farm subsidies were justifiably seen as a test of Republican resolve.
"We are being taunted with it almost daily," said Mr. Lugar, who owns a farm. "Will we act? I would guess that subsidies will be cut at least in half over the next five years. But I also see phasing out subsidies in five years, if not completely then in such a way that there is only some minimal safety net."
Here in Reno County, where most of the 1,540 farms receive crop subsidies, growers are nervous even as they acknowledge being somewhat embarrassed about accepting Government handouts.
"It's like insurance," said Ronald Jacques, who votes Republican and raises wheat and other crops on a 2,000-acre farm 10 miles west of here. "It's not all of your income by any stretch, but it's a help. It's something you can count on."
Budd Fountain, a retired employee of the United States Department of Agriculture who raises 1,100 acres of wheat here and received $14,000 last year in subsidy payments, said: "If they totally did away with the program, there would be some problems. As long as Government is involved in setting the supply, then the farmer has no choice because he can't make his money from the market. The price is too low."
Whatever decisions are made by Congress this year, the outcome will have a significant effect in counties like this one, which received $148 million in farm program payments over the last decade, according to the Environmental Working Group.
No policy ever devised by Congress has such power to shape so much land and so many lives. It is a policy that farmers eagerly accept even as they complain about the rules, the bureaucracy and the Government's control of grain markets.
When the Government called for maximum production of grain in the 1970's, farmers here cut down trees that served as wind breaks in order to plant every available acre.
In the 1980's, when storehouses bulged with surpluses, the Government paid farmers to plant grass to conserve topsoil, making a quarter of the flat land here look like it did over a century ago, before the prairie grasses were plowed under.
But taking so much land out of production also reduced the amount of seed, fertilizer and farm equipment being used, and limited the demand for storage space in the big white grain elevator hugging the railroad tracks here. Farm supply stores went out of business, and the grain elevator was sold.
In interviews here this week, farmers said they would gladly give up subsidies if the Government also agreed to withdraw from setting supplies. By controlling the supply, the program controls demand and thereby prices.
Without being able to control supply, they said, farmers have little choice but to take the handouts because the prices they have received at the market for wheat -- from $3.02 to $3.72 over the last decade -- are below the cost of producing it.
The program for wheat, which is similar to those for corn, feed grains, rice and cotton, pays farmers the difference between the market price for their crop, and a higher "target" price that is set by Congress. Last year, the difference was at times as much as 80 cents a bushel. The wheat program cost taxpayers $2 billion, about a fifth of which went to Kansas growers.
As political pressure mounts to dismantle the programs, farmers say, consumers do not recognize the advantages of having stable grain supplies -- and therefore stable prices -- for such items as meat, bread and milk in the supermarket. If the programs were ended, they add, grain supplies and prices would be much more erratic.
"One thing overlooked by Democrats and Republicans in this debate is that farm programs are really designed to give consumers cheap food," said Jim French, who with his wife, Lisa, raises cattle and wheat on a 1,200-acre farm in Partridge, just north of here. "But we've seen the handwriting on the wall. In the early 1980's, we earned $25,000 one year from the program, the most we've ever had. That was our profit. Last year, our check was a little over $6,000."
Farmers in this region offer many ideas about how to alter the farm programs to reduce their costs and make them more useful.
Nathan Stillwell, a cattle rancher and wheat farmer who lives just outside town urges the Government to relax the strict rules, and give farmers more flexibility to decide what to plant and how much. That will save money, he says, and produce benefits for the environment because it will allow farmers to rotate crops more easily, a soil-saving practice that the programs have discouraged.
Others, like Mr. Jacques, said that dismantling the programs altogether would be possible as long as other countries also ended the practice of subsidizing their farmers. Grain markets are influenced by international factors and as long as other countries continue to subsidize their farmers, Americans will be at a disadvantage, he said.

LENGTH: 1493 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. MANEUVERS TO TOP PRESIDENT IN PARING SPENDING

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
As President Clinton lays his five-year budget on the table on Monday with a bid to shave $144 billion from Federal spending as its centerpiece, the Republican Congress is preparing to meet that -- and trim several hundred billion dollars more as well.
The prospects of negotiating such a maneuver are loaded with political as well as fiscal implications. And they will become clearer in the weeks ahead, when House Republicans unveil the first of two installments of their budget: a five-year package of $200 billion in tax cuts and another $200 billion in spending cutbacks to pay for them. 
 But even then, the Republican-controlled Congress must still find $400 billion to $500 billion more in spending cuts over the next five years, if its central political theme -- putting the Federal budget on a "glide path" toward perfect balance by 2002 -- is to be taken seriously.
Democrats predict that they cannot do it without either wrecking the economy or stirring a revolt among voters whose favorite programs will be gutted. White House officials noted today that the House had already fallen behind schedule on its promise to produce a first round of budget cuts. And powerful Republicans who won Congress by promising to cut pork have begun to complain publicly about their discomfort at supervising a slaughterhouse.
"We've already given at the office," Representative Pat Roberts, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee, said recently about calls for more cuts in farm programs. "I don't know how much is enough."
But in almost the same breath, he allowed that his committee "will meet our budget agreement" and produce whatever cuts were agreed on. Republican leaders insist other committees will, too.
"I will not dare say that every one of us is that committed," said Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, who heads the Appropriations Committee, "but the people in leadership are. The fact is, we've all been here for a good run for various lengths of time, and because of that, we recognize that if we're going to practice what we preach, this is the time."
What the Republicans are preaching -- and the reason they need so many billions of dollars in spending cuts -- is their political pledge made during last year's campaign season to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Mr. Clinton has charted a course of $200 billion-a-year Federal deficits for years to come. By contrast, the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, and many Senate Republicans committed themselves last fall not just to wiping out annual deficits, but to giving voters a tax break, as well.
The Congressional Budget Office says balancing the budget and giving voters a tax cut will cost up to $1.4 trillion by 2002. Republicans say that if they can cut spending by $700 billion between now and 2000, that should be enough to insure the budget will balance two years later, in 2002.
If the Republicans are holding the details of their plan close, its broad outline is no secret. Senators and representatives say in interviews that they hope to cut projected Federal spending by $600 billion to $700 billion through 2000 -- with about 50 to 60 percent of that money coming out of entitlement programs like Medicare, Medicaid and food stamps.
The House expects to vote on the first $200 billion of those cuts in March, as part of the tax-reduction provision of the Contract With America. According to calculations by the House Budget Committee, first published last month in The Boston Globe, more than $110 billion of those cuts would be made by committees that control benefit programs like Medicare and food stamps, and $75 billion would come from programs like road building, environmental protection and education. (The biggest entitlement program, Social Security, has been put off limits by both the Republicans and the Democrats.)
House leaders plan to roll out their remaining cuts in April or May, in the Republican version of the five-year budget blueprint that Mr. Clinton releases on Monday. The Senate, on the other hand, will propose all its cuts at once in its version of the Clinton budget, to be issued at about the same time as the remaining House cuts.
This will probably touch off a summerlong debate, leading to a final Republican budget that Congress can send to Mr. Clinton by August. That will give the President time to veto it before going on his annual vacation, one Republican legislator said last week, since there is certain to be much in Republican spending plans that the White House will not like.
The chairman of the House Budget Committee, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, and his Senate counterpart, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, made that point today. Speaking on the ABC News program "This Week," Mr. Domenici said Mr. Clinton's new budget "took a walk" on cutting the growth of mandatory spending like Medicare, which he said could go broke in six years.
Mr. Kasich, who appeared on the same program, concurred. "The bottom line is, they refused to deal with entitlements and we are going to have to, if we are going to get to zero over seven years," he said.
At 60 percent of all Federal spending, entitlements -- those programs that automatically pay benefits to anyone who qualifies -- are the toughest and largest challenges to the Republican budget cutters. They may parcel some entitlements to the states in the form of block grants for welfare, leaving the states to try to run the programs more efficiently.
But the House may also try this year to reorganize Medicare and Medicaid, two of the biggest and most politically sensitive entitlement programs. Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the Ways and Means Committee, which oversees Medicare, has refused to discuss his plans. But Mr. Livingston said in an interview that a health care bill that reworks Medicare should not be ruled out this year.
Mr. Kasich and others talk openly of some sort of plan that either forces wealthy retirees to pay more for Medicare benefits or prods them to buy private insurance. Republicans also talk of moving more retirees into managed-care medical programs, which they say are cheaper to run. But that would limit retirees' choice of doctors, a politically unattractive move, and many experts say the short-term savings would be small.
And the Republicans need big savings in that area. Medicare premiums now pay less than a third of the program's actual cost of $175 billion a year; the rest comes out of the Government's general fund. Mr. Gingrich has said he wants to cut the annual growth of Medicare to 7 percent from the current 10 percent, saving about $140 billion over five years.
The Republicans are also looking at big cuts in the other large chunk of the budget, the $275 billion or so a year that goes for discretionary spending on things like roads, schools and the environment. They have ruled out further significant cuts in the Pentagon budget, the other major domestic spending program.
Speaking today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Livingston said the House would probably not propose this year to wipe out an entire Cabinet agency or two, as many had suspected. But he forecast vast cuts and the termination of entire spending programs and smaller agencies, well beyond the 138 programs that Mr. Clinton's budget proposes to end, and the one agency -- the Interstate Commerce Commission -- that he would abolish.
In an interview last week, Mr. Livingston suggested that his committee would take aim first at any program that was not an essential Government function. And while he mentioned some that were beloved by many Democrats -- including financing for public television and radio -- he said that need, not politics, would be the criterion for judging them.
"Those sorts of programs are just pittances compared to what we have to do across the board," he said. "But if we can't do it to programs that are nice to have, we certainly can't do it to essential functions of Government. So nice-to-haves are as good as gone."
Republicans are also considering some mathematical changes that will make their job easier, including revising the Labor Department's method of measuring inflation, the Consumer Price Index. The index is used as a yardstick for annual cost-of-living increases for many Federal programs, including Social Security, and many economists contend that it overestimates the rise in prices.
Shaving back the index would shave back the growth of all those programs, and while the short-term savings would be small, the savings over a few decades would reach well into the billions of dollars.
Those are big figures, but Republicans say they are starting to become comfortable with them.
"When we did these numbers before," said Representative David L. Hobson, Republican of Ohio, "nobody really cared. They knew it wasn't going to be law. Now they're looking at what we're doing."

LENGTH: 1279 words

HEADLINE: Is China Stumbling?;
Some See Mishandling of Ties With U.S., Raising Questions About Deng's Successor

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 5

 BODY:
After a series of policy miscalculations by China's Communist Party leadership, Chinese and Western officials are beginning to ask whether President Jiang Zemin is mishandling the nation's relations with the United States.
Despite an initial success last May -- President Clinton's decision to determine China's trade privileges independent of its human rights record -- Mr. Jiang, 68, has made one stumble after another in dealing with Washington, these officials say. 
 To be sure, Chinese leaders feel that Mr. Clinton shares much of the blame. But for the better part of a year, the Communist Party leaders, led by Mr. Jiang, have assumed that the President was willing to overlook a great deal in trade, human rights and other points of contention for the sake of a policy of "strategic engagement" with China.
But time and again, that strategy has proved wrong, as it has over China's continuing copyright violations, which have now drawn the largest trade sanctions ever announced by Washington.
As a result, some experts believe that Mr. Jiang is increasingly vulnerable to an early challenge as the designated heir of Deng Xiaoping, the country's ailing, 90-year-old paramount leader.
"I think the question of the handling of the relationship could become an issue in his leadership," a resident Western diplomat said this weekend.
He added that Mr. Jiang might be especially vulnerable "if the relationship is going badly" because this can only embolden future rivals to argue that he is "not up to the legacy of Deng Xiaoping because he is not showing the strategic vision to keep this relationship from going completely off the rails."
The litany of political errors began in the wake of Mr. Clinton's decision in May to grant China low tariffs and "most favored nation" trade privileges for its exports to America despite a crackdown here on dissent that included the reincarceration of the country's best-known democracy campaigner, Wei Jingsheng.
In the ensuing months, Mr. Jiang gave Mr. Clinton nothing in return for the political capital the President risked by ending five years of trade pressure aimed at winning freedom for thousands of political prisoners here.
Mr. Jiang assumed that human rights would disappear from the diplomatic agenda with Washington, diplomats reported.
But it has not.
Then in September, Mr. Jiang began calling on Mr. Clinton to make a state visit to China, something that would enhance Mr. Jiang's image as the paramount leader-to-be. But the White House demurred largely because it believes China has done nothing to ease repression.
In economic relations, China insisted that the United States make a "political decision" to back China's entry into the World Trade Organization. But China's pressure tactics backfired and galvanized the West behind the principle that China could enter the trade body only on a sound economic basis, mainly by lowering its extensive trade barriers.
And most recently, China has mounted personal attacks on United States trade negotiators sent to bring an end to copyright piracy in China. This, too, has backfired.
Taken together, such missteps indicate that Beijing has lost its way in dealing with the country that it most identifies as the key to bringing about China's modernization over the long term.
Michel Oksenberg, a Presidential assistant on China in the Carter Administration and now president of the East-West Center in Honolulu, said that "the Chinese after the M.F.N. decision overestimated their leverage" with Washington.
"There has been a hubris in China," he added, "growing out of their very rapid economic growth plus an element of nationalism and a belief that their market is so attractive that they can really influence the domestic politics of other countries. But I think they have overestimated."
Thus it is not enough to say, these analysts suggest, that China's leaders, seized by the political transition that will be brought on by Mr. Deng's death, are paralyzed or acting with extreme caution. These are undeniable factors in explaining Chinese behavior, the experts say, but the policy mistakes also suggest a political clumsiness at the top.
Some Chinese say Mr. Clinton has also missed opportunities to move the relationship forward. "I thought Mr. Clinton missed a big chance when he did not come to China," said Yuan Ming, a Beijing University specialist on the United States. "That would have been a big step forward to improve the relationship and to establish a working relationship with China as a strong partner for America, certainly not as a threat."
A former Ambassador to China, James R. Lilley, who recently visited Beijing, said there were whispers among Chinese officials that the ailing Mr. Deng feels that Mr. Jiang is mismanaging the all-important American relationship.
Where Mr. Deng in his heyday was at ease negotiating one on one with President Carter, touring America and even wearing a 10-gallon hat at a Texas rodeo, Mr. Jiang refuses to have personal telephone contact with Mr. Clinton, preferring to read from cablegrams with the advice of his Foreign Minister. When Mr. Jiang and Mr. Clinton have met, the exchanges have been stiff, with Mr. Jiang often reading from note cards.
Mr. Deng's youngest daughter and biographer, Xiao Rong, who insists that her father is "content" with his choice of Mr. Jiang, recently stated in an interview the blunt reality of Mr. Jiang's exposure.
"The real question," she said, "is not whether my father's health is good or bad right now, but rather whether the people who have taken over the leadership since his retiring have done a good job or not."
By posing this question, Ms. Xiao was making the point that it has yet to be answered.
Mr. Jiang, for his part, knows that his leadership is untested and he, therefore, must walk a careful path between hard-liners who want him to stand up to foreign "meddling," and reformers who want to quicken the pace of dismantling the economic legacy of orthodox Communism.
Some hard-liners in the party, Mr. Jiang recently complained, have branded him a "capitalist," a word that carries a condemning connotation dating to the 1950's, when Mao Zedong purged economic liberals from the party.
In this season of political transition in China, more may be on the line than Mr. Jiang's management of relations with Washington.
A book titled "Looking at China Through the Third Eye" that circulated in China last year rattled the party establishment and was banned because it struck at the heart of Mr. Deng's reforms, asserting that they have created "volcanic" forces of disparity and surplus labor that could explode in rebellion. The book's authorship is uncertain.
A Western diplomat said: "I think this may be the issue. Is there a debate in the top leadership as to whether China is trying to do the wrong thing?"
The wrong thing, he explained, is China's attempt to enter the World Trade Organization by stripping away the protected markets of its state-owned industries, by reforming its banking system by acknowledging colossal bad debts, and by forcing money-losing state enterprises into bankruptcy.
If the consequences of these steps are lost markets, production shutdowns, large-scale layoffs and social instability, that could spell catastrophe for the Communist Party.
For now, Mr. Jiang is neither defending himself nor articulating a new vision of relations with the United States. Soon he may have a new challenge, as powerful voices in Congress press for stronger American support for Taiwan.
"What we see at the moment is an inability by the Chinese to give any signals," a diplomat said.

HEADLINE: Lingering Shadow -- A special report.;
Rebels Still Torment Cambodia 20 Years After Their Rampage

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHOEUNG EK, Cambodia, Feb. 2

 BODY:
It is said by Cambodians that anyone who doubts the truth of what happened here in 1975 must make the pilgrimage to this tiny village. Because in what was once a fertile rice paddy on the outskirts of Phnom Penh, the capital, there is today a grisly and convincing memorial to the frenzied slaughter that erupted across Cambodia 20 years ago this spring.
One visitor needed no convincing at all. 
 "I was a boy during the Pol Pot times, and I still remember how they would line up people -- 10 people, 100 people -- and tie their hands and shoot them in the back," said Buntha Krouch, a 25-year-old Cambodian-American whose Cambodian mother-in-law had insisted that he make the trip to Choeung Ek.
"You don't forget this."
Mr. Krouch, who fled Cambodia in 1979 and is now an engineering student at Pennsylvania State University, stood transfixed before the Government-built ossuary here: a giant glass pagoda encasing 8,985 human skulls.
These were the victims of the killing fields of Choeung Ek, one site of the death camps organized by the Khmer Rouge, the Maoist-inspired guerrillas whose reign of terror over Cambodia began with the capture of Phnom Penh in April 1975. The skulls were unearthed from deep pits that are still littered with shards of bone and frayed strips of cloth.
Two decades after they launched their final assault on Phnom Penh and set in motion a crazed peasant revolution that killed hundreds of thousands and perhaps more than one million Cambodians, the Khmer Rouge and their notorious leader, Pol Pot, continue to torment this nation with violence, and with at least the threat of another savage takeover of Cambodia.
Much has changed here in those 20 years: a 1978 Vietnamese invasion that forced the Khmer Rouge back into the jungle, a 1991 peace agreement that was supposed to end the civil war between the Khmer Rouge and the Vietnamese-installed Government, a 1993 election that established the first freely elected Cambodian Government. But Cambodians face a threat that is hauntingly reminiscent of that era.
Then, as now, Pol Pot, the French-educated Cambodian born with the name Saloth Sar, stalks the dense forests, waiting for his chance to grab power from a Government perceived by much of the public as corrupt and incompetent. Then, as now, his most effective weapons are the terror that he can unleash almost at will in the countryside, and the hypnotic loyalty of a handful of ruthless disciples. Then, as now, Pol Pot has powerful friends in the outside world who want him to survive. Today, those friends are in neighboring Thailand.
Some diplomats and certainly many Cambodian officials argue that the Khmer Rouge are growing weaker and more isolated as thousands of Pol Pot's troops have defected.
"The Khmer Rouge will definitely disappear," Foreign Minister Ung Huot said. "It is only a matter of time."
But others find it difficult to be so hopeful, predicting that the guerrillas will plague Cambodia for years, possibly another generation -- certainly until Pol Pot is dead.
 
Attacks
Khmer Rouge Still on Offensive
 There are no reliable reports on the whereabouts of Pol Pot, although the shadowy 66-year-old guerrilla leader is believed by foreign intelligence agencies to be living in comfort, shuttling among rebel camps in western Cambodia. Scholars are convinced that Pol Pot remains a dedicated Marxist, and that he holds to a dream of another violent peasant revolution in Cambodia.
His army today has an estimated strength of 5,000 to 10,000 soldiers, far smaller than when his forces overran Phnom Penh in 1975, which the Khmer Rouge named Year Zero because it was supposed to mark a rebirth of Cambodian history. But while the rebel army is too small today to pose any immediate threat to the capital or other large cities, it is capable of wreaking havoc on the Government elected in 1993.
In recent weeks, the Khmer Rouge have attacked dozens of farming villages in western Cambodia, killing at least 100 people, burning homes and crops and slaughtering farm animals. Tens of thousands of people have been made refugees in the area around Battambang, the country's second-largest city, and the Government is struggling to feed them in the midst of a nationwide drought.
The United Nations-sponsored elections produced a coalition between the party associated with King Norodom Sihanouk, who has been returned to the throne after most of two decades in exile, and the party associated with the Cambodian leaders installed by Vietnam in 1979.
The new Government is trying to revive Cambodia's shattered economy -- living standards are among the most miserable on earth, with most Cambodian adults earning less than $1 a day and with widespread malnutrition and disease -- by enticing foreign investors and tourists here.
"Our policy is to develop the country in order to stop the Khmer Rouge, and the policy of the Khmer Rouge is to try to stop the development to destroy us," Foreign Minister Ung Huot said.
The Khmer Rouge want the foreigners out, hoping that an exodus of investors and tourists will insure the Government's collapse. The rebels have begun to attack foreigners, reportedly offering a bounty of $8,000 for every Westerner who is caught or killed. They have taken responsibility for the killing of an American tourist last month near the ancient capital of Angkor. While the Government blames bandits for that killing, there is no doubt that the Khmer Rouge were responsible for the deaths of several other Westerners last year, including three backpackers slain in September after rebels attacked a train in rural southern Cambodia. The three young men -- an Australian, a Briton and Frenchman -- were killed with blows to the head, long the preferred method of execution by the Khmer Rogue because it saves bullets.
 
The People
Rebels Praised As Uncorrupt
 It is difficult to overstate the fear that the Khmer Rouge still arouse among Cambodia's seven million people. It is the rare Cambodian who cannot identify several family members who died during what is commonly known here as the Pol Pot time. It is common to find Cambodians who lost everyone. Most of the victims of the Khmer Rouge died from starvation or disease. Thousands of others were executed in killing grounds like Choeung Ek, targets of Pol Pot's paranoid fear that anyone with an education or a special calling -- doctors, teachers, businessmen, painters, dancers, Buddhist monks -- posed a threat to a revolution meant to glorify peasants.
One sign of how seriously Cambodia's new Government has failed to inspire confidence is that some Cambodians are quietly expressing support for some of the ideals of the Khmer Rouge, sometimes even for the organization itself.
"The Khmer Rouge are not corrupt, and that is why some people still support them," said a 23-year-old student at the University of Phnom Penh, who like many of his classmates did not want his full name used for fear of retaliation from the Government.
"In the Khmer Rouge time, they killed many people, but there was no corruption," he said. "And corruption is the most terrible problem that we have now."
He sat with other students around a formica table in the library of an English-language training program that is being underwritten by the Government of Australia. Apart from the classrooms renovated by the Australians, the university is a moldering wreck. The campus buildings were all but dismantled by the Khmer Rouge as part of their vicious purge of intellectuals. In the minds of many students, the slaughter of the 1970's is associated with Pol Pot and his senior henchmen, not with the entire organization. The Khmer Rouge are seen as savage, but they are also seen as nationalistic and honest.
"The corruption is destroying Cambodia, and I think maybe that is a much bigger danger than the Khmer Rouge," another student said. "Pol Pot may be bad, but some of the other Khmer Rogue leaders are not so bad."
Corruption allegations dog most senior officials in the Cambodian Government. Despite paltry government salaries, many live lives of luxury, disappearing on short notice for holidays in Hong Kong, Europe and the United States. The number of expensive European sedans prowling the potholed streets of Phnom Penh defies any explanation other than corruption.
"Today's Cambodia crawls with greed and corruption at the highest levels," warned Julio Jeldres, founder of the Khmer Institute of Democracy, a human rights group. "Corruption creates resentment and inequality and helps dissatisfied people to fall under the spell of the Khmer Rouge."
The Khmer Rouge have clearly struck a chord with many Cambodians in their endless propaganda, heard in rebel radio broadcasts, blaming the nation's problems on Cambodia's traditional enemy, Vietnam, and on the hundreds of thousands of ethnic Vietnamese who live here.
"We all think that Pol Pot hates Vietnam very much, and we agree with him on that," a 19-year-old university student said. "Vietnam will eat up Cambodia if it can."
 
Foreign Support
Now Thais Help Khmer Rouge
 The Khmer Rouge have outlasted almost every other Communist insurgency in Asia. It is a measure of Pol Pot's tenacity, and the greediness of some of Cambodia's neighbors, that the Khmer Rouge still exist. China, the principal foreign patron of the Khmer Rouge in the 1980's, is applauded by diplomats here for having cut off assistance to the rebels. But there is unending suspicion about Thailand, where elements of the Thai military and dozens of logging and gem companies are reported to continue a lucrative border trade with the rebels.
It does not take much searching along the long dusty stretches of the porous border to find Thai traders who acknowledge that they have ignored the Thai Government's demands that they cut off trade with the Khmer Rouge, who control areas of western Cambodia rich in lumber and gems. The trade through Thailand is thought to bring the rebels millions of dollars, enough to continue the fighting indefinitely.
"I think the world lies about the Khmer Rouge -- they are really good people," said a Thai gem merchant whose workshop is near the Thai border city of Aranyaprathet.
Giving his name as Mr. Vichi, he held up a blood-red ruby that he said had been sold to him by the Khmer Rouge. He admired the gem as it glistened in the harsh sun.
"Why should I care about the internal problems of Cambodia?" he asked. "That is not my country."
The Thai Government denies that it knows of any border trade, and diplomats acknowledge that the Government of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai has done more than any of its predecessors to cut off support for the Khmer Rouge. But diplomats say there is still plenty of evidence showing that the trade continues, although curtailed. Cambodian officials say 16 Thai gem-mining companies were digging as recently as last month in rebel-held areas. Some of the best evidence against the Thais has come from recent Khmer Rouge defectors, who say Thailand remains the lifeline for Pol Pot.
Chea Sari, a Khmer Rouge major who defected last fall after 23 years with the rebels, said: "The Thai support the Khmer Rouge 100 percent. They are like an artery that provides blood to the Khmer Rouge."
 
Changes
Abuses Laid To Local Chiefs
 Whatever the threat, there are foreign investors who remain enthusiastic about Cambodia. Beyond lumber and gem-mining, tourism is promising. The stone temples of Angkor, the ancient capital of the Khmer empire, are the greatest archeological wonder in Southeast Asia, and it is commonly said in the travel industry that Cambodia's small population could support itself largely from the hard currency brought here by tourists.
Despite its battlefield struggles with the Khmer Rouge, the army is encouraged by the recent defection of thousands of rebel soldiers under a amnesty program begun last year. The defectors have reported that while the central command of the Khmer Rouge remains loyal to Pol Pot, the once strict chain of command may be dissolving in parts of the countryside.
"The Khmer Rouge were once a very honest organization," said Mr. Chhum Song, who lost an eye to shrapnel while fighting in 1975. "Everywhere that Pol Pot occupied, it was a good place. No brutality, no violence. And we were all brought together by his principle to stop the Vietnamese, get rid of the Vietnamese."
But he explained that in the early 1990's, the Khmer Rouge decentralized authority, allowing local commanders more power to make decisions. Mr. Chhum Song and other defectors say the result was chaos in many provinces, with Khmer Rouge commanders turning to corruption and indiscriminate violence.
"In 1990, many people in the Khmer Rouge became corrupt," he said. "The commanders would begin to tax the villages, tax them for every tree that was cut down. And even with all this money, there was not enough food for us soldiers."
But none of this, he insisted, is a reflection on Pol Pot -- "Brother Number One," as he is called in the Khmer Rouge -- and his closest deputies.
"There is no hint of corruption about them," Mr. Chhum Song said.
"At the very top of the Khmer Rouge, I believe, there are honest men. They are committed to the same revolution, as always. They do not intend to go away."
