HEADLINE: One-Stop Shopping in the Mini-Bar

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Hotel mini-bars, long a solace for weary business travelers looking for a quiet drink after a hard day on the road, are now becoming veritable self-service bazaars where almost anything that fits inside is available -- for a price.
The usual array of snacks, sodas and spirits is still offered, of course, but nowadays the highly profitable guest-room refreshment centers also dispense vitamins, disposable cameras, condoms and more. And no longer the province of luxury hotels and resorts, mini-bars are increasingly showing up in midpriced hotel rooms -- and even finding their way into economy lodgings. 
 Hotels are expanding their mini-bars, which have been around for 20 years, because they are such money-makers. A can of Coca-Cola, for instance, is frequently marked up to $2.50.
"In-room bars typically account for only 2 percent of the food and beverage turnover, but 20 percent of its profits," said Andreas Jacobs, chairman and chief executive of the privately held Minibar Group A.G. of Zug, Switzerland, which owns several companies in the United States and Canada that sell and install mini-bars and offer consulting services.
Like most hotel managers, David Dressler, room service manager at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York, will not talk specific numbers. But he acknowledges that mini-bars "are a tremendous profit center."
Tastes of mini-bar users once ran heavily to alcoholic beverages, but that is no longer true. Of the top 10 sellers in 1993, colas outsold light beer by four to one, bottled water outsold light beer three to one, and even orange juice was more popular. Hard liquor, while still a mini-bar staple because of its higher markup, did not make the top 10 sales list.
Mini-bars, once no bigger than tiny refrigerators, can now be custom-made for larger spaces, with a section for refrigerated foods and another for snacks and other products. Literary tastes can be satisfied at mini-bars in Chicago's Palmer House, whose current paperback book offerings include "For Love Alone" by Ivana Trump and "Get Shorty" by Elmore Leonard. Mini-bars at Si Redds Oasis Resort in Mesquite, Nev., periodically offer a casino coupon book good for a free $1 wager. Other items available in mini-bars around the country include T-shirts, golf balls, playing cards, hosiery, greeting cards, sunglasses and lip balm.
Condoms can be purchased in the mini-bars of the Mondrian Hotel in West Hollywood, Calif. "Condoms come in our 'care package,' and they're almost as big a seller in our mini-bars as Pringles," said Amilcar Rivera, who oversees the mini-bars in the hotel.
These days, many guests are disappointed if their rooms lack mini-bars. Visitors from Europe and South America, where mini-bars are widespread, are particularly fond of the amenity.
"Until about six months ago we only had mini-bars in about 450 of the 2,400 rooms in our two hotels," said Leora S. Halpern, a spokeswoman for the Sheraton New York and the Sheraton Manhattan. "But so many guests wrote on comment cards that they wanted mini-bars, now we have them in every room."
The mini-bar industry has long been hobbled by the patchwork of state, county and local laws regulating alcoholic beverages. Only eight years ago, such laws effectively banned mini-bars in 32 states. But many obstacles to the sale of alcohol, including alcohol in mini-bars, have since disappeared. They were swept aside by the lure of added tax revenues, the same incentive that overcame objections to lotteries and other legalized gambling in some states.
Some city and county governments in states including Tennessee, Kentucky and Utah continue to ban alcohol sales. What has carried the day in many states, however, is the argument that it is safer to imbibe in a hotel room than to drive back from a bar under the influence.
And it beats getting lost looking for a drinking establishment in a strange town.
As a result of the shift in attitudes, the self-dubbed "refreshment center" industry is euphoric. "We expect to grow 16 to 20 percent a year over the next few years," said Stephen Reid, executive vice president of Minibar North America in Bethesda, Md., a subsidiary of the Minibar Group.
Steve Sunyich, president of Room Systems Inc., a newcomer to the business based in St. George, Utah, said, "We'll probably grow as much this year as the previous four years we've been in business."
The industry, which sold or leased about $80 million worth of mini-bars last year, still has a long way to go. There may be as many as 380,000 mini-bars, but that is only enough to fill about 12 percent of the nation's 3.2 million hotel rooms. No firm numbers exist, but estimates of total sales of items from mini-bars run into the hundreds of millions of dollars.
A handful of industry officials think the potential is most promising in economy lodgings, partly because only 4 percent now have refreshment centers. "A few years ago you almost never found mini-bars in the one- or two-diamond properties," said Kris Rashedi, director of industry evaluations for the American Automobile Association, which ranks hotels from one to five diamonds. "Now you see them more and more."
But the biggest obstacle in the low end of the market is that few guests at economy hotels, most of which rely on automobile traffic, will pay $2 to $3 for a beer when they can buy it for half that price at a nearby convenience store.
Prices of mini-bars vary from about $350 to more than $1,000, depending on the features. Room Systems even installs them free. "We share the revenue with the hotel until we get to a certain level, usually after two or three years," Mr. Sunyich said. "Then the hotels get 90 percent."
While standard brands dominate mini-bars, some hotels also offer regional treats.
The Lowes Vanderbilt Plaza in Nashville sells Goo Goo Clusters, the sinfully delicious concoctions of chocolate, carmel, marshmallow and peanuts that have tickled the palates of Southerners for more than 80 years. Mini-bars in the Anatole Hotel in Dallas stock Texas smoked beef.
The Kahala Hilton in Honolulu, now undergoing renovation, has long carried cookies made in Kauai and potato chips flavored with onions, while the Sheraton Waikiki sells chocolate-covered macadamia nuts. Many San Francisco hotels carry Ghirardelli chocolate and Anchor Steam beer, while the Samuel Adams brew is popular in Boston.
Visitors to hotels at resorts and in New York often find disposable cameras in mini-bars. And hotels frequented by Japanese guests often carry miso soup, Japanese beer, green tea bags and sake.
The Four Seasons in Manhattan sells five kinds of cordials, four fruit drinks, three brands of vodka, two California wines and a partridge in a pear tree (well, all but the partridge in the pear tree).
Prices of mini-bar products are also starting to come down. Some hotels have found that they can sell even more and that guests complain less about high markups.
But hotel guests have found plenty of ways to vent their feelings about the high prices at most mini-bars.
Some guests, for instance, have been known to drain cans of soda and beer by punching a hole in the bottom, or to replace the clear liquor in miniature bottles with tap water. Losses at honor bars, which depend on guests' truthfulness at checkout or a visual canvass of the contents by maids, can run as high as 20 percent.
As a result, more hotels are installing computerized mini-bars that sense when an item has been removed and record transactions instantly, through a cable television channel or an extra telephone line.
Automated mini-bars can also be locked and unlocked at the front desk in order to comply with liquor laws in some states that limit selling hours. The automation also reduces labor costs, because the hotel staff no longer needs to inspect or restock each mini-bar each day.
Still, not everyone is enamored of the high-tech versions. "We used to have them, but no longer," said Keith Miller at the Delta Chelsea Inn in Toronto. "Whenever people opened the door and examined the product, they got charged for it whether they used it or not."
For all the new mini-bar offerings, some places still depend on the tried and true. In Washington, the consumption of alcoholic beverages is much higher than average. Asked why, Mr. Sunyich of Room Systems offered a diplomatic explanation: "Maybe it's because of so many foreign visitors."

HEADLINE: Administration Resists Pressures to Cut Foreign Aid for 1996

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Despite Congressional pressures to cut foreign aid, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that the Clinton Administration planned to keep next year's aid budget at current levels to help the United States maintain its commitments overseas.
In unveiling the $21.21 billion budget for international affairs, down $81 million from the budget approved for the previous year, Mr. Christopher said that aid to countries of the former Soviet bloc would increase modestly while spending on international peacekeeping would fall sharply. 
 Under the new budget -- which represents 1.3 percent of the total Federal outlays -- aid to the two largest recipient nations would remain untouched, at $3.1 billion for Israel and $2.1 billion for Egypt. Mr. Christopher asserted that maintaining aid to those two countries was vital to buttress the faltering Middle East peace negotiations, which he hopes to advance when he meets in Washington on Sunday with the foreign ministers of Israel, Egypt and Jordan as well as a senior Palestinian official.
"The resources that we are requesting are the rock-bottom minimum that we need to defend and advance America's interests," Mr. Christopher said at a news briefing. "Last November's elections certainly changed many things, but they were not a license to lose sight of our global interests or to walk away from our commitments around the world."
By far the biggest cuts in the new budget are for international peacekeeping, an area that Congressional Republicans have singled out for sharp cuts. Mr. Christopher said the Administration was requesting $440 million for peacekeeping for the fiscal year 1996, down $760 million from $1.2 billion the previous year. The 1995 amount was so much larger in part because it included a supplemental $672 million for peacekeeping funds already owed to the United Nations.
Mr. Christopher said the peacekeeping budget was being cut not in response to Republican pressure, but because the $440 million was his best estimate of next year's peacekeeping costs. He said, though, that if a United Nations peacekeeping force remains in Bosnia beyond March 1996, the Administration will probably have to ask Congress for more peacekeeping funds for its share.
Some Republican lawmakers disputed Mr. Christopher's description of the budget as "austere," noting that without the peacekeeping cuts, the budget would be up 3 percent and that the part of the international affairs budget going to foreign aid would be up 6 percent.
Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, said: "When dozens of other programs are being subjected to draconian cuts, I can't support a 6 percent increase in foreign assistance. The subcommittee is going to take a good hard look at the continuation of traditional aid entitlement programs."
But Mr. McConnell said he was pleased that the budget expands military aid and continues programs to promote exports.
Although Republican leaders have criticized the Administration for giving Russia too much aid, the new budget would increase aid to the former Soviet Union to $788 million, from $719 million this year. In an seeming nod to Republican pressures, State Department officials said this increase was directed to countries other than Russia that have undertaken economic reforms, including Ukraine and Georgia.
Nonetheless, Mr. Christopher defended aid to Russia, saying, "Russia's indiscriminate and excessive use of force in Chechnya has certainly dealt a setback to reform in that country, but it has not altered our fundamental interest in helping Russian reformers build a nation that finally is at peace with itself and its neighbors."
Aid for Eastern Europe would increase 33 percent, to $480 million. Craig Johnstone, the State Department's director of resources, plans and policy, said that the focus would shift to the southern part of the region and that $60 million would be used to rebuild Bosnia.
Spending for nuclear nonproliferation and disarmament would rise 61 percent, to $166 million. State Department officials said $22 million would be used for the agreement that seeks to get North Korea to freeze its nuclear program.
The international affairs budget, which includes spending for various agencies, including the United States Information Agency and the Export-Import Bank, calls for increased spending on some of Vice President Al Gore's favorite programs: population stabilization, up 10 percent to $635 million, and environmental protection, up 10 percent to $378 million.
The budget would further Mr. Christopher's efforts to make the State Department a major player in advancing the Administration's anti-crime strategy. It calls for more than doubling the spending for international narcotics control, to $213 million.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Trade Thinly; Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday in thin trading ahead of the Government's debt sales this week.
Dealers typically lighten their inventories of securities before an auction, but the rally last Friday left some market participants debating about how much strength was left. 
 The Treasury's quarterly refinancing this week begins with the sale of $17 billion of 3-year notes today, $12 billion of 10-year notes tomorrow and $11 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
With a Government report on producer prices scheduled to be released on Friday, traders and analysts expect yields will slip in order for the market to absorb the new supply of debt. But after the rally on Friday, some investors are wondering if bonds are overpriced.
"This is an uncertain time for the market," said Kevin McClintock, manager of fixed-income portfolios for Aeltus Investment Management Inc., in Hartford. "Once we get through the auction this week and leave that supply behind us, the bond market could do better for several months, purely based on the flow of funds going into the bond market."
The price of the 30-year bond fell 5/32 , to 9812/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.64 percent, from 7.62 percent on Friday.
Shorter-maturity bills were up a few basis points, while at the Treasury's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, the average rates were mixed.
The average rate of a three-month maturity rose to 5.83 percent, from 5.79 percent last week, with the six-month falling to 6.10 percent, from 6.12 percent.
In when-issued trading late in the day yesterday, yields inched higher. The three-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.37 percent, the 10-year note at a price to yield 7.53 percent and the 30-year bond at a price to yield 7.59 percent.
Treasury prices rallied on Friday after the employment report for January showed clear evidence of a slowdown. But some traders and analysts said yesterday that they were not so sure about the direction of the economy.
 "The economy is not as weak as recent data suggest," said Roseanne M. Cahn, director of the economics department at CS First Boston. She said weak retail sales were misinterpreted, given the strength of employment and consumer optimisim.
Mr. McClintock of Aeltus said: "The economy tends to grow not in a straight line but in spurts. So the question now becomes, 'Is this an intermediate slowing of the economy or is this a permanent slowdown?' "
In the municipal bond market, where money is chasing too few new issues, prices rose for the second consecutive day.
States, cities and other municipalities are scheduled to sell about $1.43 billion of new debt this week, or about twice the amount sold last week.
According to The Bond Buyer, the 30-day supply is about $2.22 billion, or about 60 percent lower than it was at the same time last year.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance for Fifth Straight Session

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Wall Street yesterday continued its rally of last Friday, closing the session with a fifth consecutive advance. But the day's gains were curbed by profit taking in the last hour of trading.
Despite facing a week with relatively few economic reports that move markets, stock prices may rise even further, analysts said. The market had some wildly volatile sessions in January, but finished the month virtually unchanged, so it may be poised for a sustained rally, they said. 
 David Shulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, however, said the recent Wall Street rally was based largely on the assumption that the Federal Reserve was through raising interest rates.
He said that with factory use at more than 85 percent and unemployment less than 6 percent, such a view was flawed because wages and salaries were bound to rise. "Wall Street thinks no one in America is ever going to get a raise," said Mr. Shulman, who thinks the Fed will continue to lift rates.
Indeed, a rally could goad the Fed into action, he said. "If Alan Greenspan sees a roaring stock market, do you think he's going to conclude that monetary policy is too tight or too easy?"
In the short run, the wild card is this Friday's report on producer prices. A recent survey of economists by Bloomberg Business News predicts that the index, a measure of wholesale price inflation, increased four-tenths of 1 percent in January.
Excluding volatile food and energy prices, the survey forecasts a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with two-tenths of 1 percent in December. If the producer index comes in higher, the development may surprise Wall Street and send stock prices tumbling.
Yesterday, after rising as much as 23 points, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,937.73, up 9.09 points, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.49 points, to 481.14. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index rose 6.79 points, to 778.85.
Shares of America Online, a provider of computer on-line services, hit a 52-week high of 62 3/4 before closing at 62 3/8, up 3 3/4. An analyst at Goldman, Sachs predicted that America Online would overtake its larger rivals, including Compuserve.
Another computer-related stock, that of the LSI Logic Corporation, also set a 52-week high of 47 3/4 before closing at 47, up 2 7/8. A Merrill Lynch analyst recommended LSI, a semiconductor maker, as "above average."
Shares of the Duracraft Corporation, a maker of consumer products like heaters and fans, rose 3, to 36. Company executives said they agreed with analysts' estimates of fourth-quarter earnings reaching 51 cents a share, up from the 43 cents of a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Chinese Invite U.S. to Resume Talks on Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Just two days after being slapped with punitive tariffs against more than $1 billion in goods, China today asked United States negotiators to return to Beijing next week to resume talks on the piracy of American-made music, movies and software.
Administration officials welcomed the move, and said it might indicate that China's leadership was reconsidering the wisdom of a confrontation -- and perhaps a trade war -- over violations of American copyrights on items from compact disks to popular personal computer programs. 
 "The mere fact that they came back so quickly tells you that they are ready to respond in some way," the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said today.
But Mr. Kantor cautioned that China's invitation, sent by the Trade Minister, Wu Yi, included no specific proposals. It is still far from clear, he said, that the dispute will be settled by Feb. 26, the day on which the tariffs automatically go into effect.
On Saturday, the Clinton Administration announced the imposition of 100 percent tariffs on a range of Chinese goods as punishment for China's failure to crack down on piracy. The Administration did not say whether, to meet American demands, China would have to close the 29 plants that are producing 70 million compact disks and videodisks annually.
Presumably the United States would be satisfied if the factories licensed production of the movies and music, paying royalties. But that would so increase the cost that the business might no longer be viable for the Chinese manufacturers.
Today's announcement of China's willingness to act came as the White House held a meeting over how to handle the increasingly complex web of issues surrounding the American relationship with China on trade; on the transition of power as the country's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, lies gravely ill; on human rights, and on China's shipment of missile technology abroad.
"There is a sense that there is not a lot of order to all of this, and we have to get it together," one participant in the meeting said today.
The confusion of priorities will be particularly evident later this month, when Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary arrives in Beijing on a mission to get the Chinese to spend billions of dollars on American-made electric-power systems.
But Ms. O'Leary will also be carrying another message, State Department officials say. She will be urging China to accept Secretary of State Warren Christopher's offer to begin regular discussions on Chinese missile exports, including an offer to forgive past violations in return for a full accounting of past sales.
At roughly the same time, Mr. Kantor's deputies will be reopening the trade talks and telling the Chinese that commercial relations between the world's largest and third-largest economies will be gravely threatened if Beijing does not meet American demands to stop copying music and software.
Mr. Kantor and his aides said last week that they believed the announcement of sanctions would bring the Chinese back to the negotiating table, much as a similar action did last year in a lower-profile dispute over textiles.
But with the Chinese leadership in considerable disarray, some American diplomats expressed concern today that there were still powerful interests in Beijing arguing against an accommodation with the United States, in part because an agreement to crack down on the disk makers would interfere with one of the most profitable businesses in which China's military has a stake. That comes just as the Pentagon is trying to deepen its relations with China's military leaders, setting up regular consultations and even discussing the possibility of allowing port calls by each nation's naval veseels and other such arrangements.
"We've got the Pentagon trying to build a better relationship with these guys, and Mickey Kantor cutting off their revenue," an Administration official involved in the issue said.
Much of that revenue comes from the 29 plants that produce compact disks and videodisks, sometimes bringing out hit movies before they are sold or rented in the United States ("Jurassic Park" being a recent example of that). Almost all of the products are then exported to South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia and other markets where American movies are popular.
Within hours of Mr. Kantor's announcement of trade sanctions on Saturday, China angrily responded that it would place 100 percent tariffs on American-made goods, ranging from video games to cigarettes and alcohol. Still, both country's lists were notable for what they excluded.
The American list, for example, has no toys and few electronics, China's No. 1 and 2 exports to the United States. American officials decided that a doubling of the wholesale price of Chinese-made toys would hurt large and small American retailers -- to say nothing of making the White House akin to the Grinch -- and that placing tariffs on electronics parts would hurt American computer makers.
The main beneficiary of such a move on electronic components would probably be Japan, where producers would not be paying a tariff on their purchase of components.
Some shoes and winter apparel are included on the American list, but these items represent only a fraction of such products that are shipped to the United States by China. Other items that Washington picked for tariffs include fishing rods, surfboards and bicycles, all of which are available from American producers or are imported to the United States by manufacturers in other nations.
China excluded from its list aircraft and aircraft components, which are among its biggest imports from the United States.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Proposal From Mediator Is Put Off Until Today

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
Faced with a task so difficult that the striking baseball players and owners have been unable to solve it in eight months, President Clinton and the mediator he has asked to settle the dispute took a step back today.
Bill Usery Jr., the mediator, was supposed to present Clinton with a proposal that was to be his best effort to produce an agreement, or one that possibly could serve as the basis for legislation by which Congress could impose a settlement. 
 But in a 40-minute meeting at the White House this evening, Labor Secretary Robert Reich said, Usery asked the President for additional time to refine his proposal. Clinton readily agreed, asking Usery to deliver his recommended settlement at 3 P.M. Tuesday.
Michael D. McCurry, Clinton's press secretary, said the President was "not overly optimistic" about the prospects for a settlement. Clinton, McCurry said, had been told that the negotiators "did not appear to make significant progress."
But there was no progress to be made today because negotiators for the two sides did not even meet.
"No joint meeting is scheduled," Dick Conn, Usery's spokesman, said early in the afternoon.
Nor did negotiators meet separately with Usery to discuss a settlement, as they have so often in the plodding talks that formally began on June 14 with the owners' first salary-cap proposal. Each side did meet with the mediator, but he summoned them to get their input for the proposal he was formulating.
A person familiar with Usery's efforts said that when he left his office at 4:55 P.M., he took a proposal with him. But he apparently left it in his briefcase, at least figuratively, when he met first with Reich and Bruce Lindsey, deputy White House counsel, for about 45 minutes, then with those two and Clinton.
"He didn't want to leave any stone unturned," Reich said at a news briefing. "He didn't want to really risk not thinking of and not giving both parties a full opportunity for resolving this dispute. The President agreed to wait until 3 o'clock tomorrow for former Secretary Usery's final reports and recommendations."
Noting that this was the 100th anniversary of Babe Ruth's birth, Reich said that "the Babe would not be enormously optimistic for a quick settlement right now."
Ruth hit 714 home runs in his legendary career, but no one has come close to hitting one in this extended dispute, which has confounded everyone who has put his hand in -- Donald Fehr, Richard Ravitch, John Harrington, Jerry McMorris, Usery, now Clinton.
When the President was asked in the Oval Office earlier in the day about the status of the talks, he said: "We're working -- I just keep telling them to play ball. It's time to go. It's just a few hundred folks trying to figure out how to divide nearly $2 billion. They ought to be able to figure that out in time for the rest of America to enjoy this baseball season."
Usery, following Reich at the news briefing at the Mayflower Hotel, site of the non-talks, said he was "usually very optimistic" and refused to be pessimistic, "although it is very difficult to seem to find a voluntary agreement."
Pressed to explain why he didn't deliver, as promised, a proposal to the President, he said: "I simply ran out of time. I was working with the parties, and when you have to write a recommendation that goes to the President of the United States and may be used other ways, it takes a lot of time to do that."
Usery said he would "finalize" his recommendation Tuesday and "get it to the President." Meanwhile, he said, "I will continue to do my very best to bring about a voluntary settlement." The mediator also said circumstances were "most unfortunate for everyone concerned."
That is true because the players and the owners couldn't get it done voluntarily in the first four months of their talks, haven't been able to get it done since Usery entered the dispute at the Administration's request Oct. 14 and haven't exactly flogged themselves to an agreement since the President applied public pressure Jan. 26 by giving them until today to settle their billions of dollars of differences or face a mediator's proposal and possible forced imposition.
The player members of the union's negotiating committee, frustrated with the inability to negotiate a deal, took the opportunity of Usery's appointment at the White House to ask him to deliver a letter to the President.
"They wanted to make sure the President understood all the aspects of the dispute," Usery said.
Tom Glavine of the Atlanta Braves, one of the players who wrote the letter, declined to disclose its contents but said: "It's not an appeal. We just wanted to express how we felt about things and where we thought we were."
After returning from the White House, Usery spent time meeting with each side separately. After his evening session with the players, Donald Fehr, the union leader, said the mediator told them he would be back to them with suggestions before he heads to the White House Tuesday.
"My expectation is he'll make suggestions that will cause us to want to negotiate, so he wouldn't have to go back to the White House," Fehr said.
When Usery revealed Sunday that he had a 5 o'clock appointment at the White House, some people viewed it as a deadline for the two sides to reach agreement, but there was never any chance that they would approach that position.
During the morning and afternoon, Usery met with different groups from each side. At one point, he met with several general managers who have been standing by.
"He wants to get their thoughts," said Conn, his spokesman. "There are various aspects of the problem. He's trying to factor in all matters. He's talking to representatives of both sides to get their final input. He's open to anything. He is discussing aspects of his thinking, his philosophy, parameters. He will congeal this into a recommendation and take it to the President."
Given the time constraints of his Presidential assignment and the rigid positions of the owners and the players, Usery did not try to generate interest in a bargaining session.
"It doesn't look likely," Conn said when asked about a possible settlement, "but he always hopes lightning will strike and something will happen because he would so much prefer to have this settled by both sides rather than have an imposed settlement."
Conn was asked about the effect of the controversy over the signing freeze the clubs imposed as of today after the players lifted their freeze.
"I can't say it's had any effect," he replied. "It certainly has created unhappiness on both sides, but I couldn't say what bearing, if any, it will have on the recommendation."
No one in the Usery group offered any hint of where the mediator was headed with his proposal.
Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, said that Usery had asked the union to provide its views in nine areas of the talks -- a payroll tax, salary arbitration, free agency, term of a deal, revenue sharing, non-economic issues, a strike settlement, governance and a growth fund and pension plan.
The tax element was first. with good reason. The issue of a salary cap or a tax is the one that has fueled the strike since its inception on Aug. 12.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
All Is Quiet on the White House Front

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6

 BODY:
To become the savior of America's pastime is an undeniably heady prospect. But in letting his own deadline lapse tonight for a settlement in the baseball labor dispute, President Clinton may have had his eye on the inverse: the perils of trying and falling short.
It has been 10 days since Clinton issued a veiled threat to baseball's warring players and owners. But he cannot force a settlement on them; his only real weapon is the bully pulpit. And with Congress sounding unenthusiastic about joining him in the fight, the President's silence tonight showed his uneasiness about drawing from so slim a quiver. 
 When he went to Capitol Hill last month on his plan to rescue Mexico from its peso crisis, Clinton knew all along that he could act on his own. But when it comes to baseball, he has no such authority, and his aides made reference to that relative impotence tonight as his Federal mediator, Bill Usery Jr., came and went from the Oval Office in silence.
"We just don't have that many tools," a senior White House official said tonight. "As long as there is any prospect that they'll talk further, we should pursue it."
As late as midday, aides had said that Clinton intended to put the weight of the White House behind a proposal from Usery in a bid to turn up the pressure on both sides. But by midafternoon, they had changed tune, saying that even after a day in which the players and owners had not made progress, Clinton wanted to give Usery more time to refine his proposal before he committed himself to a specific course.
Clinton has never promised outright to settle the dispute. It was not until two months after the players walked out on Aug. 12 that he appointed Usery as his mediator. It was not until Jan. 26 that he set today as his deadline for progress, and even then he made clear his preference that the parties reach their own settlement.
But as part of its pressure campaign, Clinton and his aides have gone out of their way to encourage the expectation that a continued deadlock at the bargaining table would result in swift action. They have portrayed the baseball strike as a threat to small-town economies, the American morale and the national security.
By last weekend, as the talks between players and owners entered their showdown phase, the White House was boasting that the President was wielding "a 40-ounce Louisville Slugger."
It is that strategy that seemed hollow as Clinton held his fire tonight. Public opinion polls noted carefully by the White House had shown scant enthusiasm among fans for direct Presidential intervention. And more important, early signs that Congress might join in a bid to settle the dispute had dimmed to such a degree that the third-ranking Republican in the House leadership, Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, finally said this afternoon what some of his colleagues had previously made clear in private.
"I don't think there's a great desire on the part of Congres to involve ourselves in this dispute," Boehner said.
Without Congress, Clinton has no power to force the players and managers to accept any settlement, even one put forward by Usery. Without Congress, he cannot force them either to accept binding arbitration as a way out of their dispute.
As late as last month, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, left open the prospect that Congress might at least revoke baseball's antitrust exemption as a means of pressuring the owners. But in recent days, Dole's aides have called that prospect unlikely and said that it would consume time that the House and the Senate should devote to other matters.
Clinton did get some support today from an unlikely source, Senator Orrin Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
"I think they'd better pay attention to this President," Hatch said before the President postponed the planned public statement. "I think he means business. I'm going to support him on it."
But without much hope for more substantive Congressional backing, Clinton has clearly decided to act judiciously. Barring a last-minute breakthrough, his aides said he must now decide how aggressively to let fly with his plan to hail Usery's plan as fair, reasonable and the best path toward a settlement -- a rare Presidential tribute intended to put pressure on both sides by fixing public attention on a compromise target.
"There is an opportunity to say to the public: 'This is what is the fair outcome according to the best mediator in the country,' " Labor Secretary Robert Reich said this morning. " 'Let's see if the parties can abide by it.' "

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
A Negotiating Game With Two Big Losers

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The major league owners and players milled around the Mayflower Hotel, one of those classic "power" enclaves found in the nation's capital, all but powerless yesterday as they waited for President Clinton to decide their future.
The President, and his hand-picked mediator, Bill Usery Jr., only heightened the tension by putting off their Solomonic judgment until today. But no matter how the President and Usery attempt to divide the riches that the owners and players could not, the third-party decision is bound to spark debate as to who the winners and losers are. 
 Such a debate will prove futile despite the obvious assessments if there is or isn't a luxury tax, if there is or isn't a salary cap, if there are or aren't inroads against a historically undefeated union.
There won't be any victories here, not even Pyrrhic ones, no matter which way the Clinton Administration decision falls. There will be nothing but losers in baseball's Greek tragedy.
No matter what form the sport takes next week when spring training camps open, the game will not be the same. The Clinton-applied spur may yet lead to replacement players being stopped at the borders of Florida and Arizona. It may even lead the way for the return of the striking major leaguers by the time exhibition games begin in March because the President was able to stop a strike that is closing in on its six-month anniversary.
But Clinton can't heal baseball. Nothing can, or will, for a long, long time. The partnership between players and management, severely tested in the collusion years of the late 1980's, then tenuously pieced back together in ensuing years, is shattered.
Collusion spawned such distrust and enmity that the negotiators of 1990 were forced to turn more on moral indignation than economic issues as the owners' negotiating team of the commissioner, Fay Vincent, and deputy commissioner, Steve Greenberg, tried to overcome five-year-old acrimony in aggrieved players.
Those same two negotiators are no longer with baseball because they could not overcome the obvious anger found in the majority of owners who feel too much has been given away to players in the past 15 or so years. Management's ire, which seethed just below the surface for so many years, has been vented during this strike.
The owners' resolve has been remarkable for its unity and single-mindedness, save for the lone opposition of Baltimore's Peter Angelos.
Not everyone will endorse what owners have done in their effort to tip the scales of power back in their favor. But no one can accuse them of having followed their usual path, which is to disintegrate and capitulate in ignominious fashion.
Ironically, the owners' evolution into an irresistible force has pitted them against the always immovable object that is the Major League Baseball Players Association.
In the best of times, those two groups dare to dream of full-fledged cooperation geared toward growing the game. Now, if those dreams are not dead, they are certainly on a respirator.
The past few days, labor and management haven't even been able to walk into the same room and pretend to negotiate a new working agreement. And the Government that forced them to try, hasn't applied the prod for days. And Clinton's team obviously had no intention of doing so, for the simple reason that it knows a lost cause when it sees one.
Witness the actions of Bill Usery Jr., the special mediator Clinton brought into the fray. Usery, as asked, spent Sunday night and Monday morning and afternoon working on his own recommendation for a settlement. Sunday he expressed hope that the two sides would use the first glances of his efforts as a jumping-off point for renewed talks.
Yet Usery, a mediator famous for locking warring parties in a room until a deal is done, has chosen not to at any point in these talks. Even with Clinton's mandate that a deal be made or he'd turn the situation over to Usery.
Fact is, these two sides were too angry to sit at the same table. The discourse in separate sessions before the news media deteriorated so seriously Sunday night that Donald Fehr, the head of the players union, likened the owners' decision not to allow individual clubs to sign players until there is a settlement to throwing a bomb into the negotiations with the intent of having it explode.
So, is it any wonder that when asked if there was any chance that the parties could settle the strike themselves before Usery and Clinton officially intervened, Richard Conn, a spokesman for Usery, simply replied: "No."
That certainly was the suspicion over six months ago. The suspicion grew with cynical certainty this weekend. The President of the United States might be able to make the strike go away. He won't be able to make what it has wrought do the same.
"There's so much talk about the bad relationship between the two sides, if somebody tells us what we've got to do for the next three or four or five years, that doesn't lend itself toward making this relationship any better," said Tom Glavine, a pitcher for the Atlanta Braves and a player-negotiator. "We're going to be right back in the same spot four years from now.
"The Government getting involved is not going to do anything to bridge this relationship."
